fields.headline: Justice dawns on Forgotten Five
fields.standfirst: Better late than never, a nation salutes the unsung heroes of '66
fields.trailText: At noon yesterday, they changed the guard at Buckingham Palace. No sign of Christopher Robin or Alice but the bearskinned Grenadiers were there in grey winter coats, marching and stamping as the band played a melody of Beatles hits: A Hard Day's Night, Yellow Submarine, Eleanor Rigby.
fields.body:
At noon yesterday, they changed the guard at Buckingham Palace. No sign of Christopher Robin or Alice but the bearskinned Grenadiers were there in grey winter coats, marching and stamping as the band played a melody of Beatles hits: A Hard Day's Night, Yellow Submarine, Eleanor Rigby.

Ah, Eleanor Rigby. Did the band master know how appropriate that was? July 30 1966, and while the Fab Four's song was high in the charts, England's football team was triumphing as none had done before or since.

Rewards - knighthoods, gongs and all the trappings that go with it - had come to some: Sir Alf, Sir Bobby and Sir Geoff, OBEs for Bobby Moore, Gordon Banks and Jack Charlton, and an MBE for Martin Peters. But nothing, over the course of almost 34 years, for the Forgotten Five.

Yesterday though, while the band chugged away outside, a wrong was righted in the state rooms inside the palace as Alan Ball, Nobby Stiles, Ray Wilson, George Cohen and Roger Hunt received MBEs from the Queen who had handed them their winners' medals all those years ago.

Now at least they could look Ian Wright in the eye and besides which, as Cohen was to point out, it rendered the team of which he had been an integral part the most honoured in the history of British sport and that was quite something.

The five had warmed up with a not-so-impromptu PR kickabout in St James's Park and it was bonhomie and chummy banter at a nearby hotel after the ceremonials, picture-posing with their shining crosses with the maroon ribbon.

They have, said Cohen, all maintained a remarkable friendship even after all these years, on the strength of the bond they built up during that tournament. In October, they meet up with the other surviving members of the side, Sir Bobby Charlton excepted, for a reunion Airtours Holidays sponsored World Cup winners reunion cruise and they will talk each other's legs off.

Yes, they were proud of the awards. "I love England," said Ball passionately, "and to be recognised like this is everything I have been brought up to try and achieve."

Yet the questions remain. What on earth had gone on in the intervening years that no one had seen fit to rectify the injustice? Why the omission in the first place? And did it not rankle, even just a bit, as gradually the others were recognised and they were not?

Wilson, at 65 the elder statesman, still pencil slim and dapper as he was when he was arguably the world's finest left-back, offered a dissenting voice. "You know," he said, "if people had had a vote on this over the last 20 or 30 years we probably would have had this award by now.

"One thing I have a slight problem with is that essentially I have got an award for just one game instead of my contribution to soccer. I had my name taken just once for arguing with the referee, I played all the matches in the '62 and '66 World Cups and with 63 international matches I was the fourth most-capped England player when I retired. So I think that even without that final win I still made enough of a contribution to the sport to get an award.

"To be honest though I had stopped being bothered by it any longer, those times when the honours came out and you saw certain people getting awards and I'd ring up George for instance and say, 'I see we've missed out again, mate'. It had just gone on too long."

To have recognised some and not others was in a sense projecting the idea that these had contributed more. But Ball ran himself into the deck, Stiles' unquenchable spirit goaded them on, Wilson and Cohen had calmly kept the Germans at bay and still made their overlapping forays down the flanks and Hunt's decoy running was selfless. "I don't know about that," said Ball. "But if anything disappointed me it was our own FA who didn't put us up. So if we're going to criticise anyone for the fact that this has taken so long then let's just say the FA should have done more without a shadow of a doubt. It was only last week that I discovered that if you played more than 50 games you were entitled to a pair of tickets for Wembley matches. You would have thought that someone might have bothered to let me know. But there you are." Then it was on to the real talk. "Of course the ball crossed the line," said Hunt. "I was desperate to score and I would have knocked it in otherwise."

And yes, although it hurt desperately at the time, and of course they were there to win the game first and foremost, the last-minute German equaliser had, as Wilson said, resurrected a tedious game where two good sides had just dug in, and instead made it into the stuff of legends.

Imagine, if Wilson's lunging right boot had deflected Wolfgang Weber's close-range shot or Banks's desperate dive had tipped it round the post, there would have been no extra-time and so no Ramsey exhortations on the field, no socks rolled down, no Bobby Moore last-ditch tackle, no deflection off the bar and a linesman who spoke only Russian and Turkish but waved his flag in an international language to signal the goal, no hat-trick hero and so no Sir Geoff, probably no gongs yesterday either, and definitely no laddish television quizzes called They Think It's All Over. It doesn't bear thinking about.

fields.headline: Adams goes for French check-up
fields.trailText: Arsenal's captain Tony Adams has gone to France for specialist treatment on a groin injury which has kept him out of the last two games amid fears he may need another hernia operation.
fields.body:
Arsenal's captain Tony Adams has gone to France for specialist treatment on a groin injury which has kept him out of the last two games amid fears he may need another hernia operation.

The club hope the problem is merely inflammation around a scar left by his double hernia surgery last summer, which should clear in less than two weeks. But it is almost certain he will miss tomorrow's Uefa Cup return against Deportivo La Coruna in Spain and likely he will be out of the derby with Tottenham a week on Sunday.

Emmanuel Petit, charged with misconduct by the FA after an alleged offensive gesture to Aston Villa fans, is understood to have been offered the backing of two Villa management staff in his claim that he was racially abused during Sunday's game. Villa's first-team coach Steve Harrison and the goalkeeping coach Paul Barron are thought to be willing to give evidence.

PSV Eindhoven's striker Ruud van Nistelrooy, wanted by several Premiership clubs, is out for at least six weeks after injuring a knee in a friendly. And the Barcelona forward Luis Enrique is almost certain to miss Spain's Euro 2000 campaign after rupturing a knee cartilage, which will keep him out for three months.

Arsenal's Stephen Hughes yesterday completed his £3m move to Everton.

webTitle: England has Europe's lowest card count

fields.headline: England has Europe's lowest card count
fields.trailText: The Premiership has the lowest card count per game of five major leagues in Europe, according to a study published by France Football magazine yesterday.
fields.body:
The Premiership has the lowest card count per game of five major leagues in Europe, according to a study published by France Football magazine yesterday.

And England's top division, averaging 3.90 yellow and red cards combined a match this season, is the only one of the five leagues to show a decline in these punishments compared with the 1996-97 season.

The Premiership's statistics this season may be influenced by the pre-Christmas recommendation to referees to relax the card dispensing.

Spain's card average remains the highest of the five leagues (5.84) with Italy still runner-up (4.76). France has shown the highest increase, rising to third (4.58) after having the cleanest record in 1996-97. Germany has 4.38.

England's current record is marginally better than three years ago, when its average was 3.95. It is highly encouraging when set in the context of rises in all the other leagues.

The French, who have seen their average rise from 3.74, are generally puzzled by the increase but the reason is simple, according to the league leaders Monaco's coach Claude Puel. "French referees are more strict than their English and Italian counterparts," he said.

fields.headline: Wasteful Ipswich count their blessings
fields.trailText: Ipswich 0 - 0 Blackburn
fields.body:
Ipswich dropped two more home points last night and were fortunate the damage to their Premiership ambitions was not greater after Blackburn, forced onto the back foot for most of the match, missed two outstanding opportunities in the latter stages.

George Burley's team had seen shots from Jamie Clapham and David Johnson crash against the woodwork before half-time but, as their football lost its cohesion, Rovers almost stole the three points - first when Ashley Ward was given a free header and then when Marlon Broomes took control of a free kick.

It was the game at Ewood Park in November that launched Ipswich on their long unbeaten sequence that Portsmouth surprisingly ended on Saturday. This was a good time to start another one, with Manchester City not playing until today and second place up for grabs.

James Scowcroft missed out because of a hamstring problem, while Blackburn kept faith with Ward and Nathan Blake. No Rovers striker had scored in the last six games, somewhat dampening their own promotion prospects, and they were to be frustrated again.

Ipswich passed the ball efficiently and Jim Magilton and Matt Holland were soon dominating midfield. Although space was at a premium they twice went close, Magilton going inches wide of the upright and Clapham brushing the crossbar. Blackburn's keeper Alan Kelly was at his most defiant, halting a strong run from Fabian Wilnis and then beating away Johnson's 10-yard effort.

Blackburn brought back Keith Gillespie and Damien Duff to stiffen their resistance, with the result that they could force no more than the occasional counter-raid themselves, although Per Frandsen caused momentary alarm from a free kick.

The introduction of Matt Jansen for Blake promised to give the visitors something extra and, after Johnson prodded a shot beyond Kelly only to find Simon Grayson in the way, Jansen gave Richard Wright some work with a low shot. But, once again, Rovers returned empty-handed.

fields.headline: Marcelo justifies the third prong
fields.trailText: Birmingham 1 - 0 Portsmouth
fields.body:
Birmingham reinforced their challenge for a play-off place with their ninth win in 10 games last night and in doing so ended Portsmouth's mini revival at the other end of the table.

Pompey, who had wonat Ipswich on Saturday, fielded their new signings Kevin Harper and Justin Edinburgh but not Colin Calderwood, whose supposed move from Aston Villa collapsed because the player failed to agree personal terms.

Had he played, his first touch could hardly have been more inauspicious than that of Edinburgh, his former Tottenham team-mate, whose opening act was to chop down Andrew Johnson. He escaped with a warning.

Johnson's feint is always likely to induce a false move from defenders but it was his predatory instinct in front of goal that caused Pompey most anxiety.

The England under-18 international completed City's best move of the first half when he volleyed over from close range after a back-heel from Martin O'Connor had set up Stan Lazaridis for a left-wing cross.

Johnson also went close with an acrobatic over-head kick after Martin Grainger headed on Gary Rowett's long throw. But, like other efforts from David Holdsworth, Brian Hughes and Grainger, the shot did not trouble Russell Hoult.

In the visitor's only first-half attack of menace after a bright start in which they laid siege to the City goal, Lee Bradbury was similarly wayward after a long throw by Hoult and a Rowett slip put him clear of the Blue's defence.

Trevor Francis, never afraid to use the tactical substitution, opted for the kitchen-sink approach in the second period in an attempt to convert dominance into goals. Marcelo came on for Lazaridis to give City three strikers and Pompey's three centre-backs were still coming to terms with the change when the Brazilian striker latched on to O'Connor's diagonal pass into the penalty area, cut inside his marker and fired past Hoult with the outside of his right foot.

He might have engineered a second goal when Adrian Whitbread bundled him over in the area but the referee Scott Mathieson was satisfied with the challenge.

webTitle: Hughes strikes a blow for Baggies pride

fields.headline: Hughes strikes a blow for Baggies pride
fields.trailText: WBA 2 - 0 Tranmere
fields.body:
A day after manager Brian Little was sacked, West Bromwich Albion cast aside their troubles to record only their second win in 3 months with an assertive performance at the Hawthorns.

Little's departure is likely to be followed by a demand for substantial compensation but goals from Sean Flynn and Lee Hughes just before and after half-time suggested the new man in charge will have something to work with during the 11 matches left to ensure the Baggies' First Division survival.

Possible successors to Little will be interviewed this morning. Popular speculation is that Ron Atkinson will be tempted out of retirement to embark on a third spell in charge but more realistic choices include Gary Megson, undeservedly sacked when Stoke changed ownership, and Jan Molby, in charge of the table-topping Conference side Kidderminster Harriers.

Asked about Atkinson, the Albion chairman Paul Thompson said nobody had been ruled out, although the former Aston Villa manager has not reacted with noticeable enthusiasm to being linked with the job.

Thompson made it clear he knows who he wants in the job. "We would not have taken the step we did without someone in mind," he said.

On the field, there was no lack of Albion commitment as the coaches Allan Evans and Cyrille Regis took temporary charge of a side with only one win in 18 matches.

Tranmere wasted an early opportunity when David Kelly, chasing Wayne Allison 's flick, shot wide when clear on goal. Brian Jensen, the former AZ Alkmaar goalkeeper who was Little's final signing, looked unsure on his debut but Albion steadily got the better of their opponents and went ahead six minutes before half-time.

Jason van Blerk, one of three men cautioned in the first 45 minutes by a finicky Uriah Rennie, crossed, Micky Evans saw his instant shot saved but Joe Murphy 's failure to hold the ball was punished by Sean Flynn 's follow-up.

The loss of an injured Andy Townsend from Albion's midfield was overcome without significant difficulty and after 50 minutes the advantage was doubled by Lee Hughes, returning from suspension to score his 13th goal of the season.

After James Quinn released the ball along the right, Hughes outpaced Gareth Roberts before displaying fine technique to check back and send an angled shot beyond Murphy.

Tranmere's hopes of an immediate reply were thwarted when Jensen pushed Allison's powerful header against the bar and clutched Dave Challinor's follow-up. More heroics from Jensen, this time tipping the ball over, denied Challinor a second time 10 minutes later.

webTitle: Bent gives the plot a final twist

fields.headline: Bent gives the plot a final twist
fields.trailText: Sheff Utd 3 - 3 Barnsley
fields.body:
If Barnsley fail to return to the Premiership, Dave Bassett will rue the injury-time equaliser from Sheffield United's striker Marcus Bent that left the manager beside himself with frustration on his return to Bramall Lane.

Barnsley possessed one of the worst defensive records away from home in the division and, in losing the lead three times, they provided the evidence why - John Curtis's weak header finally allowing Bent to tie up the scores in virtually the last act of the game.

A wet south Yorkshire night contributed to a hectic derby, although at least it was not as disorganised as the A61, which for the past decade has been so disrupted by road repairs that Sheffield United, in their traffic-cone red and white, should properly be sponsored by the highways department. Had that been so, last night Rob Kozluk would have been the cone lying on its side, knocked hopelessly out of position.

Neither side had settled when Kozluk committed his first error to give Barnsley an 18th-minute lead. A punt forward by Curtis should have been easily intercepted, but Kozluk made a hash of things and Georgi Hristov ran on to curl a shot around Simon Tracey.

Four minutes later Barnsley suffered for a misjudgment of their own. Kevin Miller failed to punch clear under pressure from Bent, and Alex Notman, on loan from Manchester United, stroked in his third goal for the club.

Hristov had been retained in the side after scoring both Barnsley's goals at Stockport on Friday, and 10 minutes before half-time he won a penalty under challenge from the hapless Kozluk. The Welsh international Darren Barnard scored his 12th goal in 22 games from the spot.

Kozluk was substituted and Tracey needed to save from Eric Tinkler and Neil Shipperley to prevent Barnsley extending their lead by the interval.

United had not lost at Bramall Lane since the arrival of Neil Warnock as manager and the second half was only three minutes old when they equalised for a second time through Michael Brown's near-post header from a corner.

Barnsley responded by introducing Craig Hignett, a surprise omission. His quality was decisive when he spun away from Lee Sandford on half-way, his inside pass enabling Shipperley to put Barnsley ahead for the third time by lifting the ball coolly over Tracey.

webTitle: Solskjaer takes United top in a trice

fields.headline: Solskjaer takes United top in a trice
fields.standfirst:
Pavon 9 | Keane 33, Solskjaer 84
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's inspired sense of timing again proved invaluable for Manchester United in the Champions League here last night. Within seconds of replacing Denis Irwin late on, the Norwegian whose goal in stoppage time had won the European Cup for United last season had again scored the winner.
fields.body:
Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's inspired sense of timing again proved invaluable for Manchester United in the Champions League here last night. Within seconds of replacing Denis Irwin late on, the Norwegian whose goal in stoppage time had won the European Cup for United last season had again scored the winner.

United appeared to be missing a trick when Bordeaux, down to 10 men after having Lilian Laslandes sent off in the 23rd minute and soon losing an early lead to Roy Keane's equaliser, then looked like regaining the lead and hit a post in the second half.

But with six minutes remaining Solskjaer gathered a long clearance from Raimond van der Gouw, who had been badly at fault with the Bordeaux goal, brushed aside the challenge of two defenders and coolly drove the ball home.

At Old Trafford the French champions had fenced deftly but with no finishing thrust when it came to the point. Last night United were soon to discover how keen the French side were to cause them discomfort in front of home fans.

An early header from Nisa Saveljic, following Stéphane Ziani's corner, had Van der Gouw scuttling across his goal line to make a more urgent save than he had ever had to perform against Bordeaux at Old Trafford. But the next time he was called into action the Dutch goalkeeper, brought back by Ferguson because Mark Bosnich was out of form, blundered badly.

After seven minutes Bordeaux lost Laurent Batlles, who had been kicked in the face by one of his own defenders during a goalmouth flurry.

Then in the ninth minute the substitute, Lassina Diabate, slipped the ball inside to Michel Pavon, the Bordeaux captain, who drove in a firm but saveable shot from the penalty arc. Van der Gouw was partly unsighted but this did not explain why he allowed the ball to slip through his hands and cross the line.

As soft goals go, this one was a blancmange. Soon United, far from dictating the game's pace and pattern, were having to defend with some desperation. Shots from Sylvain Wiltord and Lilian Laslandes went just wide as a fired-up Bordeaux forced the pace. Midway through the first half, however, they lost Laslandes to two pieces of petulance in the space of 20 seconds.

First the striker was cautioned after registering his disgust with a linesman who had flagged him offside. Then Laslandes lunged, studs up, at Beckham and although contact was minimal the Dutch referee was entitled to send him off for a second booking.

The locals felt Beckham had made a meal of the foul and thereafter he was loudly booed and whistled whenever he touched the ball, which must have made him feel somewhat at home. In fact it was Bordeaux who lost heart, and within 11 minutes of Laslandes' departure they had also lost their lead.

With the defenders in a ragged line, minimising the risk of offside, Beckham played the ball in to Andy Cole, who fed a short pass through to Teddy Sheringham. He then found Keane in a lot of space to his left and, although Ulrich Ramé blocked the first shot, the United captain found a gaping net from the rebound.

Early in the second half Cole, released by Nicky Butt's astutely timed lob, outpaced Saveljic and bore down on Ramé, only to see the goalkeeper deflect his shot wide.

With Bordeaux pushing for ward to give Wiltord support they were always going to run the risk of being caught on the counter-attack in this fashion. But it was United who all but fell behind to a quick break in the 57th minute when Ziani's pass sent Johan Micoud clear of Jaap Stam and Mickael Silvestre. With United's French defender on his heels Micoud unleashed a drive which cannoned off the inside of the right post and shot across goal.

By now the match was thoroughly open and enjoyable, with Keane's head glancing a left-wing cross from Beckham just wide of the far post. Just before the hour another shot from Micoud, struck from 25 yards, sailed close to the left-hand post with Van der Gouw looking beaten. For a team with 10 men Bordeaux were remarkably adept at finding spare bodies in the opposition half. But all Micoud's promptings counted for naught once Solskjaer again proved an instant hit.

 In the night's other Group B match a 35th minute goal by Valencia's Romania striker Adrian Ilie and a 90th minute panalty by Mendieta gave the Spaniards 2-0 revenge over Fiorentina for their controversial defeat last week in Italy.

Bordeaux (4-4-2): Ramé; Grenet, Saveljic, Afanou, Bonnissel; Ziani (Rouviere, 60) Batlles (Diabate, 7min), Pavon, Micoud; Laslandes, Wiltord (Feindouno, 82).

Manchester United (4-4-2) : Van der Gouw; G Neville, Stam, Silvestre, Irwin (Solskjaer, 83); Beckham, Keane, Butt, Giggs ; Sheringham (Yorke, 77), Cole (Berg, 86).

Referee: J.Wegereef (Holland).

webTitle: Vialli cool about his Bridge hand

fields.headline: Vialli cool about his Bridge hand
fields.trailText: Chelsea performances are infuriatingly good and bad. Earlier this season they sailed through their opening Champions League games while their domestic form fell apart. Now they have ghosted up to third in the Premiership while their European form is starting to fray at the edges.
fields.body:
If anyone doubted that Chelsea are a team with a split personality, the fact was comically underlined by the post-match analysis of last Tuesday's 1-0 defeat in Marseille.

"Our performance was good," argued the manager Gianluca Vialli. "Apart from the result I'm quite pleased."

"It was a very, very poor display," countered the coach Graham Rix. "Our passing was poor and so was our crossing."

Of course, Vialli was merely doling out the banal propaganda that has marked his interviews of late, whereas the Yorkshireman in Rix preferred straight talking.

But the fact remains that Chelsea performances are infuriatingly good and bad. Earlier this season they sailed through their opening Champions League games while their domestic form fell apart. Now they have ghosted up to third in the Premiership while their European form is starting to fray at the edges.

Another problem for Vialli is the form of his £3m midfielder Didier Deschamps, who was substituted after 62 muted minutes last week and was not even on the bench for Saturday's win at Newcastle.

In typically diplomatic fashion Vialli played down suggestions that the 31-year-old was in the doghouse. "Someone who gives everything each time he plays needs a rest every now and then," he said.

"I understand that people don't know him as well as I do. Maybe they expect more skill and more elegance from a midfielder who captains France. But I look at how effective he can be, not how elegant he is or how many good passes he makes."

However, the impression remains that Vialli was making a point to Deschamps on Saturday and that tonight the Frenchman will be recalled to see if it has sunk in.

Marcel Desailly is expected to recover from a knee injury in time to play tonight but Roberto di Matteo and Jon Harley both face fitness tests.

 Leeds will play Slavia Prague in the Uefa Cup quarter-finals if they get through against Roma tomorrow. The Czechs lost 2-1 at Udinese yesterday but, 2-2 on aggregate, went through on the away goal.

Chelsea (4-4-2, probable): De Goey; Ferrer, Desailly (or Lambourde), Leboeuf, Harley (or Babayaro); Petrescu, Wise, Deschamps, Poyet; Zola, Flo.

Marseille (3-5-2, probable): Trevisan; Cyprien, Luccin, Abardonado; Fischer, Perez, Dalmat, Leroy, Pires; Pouget, Bakayoko.

fields.headline: Guiding hands
fields.standfirst: The practical help in parenting that used to come  naturally from the extended family is now being  offered by volunteers, reports Kendra Inman
fields.trailText: The practical help in parenting that used to come naturally from the extended family is now being offered by volunteers, reports Kendra Inman.
fields.body:
Around the country, there is an army of almost 6,500 volunteers - mostly women - who, with the help of a cup of coffee and an attentive ear, spend a couple of hours a week working to stop families under stress from falling apart.

Home-Start is a charity with a low profile, yet it is one of the country's leading family support organisations. Since the early 1970s, it has sent trained volunteers to families struggling with everything from domestic violence, depression, ill-health and loneliness to coping with triplets. Any family with under-5s finding it difficult to cope can ask for help from the scheme.

There are currently 260 Home-Start schemes helping 17,000 families, including families of British forces in Cyprus and Germany. With prevention at the top of the government's social exclusion agenda, the charity plans to help twice as many and double in size over the next five years. Home-Start volunteers are needed everywhere, says director Brian Waller, who wants to see a scheme in every community around the UK.

The type of work volunteers are asked to do varies with the family and the area.

On the surface, leafy Richmond, in London, seems an unlikely place for a family support scheme, but there is plenty of work for volunteers here too, says the local Home-Start scheme organiser, Anthea Cameron. Pockets of deprivation are hidden among the large, expensive houses. And while most of her work is with people on low incomes, she says that "depression and isolation still exist in comfortable, middle class homes".

Waller admits that the charity has hidden its light under a bushel: Home-Start claims to support nearly three times as many under-fives as Barnardo's, a charity that has six times the income. But the organisation sits perfectly within the government's Sure Start programme, which aims to change the outcomes for young children in poor families.

Under the Home-Start scheme, trained volunteers from the local community, who have all had parenting experience themselves, offer their services to families under stress.

Help ranges from providing someone to talk to to offering a spare pair of hands to cope with difficult children or household tasks. Most families are referred to Home-Start by health visitors, some by local authorities; one in 10 refers itself.

The charity is not a home help or childminding service, Waller emphasises, and volunteers are not there to tell people how to bring up their children. "But because they have all been there themselves, they know how to deal with colic, sleepless nights and all the other pressures," he says.

In one family helped by the Richmond scheme, the father's depression had turned the mother into "a physical wreck", says one volunteer. "She was so isolated and desperate for someone to talk to. The first couple of times I went we talked about everything but her problems. I'd take her for a drive or a walk, just getting her out. Occasionally, I'd pick up the children from playgroup or help get them to school.

"Eventually, when she saw that I wasn't there to judge, she opened up. Over the year, I saw her getting physically stronger and more capable and confident in her ability to cope."

Volunteer applicants undergo a 10-week preparation course that sets out the schemes' expectations and helps organisers weed out those who are unsuitable.

Once accepted, the volunteers are carefully matched with families, but occasionally some drop out. "It can be hard to put your own feelings to one side and suspend judgment," says one Richmond volunteer.

According to Waller, the need for Home-Start has grown as pressures on family life have increased. "In the past, when society was smaller and more intimate, the kind of help our volunteers provide may have been available more easily," he says. "Now we provide the friendship that an extended family would have done."

Ministers have said they would like to see a Home-Start scheme in every Sure Start area, and it's not hard to see why. It is a lean organisation, with only 10 staff at head office. And while the local scheme organisers and administrators around the country are paid, the volunteers receive only expenses. Home-Start is looking to the government to stump up the cash to expand the service. But will getting into bed with the government result in the organisation losing the independence it values so highly? Waller thinks not. "Even when we're funded by the local authority, we work to the families' agenda not that of the social services department," he says.

Waller admits that recruiting volunteers is more difficult than when the charity began, but he says: "It is possible to find people willing to volunteer everywhere. There is goodwill and altruism in every part of the community - and 10% of families go on to be volunteers themselves."

"Part of the reward is to see the families getting better," says one volunteer. "Many of the volunteers stay firm friends with the families even after the visits are no longer needed." And, Cameron adds: "Some volunteers find the experience so empowering that they make changes to their own lives, such as enrolling on a course."

Waller, a former director of social services, believes that Home-Start can reduce the likelihood of family breakdown and even child abuse. A study of 17 Scottish schemes found that health, parental self-esteem and behavioural problems in children improved after Home-Start visits. More research is planned to evaluate which approach works best.

The volunteers say how much the women brighten up as their self-esteem increases. With a boosted confidence, they make better use of local clinics and support groups. This, in turn, has a positive, long-term impact on the children.

fields.headline: Fear of the truth
fields.standfirst: A contract has been taken out to kill a public servant. His crime? Persuading key witnesses to give evidence that helped convict a gang of thugs who beat a teenage boy to death. But this is not Sicily or the Bronx - it's Bermondsey, south London. Chris Arnot meets up with Simon Hughes, the Lib - Dem MP who has been targeted by local gangsters
fields.trailText: A contract has been taken out to kill a public servant. His crime? Persuading key witnesses to give evidence that helped convict a gang of thugs who beat a teenage boy to death. But this is not Sicily or the Bronx - it's Bermondsey, south London. Chris Arnot meets up with Simon Hughes, the Lib - Dem MP who has been targeted by local gangsters.
fields.body:
Simon Hughes arrives alone and on foot. For the first time in over three months, the MP for North Southwark and Bermondsey, in south-east London, is not being ferried around in a bullet-proof car by officers from the Special Branch. This is the kind of protection normally afforded to past and present prime ministers and secretaries of state for Northern Ireland (Mo Mowlam apart) rather than Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesmen. But since the end of October, Hughes has had to live with the knowledge that a pounds 10,000 contract has been taken out on his life.

'One of my friends said he thought it was offensively cheap,' he says as we settle down in a coffee shop near Westminster Abbey. But his levity can't quite play down the shocking nature of this case. A democratically elected member of the British parliament is still under threat of being killed - not by political terrorists or religious fanatics, but by gangsters within his own constituency.

His 'crime', in their eyes, was to persuade key witnesses to give evidence in the case of 17-year-old Jamie Robe, who was beaten to death by a gang from the Osprey estate, Rotherhithe, in August 1997. Three of Robe's assailants were jailed for life in November 1999.

The intervening two years provided a chilling example of wide-scale witness intimidation and the cost to the public purse of ensuring that the criminal justice system is allowed to take its course. About 20 people had to be moved away from their homes by the Metropolitan police's witness protection unit - one of eight nationwide with powers to provide new homes, new identities, new jobs and, in some cases, new schools for witnesses' children.

Hughes refused to move away from his constituency, but he did accept police advice on other matters. 'Instead of holding my surgeries in the main thoroughfare of a shopping centre, we had to move inside a shop so the entrance can be watched,' he says. 'And I could no longer go to meetings in crowded bars.'

The coffee shop in Westminster is comparatively quiet on this Saturday morning and we have been able to walk here apparently unobserved. 'They let me out on my own now,' Hughes cheerfully proclaims. But the police still take the threat seriously enough to maintain a round-the-clock guard on his office and the home he shares with his girlfriend. 'We're dealing with the sort of people who wouldn't find it difficult to get someone to do a shooting or a stabbing for them,' Hughes concedes, ruefully.

Indeed, it was the knowledge that he has lived for 15 years in a part of London where a high number of attacks are never resolved that persuaded him to use his influence to try to break through the enforced silence on the Osprey estate and surrounding area. 'A friend's son was killed and nobody was charged,' he says. 'I saw the trauma that that caused and it made me determined that, if it happened again, we would do better. We must make sure that people are brought to book. Otherwise we're just going to have anarchy.'

Ironically, it was two days after he had been appointed his party's spokesman on home affairs that his all-too-personal lesson in witness intimidation came home to roost. 'I'd just gone to bed, absolutely knackered, when my pager went off at about 2.15,' he recalls. 'It was the parliamentary security service telling me they'd received a threat to me and regarded it as serious. They told me they'd be with me as soon as they could. It turned out to be about 20 minutes, although it seemed longer. I was on my own that night, so I got up, made a cup of tea and hoped to goodness that if the people who were after me got here before the police, I'd be more quick-witted than they were.'

The court case had finished the previous day. But only on the eve of the trial did the judge confirm that witnesses would be able to give evidence from behind a screen while wearing balaclavas and boiler suits. Had this proviso been made known earlier, it might have eased the anguish of the key witnesses. One of them, 19-year-old Traci Broughton, had lost two stone through sheer terror.

'There's no reason why some procedural guarantees about the provision of screens in court shouldn't be agreed some time before the case is heard,' says Hughes, who persuaded Traci to speak out. 'Also, when there's so much jury nobbling going on, why does the jury have to sit directly in the view of the public gallery?'

As for witness protection, Hughes believes there should be a nationwide scheme ready to offer alternative housing and employment to key witnesses. 'Also business relocation costs,' he adds, conscious that the other two key witnesses in the Jamie Robe case were Turks running a kebab shop. 'As it is,' he says, `it's taking a lot of police time and they're dependent on the good offices of local authorities. With private sector help, a few million could be made available to get the job done quickly and efficiently. I'm working up some proposals to put to Jack Straw. We've already had a preliminary meeting. Hopefully, there's going to be another this side of Easter.'

The home secretary apparently has been very sympathetic to the plight of his opposite number on the Lib-Dem benches. Whether he'll be sympathetic to funding a national scheme for witness protection and changing the lay-out of court rooms remains to be seen.

One thing's for sure: Simon Hughes has more reason than most for being aware of the cost to society of the alternative - a steady increase in the number of court cases that collapse because witnesses to violent crime are too frightened to stand up and say publicly what they saw.

The intervening two years provided a chilling example of wide-scale witness intimidation and the cost to the public purse of ensuring that the criminal justice system is allowed to take its course. About 20 people had to be moved away from their homes by the Metropolitan police's witness protection unit - one of eight nationwide with powers to provide new homes, new identities, new jobs and, in some cases, new schools for witnesses' children. Hughes refused to move away from his constituency, but he did accept police advice on other matters. 'Instead of holding my surgeries in the main thoroughfare of a shopping centre, we had to move inside a shop so the entrance can be watched,' he says. 'And I could no longer go to meetings in crowded bars.' The coffee shop in Westminster is comparatively quiet on this Saturday morning and we have been able to walk here apparently unobserved. 'They let me out on my own now,' Hughes cheerfully proclaims. But the police still take the threat seriously enough to maintain a round-the-clock guard on his office and the home he shares with his girlfriend. 'We're dealing with the sort of people who wouldn't find it difficult to get someone to do a shooting or a stabbing for them,' Hughes concedes, ruefully. Indeed, it was the knowledge that he has lived for 15 years in a part of London where a high number of attacks are never resolved that persuaded him to use his influence to try to break through the enforced silence on the Osprey estate and surrounding area. 'A friend's son was killed and nobody was charged,' he says. 'I saw the trauma that that caused and it made me determined that, if it happened again, we would do better. We must make sure that people are brought to book. Otherwise we're just going to have anarchy.' Ironically, it was two days after he had been appointed his party's spokesman on home affairs that his all-too-personal lesson in witness intimidation came home to roost. 'I'd just gone to bed, absolutely knackered, when my pager went off at about 2.15,' he recalls. 'It was the parliamentary security service telling me they'd received a threat to me and regarded it as serious. They told me they'd be with me as soon as they could. It turned out to be about 20 minutes, although it seemed longer. I was on my own that night, so I got up, made a cup of tea and hoped to goodness that if the people who were after me got here before the police, I'd be more quick-witted than they were.' The court case had finished the previous day. But only on the eve of the trial did the judge confirm that witnesses would be able to give evidence from behind a screen while wearing balaclavas and boiler suits. Had this proviso been made known earlier, it might have eased the anguish of the key witnesses. One of them, 19-year-old Traci Broughton, had lost two stone through sheer terror. 'There's no reason why some procedural guarantees about the provision of screens in court shouldn't be agreed some time before the case is heard,' says Hughes, who persuaded Traci to speak out. 'Also, when there's so much jury nobbling going on, why does the jury have to sit directly in the view of the public gallery?' As for witness protection, Hughes believes there should be a nationwide scheme ready to offer alternative housing and employment to key witnesses. 'Also business relocation costs,' he adds, conscious that the other two key witnesses in the Jamie Robe case were Turks running a kebab shop. 'As it is,' he says, `it's taking a lot of police time and they're dependent on the good offices of local authorities. With private sector help, a few million could be made available to get the job done quickly and efficiently. I'm working up some proposals to put to Jack Straw. We've already had a preliminary meeting. Hopefully, there's going to be another this side of Easter.' The home secretary apparently has been very sympathetic to the plight of his opposite number on the Lib-Dem benches. Whether he'll be sympathetic to funding a national scheme for witness protection and changing the lay-out of court rooms remains to be seen. One thing's for sure: Simon Hughes has more reason than most for being aware of the cost to society of the alternative - a steady increase in the number of court cases that collapse because witnesses to violent crime are too frightened to stand up and say publicly what they saw.

webTitle: State of despair as public schools get the cream

fields.headline: State of despair as public schools get the cream
fields.standfirst:
The last of an agenda-setting series looks at the inequalities in funding between the two education sectors

Education Unlimited

fields.body:
Let us begin with the story of what the historian Brian Simon once described as "probably the biggest hijack of public resources in history". This was plotted 131 years ago when the government's schools inquiry commission declared that there was no reason to encourage "indiscriminate gratuituous instruction", an idea that they compared in its mischief to the indiscriminate donation of alms to beggars. They proposed an ingenious reform, which was rapidly adopted by parliament.

They would seize the schools that then provided a free education for the poor in many towns and (ignoring the statutes that had established them) they would abolish them, and then (defying the lawful wishes of their benefactors), they would take over the endowments that had been left over the years to fund them and use the money to set up schools not for the poor but " for the extension of middle-class education". This was a bold idea, for which the commissioners received much credit, but, in truth, it was not an original one.

For several centuries, the masters of the great public schools had been enriching their institutions by the same device. All of these schools were founded for the free education of the poor - that is why they were originally called public schools. When Henry VI founded Eton in 1442, for example, he instructed that "no one having a yearly income of more than five marks shall be eligible". In 1382, the founder of Winchester, William of Wykeham, declared that the school was to be made up of 70 "poor and needy" pupils, although as a concession to those whose patronage he sought, he agreed also to take 10 "sons of noble and influential persons". Rugby, Harrow and Westminster were founded as free schools for the poor. And yet, all of them eventually were hijacked by the wealthy, who paid fees to attend. The headmasters were happy to take their money and were quite clever in helping the hijack.

Thomas Arnold preserved Rugby for the rich by closing its free lower school so that, unless the children of the poor could afford to pay someone else to teach them, they could not learn enough to get into the main school. The schools insisted that new pupils should be able to speak Latin, with the same result. At Harrow, the head man took the register at noon when the poorer pupils, who were day boys, were all at home for lunch and, just to make sure of their absence, he forbade them from riding horses to speed up their journey home. Westminster wriggled out of its legal obligation to the poor by arguing that Elizabeth I had never confirmed its statutes. Winchester justified its behaviour to the 1818 Brougham commission by explaining that, in truth, its current pupils really were poor; it was only their parents who were rich.

With the public schools act of 1868, these ancient schools completed the theft by capturing any remaining endowments that were still dedicated to poor pupils. A year later, following the lead of the schools inquiry commission, the endowed schools act organised a far grander larceny, seizing from towns all over the country a fortune in endowments which had been left for the benefit of the local poor but which were now used to pay for a network of new fee-paying private schools for the middle class.

Now, look at the story of Britain's schools during the last 20 years. From poisoned roots, a mighty structure has grown: 2,300 private schools with an annual income from fees of some £3.2bn, educating nearly 600,000 pupils, a magnificent 7%of the nation's children. This remains the most unusual feature of the educational landscape of Britain.

Other countries allow private schools, and some educate far more in private schools (17% in France, 13% in Denmark). However, apart from small pockets of privilege, invariably these are religious schools, such as those in France or Italy, or "free" schools such as those in Denmark, often underfunded and relying on state subsidy to survive. There is no other country in Europe where private schools present a fully fledged alternative to the state system, open essentially only to the affluent.

Does that matter? In the first instance, it is a question of power. Stephen Pollard and Andrew Adonis, now a Downing Street adviser, recorded in their book A Class Act that, on the latest available figures, the magnificent 7% accounted for: seven out of nine senior generals; 33 out of 39 most senior judges; more than 120 of the 180 officers graduating from Sandhurst; half of the 18 permanent secretaries running Whitehall; and just under half of the 94 grade-three civil servants then aged under 50. Research for the Economic and Social Research Council found that 75% of private school pupils went on to take professional or managerial jobs. From the state schools, only 40% reached that level.

Politics marginalised

This question of power, and of social justice, has ceased to be fashionable, largely because the politics that kept the question alive have been marginalised. However, in a pragmatic age, an equally pressing version of the question remains - a purely educational one: does the existence of private schools have any impact on the educational performance of the mainstream state system? Can we relax and allow the two systems to enjoy a peaceful co-existence? Or is there some kind of destructive friction between the two? The answer is not quite what you might expect.

Consider, for example, the hiring and firing of teachers. Simon Szreter, an economic historian at St John's College, Cambridge,found that in the last 20 years, Britain had fallen behind just about every other developed country in its investment in teachers for the state sector. Meanwhile, the private schools had forged ahead.

All through the 1970s, Szreter found, both state schools and private schools were hiring extra teachers: the combined efforts of the Heath, Wilson and Callaghan governments put an extra 100,000 teachers on the payroll, with state schools closing the gap on private schools. At the beginning of the decade, the average state class contained 26 children; by 1979, it contained only 19. In private schools, the pupil-teacher ratio was about 50% lower - and the average of 19 disguised a mass of state classes of more than 30, sometimes more than 40, but the state sector was clearly catching up. Then Margaret Thatcher took over.

By demographic chance, in the 1980s pupil numbers started to fall, in both private and state schools, but, while the private sector continued to invest in more teachers, the new Conservative administration took advantage of the falling pupil numbers to get rid of them in state schools. Half of the extra teachers who had been hired in the 1970s were removed from the payroll. Szreter found that all Britain's main economic competitors had continued to invest heavily in teachers. "By 1991, the best of continental countries were running a ratio of between 10 and 12 pupils per teacher," he reported. In the early 1990s, only four of the 25 most developed nations had larger classes than Britain - Ireland, Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea - and Szreter suspects that when the figures are finally brought up to date, they may well all have left Britain behind. "No other democratically elected government in the modern world has dreamed up this masterstroke of actually disinvesting in the educational resources of the nation," he said.

In the meantime, the private schools had continued hiring and re-established their superiority, with average classes containing only 10 pupils, nearly half the state schools' 19. Szreter estimates that to regain a position where the state school classes are only 50% larger than private ones, the government would need to hire 100,000 new teachers.

Clearly, there is real unfairness in this. And yet, that does not, on the face of it, entitle us to blame the private schools. Where is the evidence that this mass shedding of teachers happened because there was a system of private schools over the fence and not simply because a Tory government was intent on cutting public spending to fund tax cuts? The cuts were part of a wider picture of encroaching financial hardship. Although the Tories often increased spending on education, they invariably failed to provide enough cash to keep pace with inflation and pupil numbers and, in spite of protests from parents and teachers, they allowed the real-terms funding of state schools to shrink.

The London borough of Ealing's director of education, Alan Parker, reconstructed what happened. The borough protected its schools and cut the support services: eight education welfare officers were lost; the education psychology service was cut to the point where it could do little more than prepare statements to get funding for children with special needs; teachers of English as a foreign language were halved. Then the borough had to cut adult education - grants went only for those on income support who chose to pursue one of a narrow range of vocational courses. The youth service was cut by 50%. Arts, libaries and museums, too. Routine maintenance of buildings fell to zero. Then the cuts reached inside the schools - no more tuition in music, larger classes, less administrative support, less for books, less for classroom equipment, less for materials.

Our survey of local education authorities produced similar accounts from all over the country. State schools found themselves caught in a pincer, compelled by law to teach the national curriculum, but compelled by cuts to reduce their service. The result was a cutback in music, sport, French in primary schools, libraries, special schools, outdoor centres - anything that was not protected by law.

In one year of John Major's spending limits, the London borough of Merton, which had drawn some £30m out of reserves, had to cut education by £4.7m. Hammersmith, in west London, has had to cut its budget for schools every year for the last six years, taking a total of £2.5m. Derbyshire has lost teachers in each of the last eight years, a total of 1,361.

When Ofsted inspected Northumberland LEA recently, it found that the council's income had fallen in real terms every year from 1992 to 1998 and schools had suffered an 11% cut in budgets while central spending on education had been cut by 36%. Since the late 1980s, budgets for secondary schools in Cheshire have fallen in real terms by 6%; student awards were cut from £9m to only £500,000; adult education has been cut by 30%. Staffordshire education had to cut £9m. And on and on.

During this long period of attrition Mrs Thatcher explained: "I do not care what people's background is, where they come from. I want them to have the same opportunities, I want to get totally rid of class distinction."

By 1991, 2,000 state schools were contacting the BBC's Children In Need project for money to repair buildings and hire more teachers.

The private schools, however, were doing well with a very healthy subsidy from the state. Despite protests from the Labour party, the Conservative government continued to allow many to enjoy charity status.

This meant that they escaped all tax on income from stocks, shares, trusts and property as well as escaping all VAT, corporation tax on their profit, capital gains tax and stamp duty on their property transactions, inheritance tax on their new endowments and up to 100% of their business rates.

Charity benefit

In 1996, the Independent Schools Council surveyed 838 of its members and concluded that they were saving £62.6m a year. In 1992, however, the master of Haileybury, David Jewell, suggested that ending charitable status would add 30% to fees - making charitable status the equivalent of a state subsidy of about £1,945 per pupil and some £200 a year more than the state now invests in the education of a child at primary school.

The private schools also continued to benefit from ministry of defence and foreign office fees for the children of some personnel, currently £72m and £12.5m a year. Arguably, universities benefit with almost 90% of private pupils going on to higher education, more than 20% of all university entrants.

All this subsidy was already in place when Mrs Thatcher became prime minister. However, in 1981 she introduced a new and even more lucrative form of support, the assisted places scheme which paid the fees of up to 36,000 pupils a year, thus providing the private schools with a guaranteed income from the state of nearly £900m during the Conservative years. In this way, new money flowed through the same old channels that had been dug more than 100 years earlier - from the education of the poor towards the well-to-do.

This financial aid was only one part of the bounty bestowed on private sector schools. There was a time when these two systems were in effect sealed off from each other as each generation of children divided to follow the footsteps of its parents but the Thatcher era saw the growth in schools of the One Big Market. Because the spending cuts were hurting the performance and reputation of state schools; because the income from fees and state subsidy was pushing the private schools still further ahead; because the Conservatives were cutting tax and putting more money into middle-class pockets, enabling them to buy their way into private schools; because private schools saw that it was financially and politically wise to invest in a wider range of pupils; because Kenneth Baker gave parents the right to choose state schools for their children; and because he then ordered that the funding should follow the children into the most popular schools, thus further damaging the reputation and performance of "failing" schools - for all these reasons the number of children in private schools began to rise.

When Mrs Thatcher came to power, only 5.8% of the nation's children were in the private sector; by the time she left, the number had risen to 7%. In Greater London, 12% of the children were in private schools. There was no doubt about where these children were coming from: according to the ISC, most parents who send their children to private schools were themselves educated in the state sector. In many other ways, the two sectors of schooling remained separate; there were still many pupils who were born into one sector and could not conceive of entering the other; but in the centre, in this commercial sense, the private schools and the state schools had been pulled together, in competition with each other in the market for pupils.

To reinforce the trend, the Conservatives encouraged state schools to opt out of LEA control, taking extra funds to become grant maintained schools with the power to select their intake.

As all this evidence unfolds, a clearer answer begins to emerge to the question of co-existence. No other country in Europe has a fully fledged alternative to its state schools. No other country in Europe "disinvested" in its state schools.

And what about the people who were responsible for this disinvestment? Ministers increased the size of state classes and sent their own children to private schools that had spent a small fortune cutting the size of their classes. This is not simply a point about jealousy: it is a point about politics.

In his book We Should Know Better, the former Tory education minister, George Walden, argues with considerable authority that Britain's state schools have suffered persistent negligence because the power elite has had no interest in protecting them. He writes: "The screening out of the sons and daughters of the affluent and influential severs our educational culture at the neck."

In this crucial sense, the history of Britain's education is about the private sector actively damaging the state sector, by providing for the children of the rich and powerful with only the most meagre political protection for state schools. In this sense, the co-existence never has been peaceful. Beyond this, the creation of the One Big Market now has introduced a second and equally important kind of damage: on a scale that they have never achieved before, the private schools are skimming bright children off the top of the state system.

Seven years ago, the national commission for education spotted the underlying trend in Britain's schools: the gap between the best and the worst. "The gulf in outcomes between our best schools and our worst is big, much bigger than in most countries," it said.

"The OECD found that differences between English schools in levels of mathematical achievement were far larger than in any of the 10 other countries studied, including Scotland, with the single exception of Switzerland."

That commission specifically warned about the potential damage caused by Kenneth Baker's introduction, five years earlier, of an effective market in school places. We described in the first part of this series how those reforms had created a two-tier system of state schools, the successful school in the affluent suburb attracting more and more motivated, middle-class pupils, and more and more funds; while the failing school down the road became a ghetto, starved of motivated children, penalised with the loss of funds. Every time a government boosts the private schools, it reinforces that process of polarisation. The fact that the private schools run explicitly on a system of academic selection means that there is no ambiguity at all about what is happening (in the way that there may be some marginal ambiguity with the middle-class state school): they are taking the brightest children. Which, in itself, adds another twist to the polarisation, by advancing their own academic results and depressing those of the state.

As a single example, take Bedfordshire, where according to county councillor Tony Mitchell, 12% of the county's brightest children are skimmed off by four private schools in the Harpur Trust. "In the heyday of the grammar school, a county like Essex selected only 6% of the ability range." In addition, the Conservatives' grant-maintained schools, with extra funding from LEAs, select pupils and skim a further 27% of Bedfordshire children. "Some schools, all in areas of disadvantage, are threatened with closure while one GM school has 54% of its pupils from outside its catchment area."

Yet this is not quite the end of the argument. Events have moved on. The year after George Walden wrote his book, New Labour came to power and it dealt private schools two painful body blows. One of David Blunkett's first steps as education secretary was to kill off the assisted places scheme, worth an annual £134.4m to the private schools. Mr Blunkett was sued in the high court, was heavily criticised but stuck to the policy. Then he introduced tuition fees in university. It hurt almost all potential students - and it hurt the private schools by diverting some of the parental cash that might otherwise have gone into private sixth-forms.

There are now signs of struggle in the private sector. The Independent Schools Council reported last year that the number of children at its schools had increased by 0.71%, but that disguised the real trend. The increase consists entirely of a surge in children going to private nurseries while the numbers taking both GCSEs and A-levels has started to fall. More than that, there has been a steady and ultimately drastic fall in the flow of the most lucrative pupils, the boarders: in 1983, 27.7% of ISC pupils were boarders; last year, it was only 14.9%. Last year alone, the number of boarders fell by 4.3%.

Last summer, the City accountant PriceWaterhouseCooper reported that scores of private schools were likely to close in the next decade. Its survey indicated that 13% of schools were running a deficit. Richard Davison of the ISC said: "It is a free market and the weaker schools are going. Once you move away from the top schools, it is brutal."

There are some deepy troubled private schools, suffering with an intake of poorly motivated children and very low fees. Ofsted's annual report in 1997/8 pointed out that while 10% of private schools see every single pupil scoring at least five A to C grades at GCSE, there are 5% of private schools who cannot score a single A to C grade for any of their pupils. That year, they inspected only 411 private schools, but 60 of them "caused considerable concern".

Public appeals

School inspectors reported: "Only one teacher has qualified teacher status; classrooms are unsafe and unhealthy and so unfit for the education of children; excessive shouting at children; overall the quality of education is poor; the air of decay; the lack of resources; low paid teachers"

A survey by the market research group Mintel last year found that in the previous year, fees had risen by 5.2% while inflation was only 3.3%. Some schools have launched financial appeals and others are investing in computer and sports facilities.

Where once private schools marketed themselves by sending the headteacher to preach in an outside church, the big private players are now playing the market game professionally. Two hundred and eighty private schools have formed the Association of Development Directors in Independent Schools. Their chair, Felicity Rutland, said: "Marketing professionals are no longer a luxury, they are key members of the school's management team."

In theory, the Blair government might have continued to defend the state schools. But in terms of their funding, the disparity between private and state remains breathtaking. Last year, ISC found that their schools were charging on average £5,460 for a year, while state schools were receiving from all sources an average of only £2,372 per pupil. To put it another way: setting aside tax breaks and other subsidies, pupils in state schools are receiving only 44% of the funding that is enjoyed by private school pupils. Bear in mind also that some of the most successful private schools receive a considerable income from investments and property which they can add to their income from fees, so that a school such as Eton can spend some £20,000 per year on each of its pupils.

In contrast to the scything cuts in music, French and sport in the state primary schools, a survey last year by the Incorporated Association of Preparatory Schools found that 93% of private prep schools teach music; almost all teach French; two thirds teach Latin; a quarter teach German; one in seven teach Spanish; and they enjoy an average of 18.3 acres of land. Since 1981, state schools have been forced to sell more than 5,000 playing fields; although Labour promised to end the sale, they are still being sold off at a rate of about 20 a year.

While private schools had been installing computers and linking them to the internet and their own internal intranets, the state primary schools in 1998 were providing only one computer for every 18 pupils; only 17% of them were linked to the internet. In secondary schools there was one computer between nine pupils. In an attempt to catch up, Mr Blunkett invested £310m in the National Grid for Learning and saw the figures start to climb in 1999. The end result of all this is a system on the edge of despair.

Since Mr Blunkett's claim to be spending an extra £19bn has collapsed in empty rhetoric, many state schools have turned to parents to raise money.

Teachers, too, have become funders: the Association of Teachers and Lecturers found that half their members had dug into their own pockets to buy resources for the literacy hour.

Corporations, sensing an opportunity, have moved to fill the gap. But many, such as Cadbury's and McDonald's, promote their own products.

The old maxim that Britain's state schools are centrally funded but locally delivered is collapsing: first, under the weight of the standards fund, which means that almost all spare cash is being directed from the centre; and, secondly, under a torrent of central instruction and criticism.

Giving evidence to the select committee on education, Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, contemptuously dismissed the idea that state teachers were suffering from a lack of resources. "They blame the government for a lack of resources, they blame parents for not producing intelligent enough pupils, and they blame the collapse of western civilisation as we know it." This was on November 3 1999. Six months earlier, the headmaster of Winchester, James Sabben-Clare, told the Daily Telegraph that if independent schools were restricted to spending an average of £2,300 a year per pupil, as state schools are, the quality of education they could offer would be greatly diminished. Fees at Winchester run at £15,000 a year.

Few other businesses are marketed by managers who publicly denounce their product; attack their staff; savage their local managers; and sing the praises of the competition.

No other organisation in the country is managed with the kind of organised public exposure experienced by schools and local education authorities. It is doubtful whether any other organisation - corporate boardroom, factory floor, legal chambers, newsroom - could survive that kind of scrutiny and denunciation. There are drunkards in alleys with a better strategy for self-advertisement.

All this means that the state schools remain highly vulnerable to the private schools they are now encouraged to see as partners. The answer to the question of co-existence is that purely in educational terms, the private schools continue to inflict damage on the state sector, draining away political interest and bright pupils. Why does the department of education not do more to protect them?

Mr Walden blamed some of the department's problems on low-calibre civil servants. He argued that top-flight officials went off to the high-prestige departments such as the foreign office, leaving education in the hands of the also-rans: "Able people have worked there, but on average the quality has not been commensurate with the importance of the work." The problem, however, surely goes deeper than a mere shortage of managerial flair.

One of the battering rams used by critics to attack state schooling in the last 20 years has been a contempt for those who, in the words of Kenneth Baker, "seek to use education for social engineering". It is this that is held to have poisoned the well of state schooling by producing the comprehensive system. It is this perversion that is blamed for a "levelling down" in the classroom.

Control of education

Now go back, for a moment, to the schools inquiry commission and look at its confident assertion that there was no justification for "indiscriminate gratuitous instruction". Well? Is there? The unemployed need no qualifications at all. Even skilled workers do not need A-levels, let alone university degrees.

The Conservative and National governments of the 1920s and 1930s understood this and resisted all efforts by the Labour party to introduce universal secondary education and to raise the school leaving age. On the eve of the second world war, working class children in this country were still entitled only to elementary education to the age of 14; 10% of them managed to graduate into county grammar schools or direct grant schools, often paying fees. And that was it.

The impetus to allow the working class into the higher reaches of education was and remains political and moral: it enables the workers not merely to work but to aspire to break out of their class and move upwards. In that sense, any move towards educating the working class is guilty of precisely the crime of which it is so frequently still accused by its conservative detractors - social engineering. If you deny the role of social justice in education, you remove any logical justification for universal schooling. For all its humanity and social justice, it makes no economic sense at all. Any sane treasury official, therefore, will resist it. Which is what they have done, very successfully.

The ideology of partnership has silenced talk of social justice in New Labour's education policy and so, in one simple sweep of rhetoric, more than 100 years of development is left hanging. The point is not that the education department or its ministers are part of some conspiracy to undermine the state schools. The truth rather is that, in an age of pragmatism, they have lost their politics and so they have no basis on which to fight a battle for public opinion to explain that they cannot fund a revival in state schools without raising taxes.

They prefer to pretend that they have found the money, regardless of reality. In the same way, they will not challenge the received wisdom of the Conservative years but prefer to recycle the muddled half-truths of parental choice and funding formulae and Ofsted and league tables, offering no kind of leadership, no kind of insight, no kind of hope. And, in the meantime, the market continues to favour the strong.

Martin Stephens, high master of Manchester grammar school, one of the private schools that commands most admiration from the government, told us: "We have created a system of almost total confusion. It is basically a vision of chaos."
