A year later, following the lead of the schools inquiry commission, the endowed schools act organised a far grander larceny, seizing from towns all over the country a fortune in endowments which had been left for the benefit of the local poor but which were now used to pay for a network of new fee-paying private schools for the middle class. Now, look at the story of Britain's schools during the last 20 years. From poisoned roots, a mighty structure has grown: 2,300 private schools with an annual income from fees of some £3.2bn, educating nearly 600,000 pupils, a magnificent 7%of the nation's children. This remains the most unusual feature of the educational landscape of Britain. Other countries allow private schools, and some educate far more in private schools (17% in France, 13% in Denmark). However, apart from small pockets of privilege, invariably these are religious schools, such as those in France or Italy, or "free" schools such as those in Denmark, often underfunded and relying on state subsidy to survive. There is no other country in Europe where private schools present a fully fledged alternative to the state system, open essentially only to the affluent. Does that matter? In the first instance, it is a question of power. Stephen Pollard and Andrew Adonis, now a Downing Street adviser, recorded in their book A Class Act that, on the latest available figures, the magnificent 7% accounted for: seven out of nine senior generals; 33 out of 39 most senior judges; more than 120 of the 180 officers graduating from Sandhurst; half of the 18 permanent secretaries running Whitehall; and just under half of the 94 grade-three civil servants then aged under 50. Research for the Economic and Social Research Council found that 75% of private school pupils went on to take professional or managerial jobs. From the state schools, only 40% reached that level. Politics marginalised This question of power, and of social justice, has ceased to be fashionable, largely because the politics that kept the question alive have been marginalised. However, in a pragmatic age, an equally pressing version of the question remains - a purely educational one: does the existence of private schools have any impact on the educational performance of the mainstream state system? Can we relax and allow the two systems to enjoy a peaceful co-existence? Or is there some kind of destructive friction between the two? The answer is not quite what you might expect. Consider, for example, the hiring and firing of teachers. Simon Szreter, an economic historian at St John's College, Cambridge,found that in the last 20 years, Britain had fallen behind just about every other developed country in its investment in teachers for the state sector. Meanwhile, the private schools had forged ahead. All through the 1970s, Szreter found, both state schools and private schools were hiring extra teachers: the combined efforts of the Heath, Wilson and Callaghan governments put an extra 100,000 teachers on the payroll, with state schools closing the gap on private schools. At the beginning of the decade, the average state class contained 26 children; by 1979, it contained only 19. In private schools, the pupil-teacher ratio was about 50% lower - and the average of 19 disguised a mass of state classes of more than 30, sometimes more than 40, but the state sector was clearly catching up. Then Margaret Thatcher took over. By demographic chance, in the 1980s pupil numbers started to fall, in both private and state schools, but, while the private sector continued to invest in more teachers, the new Conservative administration took advantage of the falling pupil numbers to get rid of them in state schools. Half of the extra teachers who had been hired in the 1970s were removed from the payroll. Szreter found that all Britain's main economic competitors had continued to invest heavily in teachers. "By 1991, the best of continental countries were running a ratio of between 10 and 12 pupils per teacher," he reported. In the early 1990s, only four of the 25 most developed nations had larger classes than Britain - Ireland, Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea - and Szreter suspects that when the figures are finally brought up to date, they may well all have left Britain behind. "No other democratically elected government in the modern world has dreamed up this masterstroke of actually disinvesting in the educational resources of the nation," he said. In the meantime, the private schools had continued hiring and re-established their superiority, with average classes containing only 10 pupils, nearly half the state schools' 19. Szreter estimates that to regain a position where the state school classes are only 50% larger than private ones, the government would need to hire 100,000 new teachers. Clearly, there is real unfairness in this. And yet, that does not, on the face of it, entitle us to blame the private schools. Where is the evidence that this mass shedding of teachers happened because there was a system of private schools over the fence and not simply because a Tory government was intent on cutting public spending to fund tax cuts? The cuts were part of a wider picture of encroaching financial hardship. Although the Tories often increased spending on education, they invariably failed to provide enough cash to keep pace with inflation and pupil numbers and, in spite of protests from parents and teachers, they allowed the real-terms funding of state schools to shrink. The London borough of Ealing's director of education, Alan Parker, reconstructed what happened. The borough protected its schools and cut the support services: eight education welfare officers were lost; the education psychology service was cut to the point where it could do little more than prepare statements to get funding for children with special needs; teachers of English as a foreign language were halved. Then the borough had to cut adult education - grants went only for those on income support who chose to pursue one of a narrow range of vocational courses. The youth service was cut by 50%. Arts, libaries and museums, too. Routine maintenance of buildings fell to zero. Then the cuts reached inside the schools - no more tuition in music, larger classes, less administrative support, less for books, less for classroom equipment, less for materials. Our survey of local education authorities produced similar accounts from all over the country. State schools found themselves caught in a pincer, compelled by law to teach the national curriculum, but compelled by cuts to reduce their service. The result was a cutback in music, sport, French in primary schools, libraries, special schools, outdoor centres - anything that was not protected by law. In one year of John Major's spending limits, the London borough of Merton, which had drawn some £30m out of reserves, had to cut education by £4.7m. Hammersmith, in west London, has had to cut its budget for schools every year for the last six years, taking a total of £2.5m. Derbyshire has lost teachers in each of the last eight years, a total of 1,361. When Ofsted inspected Northumberland LEA recently, it found that the council's income had fallen in real terms every year from 1992 to 1998 and schools had suffered an 11% cut in budgets while central spending on education had been cut by 36%. Since the late 1980s, budgets for secondary schools in Cheshire have fallen in real terms by 6%; student awards were cut from £9m to only £500,000; adult education has been cut by 30%. Staffordshire education had to cut £9m. And on and on. During this long period of attrition Mrs Thatcher explained: "I do not care what people's background is, where they come from. I want them to have the same opportunities, I want to get totally rid of class distinction." By 1991, 2,000 state schools were contacting the BBC's Children In Need project for money to repair buildings and hire more teachers. The private schools, however, were doing well with a very healthy subsidy from the state. Despite protests from the Labour party, the Conservative government continued to allow many to enjoy charity status. This meant that they escaped all tax on income from stocks, shares, trusts and property as well as escaping all VAT, corporation tax on their profit, capital gains tax and stamp duty on their property transactions, inheritance tax on their new endowments and up to 100% of their business rates. Charity benefit In 1996, the Independent Schools Council surveyed 838 of its members and concluded that they were saving £62.6m a year. In 1992, however, the master of Haileybury, David Jewell, suggested that ending charitable status would add 30% to fees - making charitable status the equivalent of a state subsidy of about £1,945 per pupil and some £200 a year more than the state now invests in the education of a child at primary school. The private schools also continued to benefit from ministry of defence and foreign office fees for the children of some personnel, currently £72m and £12.5m a year. Arguably, universities benefit with almost 90% of private pupils going on to higher education, more than 20% of all university entrants. All this subsidy was already in place when Mrs Thatcher became prime minister. However, in 1981 she introduced a new and even more lucrative form of support, the assisted places scheme which paid the fees of up to 36,000 pupils a year, thus providing the private schools with a guaranteed income from the state of nearly £900m during the Conservative years. In this way, new money flowed through the same old channels that had been dug more than 100 years earlier - from the education of the poor towards the well-to-do. This financial aid was only one part of the bounty bestowed on private sector schools. There was a time when these two systems were in effect sealed off from each other as each generation of children divided to follow the footsteps of its parents but the Thatcher era saw the growth in schools of the One Big Market. Because the spending cuts were hurting the performance and reputation of state schools; because the income from fees and state subsidy was pushing the private schools still further ahead; because the Conservatives were cutting tax and putting more money into middle-class pockets, enabling them to buy their way into private schools; because private schools saw that it was financially and politically wise to invest in a wider range of pupils; because Kenneth Baker gave parents the right to choose state schools for their children; and because he then ordered that the funding should follow the children into the most popular schools, thus further damaging the reputation and performance of "failing" schools - for all these reasons the number of children in private schools began to rise. When Mrs Thatcher came to power, only 5.8% of the nation's children were in the private sector; by the time she left, the number had risen to 7%. In Greater London, 12% of the children were in private schools. There was no doubt about where these children were coming from: according to the ISC, most parents who send their children to private schools were themselves educated in the state sector. In many other ways, the two sectors of schooling remained separate; there were still many pupils who were born into one sector and could not conceive of entering the other; but in the centre, in this commercial sense, the private schools and the state schools had been pulled together, in competition with each other in the market for pupils. To reinforce the trend, the Conservatives encouraged state schools to opt out of LEA control, taking extra funds to become grant maintained schools with the power to select their intake. As all this evidence unfolds, a clearer answer begins to emerge to the question of co-existence. No other country in Europe has a fully fledged alternative to its state schools. No other country in Europe "disinvested" in its state schools. And what about the people who were responsible for this disinvestment? Ministers increased the size of state classes and sent their own children to private schools that had spent a small fortune cutting the size of their classes. This is not simply a point about jealousy: it is a point about politics. In his book We Should Know Better, the former Tory education minister, George Walden, argues with considerable authority that Britain's state schools have suffered persistent negligence because the power elite has had no interest in protecting them. He writes: "The screening out of the sons and daughters of the affluent and influential severs our educational culture at the neck." In this crucial sense, the history of Britain's education is about the private sector actively damaging the state sector, by providing for the children of the rich and powerful with only the most meagre political protection for state schools. In this sense, the co-existence never has been peaceful. Beyond this, the creation of the One Big Market now has introduced a second and equally important kind of damage: on a scale that they have never achieved before, the private schools are skimming bright children off the top of the state system. Seven years ago, the national commission for education spotted the underlying trend in Britain's schools: the gap between the best and the worst. "The gulf in outcomes between our best schools and our worst is big, much bigger than in most countries," it said. "The OECD found that differences between English schools in levels of mathematical achievement were far larger than in any of the 10 other countries studied, including Scotland, with the single exception of Switzerland." That commission specifically warned about the potential damage caused by Kenneth Baker's introduction, five years earlier, of an effective market in school places. We described in the first part of this series how those reforms had created a two-tier system of state schools, the successful school in the affluent suburb attracting more and more motivated, middle-class pupils, and more and more funds; while the failing school down the road became a ghetto, starved of motivated children, penalised with the loss of funds. Every time a government boosts the private schools, it reinforces that process of polarisation. The fact that the private schools run explicitly on a system of academic selection means that there is no ambiguity at all about what is happening (in the way that there may be some marginal ambiguity with the middle-class state school): they are taking the brightest children. Which, in itself, adds another twist to the polarisation, by advancing their own academic results and depressing those of the state. As a single example, take Bedfordshire, where according to county councillor Tony Mitchell, 12% of the county's brightest children are skimmed off by four private schools in the Harpur Trust. "In the heyday of the grammar school, a county like Essex selected only 6% of the ability range." In addition, the Conservatives' grant-maintained schools, with extra funding from LEAs, select pupils and skim a further 27% of Bedfordshire children. "Some schools, all in areas of disadvantage, are threatened with closure while one GM school has 54% of its pupils from outside its catchment area." Yet this is not quite the end of the argument. Events have moved on. The year after George Walden wrote his book, New Labour came to power and it dealt private schools two painful body blows. One of David Blunkett's first steps as education secretary was to kill off the assisted places scheme, worth an annual £134.4m to the private schools. Mr Blunkett was sued in the high court, was heavily criticised but stuck to the policy. Then he introduced tuition fees in university. It hurt almost all potential students - and it hurt the private schools by diverting some of the parental cash that might otherwise have gone into private sixth-forms. There are now signs of struggle in the private sector. The Independent Schools Council reported last year that the number of children at its schools had increased by 0.71%, but that disguised the real trend. The increase consists entirely of a surge in children going to private nurseries while the numbers taking both GCSEs and A-levels has started to fall. More than that, there has been a steady and ultimately drastic fall in the flow of the most lucrative pupils, the boarders: in 1983, 27.7% of ISC pupils were boarders; last year, it was only 14.9%. Last year alone, the number of boarders fell by 4.3%. Last summer, the City accountant PriceWaterhouseCooper reported that scores of private schools were likely to close in the next decade. Its survey indicated that 13% of schools were running a deficit. Richard Davison of the ISC said: "It is a free market and the weaker schools are going. Once you move away from the top schools, it is brutal." There are some deepy troubled private schools, suffering with an intake of poorly motivated children and very low fees. Ofsted's annual report in 1997/8 pointed out that while 10% of private schools see every single pupil scoring at least five A to C grades at GCSE, there are 5% of private schools who cannot score a single A to C grade for any of their pupils. That year, they inspected only 411 private schools, but 60 of them "caused considerable concern". Public appeals School inspectors reported: "Only one teacher has qualified teacher status; classrooms are unsafe and unhealthy and so unfit for the education of children; excessive shouting at children; overall the quality of education is poor; the air of decay; the lack of resources; low paid teachers" A survey by the market research group Mintel last year found that in the previous year, fees had risen by 5.2% while inflation was only 3.3%. Some schools have launched financial appeals and others are investing in computer and sports facilities. Where once private schools marketed themselves by sending the headteacher to preach in an outside church, the big private players are now playing the market game professionally. Two hundred and eighty private schools have formed the Association of Development Directors in Independent Schools. Their chair, Felicity Rutland, said: "Marketing professionals are no longer a luxury, they are key members of the school's management team." In theory, the Blair government might have continued to defend the state schools. But in terms of their funding, the disparity between private and state remains breathtaking. Last year, ISC found that their schools were charging on average £5,460 for a year, while state schools were receiving from all sources an average of only £2,372 per pupil. To put it another way: setting aside tax breaks and other subsidies, pupils in state schools are receiving only 44% of the funding that is enjoyed by private school pupils. Bear in mind also that some of the most successful private schools receive a considerable income from investments and property which they can add to their income from fees, so that a school such as Eton can spend some £20,000 per year on each of its pupils. In contrast to the scything cuts in music, French and sport in the state primary schools, a survey last year by the Incorporated Association of Preparatory Schools found that 93% of private prep schools teach music; almost all teach French; two thirds teach Latin; a quarter teach German; one in seven teach Spanish; and they enjoy an average of 18.3 acres of land. Since 1981, state schools have been forced to sell more than 5,000 playing fields; although Labour promised to end the sale, they are still being sold off at a rate of about 20 a year. While private schools had been installing computers and linking them to the internet and their own internal intranets, the state primary schools in 1998 were providing only one computer for every 18 pupils; only 17% of them were linked to the internet. In secondary schools there was one computer between nine pupils. In an attempt to catch up, Mr Blunkett invested £310m in the National Grid for Learning and saw the figures start to climb in 1999. The end result of all this is a system on the edge of despair. Since Mr Blunkett's claim to be spending an extra £19bn has collapsed in empty rhetoric, many state schools have turned to parents to raise money. Teachers, too, have become funders: the Association of Teachers and Lecturers found that half their members had dug into their own pockets to buy resources for the literacy hour. Corporations, sensing an opportunity, have moved to fill the gap. But many, such as Cadbury's and McDonald's, promote their own products. The old maxim that Britain's state schools are centrally funded but locally delivered is collapsing: first, under the weight of the standards fund, which means that almost all spare cash is being directed from the centre; and, secondly, under a torrent of central instruction and criticism. Giving evidence to the select committee on education, Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, contemptuously dismissed the idea that state teachers were suffering from a lack of resources. "They blame the government for a lack of resources, they blame parents for not producing intelligent enough pupils, and they blame the collapse of western civilisation as we know it." This was on November 3 1999. Six months earlier, the headmaster of Winchester, James Sabben-Clare, told the Daily Telegraph that if independent schools were restricted to spending an average of £2,300 a year per pupil, as state schools are, the quality of education they could offer would be greatly diminished. Fees at Winchester run at £15,000 a year. Few other businesses are marketed by managers who publicly denounce their product; attack their staff; savage their local managers; and sing the praises of the competition. No other organisation in the country is managed with the kind of organised public exposure experienced by schools and local education authorities. It is doubtful whether any other organisation - corporate boardroom, factory floor, legal chambers, newsroom - could survive that kind of scrutiny and denunciation. There are drunkards in alleys with a better strategy for self-advertisement. All this means that the state schools remain highly vulnerable to the private schools they are now encouraged to see as partners. The answer to the question of co-existence is that purely in educational terms, the private schools continue to inflict damage on the state sector, draining away political interest and bright pupils. Why does the department of education not do more to protect them? Mr Walden blamed some of the department's problems on low-calibre civil servants. He argued that top-flight officials went off to the high-prestige departments such as the foreign office, leaving education in the hands of the also-rans: "Able people have worked there, but on average the quality has not been commensurate with the importance of the work." The problem, however, surely goes deeper than a mere shortage of managerial flair. One of the battering rams used by critics to attack state schooling in the last 20 years has been a contempt for those who, in the words of Kenneth Baker, "seek to use education for social engineering". It is this that is held to have poisoned the well of state schooling by producing the comprehensive system. It is this perversion that is blamed for a "levelling down" in the classroom. Control of education Now go back, for a moment, to the schools inquiry commission and look at its confident assertion that there was no justification for "indiscriminate gratuitous instruction". Well? Is there? The unemployed need no qualifications at all. Even skilled workers do not need A-levels, let alone university degrees. The Conservative and National governments of the 1920s and 1930s understood this and resisted all efforts by the Labour party to introduce universal secondary education and to raise the school leaving age. On the eve of the second world war, working class children in this country were still entitled only to elementary education to the age of 14; 10% of them managed to graduate into county grammar schools or direct grant schools, often paying fees. And that was it. The impetus to allow the working class into the higher reaches of education was and remains political and moral: it enables the workers not merely to work but to aspire to break out of their class and move upwards. In that sense, any move towards educating the working class is guilty of precisely the crime of which it is so frequently still accused by its conservative detractors - social engineering. If you deny the role of social justice in education, you remove any logical justification for universal schooling. For all its humanity and social justice, it makes no economic sense at all. Any sane treasury official, therefore, will resist it. Which is what they have done, very successfully. The ideology of partnership has silenced talk of social justice in New Labour's education policy and so, in one simple sweep of rhetoric, more than 100 years of development is left hanging. The point is not that the education department or its ministers are part of some conspiracy to undermine the state schools. The truth rather is that, in an age of pragmatism, they have lost their politics and so they have no basis on which to fight a battle for public opinion to explain that they cannot fund a revival in state schools without raising taxes. They prefer to pretend that they have found the money, regardless of reality. In the same way, they will not challenge the received wisdom of the Conservative years but prefer to recycle the muddled half-truths of parental choice and funding formulae and Ofsted and league tables, offering no kind of leadership, no kind of insight, no kind of hope. And, in the meantime, the market continues to favour the strong. Martin Stephens, high master of Manchester grammar school, one of the private schools that commands most admiration from the government, told us: "We have created a system of almost total confusion. It is basically a vision of chaos." Additional research by Helene Mulholland

webTitle: Ballymeena Protestants angered by Neeson honour

fields.headline: Ballymeena Protestants angered by Neeson honour
fields.trailText: Councillors in Ballymeena, Northern Ireland have incurred the wrath of the Democratic Unionist Party by deciding to honour Liam Neeson with the freedom of the town where the actor was born. The party, which supports union with Britain, has demanded that the council retract its invitation after comments Neeson made to an American magazine about his birthplace.
fields.body:
Councillors in Ballymeena, Northern Ireland have incurred the wrath of the Democratic Unionist Party by deciding to honour Liam Neeson with the freedom of the town where the actor was born. The party, which supports union with Britain, has demanded that the council retract its invitation after comments Neeson made to an American magazine about his birthplace.

The Star Wars star is quoted as saying that growing up as a Catholic in a predominantly Protestant area, he felt like a "second class citizen", and that he stayed indoors whenever Protestants celebrated the victory at the Battle of the Boyne.

fields.headline: Could do better
fields.standfirst: Guardian Women's editor Libby Brookes says the battle for equality is still far from won
fields.trailText: So what exactly are we celebrating? Today, on the first  international women's day of the new millennium, is there anything left to fight for?
fields.body:
So what exactly are we celebrating? Today, on the first international women's day of the new millennium, is there anything left to fight for?

The answer, it would seem, is a resounding yes: not only from women in Britain, but from women around the world who are using today to launch a raft of campaigns tackling everything from domestic violence to third world debt. The 8th of March has always given us an opportunity to think globally.

One of the most interesting campaigns to link to international women's day is Women Make the News. Run by Unesco, it's calling on all media organisations to ensure that the world's news output on the day is produced under the editorial responsibility of women. As new technology expands the range and power of the media, it becomes increasingly important to ensure that the news agenda represents women's needs and interests as much as those of men.

Of course men and women are not so fundamentally different as to choose entirely conflicting agendas - often it's about sensibility rather than gender, an occasional shift of emphasis rather than a complete change of subject.

The possibilities raised by this initiative will be more fully explored by Worldwoman - an internet based newspaper and press agency written by women for women with contributions from all over the world. The notion is that women across the globe will contribute stories on every possible issue, sometimes local and sometimes global, which can then be adapted by women in other countries to suit their particular local interests.

Of course, if all that activity doesn't appeal, you could always take the day off. Today groups of women worldwide will be striking for an end to no pay, low pay and too much work, demanding wages for all caring work, equal pay and paid maternity leave, as well as the abolition of third world debt, the burden of which falls heaviest on women.

Issues of equal pay and parental leave have particularly exercised the women of Britain in the last couple of months. Research published earlier this year by the London School of Economics found that women forfeit up to £250,000 over a working lifetime simply because they are women. While women with children and women in part-time work are most heavily penalised, the bottom line remains that women lose out not because of lifestyle choice or educational disadvantage but simply because of their gender. Meanwhile, it remains to be seen whether the introduction of parental leave will have any serious impact while it continues to be unpaid.

The Blair government's record on women has rightly been held up to close scrutiny, given the emphasis that Labour has placed on its ability to deliver on gender inequalities. And despite some significant successes - on childcare and the working family tax credit for example - it is telling that women within the government are still feeling marginalised by the predominantly male ethos of parliament.

So what are we celebrating? The myriad of advances that have improved the lives of women, particularly in the developed world, over the past decade. But still, globally as well as locally, there is plenty to think about, today and every day.

webTitle: 'Who are the democrats?' asks beseiged Blair

fields.headline: 'Who are the democrats?' asks beseiged Blair
fields.trailText: Labour's London mayor crisis dominated an explosive question time today which saw the prime minister labelled "not a control freak but a control failure".
fields.body:
Labour's London mayor crisis dominated an explosive question time today which saw the prime minister labelled "not a control freak but a control failure".

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy said in the Commons that was the only conclusion he could draw about Tony Blair since Ken Livingstone entered the ballot on Monday.

The prime minister came under attack from Tory leader William Hague who said that selection procedures used by Labour for elections in Wales, London and Scotland had been "rigged, manipulated and dictated from 10 Downing St."

Mr Hague accused Mr Blair of "breathtaking arrogance" and "creating a rotten political culture of cronyism". He later quoted a newspaper article containing comments by deputy prime minister John Prescott in which the minister for the environment, transport and regions said he was not in favour of a directly elected mayor.

"He's not a fan and he's introducing the bill bringing it in."

Mr Blair replied that Mr Prescott was entitled to "his view" and added that Labour had returned democracy to London by introducing the office of mayor and the new Greater London Assembly. "We have given back the vote in London that you took away - who are the democrats?"

London democracy also found its way into a question from Mr Hague on police numbers and street crime. Taunting Mr Blair about Mr Livingstone's decision to stand as an independent, he added: "Wasn't the Member for Brent East right for once when he said: 'The real deterrent to crime is police on the streets and we have less police on the streets today than when Labour was elected'?

"He knows because he has had something stolen from him.

"Burglary in London is up 5%, car crime is up 9%, street crime is up 50%, ballot rigging is up 100%" he said to Tory laughter.

Police numbers: The prime minister told the Commons that there had been a slight fall in the number of police officers in London. He said that the Metropolitan police had been given additional funding to recruit another 1,100 officers over the next three years. Mr Hague had claimed that police numbers in the capital were 792 down since the election, while street crime had risen by 50%. "It doesn't take a genius to know that there is a link between the two," he said.

NHS recruitment: Over 15,000 nurses have telephoned the NHS's careers hotline to enquire about joining the health service, Mr Blair said. He added that the 2000 Nurse recruitment programme would be repeated every year.
fields.bodyText: Labour's London mayor crisis dominated an explosive question time today which saw the prime minister labelled "not a control freak but a control failure". Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy said in the Commons that was the only conclusion he could draw about Tony Blair since Ken Livingstone entered the ballot on Monday. The prime minister came under attack from Tory leader William Hague who said that selection procedures used by Labour for elections in Wales, London and Scotland had been "rigged, manipulated and dictated from 10 Downing St." Mr Hague accused Mr Blair of "breathtaking arrogance" and "creating a rotten political culture of cronyism". He later quoted a newspaper article containing comments by deputy prime minister John Prescott in which the minister for the environment, transport and regions said he was not in favour of a directly elected mayor. "He's not a fan and he's introducing the bill bringing it in." Mr Blair replied that Mr Prescott was entitled to "his view" and added that Labour had returned democracy to London by introducing the office of mayor and the new Greater London Assembly. "We have given back the vote in London that you took away - who are the democrats?" London democracy also found its way into a question from Mr Hague on police numbers and street crime. Taunting Mr Blair about Mr Livingstone's decision to stand as an independent, he added: "Wasn't the Member for Brent East right for once when he said: 'The real deterrent to crime is police on the streets and we have less police on the streets today than when Labour was elected'? "He knows because he has had something stolen from him. "Burglary in London is up 5%, car crime is up 9%, street crime is up 50%, ballot rigging is up 100%" he said to Tory laughter. Police numbers: The prime minister told the Commons that there had been a slight fall in the number of police officers in London. He said that the Metropolitan police had been given additional funding to recruit another 1,100 officers over the next three years. Mr Hague had claimed that police numbers in the capital were 792 down since the election, while street crime had risen by 50%. "It doesn't take a genius to know that there is a link between the two," he said. NHS recruitment: Over 15,000 nurses have telephoned the NHS's careers hotline to enquire about joining the health service, Mr Blair said. He added that the 2000 Nurse recruitment programme would be repeated every year.

fields.headline: Roaring in the Aussie style
fields.trailText: A year ago Sri Lanka were falling apart in Australia, stung by the controversy over Muttiah Muralitharan's action. A few months later, the one-day world champions were relinquishing their crown without even a hint of a proud lion's roar. Sri Lanka's bold ambition of becoming the top one-day and Test nation by the year 2000 seemed like a crazy fantasy. But now their case is far more persuasive.
fields.body:
A year ago Sri Lanka were falling apart in Australia, stung by the controversy over Muttiah Muralitharan's action. A few months later, the one-day world champions were relinquishing their crown without even a hint of a proud lion's roar. Sri Lanka's bold ambition of becoming the top one-day and Test nation by the year 2000 seemed like a crazy fantasy. But now their case is far more persuasive.

If Sri Lanka beat Pakistan in the current Test series they will move to third place in the Wisden World Championship. While their rise is partly due to the recent decline of Pakistan and West Indies, there is plenty of evidence to suggest that Sri Lanka are rightfully one of the top three teams.

Their most significant triumph was the home defeat of Australia. Although the weather played a part in protecting Sri Lanka's lead, Australia's subsequent form has revealed the true merit of that victory. In itself that result is arguably enough to elevate them to the top of the Test pecking order. But to be acclaimed No.1 Test-playing nation requires a sustained spell of success.

Sadly, to some powers-that-be, such as the ECB, Sri Lanka remain an unfashionable draw, despite their huge popularity among cricket fans. Indeed, Sri Lanka's rise does much to ridicule those who bestow Test status so grudgingly. If cricket is to become truly global, then less-well established nations must be hurried into the fold. After all, football flourishes by embracing all nations at international level rather than insisting on exclusiveness.

Sri Lanka is a fascinating country. The sliver of sea that saved it from becoming just another part of the South Asian landmass must be responsible for its uniqueness. In some ways it is like any other South Asian nation: political turmoil on a national level is mirrored by mayhem in its cricket board. But Sri Lanka is also a world apart from the rest of South Asia: the education system is better and health indicators are far superior to its neighbours. And, most surprisingly, Sri Lankans can field (as long as the ball avoids Arjuna and Aravinda).

In fact, that is their secret. They are more like the Australians than any other South Asian nation. Their bowlers bowl a consistently tight line, their batsmen bat with their heads rather than their hearts, and their fielding turns games. They also have a star spinner: Murali v Saqlain might as well have been a rerun of Tyson v Bruno. And they have settled on different teams for different formats with minimal fuss.

How does Sri Lanka do it? Its board is in crisis, and star players have been publicly shamed and reinstated. No different, you might say, to its more illustrious neighbours. What, or who, is the common thread between the glorious 1996 World Cup triumph and their current gallop up the Test rankings? What makes them so Australian? Look no further than their coach, Lancashire's loss but Sri Lanka's saviour, an Aussie but also a Lankan: chubby-cheeked, walrus-moustached Dav Whatmore. He predicted Sri Lanka's rise all those years ago, and now he is making it happen.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the Bulletin of the World Health Organisation. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

webTitle: Cocky Paolo, Rich Mart and Big Ron

fields.headline: Cocky Paolo, Rich Mart and Big Ron
fields.trailText: CANIO I COME BACK, PLEASE?
fields.body:
CANIO I COME BACK, PLEASE?

Here's news which should ensure Paolo Di Canio gets a warm reception when he comes off the West Ham bench to make his comeback against Southampton this evening - the diminutive Italian would rather be 400 miles north playing in tonight's Old Firm derby for Celtic. "I am so happy that Tommy Burns is back at the club because I know how important it is for him to be at Celtic," he told Pravdaesque club magazine Celtic View. "I hope that he stays on past the end of the season at Celtic and if he does maybe I will get the chance to join him."

It soon became clear that the bambino-sized striker was using the pages of Celtic View as an elaborate CV-cum-begging-letter, a move sure to enhance his popularity in one East End while diminishing it in another. "Tommy knows it is my dream to win something with him, and I hope that dream comes true soon," he continued before outlining his plans for a better Celtic. "The club should try to bring me and Peter Grant back - with his passion and my ability, Celtic would be unstoppable," suggested an in-no-way-cocky Paolo.

Having promised a return to Celtic's free-flowing style of the mid-Nineties, which saw the club win a memorable 0 championships, Di Canio hammered home his point. "If I came back now I am sure that Celtic would win the league. The team has a lot of good players and if they had Paolo Di Canio they would definitely beat Rangers." It's a clever pay-off, Paolo, but if things go well for Celtic tonight you may find it'll have lost its impact a tad.

FOLLOW, FOLLOW

Chelsea play Marseille in Big Cup tonight. Follow the game live at http://www.footballunlimited.co.uk, although we can't promise the charming asides Des Lynam will give you on ITV, of course.

ANOTHER BILLION REASONS FOR PEOPLE TO DISLIKE MAN UTD

Doesn't Mickael Silvestre look warm in his smooth fur coat? See how Nicky Butt's tiara sparkles! And how posh is that butler who is pushing Wes Brown around in his diamond-encrusted wheelchair? This wanton ostentation isn't the only evidence that there are a few pennies floating about at Old Trafford, either - news has broken that Manchester United are the first ever club to be valued at a billion pounds.

United's share price went ballistic in Inverness Caledonian Thistle style this morning when shares rose to 392p as a direct result of United's Big Cup brawl/victory against Bordeaux last night. That means the value of the plc has risen from yesterday's high of £977m to £1.018bn. No, it means nothing to us either. But it doesn't half sound good, eh?

It's quite literally a change of fortune from the late Eighties, when Michael Knighton, a moustache-sporting ball-juggling UFO spotter who was famous for 14.5 minutes, nearly bought the club for £20m. Apparently, this success has something to do with the astute stewardship by Money Mart Edwards, who has done things like floating the club on the Stock Exchange, reissuing shares, securing massive sponsorship deals and failing to flog the whole lot off to Rupert Murdoch for a tidy profit. Not that the Fiver is reluctant to give him any credit or anything.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"To believe you can easily settle in Middlesbrough, Newcastle or Blackburn when you're French, I don't believe it. There is only one reason why we are here - money." - Another blatant attempt by Frank Leboeuf to curry favour with crowds all across the country.

LITTLE TO BIG WILL NOT GO

Ron Atkinson used to be linked with every semi-vacant managerial post in the land. But now it's just the Midlands, and quicker than you could say "pop it to the big lad at the back stick", Ron has been linked early doors with Brian Little's old job at West Brom. However, football's biggest walking talking stereotype has refused to return from retirement to run the club he managed twice before: "When I left Nottingham Forest at the end of last season I said 'That's it' in terms of being a football manager, and my position hasn't changed," he said.

Perhaps West Brom could not support the man whose catastrophic salary drop after being fired by Manchester United in the Eighties left him saying: "I've had to swap my Merc for a BMW, I'm down to my last 37 suits and I'm drinking non-vintage champagne." Perhaps the £10,000-a-week for failing to rescue Forest from relegation last season dented his legendary confidence. But it is more likely to be "the old foot in a bucket of hot water syndrome," as he said during the last World Cup. With a life under the tanning warmth of TV studio lights, Ron could find the First Division's backwaters a bit of a shock to the system.

However, big-hearted Ron has not ruled out mucking in: "If someone did take over the job at Albion and wanted a bit of help I'd always be willing to give them that." Former Bolton boss Colin Todd, ex-Stoke supremo Gary Megson, Cheltenham coach Steve Cotterill and Kidderminster Harriers' Jan Molby are leading the race to join the Baggies. The latter is presumably in the running - if that's not too strong a word for it - because, like Ron, he puts the "big" back into football management.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Manchester United have joined Lazio, Internazionale and Parma in the chase for River Plate's attacking midfielder Pablo Aimar.

Arsenal are prepared to pay Parma £8m for French World Cup defender Lilian Thuram.

Leicester want Coventry's Noel Whelan, and will also gamble £5m on John Hartson, who failed a Spurs medical earlier this week. Either move could see Emile Heskey move to Liverpool.

Spurs will listen to offers for Ruel Fox and Ramon Vega.

Paul Williams is a summer target for Everton. The 28-year-old Coventry midfielder will be available on a free transfer.

Bradford have rejected a bid from Huddersfield Town for out-of-favour striker Lee Mills.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Dundee will sign Sporting Gijon's veteran centre-half Jose Jesus Mesas Puerta and 24-year-old midfielder Javier Artero in the next 24 hours.

Leicester City manager Martin O'Neill is to offer a new contract to emerging midfielder Stefan Oakes.

Ade Akinbiyi has been charged with misconduct by the FA for his actions in Wolves' recent match against Nottingham Forest 11 days ago. Akinbiyi was sent off after headbutting Tony Vaughan and then refused to leave the pitch, lashing out at his own team-mates and appearing to catch his captain Keith Curle in the face.

Hearts goalkeeper Gilles Rousset has agreed a new one-year contract with the Tynecastle club.

Norwich have joined forces with Parma in a move that will see top young players from the Canaries' football academy training with the Uefa Cup holders, with Italian youth players making reciprocal visits to Norfolk.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1 Scotland: Sportscene Match of the Day (7.30pm)

Live coverage of Dougie Donnelly's bouffant. Oh, and some Old Firm thing going on at Parkhead.

ITV: The Big Match - Live! (7.30pm)

Des Lynam airs a few not-as-good-as-they-used-to-be quips before Chelsea play Marseille.

The Big Match (11.30pm)

Gabby and Barry concentrate on some team from blah playing thingummy from wherever. Oh, and Chelsea play Marseille!

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (7pm)

Not at the top of Gabby and Barry's list.

Scottish Football (10pm, 3.15am)

Highlights of the Celtic Brits v Glasgow O'Rangers. We know all about this one.

Sky Sports 3: Premiership Classics (10pm)

Newcastle United, Manchester United, a rout, a last laugh.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

A truly enjoyable radio experience.

David Mellor (10pm)

For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.

talkSPORT: Champions League Special (7pm)

This schedule looks familiar...

Champions League Phone-in (10pm)

Hmm...

fields.headline: Verisign in $21bn takeover
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Verisign, a provider of internet security services, yesterday announced a $21bn (£13bn) takeover of Network Solutions, a company which registers internet domain names.
fields.body:
Verisign, a provider of internet security services, yesterday announced a $21bn (£13bn) takeover of Network Solutions, a company which registers internet domain names.

The agreed all-share deal underlines the increasing importance of companies which provide the plumbing for the web.

Shares in Verisign were down more than 17% yesterday after the deal was announced, while those in Network Solutions rose 13% to more than $414.

The drop in Verisign's share price, reflecting market surprise at the acquisition and the relatively high offer price, comes after the shares have quadrupled in the past six months.

Verisign shares have risen sharply since last month's hacker attacks on several of the world's largest internet companies heightened security fears. ING Barings estimates that Verisign controls 83% of the market for digital certificates, pieces of software that essentially guarantee communications over the internet.

Net Solutions enjoyed exclusive rights to registering web addresses ending in dot.com, dot.net, dot.org and dot.edu until last year. Under a deal struck with the US government, this market was opened up last year but Network Solutions continues to receive a fee from new market entrants. Its registration business, which includes an 8.1m-strong database of domain names, accounts for more than 90% of its business.

Verisign, which earned $4m on sales of $85m last year, has bought several companies which provide internet infrastructure services. Over the past year, Verisign has bought Signio, a payment processing company, and the Go Secure platform, a service for the wireless market.

The company will issue 2.15 shares for each share of Network Solutions at the end of this week. The offer price represents a 48% premium to Network Solution's pre-bid share price and the deal is expected to close in the third quarter.

webTitle: Ulster: ready to talk, but little to say

fields.headline: Ulster: ready to talk, but little to say
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown explains why today is so vital for the peace process
fields.trailText: Derek Brown explains why today is so vital for the peace process.
fields.body:
Talks which, it was hoped, would breathe new life into the stalled Northern Ireland peace process, are making little headway.

Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson convened the talks to shore up public confidence in the faltering peace deal. "It is vital we don't allow a sense of drift, a sense of malaise, to creep in."

He was joined in Belfast by Irish foreign minister Brian Cowen for a series of head-to-head sessions with each of the pro-agreement factions in the suspended Northern Ireland Assembly.

Mr Cowen spoke of the general anxiety to devise a formula for the devolved institutions to get back to work, following last month's abrupt reimposition of direct rule by Mr Mandelson.

The two ministers plan to follow their meetings with the Northern Ireland parties with a round-table discussion. But after the initial encounters, hopes of a breakthrough receded sharply.

Monica McWilliams, leader of the Women's Coalition, said after her encounter with the ministers that nothing new had emerged. "They don't seem to have an agenda. If they have, they are keeping it under the table at the moment. This is more of a listening exercise," she said.

The impasse in Northern Ireland is still centred on the bitter dispute between the Ulster Unionists and Sinn Fein over IRA disarmament. Before the suspension of the power-sharing executive last month, the Unionists were poised to walk out in protest against the lack of movement on arms 'decommissioning'. Sinn Fein insists that it cannot order the IRA to give up its weapons, and that in any case disarmament has little to do with devolution.

Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams held out little hope of any change of heart as he prepared to meet his Unionist critics at the round table talks. "I don't have any faith in round tables, square tables, rectangular tables, coffee tables or any other variation of meetings until the British government realises it caved in to unionist demands and tore down institutions and tore up the agreement," he said.

Meanwhile, President Bill Clinton's special adviser Jim Steinberg is making a two-day visit to Northern Ireland to assess the latest situation. He has been given a blunt message by the anti-agreement Democratic Unionist Party.

Deputy DUP leader Peter Robinson said he told Mr Steinberg that the Good Friday process should be abandoned. The majority of unionists did not believe "that you can build any democratic process upon the principle that representatives of unrepentent armed terrorists could be in government".

Close observers of the peace process believe that the Steinberg mission is more crucial than the latest political talks. One participant told the Irish Times: "It is about giving the appearance of movement and discussion before everybody goes to the White House next week for St Patrick's Day."

Before the suspension of the power-sharing executive last month, the Unionists were poised to walk out in protest against the lack of movement on arms 'decommissioning'. Sinn Fein insists that it cannot order the IRA to give up its weapons, and that in any case disarmament has little to do with devolution. Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams held out little hope of any change of heart as he prepared to meet his Unionist critics at the round table talks. "I don't have any faith in round tables, square tables, rectangular tables, coffee tables or any other variation of meetings until the British government realises it caved in to unionist demands and tore down institutions and tore up the agreement," he said. Meanwhile, President Bill Clinton's special adviser Jim Steinberg is making a two-day visit to Northern Ireland to assess the latest situation. He has been given a blunt message by the anti-agreement Democratic Unionist Party. Deputy DUP leader Peter Robinson said he told Mr Steinberg that the Good Friday process should be abandoned. The majority of unionists did not believe "that you can build any democratic process upon the principle that representatives of unrepentent armed terrorists could be in government". Close observers of the peace process believe that the Steinberg mission is more crucial than the latest political talks. One participant told the Irish Times: "It is about giving the appearance of movement and discussion before everybody goes to the White House next week for St Patrick's Day." fields.headline: The Footsie
fields.standfirst:
FTSE.com
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: What is it?
fields.body:
What is it?

It's the index of the top 100 shares in the United Kingdom. It was originally called the Financial Times Stock Exchange index but is now known universally by its acronym FTSE and its chummier name Footsie.

When did it start?

The index was established in 1984 taking over from the All Share index, which included some 800 shares, to meet the need of traders for a narrower marker. The index began at a nominal figure of 1000 and is monitored by FTSE International, based in Moorgate. The index is updated every 15 seconds - at 11.47am today it stood at 6452.8.

Who are the top 100?

Every three months the membership of the index is reviewed. Normally two or three companies are replaced by new entrants whose value has increased during the previous quarter. Virtually all UK companies are eligible for inclusion.

How much are the shares on the index worth altogether?

As with the index itself, the total value of the 100 companies is calculated four times a minute. Vodafone is the current number one, making up around 15% of the value of the whole index. Yesterday that stood at £1,407,551,000 or around £1.4 trillion.

Who cares about it?

It is the UK's premier share index, as well recognised internationally as the Dow Jones in the USA , Dax in Germany and Cac in France.

Why is it important?

The Footsie is the UK's barometer of corporate health. It is also a guide to how the nation is faring. If the FTSE increases it means share prices are rising and that means a lot of people are getting richer. Because many pension and trust funds invest in FTSE 100 stock, millions are affected by the variation in the index's value.

But why is the Footise so important today?

At 5.30pm today the FTSE index committee meets to decide who is in and who is out for the coming quarter. Observers believe the index is due for its biggest shake-up. As many as 10 promotions and demotions are expected.

Why the big upset?

Technology and telecommunications stocks have gone through the roof. Companies providing internet-related products are booming. Some observers believe we are seeing a second industrial revolution and those in the markets see the future hinging on hi-tech.

So who's in and who's out?

Those looking at an early exit include Imperial Tobacco, Thames Water, Scottish and Newcastle and Allies Domecq. Those coming in should include Cable and Wireless, Psion, Baltimore Technologies and Freeserve.

webTitle: Take a walk on the wild side

fields.headline: Take a walk on the wild side
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: Between spoonfuls of Fruit Corner, Billy, the youngest of my part-time children, produced a piping profundity.
fields.body:
Between spoonfuls of Fruit Corner, Billy, the youngest of my part-time children, produced a piping profundity.

"Er, Joe."

"Yes, er, Billy?"

"Do you know what?"

"What?"

"You know Andy?

"Yeah."

"Andy hasn't got a dad."

He was talking, of course, about the little boy in the Toy Story films, the owner of Woody and Buzz. And he was absolutely right: so far as anyone can tell, Andy only has a mum. She's an insubstantial character: in Toy Story 2 she has few lines of dialogue and only one significant scene, while in the original movie I can't recall even seeing her face. But at least it is clear she exists. By contrast, Andy's co-progenitor is a mystery, an enigma, literally an unseen man.

Who is he? A hopeless workaholic who never gets home before dark? A shameless love rat, deservedly divorced? One of those rumoured internet sperm spivs who broody women pick from websites to provide vials of reproductive fluid for a fee? (OK, Andy was conceived before cyberspace got that weird but, hey, relish the thought).

Whatever, Billy's insight immediately struck me as an opportunity to seize the moral high ground. It's a manoeuvre I have rehearsed many times. When I'm being a sad bastard I construct mental conversations with Billy and his big siblings in which I demonstrate that I'm the most devoted daddy in the world, that their lovestruck mother Dilys does not deserve to share them, and that their pseudo-stepdad Chris The Pillock is a posturing parvenu. Oh, the poignancy of their questions in these delicious reveries! Oh, the aching melodrama of my replies!

"But how could our mum leave us? And leave you, too, all on your own?"

"Only she can tell you that, my angels. But suffering has made us strong."

Beat that, Albert Square.

Alas, reality is rarely quite so tidy. "You're quite right, Billy," I began. "Andy doesn't seem to have a dad. I wonder why that is?"

"He dumped them, I expect," growled Gloria, tossing her magenta mane. "Couldn't cope with commitment."

Jed said nothing, as usual. But he whispered something to Billy, and Billy instantly announced: "He's probably just dead!"

Shrugging off this glib dismissal of paternal bereavement, I soldiered on: "Well, Gloria, maybe it was the mum who did the dumping. But I suppose the people who made Toy Story thought if Andy was only going to have one parent it would have to be his mum. After all, lone dads are exceptional. You don't get very many."

I let that one sink in. Then . . .

"Yes you do," said Billy, firmly.

"Oh really. Like who?"

"Like in Pocahontas. She's only got a dad."

"Alright, then," I countered, "What about Dumbo? That's just him and Mrs Jumbo against a cruel, uncaring world. Not a dad in sight."

But Billy was listening to Jed whispering again: "And the Little Mermaid!" Billy almost shouted. "She's only got a dad, too!"

"She doesn't count," I blustered. "She's a vain, silly sea creature who wants to marry into a family of sea creature-eaters. She's a bimbo and a collaborator. Isn't she Gloria?"

But this appeal to my big daughter's suffragette streak was doomed: "There's only a dad in Beauty and the Beast," she said. "Thing is, he's a bit mad!"

Amid peals of laughter, my strategy capsized.

"There's only a dad in The Swan Princess," Billy squeaked, now drunk on triumph.

"And in A Goofy Movie," drawled Gloria from across the table, delivering the coup de grace.

I looked across at Angie, cradling baby Estelle. She gave me a concerned but chiding smile that said: well, if you will go fishing for compliments . . . A Goofy Movie! Not just an animated story that only has a dad, but a story of the most embarrassing dad ever.

"Can't you think of a Disney dad who's not a laughing stock?" I implored.

"How about the Lion King?" suggested Angie, rushing to my aid. "He's a really nice dad."

"Yeah, Mufasa!" Billy enthused. "Big an' bad out there in the jungle. Chris really likes him."

Mention of jungles suddenly prompted me to take a walk to the end of the garden. There among the weeds and rubble my thoughts turned inexorably to our old friend Bambi. Remember his dad? A distant patriarch who just stomped round the forest, barking the odd command? He had the right idea.

fields.headline: Words of wisdom
fields.standfirst: Careless talk could cost IQ points.  Rebecca Smithers  meets a speech therapist who says she can make your child cleverer
fields.trailText: For most parents, talking to their children comes naturally - we may try to curb the excesses of our baby talk when in company, but left alone with our babies we goo and gaa with the best of them. As the child gets older, our chit-chat matures, too - but are we saying what our children need to hear?
fields.body:
For most parents, talking to their children comes naturally - we may try to curb the excesses of our baby talk when in company, but left alone with our babies we goo and gaa with the best of them. As the child gets older, our chit-chat matures, too - but are we saying what our children need to hear?

According to speech therapist Dr Sally Ward, whose book Babytalk is published this week, a more structured approach to talking to children - a "programme", no less - can have a dramatic effect not only on the child's language development but also on his or her IQ. Ward argues that because children acquire all language skills in their first four years, the right stimulus at this critical stage can speed up a child's linguistic development - and with it, their cognitive skills.

At the heart of the programme, which is based on 20 years of research into the acquisition of language, is what appears to be a simple requirement: that parents spend half an hour a day in a quiet environment (no music, no hoovering, and definitely no television) playing with their child.

Surely, even with the pressures of work, this is something most parents do anyway? "In my experience it isn't, for all sorts of reasons," says Ward. "At one end of the scale you have youngsters stuck in front of the TV. At the other, you have toddlers being whisked around by nannies to Tumble Tots, baby gyms and music classes. Parents and carers often forget the importance of one-to-one contact.

"Parents do not need to feel guilty about going out to work, and they don't need to spend huge amounts of time with their children at this stage. If you're following the programme, 30 minutes a day is fine."

The book is divided into age bands from birth to four. Ward offers a detailed account of expected communication, speech and language development for each age group, and advice on making the most out of playtime.

In her clinical and research work Ward has observed that it is often well-meaning parents who cause problems, often because of their own unrealistic expectations. "Parents are tremendously keen to do the right thing, but they sometimes don't know what they should be doing."

The most common mistakes are speaking too fast, using complicated sentences, and an overenthusiastic attitude towards correcting their childrens' speech. Perfectionist grandparents, overworked childminders and nannies with a poor command of English are also fingered. Ward cites the case of a little boy who was looked after by 16 different foreign nannies in his first two years. His speech suffered, but he made a rapid recovery under the Babytalk programme.

Despite the promise of "stress-free fun for parent and child", there is a long list of don'ts, the most important of which is that parents should not ask their baby to say or copy words or sounds. "There is no need," Ward explains. "Our job is to talk to him in the most appropriate way. If we do this, he will look after the talking."

She is also particularly firm about not correcting speech, as this will send the wrong signals, making them self-conscious and less likely to try out new words. She also urges parents to resist the temptation to tick children off with negative speech such as "Don't do that", "Get down now!", "Stop it at once" in favour of physical restraint.

There are strict rules across all age groups: no television at all for very young babies; no more than half an hour a day for older children. She is quite firm about allowing toddlers to use baby words such as "tummy" and "gee-gee" rather the adult forms, which she says they will soon pick up.

Parents hoping this book will help their child clear the first hurdle in New Labour's regime of virtually continual testing throughout their school career will be disappointed. "This is an 'enabling' rather than a teaching or a testing tool," Ward insists. "The idea is to help parents give their children the best possible foundation for their future learning."

The babytalk programme

* Birth to three months: spend half an hour a day, from day one, talking to her. Use short, simple sentences that are tuneful, such as "Up you come" or "You're on my knee". Speak slowly, with pauses between each phrase. Use lots of repetition.

*Six to nine months: she will continue to enjoy repetitive, simple interactive language games. Play "Clap hands" and "Peekaboo" using the same words and actions each time, always with a lively facial expression. Repeat her sounds back to her, and say for her what she means, but never ask her to copy sounds or words. Make play sounds to go with what is happening, such as "brm brm"as you push a toy car.

*Twelve to 16 months: help her to enjoy listening, through "noise" books and noisy toys. Use short, simple (but grammatical) sentences. Speak slower and louder than normal, with a singsong voice. Point to objects when you name them. Your baby will be more mobile, but keep language positive. Distract him physically rather than saying "No" or "Don't touch".

*Sixteen months to two years: bring in new words, but keep to a "running commentary" on what she's doing. As her language improves, don't let your sentences get too long. Always start your replies with a "yes".

For Babytalk workshops, ring 0870-7407007. Babytalk is published by Century at £12.99. To order a copy for £10.99, plus 99p UK p&p, phone Guardian CultureShop: 0800 316 6102.

fields.headline: Phoebe's choice
fields.standfirst:
Dad favours the local comp; Mum prefers a top-flight school miles away. Marina Cantacuzino on how the great schools debate split her family

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Dad favours the local comp; Mum prefers a top-flight school miles away. Marina Cantacuzino on how the great schools debate split her family
fields.body:
It should have been a day to celebrate. My 10-year-old daughter Phoebe opened up the letter from the St Marylebone school, and there it was: the announcement that she was one of the lucky 120 applicants (out of a total of 723) to be offered a place there this autumn. But there was no celebrating; instead, all hell broke loose.

St Marylebone is a multi-faith, single-sex state school. It is top of the Westminster league tables and the most improved state school in the country at GCSE level. Little wonder that most parents - me included - are desperate to send their children there. But not my husband, Dan. He felt passionately that she should go to Queens Park community school, where Phoebe had also been offered a place. QPCS is a mixed comprehensive somewhere near the bottom of the Brent league tables, but rising fast. It has suffered over the years from too many middle-class parents (like us) moving their children out of the area to other more popular state schools. Now at last, after a massive rebuilding programme and a slow but steady improvement in results, the school is gaining popularity.

For a week Dan and I waged a fierce but civilised war, made all the more complicated by the fact that each of us saw merits in the other school. My argument was that Phoebe, an industrious, intelligent girl, needed the stimulation of a more academic school and would benefit from being in an all-girl environment. His argument was that she would do equally well at QPCS, while benefiting from a more dynamic and exciting environment. He also felt single-sex schooling was a disadvantage socially if not academically and he couldn't understand why I wanted to subject a child to two journeys a day in a crowded tube when the alternative was a short walk across a park.

When the deputy chief whip, Keith Bradley, announced at the weekend that he was taking his son out of the local comprehensive and sending him to the fee-paying Manchester grammar, he was condemned from all sides. But at least there seems to have been a semblance of family unity within the Bradley household. Not so for us.

For the first time in our long and harmonious marriage we found ourselves at a deadlock. We tried desperately to remain reasonable but for a week the subject was discussed, mauled, massacred and cried over until we both realised we would never agree. At this point we had no choice but to put the ball firmly back into Phoebe's hands, giving her a week to make up her mind, and making a pact with each other not to influence her.

While Phoebe had been thrilled to be accepted by Marylebone and was initially convinced that it was the school for her, it then transpired that her two best friends were going to QPCS. Suddenly the local school seemed overwhelmingly attractive. Furthermore, reading the long list of rules from St Marylebone made the trek by tube to Baker Street seem even more daunting.

As a parent it's a weird sensation to find yourself suddenly bereft of advice for your child when there's so much you want to say but, out of loyalty and fairness to your partner, so little you feel you can. I spoke to a fellow parent who told me categorically, "You simply can't leave such an important decision up to Phoebe. You two have to come to some kind of agreement and help her out." But the trouble was we couldn't reach an agreement as neither of us were prepared to back down from something that went to the core of our beliefs.

No doubt our own schooling came into play here. I went to a small independent girls' school in London ("rarefied and insular", Dan calls it); Dan want to a large boys' comprehensive in King's Cross ("rough and tough", I call it. Although Marylebone is neither rarefied nor insular and QPCS has left its rough, tough reputation behind it, nevertheless our very different educational backgrounds inform our views.

When I was telling all this to a close friend, her French husband left the room. "All you English people ever do is talk about schools," he said. But the English education system is so fragmented, so selective and so open to abuse that there are no simple choices to be made. Talking about it - even if you do end up going round in circles - is the only option we have.

For a week Dan and I sat on our hopes and fears. Finally Phoebe made her choice. It was, she said, to be Marylebone, "because I think the school would suit me better". While I was quietly thrilled, Dan was disappointed. He knows that Phoebe will do well at St Marylebone and will be happy there. But he has a passion for change and a strong presence in our community; for him, not sending his daughter to the local school felt like a betrayal of that community.

In the end, however, we both had to accept that this wasn't about our needs. It was Phoebe's choice. It had to be.
