His argument was that she would do equally well at QPCS, while benefiting from a more dynamic and exciting environment. He also felt single-sex schooling was a disadvantage socially if not academically and he couldn't understand why I wanted to subject a child to two journeys a day in a crowded tube when the alternative was a short walk across a park. When the deputy chief whip, Keith Bradley, announced at the weekend that he was taking his son out of the local comprehensive and sending him to the fee-paying Manchester grammar, he was condemned from all sides. But at least there seems to have been a semblance of family unity within the Bradley household. Not so for us. For the first time in our long and harmonious marriage we found ourselves at a deadlock. We tried desperately to remain reasonable but for a week the subject was discussed, mauled, massacred and cried over until we both realised we would never agree. At this point we had no choice but to put the ball firmly back into Phoebe's hands, giving her a week to make up her mind, and making a pact with each other not to influence her. While Phoebe had been thrilled to be accepted by Marylebone and was initially convinced that it was the school for her, it then transpired that her two best friends were going to QPCS. Suddenly the local school seemed overwhelmingly attractive. Furthermore, reading the long list of rules from St Marylebone made the trek by tube to Baker Street seem even more daunting. As a parent it's a weird sensation to find yourself suddenly bereft of advice for your child when there's so much you want to say but, out of loyalty and fairness to your partner, so little you feel you can. I spoke to a fellow parent who told me categorically, "You simply can't leave such an important decision up to Phoebe. You two have to come to some kind of agreement and help her out." But the trouble was we couldn't reach an agreement as neither of us were prepared to back down from something that went to the core of our beliefs. No doubt our own schooling came into play here. I went to a small independent girls' school in London ("rarefied and insular", Dan calls it); Dan want to a large boys' comprehensive in King's Cross ("rough and tough", I call it. Although Marylebone is neither rarefied nor insular and QPCS has left its rough, tough reputation behind it, nevertheless our very different educational backgrounds inform our views. When I was telling all this to a close friend, her French husband left the room. "All you English people ever do is talk about schools," he said. But the English education system is so fragmented, so selective and so open to abuse that there are no simple choices to be made. Talking about it - even if you do end up going round in circles - is the only option we have. For a week Dan and I sat on our hopes and fears. Finally Phoebe made her choice. It was, she said, to be Marylebone, "because I think the school would suit me better". While I was quietly thrilled, Dan was disappointed. He knows that Phoebe will do well at St Marylebone and will be happy there. But he has a passion for change and a strong presence in our community; for him, not sending his daughter to the local school felt like a betrayal of that community. In the end, however, we both had to accept that this wasn't about our needs. It was Phoebe's choice. It had to be.

fields.headline: Chains of love
fields.standfirst: A Beverly Hills family pays their Filipino nanny $400 a week. She, in turn, pays her nanny $40 a week to look after the children she's left behind. The celebrated US thinker  Arlie Russell Hochschild counts the true cost of childcare
fields.trailText: Vicky Diaz is a 34-year-old mother of five. A former teacher in the Philippines, she migrated to the United States to work as a housekeeper and nanny to the two-year-old son of a wealthy family in Beverly Hills, Los Angeles.
fields.body:
Vicky Diaz is a 34-year-old mother of five. A former teacher in the Philippines, she migrated to the United States to work as a housekeeper and nanny to the two-year-old son of a wealthy family in Beverly Hills, Los Angeles.

"Even now, my children are trying to convince me to go home," she says. "They weren't angry when I left because they were still very young. My husband couldn't get angry either because he knew this was the only way I could help him raise our children. I send them money every month."

The Beverly Hills family pays Vicky $400 a week; Vicky pays her own family's live-in domestic worker back in the Philippines $40 a week. But living in this "global care chain" is not easy on Vicky and her family. "I'm paid well, but I'm sinking in work. Even while I am ironing the clothes, they can still call you to the kitchen to wash the plates. It is also very depressing. Away from my children, the only thing I can do is give all my love to Tommy [the two-year-old American child]."

Paradoxically, Vicky got her job by telling her prospective employer she had experience raising children. "They asked me if I knew how to take care of a child and I told them I did because I had five of my own."

Global capitalism affects whatever it touches, and it touches everything. Global care chains are usually made up of women. Most start in a poor country and end in a rich one. The chain Vicky Diaz finds herself in is an increasingly common one: (1) an older daughter from a poor family cares for her siblings while (2) her mother works as a nanny caring for the children of a migrating nanny who (3) cares for the child of a family in a rich country.

However long the care chain is, everyone in it tends to focus on the link closest to them. From time to time, Vicky may feel keenly the link between her love for the children she is paid to care for and love of her own children, whom she pays another to nurture. But her American employers are more likely to see this love as natural, individual, uncircumscribed by context. "Vicky is a loving person," they might say. "Vicky loves Tommy."

But can love be "displaced" from Vicky Diaz's son Alfredo, in the Philippines, on to Tommy, the son of her employers in Los Angeles? And should we worry that the direction of displacement is upwards in privilege and power? Are first-world countries importing maternal love as they have imported copper, zinc and gold from third-world countries in the past? Love is not simply a "resource" that can be taken from one person and given to another, but nor is it entirely unlike a resource. Is time spent with the first-world child "taken from" a child further down the care chain? Is the Beverly Hills toddler getting "surplus" love just as the mine owner gets surplus value from the worker digging for gold?

The idea is unwelcome, both to Vicky Diaz, who wants a first-world job, and to her well-meaning employers who need someone to give loving care to their child. Each person along the chain feels he or she is doing the right thing for good reasons. But transfer of care takes its toll both on the child left behind and on the mother. "When I saw my children," said one Filipino nanny, weeping, "I thought, 'Oh, children do grow up even without their mother.' I left my youngest when she was only five. She was nine when I saw her again but she still wanted me to carry her. That hurt me because it showed me that my children missed out a lot."

Sometimes the toll it takes is overwhelming. As one Filipino nanny said: "The first two years I felt I was going crazy. I would catch myself thinking about my baby. Every moment, every second of the day. When I receive a letter from my children, I cannot sleep. I cry."

Given the depth of this unhappiness, one might imagine care chains are a minimal part of the global show. But this is not the case. Since the early 50s, for example, 55% of migrants from the Philippines have been women and, next to electronic manufacturing, their remittances make up the country's major source of foreign currency. Recent improvements in the economy have not reduced female emigration; rather, it continues to increase. In addition, migrants are not drawn from the poorest classes. In one study of migrant Filipino domestic workers, over half the nannies were graduates and most were married mothers in their 30s.

Money provides a powerful incentive to work and the yawning global wage gap provides a powerful incentive to move. Migration is, simply, a ticket to a better life.

Just as global capitalism helps create a third-world supply of mothering, so it creates a first-world demand for it. At the first-world end, there has been a huge rise in the number of women in paid work -from 15% of mothers of children aged six and under in 1950 to 65% today. Indeed, American women now make up 45% of the US labour force; 75% of mothers of children aged 18 and under now work, as do 65% of mothers of children aged six and under.

In addition, working hours have been rising and a lot of American grandmothers, who might otherwise have looked after a worker's children, now do paid work themselves. Thus, at the first-world end of care chains, we find working parents who are grateful to find a good nanny and able to pay more than the nanny could earn in her native country.

First-world women who hire nannies are themselves caught in a male career pattern that has proved surprisingly resistant to change. Women have joined the law, academia, medicine, business - professions still organised for men with families who are free of family responsibilities. Today, men take on much more of the childcare and housework, but they still base their identity on demanding careers. Hence the resistance to sharing care at home and the search for care further "down" the global chain.

Among these first-world mothers are those who give their emotional labour, in turn, to companies that hold themselves out as a "family". Researching a leading multinational company I call Amerco, I discovered a disproportionate number of women employed in the human side: public relations, marketing, human resources. It was often the "soft touch" of women that made Amerco seem like a family to other workers. Among the ultimate beneficiaries of various care chains we thus find multinational companies.

Given the existence of this global care chain, and given the chain's growing scope, it is worth asking how we are to respond. I can think of three ways to see care chains: through the eyes of the primordialist, the sunshine modernist, and the critical modernist. To the primordialist, the right thing would be for each of us to take care of only our own family, in our own nation. To such a person, the existence of care chains seems wrong. Because such care is usually done by women, primordialists often also believe that women should stay at home to provide this care.

But for the sunshine modernist, care chains are an inevitable part of globalisation, which is itself uncritically accepted as good. If a supply of labour meets demand, the sunshine modernist is satisfied - the issue of inequality of access to care disappears.

The critical modernist has a global sense of ethics. If she goes out to buy Nike shoes, she is concerned to learn how low the wage and how long the hours were for the third-world factory worker making them. She applies the same moral concern to care. So she cares about the welfare of the Filipino child back home, and sees globalisation as a very mixed blessing. It brings new opportunities - and the nanny's access to good wages is one - but also new problems, including costs we have hardly begun to understand. Though it is not always the case, the poor maid's child may be getting less motherly care than the first-world child. We needn't lapse into primordialism to sense that something may be amiss and to search for solutions.

One approach is to try to reduce incentives to migrate by addressing the causes of the migrant's economic desperation. Another would be to raise the value of caring work, such that whoever did it got more credit as well as money for it, and care wasn't such a "pass on" job. The value of the labour of raising a child - always low relative to the value of other kinds of labour - has, under the impact of globalisation, sunk lower still. The declining value of childcare can be compared with the declining value of basic food crops relative to manufactured goods on the international market. Though clearly more necessary to life, crops such as wheat, rice or cocoa fetch low and declining prices, while those of manufactured goods continue to soar.

Just as the market price of primary produce keeps the third world low in the community of nations, so the low market value of care keeps the status of the women who do it - and, by association, all women - low. A final basic solution would be to involve fathers in caring for their children. If fathers shared care, it would spread laterally instead of being passed down a social class ladder.

According to the International Labour Organisation, half of the world's women between 15 and 64 are in paid work. Since 1950, the rate of increase has skyrocketed in the US and has been high in Scandinavia and the UK. If we want developed societies, with women doctors, political leaders, teachers and computer programmers, we will need qualified people to help care for their children. And there is no reason why every society should not enjoy such loving paid childcare.

It may even be true that Vicky Diaz is the person to provide it. At the same time, critical modernists would be wise to extend their concern to the possible hidden losers in the care chain. For these days, the personal is global.

This is an extract from an essay which appears in On the Edge: Living with Global Capitalism, edited by Will Hutton and Anthony Giddens, published by Jonathan Cape on March 9, price£16.99. fields.headline: Battle of two dynasties
fields.standfirst: Mark Tran, the Guardian's former US correspondent, analyses the political pedigrees of Bush and Gore
fields.trailText: The prospective battle for the White House between Vice-President Al Gore and Republican governor George W Bush pits two of America's political dynasties against each other. This year's contest is very much a race between two establishment candidates, unlike the triumph eight years ago of the insurgent Bill Clinton against the Washington insider, George W Bush's dad.
fields.body:
The prospective battle for the White House between Vice-President Al Gore and Republican governor George W Bush pits two of America's political dynasties against each other. This year's contest is very much a race between two establishment candidates, unlike the triumph eight years ago of the insurgent Bill Clinton against the Washington insider, George W Bush's dad.

Bush Jr, the governor of Texas, has benefited mightily from his father's connections. All through his adult life, business interests have cosied up to George W, coming through for him when things looked bleak. In the process, Mr Bush has become a very rich man.

His small and obscure oil company, Harken, won a totally unexpected contract in Bahrain. Harken's share price rocketed and Mr Bush showed exquisite timing by selling his stake just before it plummeted. Again thanks to his family connections, Mr Bush's small share in the Texas Rangers baseball team ballooned into a £15m fortune.

But is America ready for another Bush in the White House? Bush Sr was one of America's most lacklustre leaders. True, he led the west to victory in the Gulf war, but that victory looks much tarnished 10 years on, with Saddam Hussein still entrenched in power and the Iraqi population ground down by sanctions.

Despite sky-high ratings after the Gulf war, Mr Bush still succumbed to the upstart from Arkansas and George W shares some of his father's political shortcomings: the inability to inspire confidence in others or to think on his feet, and the tendency to abuse the English language.

History is full of examples of unhappy restoration regimes, for in many ways this is what the George W Bush campaign is about. As the US political commentator Kevin Phillips has pointed out, restoration regimes contain an element of farce - Charles II in England in 1660 and Louis XVIII in France in 1815. George W has already been described as cocky, lazy, arrogant and intellectually undistinguished. His mother once made him sit at the opposite end of the table from the Queen for fear of what he might say. He was 44 at the time.

Al Gore's father never made it to the White House, but he was a distinguished senator of Tennessee. Albert Gore senior was a champion of civil rights and an outspoken opponent of the Vietnam war.

Like George W, Gore junior has exposed himself to ridicule more than once. He once claimed to have been the model for the male lead in Love Story and to have invented the internet. But his credentials are solid: a well-received book on the environment, acknowledged expertise on defence and - most likely - a safe pair of hands in the White House.

If experience counted for anything, Mr Gore would win comfortably. Like George W, Mr Gore is hardly inspirational, but American voters would probably welcome a president with less artifice and character than Slick Willy Clinton. The latest polls show Mr Gore and Mr Bush neck and neck, with the independents who rallied to Republican senator John McCain up for grabs.

The US electorate has a choice between two dynasties. It would be quite remarkable for Americans to vote for George W only eight years after they booted his father out of Washington. But when polling day comes, they may well remember that the last Bush experience was hardly inspiring.

fields.headline: Sweet success
fields.standfirst: Sophi Tranchell on the new mark of  respect for chocolates made from  Ghanaian cocoa
fields.trailText: Sophi Tranchell on the new mark of respect for chocolates made from Ghanaian cocoa.
fields.body:
Down the scratchy telephone line from Kumasi, in Ghana, Mr Ohemeng declared gallantly: "From all the cocoa farmers of Kuapa Kokoo cooperative, we wish you all a most happy Valentine's Day. And please do not worry, we will have no problem to find Mr Appiah in Brixton for you and send him straight to your office."

Losing Mr Appiah, our board representative of the cocoa producers who own a third of The Day Chocolate Company, which makes fairly traded Divine chocolate, was clearly not going to faze the managing director of Kuapa Kokoo, even from 5,000 miles away. Mr Appiah was promptly located, somewhere south of the Thames, with pinpoint accuracy by group email from Ghana.

Together we ponder the question of how to make stumping up more dosh for your bar of chocolate, cup of coffee or non-exploitative banana an attractive choice to the nation's shoppers. Hmmm. At least fair trade products taste a lot more yummy now than the horrible 1980s stuff that only truly virtuous people actually bought and ate.

We decide to focus on how buying fairly traded goods transforms the usual impersonal supermarket dash - where both consumer and farmer are exploited by big business - into a dignified, personal link between real people that one can be proud of. Then straight out of the meeting to present Divine to Safeway - will they stock us, won't they stock us? Divine hit supermarket shelves within weeks of being launched into a ferociously competitive UK confectionery market, and some of the big stores have been incredibly helpful, but it's a scary world of powerful supermarket buyers and billionaire multinationals out there. Never again will I approach the purchase of a simple sweetie with the carefree insouciance of the past.

Fly out at some awful hour of the morning to visit our chocolate factory in Germany. My daughter Dulcie insists that I bring back lots of samples, and declares that next time she is definitely coming too. We have a big order to sort out for the Co-op. It's the first supermarket to pioneer own-brand fair trade products, and our little chunky bar launches their range in Fairtrade Fortnight. At the factory, Mr Chocolate turns out to be the delightful, and unsurprisingly stout, Herr Budde, whose family has been in the business for over 100 years. Inside, the air - scented with the heavy sweetness of caramel and rich, liquid chocolate - engulfs us warmly as we pass by huge vats which burp and gurgle. Then we get on to the serious work of chocolate tastings.

Then we do some more. It's not a bad job really. The factory is very pleased with the Co-op order, so are the cocoa farmers, and, on my return with a sackful of chocolate samples, so is Dulcie. Six months into this job, I now have dreams involving small chocolate novelty items and the intricacies of the sterling-deutschmark exchange rate. This is worrying my husband, a sensible man who likes pianos and boats.

The samples accompany me to Comic Relief, as fuel for the team who are looking over 10,000 wrapper designs sent in by children for the Chocolate Challenge competition - part of the run-up to developing a fair trade chocolate treat aimed specifically at giving young people the chance to make their own ethical spending decisions. Big companies sink squillions into brand image consultancies - but looking through the piles of multicoloured pictures sent by kids who love chocolate is definitely more fun.

The goodwill from people involved in making this chocolate bar work is always touching, and is what makes fair trade a very personal way of doing business. Our adverts on Channel 4, featuring Ben Elton, were only possible because he waived a fee; we couldn't buy Kuapa's cocoa beans if Jessica at the department for international development hadn't worked ridiculously hard to get The Day its business guarantee; and our signature image of Divine held by a little boy from a cocoa farming family was taken by Toby, who travelled out to Ghana in the sweltering heat and let us use his photographs for nothing.

Fairly traded products, including chocolate, tea, coffee, honey and bananas, are available during Fairtrade Fortnight (ending on March 19) and throughout the year in most supermarkets and some independent retailers. fields.bodyText: Down the scratchy telephone line from Kumasi, in Ghana, Mr Ohemeng declared gallantly: "From all the cocoa farmers of Kuapa Kokoo cooperative, we wish you all a most happy Valentine's Day. And please do not worry, we will have no problem to find Mr Appiah in Brixton for you and send him straight to your office." Losing Mr Appiah, our board representative of the cocoa producers who own a third of The Day Chocolate Company, which makes fairly traded Divine chocolate, was clearly not going to faze the managing director of Kuapa Kokoo, even from 5,000 miles away. Mr Appiah was promptly located, somewhere south of the Thames, with pinpoint accuracy by group email from Ghana. Together we ponder the question of how to make stumping up more dosh for your bar of chocolate, cup of coffee or non-exploitative banana an attractive choice to the nation's shoppers. Hmmm. At least fair trade products taste a lot more yummy now than the horrible 1980s stuff that only truly virtuous people actually bought and ate. We decide to focus on how buying fairly traded goods transforms the usual impersonal supermarket dash - where both consumer and farmer are exploited by big business - into a dignified, personal link between real people that one can be proud of. fields.headline: Trading in futures
fields.standfirst: Moving to a low carbon  economy makes good  business sense, too. Chris  Hewett explains why the  government must grasp the  chance to ensure the  polluter pays
fields.trailText: Moving to a low carbon economy makes good business sense, too. Chris Hewett explains why the government must grasp the chance to ensure the polluter pays.
fields.body:
As the recent floods in Mozambique have demonstrated so graphically, climate change is set to become a major feature of 21st century life and politics. Tony Blair, speaking at a business seminar in Downing Street last week, said: "Climate change is not going to go away. If we don't tackle it, we risk leaving a terrible environmental legacy. And if business does not seize its chance, it risks being left behind in the race for low carbon technologies."

The UK is one of the leading advocates of action to reduce greenhouse gases and head off the worst consequences of climate change. This week, John Prescott will publish the government's long awaited strategy to cut UK emissions. It will emphasise the economic opportunities of moving to a low carbon economy, but it requires government action to persuade most businesses to take the opportunities seriously.

In two weeks' time, the chancellor, Gordon Brown will make the final touches to the climate change levy, which created fury in business circles last year. But he rode the storm, made some sensible changes, and business is now rapidly coming up with its own initiatives on climate change.

One group of trade associations - including the chemicals, cement and metals industries - has started to negotiate legally binding agreements to achieve improvements in their energy efficiency. In return, the government will give them an 80% reduction in climate change levy. This is welcome, but is only the first step towards recognising the challenge of climate change. The agreements are proving slow, bureaucratic and secretive - and they will not guarantee absolute reductions in emissions if output increases.

Another group of companies, including BP Amoco, Blue Circle and British Steel, is offering something far more significant: to collectively sign up to an absolute cap on their carbon emissions between now and 2010. Once that cap has been set, each company would be allocated permits to emit a proportion of the total emissions and a market could be set up in those permits. The total number of permits available, and therefore emissions, would be controlled by government, but the companies would then be allowed to buy, sell or bank the permits throughout the period. This idea has been successful in the US for controlling sulphur emissions, but no country has introduced a carbon emissions trading scheme.

So, for example, company A is allocated permits to emit 30 tonnes of carbon in 2001 and company B is allocated 50 tonnes. Company A wants to expand, but, even with the most efficient technology, it will still need to emit 33 tonnes in 2002. At the same time, company B has made a cost effective efficiency investment which reduces its emissions to 45 tonnes. With permit trading, company B could sell permits for 3 tonnes to company A, allowing both companies to meet their obligations while actually reducing overall emissions from 80 tonnes to 78.

S o all initiatives to cut emissions would be rewarded by the ability to sell unwanted permits, but if a company wanted to produce more emissions then it could buy extra permits to cover them.

Emissions trading is potentially a very powerful policy instrument, and both business and government are committed to the principle. If major companies are willing to pledge absolute cuts in their carbon emissions, then the debate over climate change would take a major step forward.

However, to make it happen two decisions have to be made. First, what carbon emissions reductions should the system deliver? Second, what incentives should government offer companies who sign up?

Emissions trading is only a desirable environmental policy if the carbon cap is ambitious and will deliver greater reductions than would have otherwise occurred.

Based on the analysis of cost effective options from the energy technology support unit (Etsu) and the experience of other trading schemes, a reduction of CO 2 emissions of 20% by 2010 would be reasonable. It is also a target of political significance, being the government's own manifesto pledge for CO 2 emissions.

Signing up to such a reduction would be a risk for many companies and government should recognise that by creating incentives for those who take part in emissions trading. The chancellor has an ideal opportunity in the forthcoming budget. He should offer a climate change levy exemption, cutting energy bills by up to 10%, for all companies that join an emissions trading scheme on the basis of a 20% CO 2 reduction by 2010.

An emissions trading scheme could be set up as early as April 2001, to coincide with the start of the climate change levy. An initial free permit allocation could be made for 2001, with allocations for subsequent years decreasing annually until the 2010 allocation was 80% of the one for 2001. (After 2010, permits should be allocated by auction, in line with the "polluter pays" principle.)

Any new business which will emit CO2 should then either join the emissions trading scheme, by purchasing permits, or pay the climate change levy.

While cutting carbon emissions is seen in terms of costs to the economy, climate change will never be tackled. Emissions trading is a way of demonstrating John Prescott's "gain not pain" approach. Government and business should embrace it.

 Chris Hewett is a research fellow at the Institute for Public Policy Research. The IPPR's budget submission on emissions trading and the climate change levy is available from IPPR free of charge (tel: 0207 470 6125; email: j.foley@ippr.org.uk.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
I 've become addicted to the "amateur" book reviews which currently clutter a number of websites. It's the contrast that appeals. After years of reading professional critics whose principal task is to persuade us of their ability to comprehend and even transcend that which they read, it's refreshing to encounter critics who happily admit to an inability to grasp the full meaning of their latest purchase from Amazon or Barnes and Noble.

Bruno Latour may have secured himself an international reputation with his case studies of working scientists and his philosophical determination to erase the current divide between nature and society. But web readers are not always too impressed. Joyce Walker, of Illinois, happily announces that she has "no idea what this man is talking about", and Nicholas F Daum candidly wonders whether Latour is "practising the French intellectual's habit of making our heads spin for the sheer thrill of watching the confusion".

What makes such comments particularly interesting is that they are prompted by a writer who is often not only a model of lucidity but almost pedantic in his descriptions of the manner in which scientists go about their business. In his most recent book, Pandora's Hope: Essays On The Reality Of Science Studies, there is, for example, a chapter entitled Circulating Reference which almost laboriously describes every single step taken by scientists as they gradually transform the concrete reality of soil samples from the Amazonian Boa Vista forest into diagrams and graphs and scientific papers. Only by tracing each of these transformations can he produce a narrative that once again unites the worlds of nature and society.

This suggests that it is not so much Latour's style which worries his readers as his project. We have become accustomed to social theorists who believe in the "solidity of the hard sciences" and the relative autonomy of the scientific world. Latour resists this "closure" and positively relishes current debates about global warming and GM foods in which alternative scientific accounts compete for the attention of politicians and the general public. Does he ever find himself taking sides in such debates? Where, as a Frenchman, does he stand on the issue of British beef? He ducks the question with aplomb. "I'm an Anglophile," he says quietly.

 Laurie Taylor talks to Bruno Latour about nature and society on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4 pm today.

fields.headline: Persistent pest
fields.standfirst: Stephen Jenkins introduces research  which quantifies the chronic nature of  being poor
fields.trailText: Stephen Jenkins introduces research which quantifies the chronic nature of being poor.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has described it as a "scar on the soul of Britain". And no wonder there is grave concern over the increase in child poverty when currently one in three lives in a poor household.

To date, policymakers have been forced to wage war against child poverty using information about who is poor at a point in time. The children who are currently poor may include someone whose dad is newly unemployed who has fallen on hard times for a few months but will shortly bounce back with a well-paid job, to a child in a lone-parent family who has been poor since birth.

Policy design needs to recognise the persistence of poverty. The longer a child is poor, the greater the deprivation entailed. Moreover, poverty during childhood has long-term effects, reducing the chances of being successful in adult life.

New research from the Institute for Social and Economic Research at the University of Essex reveals the extent to which children and adults were in poverty year-in year-out or poor for relatively brief periods from 1991-1996. The research, co-sponsored by Unicef, and based on the British Household Panel Survey, sheds light on low-income persistence and highlights the poverty risks faced by children relative to adults. The analysis shows that young children have a disproportionately high risk of experiencing repeated poverty.

D uring 1991-1996, more than one in five pre-school children lived in households where the income was below the poverty line for at least half of this period, compared to just one in 10 people in the population as a whole. The poverty line used was half the middle (median) income in 1991, which in today's prices would be £180 per week for a couple with two kids, ie close to the amount they would get from income support. That's a paltry £26 per day.

As well as counting how often people are poor, it is possible to measure poverty persistence by looking at incomes directly.

People's incomes fluctuate a lot from one year to the next, so many of those who were classified as poor last year will not be poor this year. So some of this year's poverty is transitory. If people could transfer their income from good times to bad times, then many might no longer feature in the statistics.

Using this measure, young children again come out worst off relative to other groups. Almost three-quarters (71%) of the total poverty experienced by pre- schoolers was chronic, compared to three-fifths (60%) for all children and just over one half (56%) for the population as a whole. Even if you make the poverty cut- off somewhat higher, or somewhat lower, these patterns don't change. Children, particularly young children, are still at greater risk of experiencing persistent and chronic poverty.

In order to deliver on the prime minister's promise to eradicate child poverty within 20 years, the government has introduced, or is planning to implement, a range of measures aimed at helping their parents into work and to make work pay more for those who already have jobs. These measures include the working family tax credit, the children's tax credit (from next year), the Sure Start programme and the New Deals for lone parents and the partners of unemployed people.

What is notable about all of these is that they are focused on helping people make the transition from benefits to work rather than just alleviating poverty by increasing out-of-work benefits (though of course the government is also increasing payments under income support for children and increasing child benefit). This dual approach, including a focus on dynamics, is to be lauded.

The government has also recently undertaken to monitor annually poverty persistence as well as current poverty as part of its "opportunity for all" initiative, which is another welcome move.

 Stephen Jenkins is a professor at the Institute for Social and Economic Research at the University of Essex. He is the co-author, with Martha Hill, of Poverty Among British Children: Chronic Or Transitory? downloadable from ISER's website: www.iser.essex.ac.uk/pubs/workpaps/wp99-23.htm

fields.headline: Long road to Utopia
fields.standfirst: When Jake  Bowers-Burbridge trundled by  horse and caravan through  Sweden, he felt he was following  the carefree ways of his Romany  ancestors. But back in Britain,  reality hit home
fields.trailText: When Jake Bowers-Burbridge trundled by horse and caravan through Sweden, he felt he was following the carefree ways of his Romany ancestors. But back in Britain, reality hit home.
fields.body:
Just 500 miles separates England from Sweden, but if, like me, you're a Romany traveller, the gulf in attitudes is colossal. My wife and I have recently travelled with our horse and caravan between the two countries. On our journey, we experienced not only changes in the physical landscape, but profound differences in attitudes towards many of the issues that lie at the heart of a democratic society - such as race, access to land and respect for a traditional, ecologically friendly nomadic lifestyle.

Every nation without a homeland has its promised land. For the Kurds, it is Kurdistan; for us, it is Romanestan. But Romanestan is just an ideal, a utopia in time, if not in place. We may originally have come from India but I doubt that many of the world's 8 million Romanies would choose to go back there.

In 1998, I went to Sweden with my horse and wagon, in search of Romanestan. Sweden is a large country with a small population and enough living space for thousands of travellers. The roads are empty of traffic. Its law of allemänsrätt (all man's rights) is a model law protecting the "right to roam". Everybody has the right to camp and gather firewood, berries, herbs and mushrooms from the countryside. Romanies are recognised as a distinct ethnic minority by the Swedish government and even have the right to be educated in their own language.

In short, Sweden is a land where Romanies have rights. It's a long way from Britain's endless fences, criminal justice act and feudal mentality towards land and class. When I first arrived, I felt as if I had found a little piece of Romanestan.

There is, however, an eeriness about Sweden. The woods are suspiciously silent and empty. The thing that made us come back to England after two years was the total absence of travellers in the rural landscape. Romany communities in Sweden are concentrated in larger towns. Official policy has assimilated travellers entirely through generosity, by giving them all the benefits a well-funded welfare state can muster. It's a far cry from past policy - up until the 1960s, travellers were forcibly sterilised in Sweden - but probably a far smarter strategy.

If Sweden can be criticised for anything it is that life is too easy. It's so good it's unreal. I've even had free cooked breakfast delivered to my caravan door. The Swedes are a rich nation but many cannot comprehend how anybody would choose to live such a basic life.

Having a lifestyle like mine can give you the annoying status of an eccentric semi-celebrity. A passing tourist once photographed me peeing at 7 o'clock in the morning. Another day, while fetching some water for the horse, I saw a woman walk straight into our home as if it was a tourist attraction. I've probably been photographed and filmed at least once for every mile I've travelled on Swedish roads. The exotic appeal of your life imposes different restrictions on your freedom. But that which makes you a celebrity in Scandinavia defines you as a pariah in England.

In the time of Henry VIII, there was a mandatory death sentence for Romanies. We have survived in an environment that is very hostile to our existence. England is one of the most densely populated countries on earth, with extremely concentrated land-ownership. That's bad news if you're a nomad needing constant access to new land for fuel and food.

The right to travel is not an issue; all you need is the vehicle. It's the right to stop that is the problem. Most of the old stopping places are gone. Those that haven't had a ditch put through them by local councils have been grabbed by farmers extending their fences or disappeared under the developers' tide of concrete. The commons we once used are gone, the verges made smaller by the widening of roads.

Travelling in Britain is only possible nowadays with an extremely intimate knowledge of the countryside and a willingness to trespass in defence of the right to live as our ancestors did. We face a stark choice - settle, or engage in daily law breaking. This ongoing struggle has got to be one of the longest running and least recognised campaigns of civil disobedience this country has ever known.

Since returning to England, I've experienced all these problems. I've met travellers who have been beaten by landowners and refused water by local villagers. At the first county line we crossed, there was a police car waiting, wanting to know our names and destination. The red carpet definitely doesn't stretch to our shores.

If our culture is to survive it must be made possible through political action. By going to Sweden I've seen glimpses of Romanestan in the forests now empty of travellers. By coming home, I hope I can bring a little bit of it back to a country so in need of its promise.

It's a far cry from past policy - up until the 1960s, travellers were forcibly sterilised in Sweden - but probably a far smarter strategy. If Sweden can be criticised for anything it is that life is too easy. It's so good it's unreal. I've even had free cooked breakfast delivered to my caravan door. The Swedes are a rich nation but many cannot comprehend how anybody would choose to live such a basic life. Having a lifestyle like mine can give you the annoying status of an eccentric semi-celebrity. A passing tourist once photographed me peeing at 7 o'clock in the morning. Another day, while fetching some water for the horse, I saw a woman walk straight into our home as if it was a tourist attraction. I've probably been photographed and filmed at least once for every mile I've travelled on Swedish roads. The exotic appeal of your life imposes different restrictions on your freedom. But that which makes you a celebrity in Scandinavia defines you as a pariah in England. In the time of Henry VIII, there was a mandatory death sentence for Romanies. We have survived in an environment that is very hostile to our existence. England is one of the most densely populated countries on earth, with extremely concentrated land-ownership. That's bad news if you're a nomad needing constant access to new land for fuel and food. The right to travel is not an issue; all you need is the vehicle. It's the right to stop that is the problem. Most of the old stopping places are gone. Those that haven't had a ditch put through them by local councils have been grabbed by farmers extending their fences or disappeared under the developers' tide of concrete. The commons we once used are gone, the verges made smaller by the widening of roads. Travelling in Britain is only possible nowadays with an extremely intimate knowledge of the countryside and a willingness to trespass in defence of the right to live as our ancestors did. We face a stark choice - settle, or engage in daily law breaking. This ongoing struggle has got to be one of the longest running and least recognised campaigns of civil disobedience this country has ever known. Since returning to England, I've experienced all these problems. I've met travellers who have been beaten by landowners and refused water by local villagers. At the first county line we crossed, there was a police car waiting, wanting to know our names and destination. The red carpet definitely doesn't stretch to our shores. If our culture is to survive it must be made possible through political action. By going to Sweden I've seen glimpses of Romanestan in the forests now empty of travellers. By coming home, I hope I can bring a little bit of it back to a country so in need of its promise.

fields.headline: Hidden headaches
fields.standfirst: Asylum seekers don't just need accommodation - they may well need  specialist medical help. Lynn Eaton reports on emerging problems
fields.trailText: Asylum seekers don't just need accommodation - they may well need specialist medical help. Lynn Eaton reports on emerging problems.
fields.body:
The government's controversial policy of having a centralised dispersal system for re-settling asylum seekers around the UK, due to start next month, is now to be phased in gradually, because of the lack of suitable accommodation outside London.

Instead of the home office taking responsibility for all new asylum seekers, for the time being it will only take responsibility for those claiming asylum at a port. The rest, as ever, will remain the responsibility of local authorities.

But home office scheme or not, those same local authorities have been unofficially operating displacement schemes on behalf of the home office since December. Many councils were, in their own right, already sending families outside London before that.

In an attempt to ease pressure on London and the south-east, the pressure is now on the new receiving authorities - as many are already finding out.

There are new demands on local health services from a group of patients of whom many health workers have little experience and whose expectations of the NHS may be a far cry from what it can deliver. Refugee children are particularly vulnerable, as a recent report from the King's Fund highlights.

Dr Angela Burnett, an East London GP who now works for the Medical Foundation for Victims of Torture, says young people are often put into difficult and embarrassing situations by doctors who may think they are trying to help. "I've heard cases of gynaecologists saying it is fine for a 14-year-old boy to interpret for his mother," she says.

The children may not have any records of immunisations; they may have diseases like malaria, which will be unfamiliar to most GP practices; and some doctors fear there may be pressure from the immigration authorities to assess the child's age by X-rays.

Getting on to a GP's list is a common problem. Many GPs lack sufficient knowledge of refugees' rights and may - without any sound legal reason - be reluctant to accept someone who has not been granted leave to stay.

All refugees, whether they are still in the process of seeking asylum or have been given extended leave to remain, are entitled to free NHS treatment. However, because they are not eligible for income support, they cannot automatically get free prescriptions, dental or eye treatment. They can apply for help with NHS charges by filling in form HC1, available from surgeries, benefit offices and the post office.

These are barriers enough for an adult in a strange country, let alone a child. "Peter" (not his real name) came here on his own from Rwanda a year ago. He is 18, studying and living in a YMCA hostel. "I don't see the purpose of a GP," he says. "One time when I went to see him, he said he didn't have medicine to give me - that I had to buy my own medicine. I didn't have the money."

In Rwanda, medical care is hospital based. I ask if he knows how the system works here. "I don't have time to find out these things. I have to go to college and do my assignments," he replies angrily.

Refugees, like everyone else, complain about the wait for an appointment. "By the time you get to the GP your cold has finished," says Oliver Bongele, who came to London from Zaire just over three years ago, aged 14. But rather than going to the local chemist instead, Oliver heads straight to the hospital. "They say 'why don't you go to your GP?', but the nurses are more friendly. GPs should be friendly too."

Medical specialists will also need to learn fast. Dr Anthony Tam is associate specialist community paediatrician for the Community Health South London NHS Trust, which has just been given £250,000 a year for three years from the Health Action Zone innovation fund for work with refugee children. "I came across refugee children who were not given the right support," says Dr Tam. "I was seeing young people between the ages of 14 and 16 who were on their own, not knowing where their parents were."

One young boy would not talk at all. The GP referred him - inappropriately - to a speech and language therapist. A trained counsellor might have been more help - the boy had been traumatised into silence by his experiences.

"We need to make fewer assumptions," advises Dr Tam. "Some may have a need for a psychiatrist, some may not. Don't assume they are all poor or come from a poor educational background. These are the survivors - these are the ones who have made it."

fields.headline: Ivory towers
fields.standfirst: As elephant poaching  rises again, Kenya  fears that the UK will  make things worse.  Polly Ghazi reports
fields.trailText: As elephant poaching rises again, Kenya fears that the UK will make things worse. Polly Ghazi reports.
fields.body:
Nehemiah Rotich, director of the Kenya Wildlife Service, is battling against a bloody upsurge of elephant poaching, so he doesn't mince his words. "We are very unhappy with the UK position on ivory trade," he says. "It is a major point of concern for us."

Rotich and his boss, the anthropologist Richard Leakey, who heads Kenya's Office of the President, believe the UK may support four southern African nations in their bid to step up international ivory trade when the UN endangered species convention (Cites) meets in Nairobi next month.

"Britain has such a key presence in Kenya as a development partner that I would have expected them to better understand what opening up ivory trade would mean for us," said Rotich during a last-ditch lobbying tour of Washington DC and London. "The tourist industry which funds the wildlife service would be badly hit and we would risk a return to the poaching holocaust of the 1980s."

Rotich's tough talking is the latest salvo in a bitter war of words over how best to preserve the African elephant.

On the one hand, Kenya and its east and central African allies argue that the 1990 ban on international ivory trade - partially lifted last year to allow a "one-off" sale of stockpiled tusks from Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia to Japan - must be reinstated. On the other, the three southern African nations, together with South Africa, want Cites to approve further ivory sales this year, pledging that profits will be put back into conservation. And with Africa divided, the votes of the EU and the US may well decide the outcome.

The omens are not good for Kenya. According to Rotich, Europe's governments, and particularly the UK, are snubbing Kenya's proposal to reinstate the elephant populations of Zimbabwe, Namibia and Botswana to Appendix 1 of Cites, which forbids international trade in listed species.

"Officially, the British government has not yet decided how to vote," Rotich says, "but they openly oppose Kenya's proposal - which implies that they support the southern African position."

Rotich is armed with a welter of statistics to support his case that further breaches of the ivory ban would risk a return to the 1980s' killing fields, when poachers slaughtered 600,000 African elephants. Since the stockpile sales last April, poaching has surged in Tanzania, Zimbabwe and Kenya. In Tsavo West national park, a popular Kenyan tourist spot, poaching has soared by 500%, while border prices for illegal ivory have also risen dramatically. Nationwide, 67 elephants were illegally killed last year, while 13 poachers were arrested and 10 shot. "Selling the stockpiles has sent a message to poachers across Africa that it will soon be business as usual," Rotich warns.

"We have already seen a major re-awakening of illegal trade, with nine big ivory seizures around the world in 1999, compared with only three in 1998. Sixty-seven dead elephants out of 29,000 in Kenya may not seem many, but we have to look at the bigger picture, at where this is all leading."

While he still has only 2,030 security staff to patrol 59 protected areas and 27 national parks, covering 45,000 sq km, Rotich believes the poachers can be kept at bay - but only if the ivory ban holds.

Many other states, he warns, do not have Kenya's resources to deal with a poaching epidemic, should the ivory trade resume. Uniquely in Africa, Kenya now funds 90% of its wildlife service from ecotourism.

While the southern Africans argue that sustainable use of wildlife resources - such as limited ivory trade - is the best means to ensure that wildlife pays its way, Kenya's wildlife director believes that tourist dollars provide the best hope for the continent.

"I think that the African states need to talk to each other to heal this split over ivory trade," he says. "I would say to the southern Africans that there are major opportunities in ecotourism which they are missing because they are not making the investment.

"People love elephants. They will come to Africa to see them. We need to protect the African elephant's future for the entire world."

fields.headline: Kick start
fields.standfirst: Tina Burchill on a pioneering plan  about which residents are sceptical
fields.trailText: Tina Burchill on a pioneering plan about which residents are sceptical.
fields.body:
A spirit of change is creeping across Leicester's most deprived estate. It is at the frontier of a new future, kick-started by a government grant of £49.5m.

Braunstone is a run-down estate that has suffered decades of neglect. Today, as one of the first estates in Britain awarded New Deal for Communities cash, its people are the key to a revolution in regeneration thinking. For what makes this different from other regeneration schemes is that it works through the direct involvement of residents.

Braunstone, on the edge of Leicester, ranks fifth in the national index of poverty. But although an injection of cash equivalent to £10,000 per household could be greeted with overwhelming enthusiasm, here nothing is taken at face value. The people are fiercely proud and independent. They have learnt to fend for themselves and there is widespread scepticism that nothing will change.

Alan Davie, 61, has lived on the estate for 40 years. He wants a better future for his grandchildren and is standing for election to the steering group that will oversee the project. He is critical of the way the project has been managed so far.

He says: "The worry is that they'll walk away and we'll be back to square one. We really appreciate what's been done in getting the money, but it's now time to let the residents really speak.

"They're talking about building offices and turning milk floats into buses, but the biggest problem here is poverty. We should be going from the bottom first, setting up credit unions and providing meals so the old people eat properly, before looking at the bigger projects."

Tim Haq, 39, has lived on the estate with his family for 10 years. He was employed by the project as a task force member in August. He says: "I was dubious about it succeeding when I first heard, but I'm confident we can use New Deal to make changes. The people of Braunstone have been treated badly. The doctor's surgery is a fortress. That is the corporate face of the health authority. It's just not acceptable.

"Community spirit here is fantastic. In the summer, you walk down the street and everyone is in their front garden and they all say hello. People worry if they don't see you for a couple of days."

But funnelling that community spirit into a force that will drive the New Deal is not an easy task. Alistair Reid, task force co-ordinator, says: "A lot of learning will come out of the whole process, both nationally and locally. Strategic agencies and residents are learning how to talk to each other.

"This is first time that so many different features of people's lives have been brought together, recognising that health is related to work is related to crime is related to the places where people live." The goal is that, at the end of the seven-year project, sustainable schemes run by residents will be in place.

Today, much of Braunstone is not a pretty sight: 130 houses are boarded up, burnt-out cars are part of the landscape and two schools are standing empty.

Statistics show death rates are significantly higher than the national figures for all major diseases; 51% of pupils leave school before they are 15; and only 38% of 35 to 44 year olds have jobs.

If this initiative is to be a success, these are the people who will make it so - and it will be on their terms.

fields.headline: Fear of the truth
fields.standfirst: A contract has been taken out to kill a public servant. His  crime? Persuading key witnesses to give evidence that helped  convict a gang of thugs who beat a teenage boy to death. But  this is not Sicily or the Bronx - it's Bermondsey, south  London. Chris Arnot meets up with Simon Hughes, the  Lib-Dem MP who has been targeted by local gangsters
fields.trailText: A contract has been taken out to kill a public servant. His crime? Persuading key witnesses to give evidence that helped convict a gang of thugs who beat a teenage boy to death. But this is not Sicily or the Bronx - it's Bermondsey, south London. Chris Arnot meets up with Simon Hughes, the Lib-Dem MP who has been targeted by local gangsters.
fields.body:
Simon Hughes arrives alone and on foot. For the first time in over three months, the MP for North Southwark and Bermondsey, in south-east London, is not being ferried around in a bullet-proof car by officers from the Special Branch. This is the kind of protection normally afforded to past and present prime ministers and secretaries of state for Northern Ireland (Mo Mowlam apart) rather than Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesmen. But since the end of October, Hughes has had to live with the knowledge that a £10,000 contract has been taken out on his life.

"One of my friends said he thought it was offensively cheap," he says as we settle down in a coffee shop near Westminster Abbey. But his levity can't quite play down the shocking nature of this case. A democratically elected member of the British parliament is still under threat of being killed - not by political terrorists or religious fanatics, but by gangsters within his own constituency.

His "crime", in their eyes, was to persuade key witnesses to give evidence in the case of 17-year-old Jamie Robe, who was beaten to death by a gang from the Osprey estate, Rotherhithe, in August 1997. Three of Robe's assailants were jailed for life in November 1999.

The intervening two years provided a chilling example of wide-scale witness intimidation and the cost to the public purse of ensuring that the criminal justice system is allowed to take its course. About 20 people had to be moved away from their homes by the Metropolitan police's witness protection unit - one of eight nationwide with powers to provide new homes, new identities, new jobs and, in some cases, new schools for witnesses' children.

Hughes refused to move away from his constituency, but he did accept police advice on other matters. "Instead of holding my surgeries in the main thoroughfare of a shopping centre, we had to move inside a shop so the entrance can be watched," he says. "And I could no longer go to meetings in crowded bars."

The coffee shop in Westminster is comparatively quiet on this Saturday morning and we have been able to walk here apparently unobserved. "They let me out on my own now," Hughes cheerfully proclaims. But the police still take the threat seriously enough to maintain a round-the-clock guard on his office and the home he shares with his girlfriend. "We're dealing with the sort of people who wouldn't find it difficult to get someone to do a shooting or a stabbing for them," Hughes concedes, ruefully.

Indeed, it was the knowledge that he has lived for 15 years in a part of London where a high number of attacks are never resolved that persuaded him to use his influence to try to break through the enforced silence on the Osprey estate and surrounding area. "A friend's son was killed and nobody was charged," he says. "I saw the trauma that that caused and it made me determined that, if it happened again, we would do better. We must make sure that people are brought to book. Otherwise we're just going to have anarchy."

Ironically, it was two days after he had been appointed his party's spokesman on home affairs that his all-too-personal lesson in witness intimidation came home to roost. "I'd just gone to bed, absolutely knackered, when my pager went off at about 2.15," he recalls. "It was the parliamentary security service telling me they'd received a threat to me and regarded it as serious. They told me they'd be with me as soon as they could. It turned out to be about 20 minutes, although it seemed longer. I was on my own that night, so I got up, made a cup of tea and hoped to goodness that if the people who were after me got here before the police, I'd be more quick-witted than they were."

The court case had finished the previous day. But only on the eve of the trial did the judge confirm that witnesses would be able to give evidence from behind a screen while wearing balaclavas and boiler suits. Had this proviso been made known earlier, it might have eased the anguish of the key witnesses. One of them, 19-year-old Traci Broughton, had lost two stone through sheer terror.

"There's no reason why some procedural guarantees about the provision of screens in court shouldn't be agreed some time before the case is heard," says Hughes, who persuaded Traci to speak out. "Also, when there's so much jury nobbling going on, why does the jury have to sit directly in the view of the public gallery?"

As for witness protection, Hughes believes there should be a nationwide scheme ready to offer alternative housing and employment to key witnesses. "Also business relocation costs," he adds, conscious that the other two key witnesses in the Jamie Robe case were Turks running a kebab shop. "As it is," he says, "it's taking a lot of police time and they're dependent on the good offices of local authorities. With private sector help, a few million could be made available to get the job done quickly and efficiently. I'm working up some proposals to put to Jack Straw. We've already had a preliminary meeting. Hopefully, there's going to be another this side of Easter."

The home secretary apparently has been very sympathetic to the plight of his opposite number on the Lib-Dem benches. Whether he'll be sympathetic to funding a national scheme for witness protection and changing the lay-out of court rooms remains to be seen.

One thing's for sure: Simon Hughes has more reason than most for being aware of the cost to society of the alternative - a steady increase in the number of court cases that collapse because witnesses to violent crime are too frightened to stand up and say publicly what they saw.

"And I could no longer go to meetings in crowded bars." The coffee shop in Westminster is comparatively quiet on this Saturday morning and we have been able to walk here apparently unobserved. "They let me out on my own now," Hughes cheerfully proclaims. But the police still take the threat seriously enough to maintain a round-the-clock guard on his office and the home he shares with his girlfriend. "We're dealing with the sort of people who wouldn't find it difficult to get someone to do a shooting or a stabbing for them," Hughes concedes, ruefully. Indeed, it was the knowledge that he has lived for 15 years in a part of London where a high number of attacks are never resolved that persuaded him to use his influence to try to break through the enforced silence on the Osprey estate and surrounding area. "A friend's son was killed and nobody was charged," he says. "I saw the trauma that that caused and it made me determined that, if it happened again, we would do better. We must make sure that people are brought to book. Otherwise we're just going to have anarchy." Ironically, it was two days after he had been appointed his party's spokesman on home affairs that his all-too-personal lesson in witness intimidation came home to roost. "I'd just gone to bed, absolutely knackered, when my pager went off at about 2.15," he recalls. "It was the parliamentary security service telling me they'd received a threat to me and regarded it as serious. They told me they'd be with me as soon as they could. It turned out to be about 20 minutes, although it seemed longer. I was on my own that night, so I got up, made a cup of tea and hoped to goodness that if the people who were after me got here before the police, I'd be more quick-witted than they were." The court case had finished the previous day. But only on the eve of the trial did the judge confirm that witnesses would be able to give evidence from behind a screen while wearing balaclavas and boiler suits. Had this proviso been made known earlier, it might have eased the anguish of the key witnesses. One of them, 19-year-old Traci Broughton, had lost two stone through sheer terror. "There's no reason why some procedural guarantees about the provision of screens in court shouldn't be agreed some time before the case is heard," says Hughes, who persuaded Traci to speak out. "Also, when there's so much jury nobbling going on, why does the jury have to sit directly in the view of the public gallery?" As for witness protection, Hughes believes there should be a nationwide scheme ready to offer alternative housing and employment to key witnesses. "Also business relocation costs," he adds, conscious that the other two key witnesses in the Jamie Robe case were Turks running a kebab shop. "As it is," he says, "it's taking a lot of police time and they're dependent on the good offices of local authorities. With private sector help, a few million could be made available to get the job done quickly and efficiently. I'm working up some proposals to put to Jack Straw. We've already had a preliminary meeting. Hopefully, there's going to be another this side of Easter." The home secretary apparently has been very sympathetic to the plight of his opposite number on the Lib-Dem benches. Whether he'll be sympathetic to funding a national scheme for witness protection and changing the lay-out of court rooms remains to be seen. One thing's for sure: Simon Hughes has more reason than most for being aware of the cost to society of the alternative - a steady increase in the number of court cases that collapse because witnesses to violent crime are too frightened to stand up and say publicly what they saw.

fields.headline: Dealing with discord
fields.standfirst: An old clash of cultures is one of the  main obstacles in the way of Tony Blair's  dream of coordinating ministerial  policies. William Plowden questions  whether anything has been learnt from  the past
fields.trailText: An old clash of cultures is one of the main obstacles in the way of Tony Blair's dream of coordinating ministerial policies. William Plowden questions whether anything has been learnt from the past.
fields.body:
Recent weeks have seen an avalanche of paper - including two massive reports from the cabinet office's performance and innovation unit (PIU) - aimed at clearing the obstacles to "joined-up" or "cross-cutting" government. Little contained in this paper acknowledges that we have been here before. The phrases may be new, but the concept has a long history.

The 1970s saw the brief but intense experience of Jasp - the "joint approach to social policy". In the 1980s, I was among the authors of a research study which looked back at Jasp and also examined contemporary efforts at coordination in making and implementing policy, both centrally and locally.

Tomorrow, several of the other authors of that study, as well as some of those now actively engaged in "joining up", will attend a seminar hosted by the Nuffield Trust to consider the lessons of the past in the light of the present. Have we, or should we have, learned anything which might now save us from stumbling over the same problems or re-inventing the same solutions?

Much of the political rhetoric about "joining up" expresses dismay and surprise at individuals' and organisations' propensity to think and work in "boxes" or "silos" - that is, pursuing their own sectoral objectives, whatever the nature of collective goals.

One lesson that should have been learned by now is that the surprise is misplaced. Any advocacy of joined-up government must start from the recognition that working jointly, or coordinately, or collaboratively, is unnatural. Organisations and professions have their own routines, cultures and languages - all of which are integral to what they do. To work in a cross-cutting way means learning new routines, new cultures and new languages. Established goals must be modified, sometimes even abandoned. This can impose real costs both on organisations and individuals.

The calculus is, therefore, simple. The costs of ignoring such enduring organisational imperatives as budget maximisation, maintaining autonomy and professional self-interest must be outweighed by the gains from coordination. However, as our study concluded, those who stand to gain from the outcome of successful coordination are usually a diffuse and unorganised constituency (like the socially excluded). And those who gain from maintaining the status quo are almost by definition concentrated and organised (like doctors, police officers or permanent secretaries).

Politicians and their advisers enjoy launching initiatives - hence the plethora of overlapping, sometimes clashing, usually unrelated, often unevaluated sub-national programmes deplored in Reaching Out, a report by the PIU. Given the costs of joining up for individuals and organisations, there is a strong case for parsimony here. If initiatives proliferate to excess, who will join up the joiner-uppers?

One reason for this multiplication of programmes is that politicians often cannot bear to wait for the results of existing programmes; their time horizons require quicker results than complex new initiatives can usually deliver. More generally, Jasp experience suggested that ministerial enthusiasm for joint activities - threatening their departmental budgets and distracting them from their own policy goals - may be short-lived. Requiring ministers to specify the intended outcomes of coordination, as we suggested, might have a restraining effect, especially if they were also required to stipulate realistic timetables. A crucial question is whether there can be life for cross-cutting activity, or coordination, after ministerial support has been switched off.

The answer to this question will depend on how far the benefits of coordination are perceived to outweigh the costs at every level of government and administration, local as well as national. In our study, we argued that promotion, knighthoods and lesser gongs must go to those prepared to take risks by cutting across organisational boundaries. Particular problems arise when it comes to changing the reward structure of professionals - that is, precisely those who have to make coordination real by tying the threads together in the field.

It is not only individuals' reward structures which must be changed. So must the reward structures for organisations. Hence the case for what our study called "crocks of gold" - central funds, access to which is conditional on taking part in joined up activities. This condition may be met if the treasury signs up to some of the proposals in the PIU's report, Wiring It Up.

Finally, a necessary condition for effective coordination is, of course, that Whitehall should get its various acts together. But this should mean less prescription, more permission. When it comes to service delivery, Whitehall should not centrally lay down templates for joined-up local activities. As a separate Jasp report on local government pointed out nearly 25 years ago, those most likely to know what makes local sense, and be best placed to put this knowledge into effect, are the agencies actually delivering services on the ground - local authorities, health authorities, quangos, non-profits. They need freedom to act on this knowledge, and are likely to be unenthusiastic partners if they do not have it.

But freedom to act, and to make appropriate local connections and deals between services, logically implies - like devolution to Scotland and Wales - the possibility of local variations in services. Ministers will have to accept the need to let go if they are serious about joining up.

 Willliam Plowden was a member of the cabinet office's think tank in the 1970s, a director of the Royal Institute for Public Administration and is now a visiting research fellow at University College's constitution unit, London.

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: A 76-year-old woman who had spent 38 years searching for her brother traced him in Florida via the internet within two hours of starting an Age Concern computer course in Gateshead.
fields.body:
Free love: Goldfish, grass snakes, garden gnomes and green wellies have been subjected to amorous advances by frogs in Dorset because of a lack of females at the start of the mating season.

Tired excuse: An independent member of Headland town council, Hartlepool, has been disqualified for not attending monthly meetings because he says the 7.15pm start time is past his bedtime.

Double take: A first world war memorial statue stolen from its plinth in Walkerburn, near Peebles, has been discovered in an Edinburgh scrap yard, 10 months after residents raised £12,000 to erect an identical replacement.

Who'd 'ave 'em? The winner of a Bristol-based radio station's competition to find the worst school half-term horror story is being offered the prize of a free vasectomy for her partner.

Big stir: Celebrity Chinese chef Ken Hom has designed a massive wok so that a Derby company producing ready-made meals can stir-fry 880lb of vegetables at a time.

Smart move: Local traders in upmarket Cheltenham have clubbed together to buy smart matching blue coats for Big Issue vendors and their dogs.

Spreading's out: An art gallery in the New Forest, Hampshire, has had to turn off its central heating to protect a 10-foot sculpture made of butter.

Broken art: Residents who phoned Brighton police asking for an abandoned car to be removed were told that it was a work of art by a local university student.

Net response: A 76-year-old woman who had spent 38 years searching for her brother traced him in Florida via the internet within two hours of starting an Age Concern computer course in Gateshead.

Clean break: Thieves who broke through the wall of a west London art warehouse stacked up the bricks they had removed and swept up the area before escaping with paintings worth £400,000.

Winning smile: A pensioner from Durham who won £110,000 at bingo has decided to buy his wife a cardigan, two nighties and a new set of teeth.

Landing in trouble: A burglar who landed on a woman when he jumped 12 feet from the window of a house in Wallsend, Tyne and Wear, was caught when he was put in the next bed to her in casualty.

Tunnel vision: Residents campaigning for a pedestrian crossing on a stretch of the A6 at Rowsley, Derbyshire, say that mothers and children are having to crawl through a storm drain to get to the other side of the busy road.

Woolly thinking: A family cautioned by RSPCA inspectors who spotted a ram in the back of their car in King's Lynn, Norfolk, said they were only taking their pet for a walk.
