webTitle: BNFL pays to put own man in Tokyo embassy

fields.headline: BNFL pays to put own man in Tokyo embassy
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels pays the foreign office £500,000 a year to have its own man working inside the British embassy in Tokyo with a diplomatic passport and negotiating on behalf of the government with the Japanese on nuclear trade, it was revealed last night.
fields.byline: Paul Brown  and Ewen MacAskill  in Tokyo
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels pays the foreign office £500,000 a year to have its own man working inside the British embassy in Tokyo with a diplomatic passport and negotiating on behalf of the government with the Japanese on nuclear trade, it was revealed last night.

Tom McLaughlan, who appears on the official diplomatic list, holds one of the most senior posts at the embassy as Counsellor (Atomic Energy).

His brief is to advise on British nuclear interests and to increase trade with Japan's nuclear industry. The foreign office said last night that Mr McLaughlan was answerable to its officials rather than BNFL.

He has been in the post since 1995, before when he was director of communications in BNFL's London office, and is expected to return to a more senior job next year. The nuclear industry has been paying for a diplomatic post in Tokyo for 20 years.

Last night the foreign office sought to play down the BNFL connection, saying that it had a well-established practice of secondments from the private sec tor. But the scale of the payments and the full diplomatic status granted to Mr McLaughlan is unprecedented.

It was not clear yesterday whether the Japanese government knew that its contact at the British embassy wasfunded by BNFL. Britain's diplomatic difficulties with Japan over the revelation that BNFL had falsified safety data on nuclear shipments to the country will not be eased by the disclosure.

The Japanese science and technology agency was not prepared to comment yesterday. "It is up to the British government who they employ."

A spokesman for Kansai, a private company involved in the nuclear industry, said it was not aware that an embassy official was an employee of BNFL.

Last night a political row was developing over the disclosure. Alan Simpson, Labour MP for Nottingham South, said: "I am flabbergasted, it is outrageous. It is the sort of thing that might have happened in the worst days of the dying Conservative government but to carry it on under Labour - it is purchasing a government. It must be stopped."

Tom Burke, who was John Gummer's adviser at the department of environment when the decision was taken in 1993 to go ahead with the controversial £1.8bn Thorp nuclear reprocessing plant, said: "The BNFL man in post wrote all the official telegrams home even though they came in the name of the ambassador. They gave an entirely rosy view of BNFL prospects and contracts to say the least. All the distracting noises that might have given an alternative view were filtered out."

William Walker, professor of international relations at St Andrews university, who discovered that BNFL was paying the foreign office, said last night that senior executives in Japanese nuclear utilities had told told him they had no way of communicating with the British government "because of the BNFL man at the embassy. I thought this was wrong and wrote to the foreign office about it but never received a reply."

BNFL said last night the £500,000 was to cover salary, the cost of a flat, a car, language training and stationery. "It's a very expensive place, Japan," a spokesman added.

In a statement, the company said it "rejects any assertion that the BNFL secondee to the post of atomic energy counsellor distorted messages from Japan". The post was useful to BNFL especially before it opened its own office in Japan in 1994, it added.

The foreign office denied there was any conflict of interest. "The work he does is for the foreign office. He has to stick to the objective we set out for him. He is answerable to the ambassador, not BNFL."

Japan is the only country in which Britain has a nuclear post, although there are scientific and technical counsellors in other embassies, such as Bonn.

Over the last two decades, the government has sought to change the role of British embassies from being primarily concerned with politics to being mainly involved in encouraging trade. The process began in earnest under Margaret Thatcher and has continued under Labour.

Given the shortage of technical knowledge and business skills among traditional career diplomats, the foreign office has had to look to the private sector. Businessmen and scientists have been recruited for two to three year secondments overseas or at the foreign office in London, and career diplomats are being given temporary jobs in the private sector to gain business skills.

Those seconded from the private sector are not normally granted full diplomatic status.

Last week Mr McLaughlan was visiting BNFL headquarters at Risley where Japanese customers were meeting senior company officials. Yesterday he was on holiday and unavailable for comment.

fields.headline: Gunfire and grenades in Mitrovice
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Serious fighting erupted in the disputed, northern suburbs of Mitrovice yesterday after hand grenades were thrown into crowds of Serbs and French troops of the K-For peacekeeping contingent in Kosovo's flashpoint town. Around 40 soldiers and civilians, including a young child, were injured.
fields.body:
Serious fighting erupted in the disputed, northern suburbs of Mitrovice yesterday after hand grenades were thrown into crowds of Serbs and French troops of the K-For peacekeeping contingent in Kosovo's flashpoint town. Around 40 soldiers and civilians, including a young child, were injured.

Automatic gunfire was later heard in another part of the north side, near where the Nato-led administration had been trying to return ethnic Albanians who fled from their tower-block apartments after 10 people were killed by Serb gangs.

The violence was the latest evidence of deteriorating security in the province of Kosovo. Nearby, in the southern Presevo region of Serbia proper, an increasing number of ethnic Albanians have been running away into Kosovo. They are fearful that clashes will intensify in Presevo between new Albanian paramilitary units and Serb police. On Monday, 626 Albanians registered with the UN High Commissioner for Refugees in the Kosovo town of Gnjilane.

But it has been in Mitrovice, a town with a big Albanian majority where Serbs dominate the north bank of the river Ibar and Albanians the south, that Nato is facing its stiffest test in trying to reintegrate bitterly divided peoples.

Yesterday's disturbances began, according to Lieutenant Matthieu Mabin, a spokesman for the French force in charge of the area, as a fight between two men in the Bosnjacka Mahala section of the town where Serbs were registering to return to their homes in the southern suburbs. The brawling spread, then shots were heard.

"That created panic and hand grenades were thrown, we don't know from whom or from where ... but it created very many injured, especially French soldiers," said Lieut Mabin.

According to Oliver Ivanovic, a local Serb official, the violence began after an ethnic Albanian attacked a Serb with a metal bar. When the Serb retaliated, another Albanian appeared and shot at the Serb before hand grenades were tossed into the Serb crowd.

Philippe Paco, a spokesman for the UN mission which is trying to administer Kosovo, said: "One Albanian fired a hunting rifle [at] a young man and wounded him and immediately after that Albanians from a courtyard fired two hand grenades".

By late afternoon local hospitals had treated 20 Serbs, 14 French K-For soldiers and five Albanians. Two of the Serbs were reported to have been seriously wounded.

A Reuters reporter at the scene said he saw six French soldiers and an officer injured when Albanians threw explosive devices at a military unit surrounding an Albanian house from which there had been shooting.

Colonel Patrick Chanliau, another K-For spokesman, said French soldiers were still surrounding the house where the shooting had started. He also confirmed that a child was among the injured. Several cars were later set alight.

Extra troops and UN police were posted at the bridges dividing the town. The atmosphere remained very tense but quieter after the shooting ended.

Russia's foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, called for more peacekeepers in Kosovo, after he held a meeting with the UN special envoy to the Balkans, Carl Bildt.

Earlier, Russian politicians had suggested Russia might pull out of the peacekeeping operation in Kosovo in protest at inadequate protection for the province's minority Serbs.

Colonel Patrick Chanliau, another K-For spokesman, said French soldiers were still surrounding the house where the shooting had started. He also confirmed that a child was among the injured. Several cars were later set alight. Extra troops and UN police were posted at the bridges dividing the town. The atmosphere remained very tense but quieter after the shooting ended. Russia's foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, called for more peacekeepers in Kosovo, after he held a meeting with the UN special envoy to the Balkans, Carl Bildt. Earlier, Russian politicians had suggested Russia might pull out of the peacekeeping operation in Kosovo in protest at inadequate protection for the province's minority Serbs.

fields.headline: Jack Straw's jury trials
fields.standfirst: Political Correspondent Nicholas Watt analyses the moves in Westminster last night to push Jack Straw's jury trial bill through
fields.trailText: Political Correspondent Nicholas Watt analyses the moves in Westminster last night to push Jack Straw's jury trial bill through
fields.body:
Tony Blair rarely troubles himself with commons votes these days, leaving it to Labour's lobby fodder of loyal backbench MPs to turn up night after night to support the government.

But the prime minister made one of his rare appearances in the division lobby last night in a sign of the government's unease over the rebellion against Jack Straw's plans to curb the right to trial by jury.

Mr Straw this morning dismissed the revolt against his Criminal Justice (Mode of Trial) Bill, saying that he was pleased that only 29 Labour MPs had rebelled against the government. "I'm very pleased therefore that about half of those who voiced concerns were reassured by what I said in the House," he said.

However, ministers will know privately that it will be difficult to brush aside the vote because the Labour rebels included more than the "usual suspects" of disgruntled left wingers, such as Tony Benn and Jeremy Corbyn, who have never come to terms with New Labour. The rebels included the former minister Mark Fisher.

In a sign that the rebellion may have paid off, Mr Straw indicated this morning that he may be prepared to amend his bill when MPs consider it in detail. "I have never seen a Bill go before the House of Commons that has not been improved by the process of debate, and I look forward to the debate which can take place in the standing committee on the Bill," the Home Secretary told the Today programme.

However, ministers may feel that they can relax because the rebellion was far smaller than the massive revolt against cuts in benefits to single parents in 1997 when 47 MPs defied the government.

One whip, who had spent the day "persuading" potential rebels to line up behind the government, chuckled when a waverer rushed up and announced that he was now on board. "I've forgotten what I said earlier," the MP said.

His U-turn will have been immediately reported to the home secretary, providing another excuse for him to stand by his contentious bill.

webTitle: 'Super Tuesday 2000 accomplished exactly what the fixers designed it to do'

fields.headline: 'Super Tuesday 2000 accomplished exactly what the fixers designed it to do'
fields.standfirst: Guardian Washington correspondent Martin Kettle analyses yesterday's victory of the establishment over the mavericks
fields.trailText: Guardian Washington correspondent Martin Kettle analyses yesterday's victory over the mavericks
fields.body:
After the first election year contests in Iowa and New Hampshire, the Republicans took the scenic route to Super Tuesday that led through South Carolina, Michigan and Virginia. The Democrats went more directly to it, amid far less squabbling and without nearly so much entertainment. Last night, though, both American parties rejoined one another to find their presidential nominations at the same place and back in step.

Super Tuesday 2000 accomplished exactly what the fixers designed it to do, by enabling the two party establishment favourites to rack up emphatic wins in yesterday's contests which effectively end their respective challengers' hopes. The contest in November will be Al Gore v George W Bush, just as the party bosses planned. Bill Bradley won't you please go home now. And bye bye Johnnie McCain.

On the Democratic side, last night's results were a triple triumph for Al Gore. Not only did the vice-president knock down Bill Bradley's challenge everywhere that it raised its head, giving Gore eleven wins out of eleven yesterday. He also won each contest by a distance. And, in addition, Gore had the satisfaction of accomplishing a shut-out mission that he himself helped to plan.

The vice-president's wins were big. Gore won in California, where Bradley was supposed to have so much Silicon Valley support; he won in New York, where Bradley was meant to be rewarded for those idolised years on the Knicks' basketball court; he won in Missouri, where Bradley was born and raised; he won in New England, where Democrats are supposed to lean to the kind of gentle left alternative which Bradley was offering. In most places, Gore didn't just defeat Bradley, he overwhelmed him. The margin was over 65 points in Georgia, a state with a moderate Democratic governor, a result which, in itself, is surely enough for Bradley to see the futility of continuing into next week, when there are six more southern primaries.

Assuming that Bradley now withdraws, as surely he will, the redesign of Super Tuesday 2000 has worked exactly the way that the Gore people anticipated. They themselves moved the California primary up the calendar from June to March precisely in order to make the largest state - which Gore has worked for years - count for more in the scheme of things. That made March 7 into a hurdle which only a well-funded, well-grounded candidate could clear. Yesterday was in every sense a victory for the Democratic machine that Al Gore controls.

But a mirror image triumph was played out yesterday on the Republican side too. March 7 was also tailor made for the frontrunner George W Bush, with his money, his endorsements, his organisation and his conservatism. Here too, the proliferation of contests enabled the front-runner to defeat an overextended rival. If California had not voted yesterday, McCain's clutch of little wins in New England states would look much more impressive than they do this morning, when they are eclipsed by his losses in California and elsewhere.

In terms of individual states won and lost in this campaign, McCain and Bush still remain more or less on competitive terms this morning. But today the weight and the momentum is all irresistibly with Bush. California, Ohio and a majority among voters in the byzantine politics of New York give the Texas governor the wins that mattered most.

A bad outlook for McCain only gets worse when you consider that the nine next Republican primaries - three in the western mountain states this weekend, and six in the south next week - all look to have Bush's name on them. This time next week, as McCain knows only too well, things will look even more formidably difficult than they already do today. It's no wonder that the McCain camp is massively divided this morning about almost every decision that it must now take. To carry on or to quit. To bolt to the Reform Party or not. To go back to the drawing board for 2004 or not.

Yet, listening to Bush and McCain address their supporters last night there was little doubt that they both recognised this was the decisive moment of the 2000 nominating campaign. Bush, like Gore, addressed himself to the November election not next week's primaries. McCain seemed to be signalling that, after a day or two of reflection, he will pull out. The mathematics of the delegate count for the national convention is simply against him.

And so it will be, as some intended and many feared, an establishment v establishment general election, though with two candidates who are far from interchangeable. The big question today, as the rebels prepare to retreat from the field, is what happens to their voters? It is not clear that either Bush or Gore holds any instant appeal for what, a couple of weeks ago, called itself "the McCain majority" Inevitably now, the Reform Party - under Pat Buchanan or even Ross Perot once again - looms as a bigger player in the new game. The bigger likelihood is that the political rebels will simply decide to sit this one out, reducing the turnout in November still further in a country where fewer than half of the electorate now vote in presidential elections.

fields.headline: Blofeld actor dies
fields.trailText: British actor and memorable Bond villain Charles Gray has died at the age of 71.
fields.byline: By Film Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
British actor and memorable Bond villain Charles Gray has died at the age of 71.

Born in Bournemouth, Gray made his uncredited film debut in 1955's One Desire and rose to fame playing a string of villains and colonial types in everything from Hammer horror films to TV series such as Hannay. His last appearance was as Admiral Balchen in Channel Four's Longitude, which aired over Christmas. Gray died at London's Brompton Hospital.

In a theatrical career spanning five decades, Gray's steely persona and lip-curling delivery made him a familiar face on stage and screen. But he remains best known for his role as the suave, cat-stroking Ernst Stavro Blofeld in the 1971 James Bond outing Diamonds are Forever.

webTitle: Super Tuesday: reaction from the US

fields.headline: Super Tuesday: reaction from the US
fields.trailText: Reaction from the American press to the Super Tuesday primary.
fields.body:
Bush emerged more scarred from the battle with McCain than Gore did from his tussle with Bradley. Bush was driven further to the right by the McCain challenge than Gore was forced to the left by Bradley.

David Broder The Washington Post

The single most important question in the election might be this: Where do the independent-minded people such as those who turned out for McCain in New Hampshire and Michigan end up going?

Susan Page USA Today

What McCain leaves behind, then, is a fractured party, a damaged Republican nominee apparent, and a large, unserved constituency at the heart of the American electorate. His campaign revealed a huge national appetite for political reform and personal integrity. Once McCain is gone, Bush and Gore will vie for the truth-starved, disenchanted voters he left behind. The one who wins them will be the next president.

Jacob Weisberg Slate magazine

McCain's up from nowhere campaign - driven by his compelling tale of Vietnam prisoner of war heroism and his straight talk style - was the compelling story of the 2000 race, rocking the Republican establishment.

The New York Post

It was a bravura performance by the vice president, if no longer surprising in view of the near-collapse of Mr. Bradley's campaign in recent weeks, and it positioned him well for the battle against the eventual Republican nominee, although perhaps situated somewhat farther to the left on some key issues than he had hoped.

R W Apple The New York Times

webTitle: BT enters tussle over internet access

fields.headline: BT enters tussle over internet access
fields.trailText: BT leapt into the internet access fray today by offering its own low cost package, but failed to win over analysts with its response to a flurry of rival schemes.
fields.body:
BT leapt into the internet access fray today by offering its own low cost package, but failed to win over analysts with its response to a flurry of rival schemes.

BT will introduce unmetered access to an internet service provider (ISP) for frequent users and metered access for occasional surfers. It believes its SurfTime scheme has significantly lower charges than those in the US.

But analyst John Tysoe at West LB Panmure was unimpressed and warned that BT risked losing its high-spending internet customers just as the US telecommunications giant AT&T had done.

BT chairman Sir Iain Vallance denied that his company had been caught napping by cut-price offers from companies like AltaVista, the internet search engine, and NTL, the US cable group.

"One of the reasons why BT is not able to come out of the traps as quickly as we would like is because of the regulatory system under which we operate," said Sir Iain. "We are running with a ball and chain around our legs. Until that regulatory system is brought up to date we would not be able to move as quickly as we would like." BT has been criticised by government and analysts for keeping telephone charges high, impeding widespread internet use and the spread of e-commerce in the UK. AltaVista and NTL have shaken up the internet market by dropping phone charges or making internet access free.

BT set out to highlight the true cost of the headline-grabbing US deals by including the price of line rental in its packages. It cut the price of its unlimited access service to £29.25 a month (including line rental of £9.26) from the £34.99 excluding rental announced in December - a 43% reduction.

The deal is less generous than NTL's offer of free access for its telephone customers and AltaVista's plan for a one-off fee of up to £50 plus £20 a year for unmetered surfing. But BT said its plan was good value when line rental and other costs were added to the rival products.

"We want to put the focus on the complete costs of telephony," a BT official said.

Shares in BT rose on news of its internet scheme. The stock climbed as high as 1,205p after a 118p loss on Tuesday, and traded 1.1% or 13p ahead at 1,183p in morning trading with 4.5 million shares changing hands before 10am. Analysts said the stock was also supported by news that BT had won a £2.5bn contract to provide the police with a digital radio service.

BT reduced the cost of metered access to a penny per minute during the day, 0.6p in the evening and 0.5p at the weekend, with no additional monthly charges on top of line rental. All prices will apply to any internet service provider (ISP) offering dial-up to a new 0844 number, meaning users will not be forced to use BT's service. June 1 is the target date for the initiative.

fields.headline: McCain's last hurrah
fields.trailText: The glittering confetti rained down on the loyal supporters, the disco sounds belted over the loud speakers and cries of "you're the man, John!" punctuated the air. But behind the razzmatazz  in West Hollywood, the hoped-for victory rally turned out to be John McCain's last hurrah.
fields.body:
The glittering confetti rained down on the loyal supporters, the disco sounds belted over the loud speakers and cries of "you're the man, John!" punctuated the air. But behind the razzmatazz in West Hollywood, the hoped-for victory rally turned out to be John McCain's last hurrah.

Mr McCain lost to Texas governor George Bush in the crucial Californian primary and, despite defiant noises from the platform, his supporters conceded that his bid to be the first US president of the new millennium has almost certainly ended.

With just over half the votes counted, Mr McCain was trailing Mr Bush among both Republican voters and the general electorate in America's most populous state. With 52% counted, Mr Bush was beating Mr McCain by 56% to 32% of the Republican voters, with Alan Keyes on 3%. Among all voters, in what is often known as the "beauty contest" because it has no effect on the selection of the delegates, early returns showed Democrat Al Gore ahead with 33%, Mr Bush on 29%, Mr McCain on 25%, Democrat Bill Bradley 9% and Mr Keyes 2%.

In the Democrat contest, Mr Gore swamped Mr Bradley by 81% to 18%.

"Our crusade continues tonight, tomorrow, the next day, the day after that and for as long as it takes to restore America's confidence and pride in the practice and institutions of our great democracy," Senator McCain told a gathering of his campaign team and the media last night. But elsewhere in his speech were clues that he realised that his Straight Talk Express has finally run into the buffers.

In congratulating Mr Bush, Mr McCain said that "we may meet again in primaries a few days from now and we have both earned a little rest." He would, he said, "take a little time to reflect on the direction of our campaign." Decoded, the message was fairly clear - that Mr McCain accepted that the crusade may be over, at least in terms of winning the Republican nomination.

In true McCain tradition, the disco, soul and hip-hop was blaring out as his young campaign volunteers handed out stickers and badges for what may be the last time. His team made sure that he received a hero's welcome as he came down the steps to make a brief speech.

With his wife Cindy and his entire family on the platform, Mr McCain gave his trademark thumbs up salute and thanked all those who had campaigned for him. He told them he would never give up his mission: "America stands for something so much greater than the cynicism that sometimes afflicts us." He concluded by saying that he was "humbled beyond expression" by all the support he and his wife had received throughout his campaign.

Local supporters who bade him farewell as he set off to his home state of Arizona would reflect that the campaign had also been humbled by the magnitude of the vote against their man.

The actress Connie Stevens, who has coordinated support for Mr McCain in the film industry, said he had achieved one of his main goals by drawing attention to the corruption of the system. "We are the greatest country in the world but we do need a couple of changes," she said.

Another supporter, David Lasdon, a lifelong Republican, said Mr McCain was the only candidate for whom he had ever campaigned. "Bush will say anything - they [the Bush team] don't believe in ethics," he said.

California was meanwhile digesting the results of other votes made yesterday. By a large majority voters decided not to recognise gay marriages that had been conducted outside the state. This issue has polarised the Los Angeles community, with the religious right mobilising support and many in the entertainment industry campaigning against it. Early returns showed the proposition backed by 62% to 38%.

A proposition that grants Indian reservations greater rights to run casinos was passed, with early returns showing 64% in favour and 36% against.

But the main spotlight last night fell on Mr McCain. His aides are adamant that he will not accept any invitation to stand for the Reform Party and he is apparently reluctant to accept a post as Mr Bush's running mate considering the abuse the Bush campaign has heaped on him. Today he will consult with his aides in Arizona before deciding whether his great adventure has come to an end.

fields.headline: Highlights from the jury debate
fields.standfirst: MPs debate Jack Straw's removal of the right to trial by jury
fields.trailText:
Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman
We have a system - and we can argue about how we got here - in which some cases have to go for jury trial. Those are the big cases. Some cases - the smaller ones - have to go before the magistrates. In between are many offences that are either way offences. There are 370 categories of such offences in English law, applicable in England and Wales. The proposal is that - without considering the detail or whether it is appropriate for the individual offence - all those offences will be changed in one go from a situation in which the defendant chooses the venue to the court choosing the venue.
fields.body:
Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman
We have a system - and we can argue about how we got here - in which some cases have to go for jury trial. Those are the big cases. Some cases - the smaller ones - have to go before the magistrates. In between are many offences that are either way offences. There are 370 categories of such offences in English law, applicable in England and Wales. The proposal is that - without considering the detail or whether it is appropriate for the individual offence - all those offences will be changed in one go from a situation in which the defendant chooses the venue to the court choosing the venue.

The public case for retaining a broad base for jury trial is that it allows citizens to participate in the legal process. Jury trial is popular and adds to the legal system's credibility. It reduces those elements of the legal process in which only lawyers are involved.

Robert Marshall-Andrews, Labour MP and barrister
The point of principle is that jury trial is fundamental to our system of criminal justice. The reason - which the government seek to avoid - is simply this: our system is adversarial. We do not inquire after the truth; we are interested in proof. The state brings the case against its own citizen, and must prove it. It is an axiom of our law that the state does not prove it in front of its own appointees. If cases are serious, they must be proved in front of your fellow citizens. That is the right that you have. That is not an aspersion on magistrates. It is simply a matter of saying that justice must be seen to be done.

Brian Sedgemore, Labour MP and lawyer
Before trial by jury, England had trial by ordeal, which was certainly summary justice, the scope of which the home secretary is intent on extending. The ordeal often involved submerging people in cold water. If the suspect sank, God had accepted him, and he was innocent. If he bobbed to the surface, however, God had rejected him, and he was guilty. Today, we would call that a catch-22. I suspect that the home secretary, as a born-again Christian, and though constrained by the mores of modern civilisation, has a sneaking admiration for that quick, cost-free kind of summary justice.

Jack Straw
The bill enjoys the active endorsement of the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Bingham, and of the vast majority of the High Court Bench of nearly 100 senior judges; of the Magistrates Association, representing 30,000 justices of the peace; and of all three police associations, representing more than 125,000 police officers, each of whom has to deal every day with the victims of crime and its perpetrators and who know that justice is not served, either for victim or defendant, by an antiquated and time-wasting procedure, which the bill seeks to remedy.

In no sense does the bill undermine the availability of trial by jury for appropriate offences. What it does is to ensure that there is a fairer and more objective basis than the decision of the accused for determining which cases involving the middle range of offences should be so tried.

Edward Garnier, Conservative party legal spokesman
He [Jack Straw] is not the only man guilty of conspiring to damage the administration of justice. Step forward another lawyer, the right hon. Member for Sedgefield [Mr Blair], who said that it was "totally unsatisfactory" to prevent defendants from choosing trial by jury. He said that "fundamental rights to justice" could not be "driven by administrative convenience." I agree.

Who else agrees with the views then expressed by those three members of the Government? The Criminal Bar Association, the Bar Council, the Association of Magisterial Officers, the Society of Labour Lawyers--every member of the home office apart from the minister of state, the hon. member for Norwich, South [Charles Clarke], may be a member of that august body - the Society of Conservative Lawyers, the Society of Liberal Democrat Lawyers, the Law Society, any number of Crown court and High Court judges to whom I and others have spoken but who cannot speak out publicly, the Legal Action Group, Justice, Liberty, the Institute of Race Relations, the Blackstone Society, the Howard League, the Portia Trust, Professor Lee Bridges - professor of law at Warwick university - Northumbria police, the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, the Quakers and the legal committee of the joint council of Her Majesty's stipendiary magistrates, the Institute of Legal Executives, the Society of Asian Lawyers, the Association of Chief Officers of Probation.

Hazel Blears, Labour MP
Research has also shown that 27% of defendants who plead not guilty and elect for Crown court trial intend to plead guilty later. That means that nearly 6,000 cases are a complete sham from start to finish. It means that the full machinery of the Crown court system has to be put into action. Victims and police are involved, witnesses are warned and a great deal of money is spent - when, in 6,000 cases, the defendant knows from the outset that he intends to plead guilty to the offences charged.

James Clappison, Conservative MP
Does not the real unfairness of the bill rest in who will be allowed to have a trial by jury? Will not it benefit the rich, the powerful and the famous who will have the right to trial by jury? Will the home secretary answer the questions he himself asked a few years ago: "If a member of parliament or even a secretary of state were charged with an offence of dishonesty, would they not insist on being tried by a jury? If that is the case, why should others be denied that right of election?" [1997]

The lorry driver, the council employee charged with stealing from the council, the shop assistant alleged to be stealing from her employer, the confused old lady charged with shoplifting, a coal miner charged with stealing coal - I have defended many humble people like that in the course of my career as a member of the bar, and in each case I think that the person concerned should have had the right to a trial by jury.

These are the sorts of people most likely to lose the right to a trial by jury. The famous broadcaster, businessman or politician, the member of parliament and certainly the secretary of state, perhaps also the rich man who arrives at the magistrates court with eminent counsel - all those people will get the right to a trial by jury. But the man in the street, who comes from humble origins, has a lower income and perhaps cannot afford counsel at all will not. It is inevitable that, under the proposals, ordinary men and women will lose the right to trial by jury - trial by their peers. They want to exercise that right when something greatly important to them - their reputation for honesty, their livelihood - may be at stake.

David Davies, Conservative MP
When the bill was being debated in the other place [the House of Lords] we were told that the savings were £105 million. Now we are told that the figure is £128 million. There has been no explanation of that difference. A large proportion of the savings come from a reduction in sentences, which I am not comfortable with when assessing the value of the measure. Those in the other place were also told that there would be no loss of public service jobs. I spend a lot of my time looking at supposed economies in government, and those two claims strike me as inconsistent. I find the proposal implausible in financial terms.

We must remember the size of the costs that we are discussing - £9 billion a year. We are now talking about £128 million, of which a small fraction would be within the judicial system per se. We will never know whether these illusory savings are actually made. Even if they were, if we had to choose between money and justice, surely we would choose justice every time.

Mark Fisher, Labour MP
One thing on which everyone I consulted agreed was that they could not understand why the government were proposing the changes now, rather than waiting for the review of the criminal justice system that they themselves established. The review is chaired by Sir Robin Auld and will report later this year. Both magistrates and solicitors in my constituency said that, until they saw the exact scope of Sir Robin's report, we should not be tackling this one, small - albeit very important - part of the criminal justice system. They thought that we should first have the benefit of that overall review of the criminal justice system - much of which they thought could be improved.

Read the full debate

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Columbia gets cold feet over Keanu's sex comedy, Reeves and Mortimer talk rubbish, and, on the casting couch, John Travolta as a super spy, Alexander Payne's literary turn, and the latest ER resident to hit the big screen
fields.body:
Columbia has decided not to go ahead with its comedy The Ottoman Empire. The movie, which was to have starred Keanu Reeves as a furniture salesman who hides his previous life as a porno star, has been abandoned following the poor performance of Columbia's latest sex comedy, What Planet Are You From? Starring Gary Shandling (aka Larry Saunders), What Planet barely scraped $3m on its opening weekend.

Comedians Vic Reeves and Bob Mortimer, whose recent foray in the movie world is currently being shown in the Sky cinema at the dome, have revealed that their next project is a social realist black comedy about dustbin men.

Casting couch

 John Travolta appears poised to commit to the MGM production Quiller Solitaire, a James Bond-esque adventure story based on one of a series of novel's by thriller writer Adam Hall. In keeping with his current power within Hollywood, the actor's involvement allows him to hand-pick the film's director. Even so, Quiller Solitaire will be hard-pressed to fit into a hectic Travolta schedule. At last count, the actor had three other projects at various stages of development, and has just finished shooting his lead role in Nora Ephron's lottery comedy Numbers.

 Looking to capitalise on his success with the Oscar-nominated Election, director Alexander Payne is busy lining up his future projects. Variety announced yesterday that the Nebraska-bred film-maker is to direct his own adaptation of Oscar Wilde's The Portrait of Dorian Gray. Payne's picture will be a modern update of the Wilde novel, though its tale of rampant narcissism and beauty gone bad is as contemporary now as it was a century ago. However, The Portrait will have to wait a while. Payne's next film, About Schmidt, is still in pre-production pending a decision from Jack Nicholson over whether to star.

 The latest ER resident taking the George Clooney route from TV to film is Eriq La Salle (aka the truculent Dr Benton). A mainstay of the hospital drama since it began airing in 1994, La Salle will make his feature directing debut this Spring with the low-budget indie thriller Danger. Written by Joe Singer and Jason Squire and produced by La Salle's own production company, Humble Journey Films, Danger tells the tale of an innocent on the run from the authorities. La Salle has already written and directed a short film, Psalms From the Underground, about the legacy of the 60s Civil Rights movement and in 1996 helmed the HBO basketball picture Rebound. He has no immediate plans to quit ER.

fields.headline: Sweet bid for Hughes poem
fields.trailText: A lost poem by the late poet laureate Ted Hughes, which was written on the back of a chocolate wrapper, sold at auction yesterday for £575, five times its estimated price.
fields.body:
A lost poem by the late poet laureate Ted Hughes, which was written on the back of a chocolate wrapper, sold at auction yesterday for £575, five times its estimated price.

The five-line poem dates back to 1987 and was one of three written in response to an appeal by the St Andrews Tunnocks caramel wafer appreciation society.

The confectionary has been a Scottish institution for decades, selling two million bars a week. Its cult status among St Andrews university students may be partly because the firm supplies them with a crate of free bars every term.

The St Andrews appeal was a charity fundraising stunt. Two of the wrappers have disappeared, but the one sold yesterday at Bonham's, London, was originally bought by a student who is now a doctor.

St Andrews, Scotland's oldest university, wanted the wrapper back as a star exhibit for its new museum, but was heavily outbid.

Alastair Work, assistant principal at St Andrews, who is closely involved in the museum project, said yesterday: "I am very disappointed, but I am pleased that after all these years it has turned up, and I hope it brings joy to the new owner."

The poem reads:

St Columbus ate a heifer

then wrote a psalm on the hide

Good News!

So I ate a Caramel Wafer

and rhymed on the wrapper's inside.

Mr Work, a founder of the Tunnocks caramel wafer appreciation society, urged former students to ransack their homes for the other poems. Somewhere there must be two more red and gold wrappers, with the immortal lines

To have swallowed a

crocodile

Would make anybody smile

but to swallow a Caramel Wafer

is safer

and the more characteristic Hughes terse bleakness of

Where the Devil can't get

He sends the Old Woman

fields.headline: No-smoking day
fields.trailText: Information on no-smoking day
fields.body:
1. Today is no smoking day, when anti-tobacco pressure groups and the health profession persuade you to give up.

2. And why should you? Smoking does a lot of damage to your body - medical research suggests that smoking leads to fatal illnesses such as cancer and coronary heart disease.

3. 100m people died of tobacco related deaths in the last century. At a recent world health organisation (WHO) conference one speaker said a a billion people will die from tobacco related deaths in the next hundred years. Though it may not be churlish to suggest that as the world's population grows the number of people who could potentially die of any disease will grow too.

4. Even so, according to WHO estimates there are currently 4m deaths a year from tobacco, a figure expected to rise to about 10m by the 2020s or early 2030s. By that date tobacco is predicted to be the leading cause of disease in the world, causing about one in eight deaths (70% of those deaths will occur in developing countries).

5. Tobacco came to Europe with the discovery of the Americas. On 13 October, 1492, Christoper Columbus encountered a man on San Salvador with dry tobacco leaves, and on 2 November he saw the native Cuban Tainos smoking cigars. The first European woman to smoke was Queen Isabella, Columbus's sponsor.

6. In 1560 Jean Nicot, the French Ambassador to Portugal, introduced tobacco to England. Nicot made a fortune selling tobacco, and was honoured after his death with the word nicotine

7. Some decades later the English decided to set up tobacco plantations in the Americas, first at Jamestown.

8. China now the fastest growing tobacco market in the world. Two out of three Chinese males now become smokers before age 25. If present smoking patterns persist, at least 100m of the 340m Chinese males below age 29 will eventually be killed by tobacco.

9. Tobacco is considered such a threat to the world's well-being that the World Bank refuses to lend money for its production.

10. If you ever want to give up, there are plenty of places to start.

webTitle: US studios enjoy lower costs and record box-office takings

fields.headline: US studios enjoy lower costs and record box-office takings
fields.trailText: Figures released today reveal that marketing and production costs fell last year and box-office revenue is at a record high
fields.body:
Cash-strapped Hollywood execs have been keeping tight control over the studios' purse-strings last year, and for the first time in two decades marketing costs for the major studio films fell, while production costs for new movies dropped for the second consecutive year.

In a new report, the trade group the Motion Picture Association of America said that marketing costs dipped by an average of $780,000 per film to end the year at $24.5m. Production costs fell $1.2m in 1999, to $51.5m. The total average cost per picture now stands at $78m.

The figures indicate that studios are deadly serious about cutting costs to make the industry more profitable. "It's two years in a row that average negative cost is down - extrapolate that to three or four years out, and you're going to see a major change,'' said the trade group's president Jack Valenti.

Meanwhile, the industry's record box-office year of $7.5bn was attributed not to an increase in cinema-goers nor the proliferation of multiplexes, but to the increase in ticket prices, which have risen 8.3% in the last year.

webTitle: 80 per cent of Academy ballot papers 'lost in post'

fields.headline: 80 per cent of Academy ballot papers 'lost in post'
fields.trailText: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences are today sending out 4,000 duplicate Oscar ballot papers following the loss of eight bags of mail containing the original forms.
fields.body:
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences are today sending out 4,000 duplicate Oscar ballot papers following the loss of eight bags of mail containing the original forms.

It was discovered at the beginning of this week that 80 per cent of the voting papers had gone missing 'in the mail' before they even reached the voters.

John Pavlik, head of PR at the Academy, said that although the organisation had "lit a fire" under the notoriously inefficient US Postal Service - which was responsible for a similar sort of bungle in 1982 - only two of the missing bags had been recovered. Apparently the mail was last seen drifting around the outskirts of Los Angeles.

The distinctly unamused Mr Pavlik said he expected the Postal Service to send the new papers special delivery, and that he fully anticipated that the new ballots would be delivered today or tomorrow morning. The new papers will be in specially coded envelopes, to avoid confusion and double voting in the event that the missing ballots turn up after all.

The deadline for returning the votes is March 21, just five days before the industry's most prestigious ceremony in Los Angeles on March 26.

webTitle: Campbell hits double-century as Queensland suffer first defeat

fields.headline: Campbell hits double-century as Queensland suffer first defeat
fields.trailText: Australia
fields.body:
Australia

Western Australia's Ryan Campbell blasted 203 off 222 balls at the WACA to help inflict Queensland's first defeat of the season in the Pura Milk Cup (and at an innings and 257 runs, it was quite a defeat). Campbell dominated a first-wicket stand of 141 with Michael Hussey (33) and was later supported by Michael Dighton, who hit 182* in WA's massive first-innings total of 558 for 9 declared. Queensland folded twice in reply: they began with 173, as Brad Williams picked up 5-38, and did even worse following on, dismissed for just 128. Only Stuart Law, with 68, resisted for long. But Queensland remained top, having already ensured qualification for the final.

Western Australia 558 for 9 decl.
Queensland 173 and 128
Western Australia won by an innings and 257 runs

They will be joined in that final by Victoria, after left-arm seamer Matthew Inness took a hat-trick and returned match-figures of 11-108 in their thrashing of bottom-of-the-table New South Wales at the Richmond Cricket Ground in Melbourne. Inness began with 5-38 in NSW's first-innings 148. Then, after centuries from Matthew Elliott (101*) and Darren Berry (106 off 119 balls) had allowed Victoria to declare on 410 for 8, Inness claimed 6-70, including Shawn Bradstreet (caught), Mark Higgs (caught) and David Johnston (lbw) in successive balls. NSW had been cruising at 184 for 1, but Inness's burst hurried them out for 290. Set 29 to win, Victoria gallopped home.

Victoria 410 for 8 decl. (Laurie Harper 92) and 30 for 0
New South Wales 148 (Paul Reiffel 4-33) and 290
Victoria won by 10 wickets

Darren Lehmann gave the national selectors another reminder of his ability with 149 in South Australia's win over Tasmania at Adelaide. Lehmann's innings was part of a big SA total of 502 for 5, which also included 128 from in-form opener Dave Fitzgerald; he put on 233 for the first wicket in 51.5 overs with Shane Deitz (85). Daniel Marsh responded with 72 for Tasmania and veteran opener Dene Hills made 63, but they could manage only 337. Fifty from Fitzgerald then set up SA's declaration to leave Tassie a target of 344. Hills again made runs (50) and Michael Di Venuto chipped in with 61, but no-one played the big innings that was necessary.

South Australia 502 for 5 decl. and 178 for 6 decl.
Tasmania 337 and 244
South Australia won by 99 runs

How they stand: 1 Queensland (Played 9, Points 42), 2 Victoria (9, 36), 3 Western Australia (9, 24), 4 South Australia (9, 24), 5 Tasmania (9, 16), 6 New South Wales (9, 7)

South Africa

Matches played March 3

An innings of frightening brutality from Gerald Dros catapulted Northerns to an easy win over Griquland West in the one-day Standard Bank Cup at Centurion. Dros thrashed 105* off 86 balls, with 14 fours and three sixes; he made his runs out of 155 while he was at the wicket, as Northerns won with more than 14 overs to spare.

Griqualand West 181 for 6 in 45 overs
Northerns 182 for 2 in 30.4 overs
Northerns won by 8 wickets

Another hat-trick for another left-arm seamer: Ross Veenstra took three in three and finished with 6-34 to set up KwaZulu-Natal's seven-wicket victory over leaders Gauteng at Durban. Veenstra's hat-trick came in the last over of Gauteng's innings of 197 for 8, in which Adam Bacher scored 58, and shared a stand of 91 for the second wicket with ex-Kiwi skipper Ken Rutherford (58). But Natal were never in trouble after Mark Bruyns (46) and Doug Watson (55) put on 112 for the first wicket, and sailed home with 14 balls to spare.

Gauteng 197 for 8 in 45 overs
KwaZulu-Natal 201 for 3 in 42.4 overs
KwaZulu-Natal won by 7 wickets

Kevin Duckworth, who sounds like he should be in Coronation Street, hit 110 and shared an opening stand of 197 with Carl Bradfield (77) as Eastern Province overhauled Free State by seven wickets with two balls to spare at Bloemfontein. Free State's Andrew Gait had top-scored with 88.

Free State 229 for 7 in 45 overs
Eastern Province 230 for 3 in 44.4 overs
Eastern Province won by 7 wickets

Matches played March 5

Hylton Ackerman showed how not to pace a one-day chase in Western Province's 22-run defeat at the hands of Griqualand West in Cape Town. Set 223 to win, WP closed on 200 for 6 with Ackerman unbeaten on 78 from 97 balls. Martin Gidley had earlier scored 60 for Griquas.

Griqualand West 222 for 5 in 45 overs
Western Province 200 for 6 in 45 overs
Griqualand West won by 22 runs

An innings of 93 from Steven Pope was the basis of Border's matchwinning total of 259 for 4 in the game against North West in Potchefstroom. NW opener Gary Outram replied with 83, but Makhaya Ntini, with 3-43, kept the innings in check.

Border 259 for 4 in 45 overs
North West 234 for 7 in 45 overs
Border won by 25 runs

Former West Indian fast bowler Eldine Baptiste took 3-24 for KwaZulu-Natal but his side still went down to Eastern Province in Port Elizabeth. Chasing 231, Natal could do no better than 207, despite 55 from Errol Stewart and 54 from Bruyns.

Eastern Province 230 for 6 in 45 overs
KwaZulu-Natal 207 in 44.2 overs
Eastern Province won by 23 runs

India

Mumbai stayed top of group A in the Super League stage of the Ranji Trophy after a remarkable collapse by visitors Rajasthan. Set a massive 393 to win, Rajasthan recovered from 0 for 1 to reach 288 for 2. Then they blew it, losing their last eight wickets for 32, including their last four for just one run. Nikhil Doru made 105, Saket Bhatia 90 and Gagan Khoda 70, but no-one else reached double-figures; slow left-armer Rajesh Pawar picked up 4-93. Earlier, Vinod Kambli had struck 59 to further his claims for a return to the Test side, and Amol Muzumdar 63 as Mumbai totalled 336 in their first innings. Santosh Saxena then claimed 5-56 as Rajasthan replied with 229, before Muzumdar scored another 63, this time unbeaten, in Mumbai's second innings of 285 for 5 declared.

Mumbai 336 and 285 for 5 decl. (Sameer Dighe 64, Sanjay Manjrekar 61)
Rajasthan 229 (Gagan Khoda 83) and 320
Mumbai won by 72 runs

Big hundreds from Dinesh Mongia (179) and Vikram Rathour (158), and nine wickets for former Test offspinner Harbhajan Singh paved the way for Punjab's innings mauling of Bihar at Chandigarh. Punjab declared on 503 for 9 in reply to Bihar's 244, in which Singh took 5-69. He followed this up with 4-68 as Bihar stumbled to 239 in their second innings.

Bihar 244 and 239
Punjab 503 for 9 decl.
Punjab won by an innings and 20 runs

Saurashtra offspinner Nilesh Odedra returned match figures of 10-119 but couldn't prevent his side going down to a 235-run defeat against Uttar Pradesh in the group C game at Rajkot. Odedra took 4-56 in UP's first innings of 206, and 6-63 as UP scored 300 second time round; Mohammad Saif hit 83, and Rizwan Shamshad a run-a-ball 81. But in between Saurashtra were shot out for 118, as slow left-armer Gyanendrakumar Pandey finished with 5-39. They were left needing an unlikely 389 to win, but this time collapsed to Ashish Zaidi, who claimed 6-42; Pandey added 3-44.

Uttar Pradesh 206 and 300
Saurashtra 118 and 153
Uttar Pradesh won by 235 runs

Tamil Nadu and Orissa fought out a bizarre draw in the other group C match, in Cuttack. First TN were rescued by a last-wicket stand of 137 in their first innings between Rajat Bhatia (72) and Jayaraman Gokulakrishna (59*). Orissa responded with 195, and TN declared their second innings on 309 for 8, as Bhatia, promoted to open, made 60. This left Orissa with the seemingly impossible task of getting 442 to win. But by the time the game ended as a draw, Orissa had reached 311 for 3, with Rashmi Parida undefeated on 147. He added 174 for the second wicket with opener Shiv Das (83). TN stayed top of the group.

Tamil Nadu 327 and 309 for 8 decl.
Orissa 195 and 311 for 3
Drawn

Test batsman Vangipurappu Laxman made 109 and Ammanabrole Nandakishore 119 for Hyderabad but their game with Railways at Delhi ended in a draw as well. Devendra Singh responded with 87, and Railways were eventually set 331 for victory. They opted to bat out their overs instead and closed on 182 for 7, with Kawaljit Singh returning the economical figures of 35-16-40-4.

Hyderabad 347 (Balaji Rao 5-56) and 212 for 7 decl.
Railways 229 and 182 for 7 (Abhay Sharma 59)
Drawn

A marathon spell from veteran left-arm spinner Utpal Chatterjee helped Bengal to a first-innings lead in the draw with reigning champions Karnataka. Chatterjee, 35, toiled away for 61.1 overs for figures of 6-102 as Karnataka made 268 in reply to Bengal's 316, which centred on 129* from Syed Karim. Bengal then declared on 264 for 9, with Devang Gandhi hitting 88 and Karim adding 55*, but left Karnataka no time to get the 313 they needed for victory.

Bengal 316 (Venkatesh Prasad 4-62) and 264 for 9 decl.
Karnataka 268 and 52 for 1
Drawn

New Zealand

Auckland moved top of the Shell Trophy standings after overcoming bottom-of-the-table Canterbury at the Eden Park Outer Oval in Auckland by six wickets. Canterbury slumped to 187 in their first innings, with only AJ Redmond (72) making an impact, before Auckland replied with 285. Former Test opener Blair Pocock scored 56, and Redmond laboured through 40.1 overs for 4-72. Stephen Fleming (78) and Chris Harris (60*, including three sixes) gave Canterbury hope second time round, but Auckland had little difficulty knocking off 161 to win. Canterbury have yet to gain a point after four matches.

Canterbury 187 and 258 (Jarrod Englefield 50, Andre Adams 4-59)
Auckland 285 and 161 for 4 (Richard King 57)
Auckland won by 6 wickets

Jason Wells hit twin hundreds for Wellington in their run-loaded draw with Central Districts at New Plymouth. He began with 107 in Wellington's first innings of 438, adding 186 for the third wicket with SJ Blackmore (88). CD did even better in reply, reaching 468 as Glen Sulzberger registered 159. But Wells then feasted on some declaration bowling to spank 132* from 148 balls; Blackmore thrashed 91 from 56 deliveries with 13 fours and five sixes. The cheap runs allowed Wellington to declare on 331 for 4 and leave CD a target of 302. But a dull game ended without either side getting close to victory as CD finished on 202 for 4, with David Kelly scoring 105.

Wellington 438 (Lance Hamilton 5-106) and 331 for 4 decl.
Central Districts 468 (David Kelly 62, Craig Spearman 61) and 202 for 4
Drawn

How they stand 1 Auckland (Played 4, Points 18), 2 Northern Districts (3, 14), 3 Central Districts (4, 14), 4 Otago (3, 8), 5 Wellington (4, 2), 6 Canterbury (4, 0)

fields.headline: Lloyd-Webber to stage Bollywood musical
fields.trailText: Andrew Lloyd-Webber is to combine forces with the acclaimed Indian director Shekhar Kapur to produce a musical set in the Bollywood movie scene, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Andrew Lloyd-Webber is to combine forces with the acclaimed Indian director Shekhar Kapur to produce a musical set in the Bollywood movie scene, it was announced yesterday.

Mr Kapur, who directed the film Elizabeth and the controversial Bandit Queen, will be joined on the project by Indian composer AR Rehman, the first composer Lord Lloyd-Webber has invited to collaborate on a production.

The production, which will be called Bombay Dream, is still in its infancy but is expected to be staged in the west end of London.

Lord Lloyd-Webber and Mr Kapur have been collaborating on a movie version of the musical Phantom of the Opera, and yesterday Lord Lloyd-Webber said from Mumbai (Bombay), India, that he had been inspired after seeing a Bollywood movie, Dil Se (From the Heart) which was scored by Rehman.

"I was excited by the tunes, the dancing and the locales," he said. "I have been watching Indian films for some time and I think the Bollywood culture has a lot to offer to international audiences. There is a tremendous talent here."

Bombay Dream will tell the tale of a young man's struggle to make it in the thriving movie scene in Mumbai, which produces more films than Hollywood each year. The classic Bollywood genre movie, a melodrama heavy on romance, music and violence, is likely to transfer well to the stage.

fields.headline: ...but quite a few against
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone would make a magnificent mayor of London but as a Labour party member I couldn't possibly support him. By abandoning the party, he exposes a fundamental misunderstanding of its very nature. Labour isn't just Tony Blair and Millbank. It is also thousands of activists fighting for democratic socialism who today feel utterly betrayed.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone would make a magnificent mayor of London but as a Labour party member I couldn't possibly support him. By abandoning the party, he exposes a fundamental misunderstanding of its very nature. Labour isn't just Tony Blair and Millbank. It is also thousands of activists fighting for democratic socialism who today feel utterly betrayed.

Livingstone rationalises that the people of London have demanded his candidacy, a claim eerily similar to that made by Ramsay MacDonald when he too forsake the Labour party in 1931 for the corrupting, unprincipled heights of power.

Like many others I will work for Frank Dobson's mayoral election with a heavy heart but one that remains committed to Labour. Yes, our faith is temporarily weakened. But it is now weakened as much by Ken Livingstone's betrayal as it was by Millbank's machinations.
Ian McKay
London Imckay@rfh.org.uk

 Thank goodness for Hugo Young's intelligent and thoughtful analysis of Ken Livingstone (March 7); at least one heavyweight journalist has seen through this character. London needs a mayor who has integrity and principle. I'd put more trust in a double glazing salesman than Livingstone. The man is an egotist and I suspect the next eight weeks will prove this.
Cllr Dan Redford
Labour chief whip, London borough of Harrow
danredford70@hotmail.com

 May I ask what the current going rate is (Send me your money, says the leader of the Stuff Blair party, March 7); is it still 30 pieces of silver?
Ken Rydings
Grays, Essex

fields.headline: Lots of votes for Ken...
fields.trailText:
In May my family and I will move from Belfast to London. For some years we have been living in a province virtually guaranteed to have no effect in Westminster elections and, at present, seemingly unable to govern itself even when granted the opportunity. The prospect of further "direct rule" by a New Labour stooge as London's mayor is therefore repellent, to say the least. Ken Livingstone's candidacy offers a genuine opportunity for Londoners to resist the type of "managed democracy" that has failed us in Northern Ireland. I wish him well.
Dr James Martin
School of Politics, Queen's University, Belfast
james.martin@qub.ac.uk

james.martin@qub.ac.uk

 As a Labour party member who lives outside London, I wholeheartedly support Ken Livingstone's campaign as an independent candidate for mayor. He is the best candidate. He has the brains, experience, policies and commitment to benefit our capital city. I shall be sending him a financial contribution toward his campaign costs and urge other Labour party members to do the same.

Oh, by the way Tony, my membership number is A851098. If you wish to expel me then so be it, but first, please refund my subscription as I do not wish to fund the Dobson campaign in any shape or form.
Chris Williams
Bristol
ccc-web@dial.pipex.com

 I read Hugo Young's article (Comment, March 7) just after posting a cheque for £50 to the "Livingstone for London" campaign. I don't even live in London any more. This was my first ever political donation. I have only voted once in the last 20 years (Labour in 97).

Like millions, this was not a vote for Labour policies, but a vote to get those Tory bastards out. Ken Livingstone's campaign doesn't require millions of donations, only thousands.

Hugo Young is out of touch. New Labour is now perceived to have lost its integrity: Pinochet, trial by jury, political asylum. All politicians are evasive and manipulative. Ken Livingstone may be a liar, but at least he's an honest liar.
David Kennedy
Bath
david@providan.demon.co.uk

 The anti-Livingstone machine must be careful about playing the "dreadful GLC" card. fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Today's mayoral special begins with a word of praise to Frank Dobson for celebrating the fact that now, at last, we can put aside the obsession with personalities and get down to the nitty-gritty of policy. Take one of Dobbo's very few guaranteed pledges to the electorate of London. Should he become mayor, he promises that by 2004 four out of five London households will have access to the internet. Hats off, Dobbo! Eager to read more of his policy commitment, we make straight for Frank's own website at www.frank-dobson.org.uk - and would you believe it, Frank takes the net so seriously that the site hasn't been updated since February 16. Nowhere does it mention that Frank won the Labour ballot, let alone that Ken is running. What it does say, on the transport front, is that Frank remains utterly committed to a public-private partnership to fund the tube, and won't countenance private bonds. Thank God Frank is making such a strong early showing in the polls, or you'd begin to wonder about morale in his camp.

 You will recall how yesterday we asked Dobbo to specify the firms he had in mind that, he claimed, were having second thoughts about their plans to invest in London through fear of Ken's mayoralty. Well, Radio 4's World at One had the same thought yesterday, and rang the Dobbo camp, which couldn't name a single firm but mentioned a Sunday Times article (pulled, we discover, after the first edition) quoting "a CBI source" saying that Ken would scare off business. Mmm. But when we ring the CBI, it says: "We don't have any views on the subject," according to a press officer. "We have no evidence that companies are reconsidering investing in London depending upon who is mayor." Aha.

 Meanwhile, how interesting to note, as did my so-called rival in the Telegraph, that on the very day the paper's ultra-Blairite columnist Sion Simon raised the prospect of New Labour using Joe Louis's "you can run but you can't hide" taunt, Dobbo began to use the line himself. Ah well, let's just be grateful that Frank is distancing himself from that absurd "Tony's poodle" caricature.

 In the last couple of days, we have received an amazing number of calls from people (primarily outside London) eager to contact the Livingstone campaign, and asking for the address. It is: Livingstone for London, PO Box 20052, London NW2 5ZH.

 Dobbo's gift for mimicry stretches beyond Joe Louis, of course. He's even better at Clint Eastwood ... so here, by popular request, is that Dirty Harry speech in full. "Now I do believe I know what you're thinking. Did he fire six shots or only five? Well, in all this commotion, I can't quite recall. Sally, love, would you ring Margaret and check. What's that, dear? Five, was it? Does Tony agree? Ooooh, you amaze me, I've got one left! Now where was I? Ah yes. Ken, being as this is a Magnum .44 - or is it a .45? I'd forget me own name if it wasn't on me bus pass! Sally! would you, petal? ... a Magnum .44, the most powerful handgun in the world, you must ask yourself one question: do I feel, um, do you, er ... Sally? Salll-lllly!" Tomorrow, Frank tackles the "You talkin' to me?" speech from Taxi Driver.

 A reader in Watford reports receiving his "Now you can vote for Mayor of London" leaflet from Patsy Prescott's department of the regions. Baffled by this, what with Watford being in Hertfordshire rather than greater London, he rang the DETR to ask what the hell was going on. "Oh no, you can't possibly vote for the London mayor," a censorious voice corrected him. "You live in Watford."

 Paul Boateng has been a delight this week parroting the anti-Livingstone line to anyone who will listen. And yet, at the risk of being churlish, do we need a second Gerald Kaufman?

fields.headline: Yours sincerely
fields.standfirst: He says that the trouble with the United States is Seinfeld and an irony overload. His detractors say he peddles 'unctuous sentimentality'. Oliver Burkeman on the 25-year-old country boy who just wants to inject a little honesty back into American public life
fields.trailText: He says that the trouble with the United States is Seinfeld and an irony overload. His detractors say he peddles 'unctuous sentimentality'. Oliver Burkeman on the 25-year-old country boy who just wants to inject a little honesty back into American public life
fields.body:
Jedediah Purdy is not in his natural environment. The unassuming 25-year-old with the pudding-bowl haircut belongs in the hills of West Virginia - where he was born, raised and home-schooled on a farm - not amid the ostentatious intellectualism of Yale University. It's not that he isn't clever enough to study law at Yale: quite the opposite. It's just that the quiet passion with which he speaks of his parents' hillside home makes it plain that part of him would much rather be there than in New Haven, Connecticut, pursuing his current path - one that has seen him labelled everything from the saviour of American youth to a self-righteous moraliser, a trumped-up intellectual wunderkind and a fraud.

Literary celebrity may not be in short supply in America but, even so, Purdy seems a fantastically unlikely person to have garnered so much of it so quickly. His backwoods background hardly equipped him with the connections necessary for a stellar early career as a cultural barometer. But he made it to Harvard, penned a heartfelt manuscript, landed a $75,000 book deal with New York publishing megalith Random House and a few months later finds himself a bestselling author struggling under the burden of being anointed America's latest, and youngest, young sage.

He's spent the last three months fitting radio and television interviews into his packed law school schedule. "It's been a very disorienting time," he says. "The quantity and tone of attention paid to the book is something I suppose I might have anticipated if I'd thought about it - but I just didn't anticipate at all."

The Trouble With America, as Purdy sees it, is Seinfeld. Or, at least, that much-mourned sitcom is the most sacred of sacred cows he chooses to attack in his strikingly eloquent monograph, For Common Things. (The ultra-hip cyberculture magazine Wired and the MTV cartoon Beavis and Butthead are among countless others.) All, he argues, are symptoms of a corrosive irony stalking American culture, a detachment that is suffocating community and obliterating all hope of using politics to change the world - "an insistent flatness, a wary, ironic, sceptical stance towards all things . . . quiet refusal to believe in the depths of relationships, the sincerity of motivation or the truth of speech". In its place, Purdy argues passionately for a reinvigoration of grassroots political action, for "declaring the value of hopes we know to be fragile": trust, commitment, obligation.

It's hard to imagine a stance more out of tune with fashionable thinking. As Purdy puts it: "I stepped face first into the zeitgeist."

Saturation coverage in pillars of the US media - the New York Times magazine, Harper's, Time, the Washington Post, Salon - followed the book's publication last autumn, and Purdy has opened a rift in opinion that speaks volumes about the current preoccupations of the American intelligentsia. Veteran newspapermen and academics have grown weak at the knees, breathing audible sighs of relief at the possibility that Generation X may not be the lost cause they had feared. A glowing New York Times feature labelled Purdy the harbinger of "The New Sincerity", a "fair-haired boy who not only professes decency but exudes it from every respectful pore". Robert Kuttner, co-editor of the American Prospect, the liberal journal which first discovered Purdy, is similarly breathless. "He's the genuine article," Kuttner has said. "Modesty and astonishing talent are what make him a star. Jed walked in the door and just blew our socks off. It was hard to believe he was from Earth." His publishers have energetically encouraged the perception of Purdy as a youthful 21st-century incarnation of the American poet and natural philosopher Henry David Thoreau - and it seems to be working.

But to say that Purdy's plea for a renewed engagement with civic life has got some people's backs up would be a massive understatement. A seething Harper's review accused Purdy of "unctuous sentimentality"; the New York Observer said his book was "bloated with bombast". Salon, meanwhile, labelled him a purveyor of "intellectual fogy porn": Purdy, "in his bangs and cotton sweater with no shirt", wrote critic Caleb Crain, "has not dislodged irony with faith. He has dislodged it with sly, disingenuous, manipulative pseudo-sincerity." It was the Vancouver Sun, though, which found the best expression for the combination of naivete and condescension that seems to have riled so many people, comparing Purdy to "a Tibetan monk lecturing about wife-swapping".

In person, it's hard to believe he's capable of aggravating anyone. Far from the humourless preacher he's held to be, Purdy is compulsively self-deprecating and borders on the giggly. The bit about him never stopping talking turns out to be accurate, though.

"Something I've realised since writing the book is that it invites being read as a self-righteous series of moral pronouncements, as a declaration that I have had the good fortune to lead a virtuous and morally instructive life, and that this qualifies me to decry the failings of my contemporaries, my elders, and really anyone who comes into my sights," he says, in one of the rambling, clause-strewn sentences he employs for speaking and writing alike. "That would be obnoxious, and to the extent that that is what people took it to be, I'm in sympathy with their impulse to excoriate it."

There is some justification in the hostility Purdy has aroused. For a start, his parents weren't farmers by ancestry, but middle-class members of the 1970s back-to-the-earth "neo-homesteading" movement, and the passionate tirade against commercial strip-mining in West Virginia which forms the strongest part of the book looks a little less convincing in that light. Others have detected hypocrisy in the fact that his role model for grassroots political activism is his mother, because of her work on the Purdys' local school board - and yet she chose to educate Jedediah and his sister at home.

Then again, in the context of the current presidential campaign, a blast of Purdyesque sincerity may be exactly what is needed. If John McCain - an arch-conservative, anti-abortionist, anti-gay republican - can win the admiration of liberals simply by being authentic in his arch-conservatism, sincerity is clearly in dangerously short supply. Purdy, too (a liberal through and through, despite charges of neoconservatism) is evidently speaking to such a need. "McCain puts everyone on notice that sham candidates, like Bush, won't be sufficient - that all those despairing propositions about politics that he stands for aren't enough," he says.

One problem he hasn't had to face, though, is the mockery of his classmates. Yale law students are a high-powered lot, destined for some of the best-paid jobs America has to offer. Purdy, on the other hand, plans a career in the far less lucrative arenas of writing and environmental advocacy, and his peers see little to be jealous of. "I get a little mild teasing," he says, "but they basically just think I'm a sucker anyhow."

For Common Things is published in the US by Random House, price $20. www.randomhouse.com
