fields.headline: Sex and books and rock'n'roll
fields.standfirst: Punk poets
fields.trailText: A wag in the music press once commented that Howard Devoto - formerly of the Buzzcocks and Magazine - was the only person to emerge from the British punk scene who would ever have used the word "boulevard" in his lyrics. It can't be a coincidence that shortly afterwards the singer recorded a song with the line "down on Howard Devoto Boulevard".
fields.body:
A wag in the music press once commented that Howard Devoto - formerly of the Buzzcocks and Magazine - was the only person to emerge from the British punk scene who would ever have used the word "boulevard" in his lyrics. It can't be a coincidence that shortly afterwards the singer recorded a song with the line "down on Howard Devoto Boulevard".

Devoto probably had in mind not the LA variety of boulevard, but the Parisian, most likely of the 1860s. He was a scrupulously literary soul, and I bet the Buzzcocks song Boredom (featured on the newly released 1976 recording Time's Up) would have been called l'Ennui, except that "l'ennui - b'dum b'dum" didn't have quite the same ring. Dostoevsky references also came thick and fast: one Magazine song lamented, "I coulda been Raskolnikov but Mother Nature ripped me off."

In Britain, Devoto was the first and most unashamed in a line of what the NME called pallid young things with Penguin Modern Classics in their pockets. It may have looked arch, but for many the literary dandyism was absolutely sincere, and Devoto was not alone. What's often forgotten about early punk is how much literary Europhilia fed into the imagery, especially in the US. I seem to remember that the episode of So It Goes that introduced the Sex Pistols to British television also featured a rant from Patti Smith, name-checking a figure otherwise overlooked by punk iconography: Théophile Gautier (1811-72).

Gautier, Romantic poet turned advocate of formal perfectionism, had two characteristics that qualified him as an early new-wave icon: his enthusiasm for narcotic hallucination and his appearance at the riot on the opening night of Victor Hugo's play Hernani (1830), at which he distinguished himself as a flag-bearer of Romanticism's scandalous new spirit by wearing a pink waistcoat. Gautier's only other imprint on the British school of 1976 was when ex-Subway Sect singer Vic Godard announced his intention to write a musical based on Gautier's transvestite novel Mademoiselle de Maupin.

The mid-70s wannabohemians realised that if you needed role models to help you hone your existential pique, then the Stones, the Stooges, even Question Mark and the Mysterians weren't enough: you had to call in the literary heavyweights. The most committed lit-punks were found in New York. When Patti Smith's debut LP Horses featured the line "Go Johnny go, and go Rimbaud!", it was a signal for a generation to hit the library. For her, the blessed Arthur was foremost among proto-rock star poets: precocious genius, youthful beauty, scandalous Camden Town ménage with older lover Verlaine, poetic career curtailed for a stint of gun-running and an early death.

Other Manhattanites chose more recherché idols. Rimbaud was real, but a fictional hero was even cooler: Richard Hell, formerly of Television, shared with Devoto the cult of Des Esseintes, aesthete anti-hero of Joris-Karl Huysmans's 1884 novel A Rebours (Against Nature). Decadent indulgences apart, Des Esseintes's greatest moment is a prescient vision of theme-park culture: an abortive trip to England that finds him stuck in Paris, eating roast beef and drinking warm beer, and realising that a real visit could never equal the ersatz experience. He'd only have ended up in the Safeway queue with Devoto.

Hell's other hero was Isidore Ducasse, whose steely, delirious prose poem Les Chants de Maldoror still makes Crash and American Psycho look like soft options. The fact that, for years, no one was entirely sure who Ducasse himself was, commentators invariably conflating him with his pseudonym "Lautréamont" and his demonic hero-narrator Maldoror, made him an exemplary role model for boho rockers trying to evolve their own exotic, disposable alter egos.

Where did it go, this literary fan worship? Was it ridiculed out of existence? Perhaps it was just that the mid-70s were the last time the phenomenon could happen with any plausibility: a time when marginal or "rebel" writing had not yet been commodified and consigned to the cult literature shelves in book superstores, when a dog-eared paperback edition of Lautréamont or Gautier was as prized as a Stooges bootleg. These books needed to be dug out, and were distinctly darker than, say, Hermann Hesse, the soft stuff that was on the hippies' counter-culture reading list.

The booklet that comes with Richard Hell's newly re-released Blank Generation CD features a mugshot of Edgar Allan Poe among the collage of band photos. That sums up the spirit of the time: literary forebears as pin-ups, scrapbook heroes that people wanted to be. You could imagine Patti Smith kissing her Rimbaud picture every night, or Hell practising Baudelaire's scowl in the mirror. Poor old Gautier, though - bearded and jowly, he never quite caught on as a role model.

The Buzzcocks' Time's Up is released on Mute; Richard Hell and the Voidoids' Blank Generation is out now on Sire/Warner Bros.

In Britain, Devoto was the first and most unashamed in a line of what the NME called pallid young things with Penguin Modern Classics in their pockets. It may have looked arch, but for many the literary dandyism was absolutely sincere, and Devoto was not alone. What's often forgotten about early punk is how much literary Europhilia fed into the imagery, especially in the US. I seem to remember that the episode of So It Goes that introduced the Sex Pistols to British television also featured a rant from Patti Smith, name-checking a figure otherwise overlooked by punk iconography: Théophile Gautier (1811-72). Gautier, Romantic poet turned advocate of formal perfectionism, had two characteristics that qualified him as an early new-wave icon: his enthusiasm for narcotic hallucination and his appearance at the riot on the opening night of Victor Hugo's play Hernani (1830), at which he distinguished himself as a flag-bearer of Romanticism's scandalous new spirit by wearing a pink waistcoat. Gautier's only other imprint on the British school of 1976 was when ex-Subway Sect singer Vic Godard announced his intention to write a musical based on Gautier's transvestite novel Mademoiselle de Maupin. The mid-70s wannabohemians realised that if you needed role models to help you hone your existential pique, then the Stones, the Stooges, even Question Mark and the Mysterians weren't enough: you had to call in the literary heavyweights. The most committed lit-punks were found in New York. When Patti Smith's debut LP Horses featured the line "Go Johnny go, and go Rimbaud!", it was a signal for a generation to hit the library. For her, the blessed Arthur was foremost among proto-rock star poets: precocious genius, youthful beauty, scandalous Camden Town ménage with older lover Verlaine, poetic career curtailed for a stint of gun-running and an early death. Other Manhattanites chose more recherché idols. Rimbaud was real, but a fictional hero was even cooler: Richard Hell, formerly of Television, shared with Devoto the cult of Des Esseintes, aesthete anti-hero of Joris-Karl Huysmans's 1884 novel A Rebours (Against Nature). Decadent indulgences apart, Des Esseintes's greatest moment is a prescient vision of theme-park culture: an abortive trip to England that finds him stuck in Paris, eating roast beef and drinking warm beer, and realising that a real visit could never equal the ersatz experience. He'd only have ended up in the Safeway queue with Devoto. Hell's other hero was Isidore Ducasse, whose steely, delirious prose poem Les Chants de Maldoror still makes Crash and American Psycho look like soft options. The fact that, for years, no one was entirely sure who Ducasse himself was, commentators invariably conflating him with his pseudonym "Lautréamont" and his demonic hero-narrator Maldoror, made him an exemplary role model for boho rockers trying to evolve their own exotic, disposable alter egos. Where did it go, this literary fan worship? Was it ridiculed out of existence? Perhaps it was just that the mid-70s were the last time the phenomenon could happen with any plausibility: a time when marginal or "rebel" writing had not yet been commodified and consigned to the cult literature shelves in book superstores, when a dog-eared paperback edition of Lautréamont or Gautier was as prized as a Stooges bootleg. These books needed to be dug out, and were distinctly darker than, say, Hermann Hesse, the soft stuff that was on the hippies' counter-culture reading list. The booklet that comes with Richard Hell's newly re-released Blank Generation CD features a mugshot of Edgar Allan Poe among the collage of band photos. That sums up the spirit of the time: literary forebears as pin-ups, scrapbook heroes that people wanted to be. You could imagine Patti Smith kissing her Rimbaud picture every night, or Hell practising Baudelaire's scowl in the mirror. Poor old Gautier, though - bearded and jowly, he never quite caught on as a role model. The Buzzcocks' Time's Up is released on Mute; Richard Hell and the Voidoids' Blank Generation is out now on Sire/Warner Bros.

The Sun Arsenal are prepared to pay Parma £8m for French World Cup defender Lilian Thuram.

Leicester will gamble £5m on John Hartson, who failed a Spurs medical earlier this week.

Spurs will listen to offers for Ruel Fox and Ramon Vega.

webTitle: Dando detective's gut feeling about lone killer

fields.headline: Dando detective's gut feeling about lone killer
fields.standfirst:
He will be caught: The man hunting Dando's killer speaks for the first time
More about the Dando murder
fields.trailText: The detective leading the hunt for the killer of the TV presenter Jill Dando revealed yesterday his "gut feeling" about who was responsible.
fields.body:
The detective leading the hunt for the killer of the TV presenter Jill Dando revealed yesterday his "gut feeling" about who was responsible.

Although the 45-strong murder squad will continue working on the basis that Ms Dando, 37, was targeted by an obsessive or a contract killer, probably working with a gang, Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell said his view was that the murder was the work of a lone man.

In an exclusive interview, he said: "My instinct is that it was an individual. The lack of criminal intelligence, the confusion at the scene and the mess over the firearm and there's something not right about the bullet.

"If a criminal gang, let's say of three, were at work in Gowan Avenue [the street in Fulham, south-west London where Ms Dando lived and was killed], then there would be three times as many people behind the scenes who would know about it. Yet we've heard nothing from the underworld."

He insisted that his team was still confident of catching the man who shot Ms Dando last April despite the lack of an obvious breakthrough, and he appealed for further help to solve the case.

"I am not despondent. He will be caught. I'm a great believer. I really am," he said.

fields.headline: Britain's housing problem explained
fields.trailText:
Why all the fuss about housing?
Post-war trends have seen the depopulation of city centres, particularly in the north, as people have sought jobs in the booming south-east or a better quality of life in the countryside.
fields.body:
Why all the fuss about housing?
Post-war trends have seen the depopulation of city centres, particularly in the north, as people have sought jobs in the booming south-east or a better quality of life in the countryside.

With the fragmentation of traditional families, 80% of the demand for new housing will be for single people. However, the vast majority of houses built in the past 30 years have three or more bedrooms.

To meet demand, experts say, a huge number of new houses will have to be built in Britain, particularly in the south-east. Those living in small towns, rural communities and environmentalists fear that the countryside will be concreted over.

How many houses do we need?
Estimates differ. A report by professor Stephen Crow for the government last autumn predicted that south-east England would need 1.1m new homes over the next 20 years to prevent escalating house prices, sluggish transport (as people travel further from where they live to work) and the shift of business to mainland Europe. In contrast, local planning authorities have proposed 718,000 new homes outside London over 20 years.

The government has set a target equivalent to 860,000 new homes over the same period. It favours a five-year plan initially, for 43,000 homes a year outside London in the south-east and 23,000 a year in the capital. Development outside London will be concentrated in the Thames estuary, Milton Keynes, Ashford and, potentially, the M11 corridor near Stansted.

Is Britain going to be buried in concrete?
Since the sprawling "ribbon development" along roads at the start of the 20th century, alarmists have predicted that soulless surburbia will swallow up what is left of Britain's countryside. It has not yet, but what is alarming about current development is that it wastes land.

"We insist on building as if we lived in the American midwest or the Australian outback," says eminent architect Lord Richard Rogers, whose Urban Task Force reported to John Prescott, the secretary of state for the department of environment, transport and the regions last summer.

Over the past 10 years British builders have constructed 23 houses or flats per hectare of land, which is disastrously extravagant for a country of relatively little space. The US builds on average 40 dwellings for every hectare, as Britain's green "garden city" movement at the turn of the 20th century recommended. This compares to 60-80 housing units in a traditional Cornish village, 100 houses per hectare in Georgian cities, 200 in Victorian ones, and 400 units in modern Barcelona.

Does high-density equal high-rise?
Increasing house density does not mean the return of high-rise blocks. Taking a firmer line on the size of executive homes and private garages and stopping developers building ornate brick driveways, for instance, could make for denser housing.

Lord Rogers believes that, well-planned and built, high-density suburbs are a better use of land than the high-rise blocks, which leave too much wasted, windy space between them.

"High-density urban areas, if well-managed and planned like the Georgian parts of our cities, are attractive to live in," says Lord Rogers. Denser housing can reduce dependence on the car and create vibrant communities, encouraging "civic pride, a sense of security and social and economic integration."

What is the government going to do about the housing shortage?
John Prescott has just unveiled a raft of new planning guidance, claiming its plans will save 42 square miles of countryside, an area the size of Manchester. Mr Prescott has clearly listened to Lord Rogers. He has called for developers to build more small homes suitable for the growing singleton population, with the present density of 23 homes a hectare rising to 40.

Mr Prescott has also asked Gordon Brown, the chancellor, to impose VAT on all new house building. At the moment, no VAT is levied on building, but the full 17.5% rate is applied to the refurbishment of old properties. Lord Rogers called for VAT reform to encourage the conversion of existing buildings. The building lobby is fiercely opposed to any such move and the chancellor is thought to be sceptical.

Can brownfield development save the countryside?
Brownfield development - exploiting land already built on or used by industry - is frequently held to be the solution to bricking over the countryside. The Council for the Protection of Rural England has calculated that 8m people around England could be housed on urban derelict land if it were developed along the lines of traditional, relatively high density, London streets and squares. London has room for 570,000 new homes without claiming a single green field.

Mr Prescott wants to build 60% of new homes on brownfield sites, encouraging the redevelopment of urban wasteland, which would also rejuvenate derelict and unattractive inner cities. But this is not terribly ambitious: the latest figures show that 56% of new homes are already being built on brownfield sites.

Brownfield building may be a worthy ideal, but it could be hard to attract people to live in such redevelopments. Demand for housing in the south-east has been rising largely because people move there to find work. Many brownfield sites, in areas such as East London, are not close to places of work. Developers need incentives to build on brownfield sites as making old industrial areas fit and safe for habitation is far more expensive than bricking up virgin fields.

Is the government doing enough?
Critics of all political hues tend to argue that the government is not doing enough to change Britain's wasteful house-building culture.

Liberal Democrat planning spokesman Mike Hancock argues that VAT on home improvements should be removed to encourage developers to bring the almost 1m empty houses in Britain back into use. The Liberal Democrats recommend grants to help meet the cost of clearing up brownfield sites and a tax on greenfield development to make it the more expensive option.

The Conservatives are trying to play the "greener than thou" card. Shadow environment secretary Archie Norman responded to Mr Prescott's plans by saying: "The real challenge is to convert our inner city accommodation so that it is suitable for elderly people living alone... not to migrate people out of our cities into the country, because that means the decline of the inner cities, as well as the permanent loss of the countryside."

webTitle: Prescott green light for building boom

fields.headline: Prescott green light for building boom
fields.standfirst:
Plan approved for 215,000 new homes in south-east in next five years
Britain's housing problem explained
fields.trailText: John Prescott paved the way for a new building boom in the south-east last night by approving plans for 215,000 new houses over the next five years, alongside a further 115,000 in Greater London.
fields.body:
John Prescott paved the way for a new building boom in the south-east last night by approving plans for 215,000 new houses over the next five years, alongside a further 115,000 in Greater London.

Facing unprecedented demand for new, lower cost homes, and the wrath of countryside campaigners, the deputy prime minister tried to soften the blow with strict planning guidelines.

These will give councils powers to force builders to redevelop recycled land - so-called brownfield sites - and convert empty buildings to flats before turning to greenfield sites.

But the shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, claimed the plans - representing a 10% increase in south-east house building annually and a 22% rise in London - would lead to more congestion, threaten the countryside, and choke villages and small towns.

Mr Prescott said that by rejecting recommendations from his own advisers for 1.1m additional homes in the south-east up to 2016, in favour of regular five-year reviews, he was steering a sensible middle course and would be saving 42 square miles of countryside.

The plans represent a more cautious approach to meeting the huge demand for homes. The booming property market in central London is fuelling the crisis, coupled with the spiralling divorce rate and greater longevity.

The Council for the Protection of Rural England hailed Mr Prescott's initiative as a policy watershed and an historic breakthrough in planning policy. Tony Burton, assistant director of the council, said: "The new policy will halve the amount of rural land which could be developed over the next five years."

The key to preventing excessive building on greenfield sites - many of which are already in builders' 'land banks' - is the development of what amounts to a new 'linear city' along the Thames from Greenwich east to Dartford and the Medway. Mr Prescott is also keen to expand Ashford, in Kent, into a big new town to serve the Channel tunnel alongside further expansion of Milton Keynes in Buckinghamshire. In the longer term, building might be allowed along the M11 corridor, around Stansted in Essex.

But the House Builders' Federation, fearing that new planning guidelines might stifle development, implied that insufficient homes might be built to satisfy demand from key workers - such as teachers, nurses and police officers - currently priced out of the market. "Without providing for future generations, the continued prosperity of the region and the country as a whole will be seriously at risk."

Mr Prescott told the Commons that the balance of new housing had to move from big detached houses, and semis, to smaller homes for single people. 'Singles' would contitute 70% of the housing market over the next 20 years.

Mr Norman claimed that Mr Prescott's plan would lead to almost 900,000 new homes over the next 20 years. "No matter how hard he tries to scramble the arithmetic, nothing can disguise the sheer volume of housing being imposed against the wishes of local councils."

Mr Prescott referred to Mr Norman's period as chief of the Asda supermarket chain.

"He was the director of a company that led the growth of out-of-town shopping centres ... there was more land taken in green belts by Asda and the out-of-town shopping industry than any other development in this country."

Don Foster, the Liberal Democrat environment spokes-man, described Mr Prescott's "optimistic" targets for building on brownfield sites as "whistling in the wind".

webTitle: Al Gore makes a clean sweep

fields.headline: Al Gore makes a clean sweep
fields.standfirst: Julian Borger in Nashville describes the scene in Al Gore's home state
fields.trailText: Julian Borger in Nashville describes the scene in Al Gore's home state.
fields.body:
Al Gore yesterday turned his clean sweep seizure of the Democratic presidential nomination into a platform from which to challenge his Republican opponent, George Bush, to change the rules of political campaigning.

Amid raucous scenes in a Nashville hotel ballroom, the vice-president accepted the Democratic crown and made an offer of reconciliation to his beaten challenger, Bill Bradley, calling him "a good man I respect greatly."

Mr Gore then made it clear he would take up Mr Bradley's call for campaign finance reform - a crusade which fueled the Bradley campaign, as well as John McCain's all but crushed insurgency within the Republican Party. Admitting: "I've learned from my mistakes" - a reference to his role in questionable fundraising activities in the 1996 election - he challenged his Republican opponent to give up unregulated corporate financing and expensive political advertising, and instead engage in a twice-weekly public debate in the run-up to the November election.

The emphasis on campaign finance reform signalled the Gore campaign's urgent pursuit of McCain supporters now that the Arizona senator is no longer a serious contender. Bob Shrum, one of the vice-president's top political strategists, said last night: "A lot of McCain voters are a lot closer to Al Gore than to George Bush."

Meanwhile in New York, Bill Bradley announced that he would today start discussing the future of his campaign with his advisors and would make an announcement soon. There is little chance he will carry on, having failed to win a single primary among the 15 Democratic contests decided yesterday. "Super Tuesday" leaves him in an unwinnable position. He failed to attract "crossover" voters in anything like the same numbers as Senator McCain, and the great majority of his supporters are expected to fall in behind Mr Gore in November.

Mr Gore's decision to fly to Nashville on Super Tuesday was symbolic of his campaign's renaissance. He moved his headquarters there from the capital last October, at a time when he was dogged by the image of a stiff Washington insider, and Mr Bradley - a former basketball star and senator - was gaining ground.

The move, along with his change of wardrobe from power suits to casual polo shirts and "earth tones", was initially ridiculed in the US media, but the voters responded to the more aggressive and focused campaign style which accompanied the Gore makeover.

"It was the most pivotal moment, six or seven months before the primaries," Mr Shrum recalled. "He just didn't feel right about the campaign, and completely transformed it. It was a hard thing to change." While Mr Bradley aimed at lofty, almost ethereal rhetoric, promising a new form of politics, the vice-president busied himself securing the traditional pillars of the Democratic party: the unions, minorities, women, and gays.

Next week's cluster of primaries in the South, known as "Southern Tuesday", will now be a lap of honour for Mr Gore. He will use it to road-test a new set of speeches his staff have been crafting, which will provide the initial thrust behind his campaign against Mr Bush. Aides said the new speeches would target Mr Bush's economic inexperience and warn that his promised tax-cuts would jeopardise the economic stability created by the Clinton-Gore administration.

Mr Gore's decision to fly to Nashville on Super Tuesday was symbolic of his campaign's renaissance. He moved his headquarters there from the capital last October, at a time when he was dogged by the image of a stiff Washington insider, and Mr Bradley - a former basketball star and senator - was gaining ground. The move, along with his change of wardrobe from power suits to casual polo shirts and "earth tones", was initially ridiculed in the US media, but the voters responded to the more aggressive and focused campaign style which accompanied the Gore makeover. Next week's cluster of primaries in the South, known as "Southern Tuesday", will now be a lap of honour for Mr Gore. He will use it to road-test a new set of speeches his staff have been crafting, which will provide the initial thrust behind his campaign against Mr Bush. Aides said the new speeches would target Mr Bush's economic inexperience and warn that his promised tax-cuts would jeopardise the economic stability created by the Clinton-Gore administration.

webTitle: Gore and Bush stride to victory

fields.headline: Gore and Bush stride to victory
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush took this year's US presidential election contest in an iron grip early today, after voters in 16 "Super Tuesday" primary and caucus states rallied overwhelmingly behind the Democratic and Republican party frontrunners in the day's giant coast-to-coast ballot.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush took this year's US presidential election contest in an iron grip early today, after voters in 16 "Super Tuesday" primary and caucus states rallied overwhelmingly behind the Democratic and Republican party frontrunners in the day's giant coast-to-coast ballot.

Big wins for the two favourites left their respective rivals - Bill Bradley challenging for the Democratic party's presidential nomination and John McCain for the Republicans' - gasping for political oxygen to continue their campaigns to win their parties' endorsements to run for the presidency in November.

In front of jubilant supporters in Nashville, the vice-president saluted Mr Bradley and sought to reunite the party, declaring: "Join us now. Our campaign is your cause."

Both Mr Bradley and Mr McCain were due to spend today away from the limelight weighing their options and campaign bank balances. Mr Bradley was widely expected to decide enough is enough.

In New York, which increasingly appeared during the day to be Mr McCain's last hope of securing a momentum-giving big win to keep his Republican challenge going, the result when polls closed at 9pm local time (2am GMT) was still too close to call.

Vice-president Gore, however, was heading for a clean sweep over his rival in all yesterday's Democratic contests, including, a runaway win in New York, where Mr Bradley, a former senator, once nurtured high hopes of victory.

Mr Gore conclusively beat Mr Bradley in Georgia, Ohio, Vermont, Connecticut, Maryland, Massachusetts and Missouri - Mr Bradley's home state. The Gore victories were by margins of 20% and more.

In the Republican race, Mr Bush, the Texas governor, was locked in a closer contest with Senator McCain of Arizona. But Mr Bush was on course to win seven out of yesterday's 11 Republican primaries, including the campaign crown jewel, California. In early results, Mr Bush won easy victories in Georgia, Ohio, Missouri, Maine and Maryland.

Mr McCain could hit back with wins only in Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, and in Vermont where independents were allowed to vote in his party's primary as well as registered Republicans.

Victory for Mr Bush on such a scale would put the Republican nomination effectively beyond Mr McCain's grasp, especially because he is also trailing in the opinion polls in all nine of the coming series of Republican contests over the next week, which include next Tuesday's primary in Mr Bush's home state of Texas.

Barring an improbable turn around on the Republican side, it now seems more certain than ever that when Americans vote in November on a successor to Bill Clinton, their choice will be between Mr Gore, the vice-president since 1993, and Mr Bush, the two-term Texas governor.

All the signs yesterday were that this year's primary calendar had delivered exactly what the party bosses wanted - victories for the establishment candidates and the virtual elimination of outsiders.

webTitle: Straw fails to buy off jury rebels

fields.headline: Straw fails to buy off jury rebels
fields.standfirst: Trial by jury: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw last night failed to head off a backbench Labour revolt over his plans to curb the right to trial by jury when one of his latest concessions was denounced for making the bill worse than the original version.
fields.body:
Jack Straw last night failed to head off a backbench Labour revolt over his plans to curb the right to trial by jury when one of his latest concessions was denounced for making the bill worse than the original version.

The home secretary's boast that he had improved the measure with a series of changes to "strengthen the safeguards" for defendants fell on deaf ears. Though the criminal justice (mode of trial) bill got its second reading, MPs in all parties promised to get it blocked again in the Lords unless more changes can be made.

Mr Straw signalled a willingness to negotiate rather than be forced to get the bill through using the parliament acts in 12 months' time. "The purpose of debate is indeed to consider propositions from government and, hopefully, to improve them," he said.

It is the government's second attempt this session to push through its reform, which Mr Straw argues is aimed at saving money and delays in court.

Among those opposed was the leftwing Labour MP and QC Bob Marshall-Andrews. He said that under this bill Peter Hain - now a foreign office minister - would have been denied a jury trial in 1976 when the South African security services contrived to have the young anti-apartheid activist charged with robbing a London bank.

Nineteen Labour MPs had tabled a Commons motion demanding extra safeguards - and last night the Conservatives' spokesman, Edward Garnier, promised that a future Tory government under William Hague would repeal the "madness".

During sharp exchanges across the floor of the Commons, Liberal Democrat lawyers also joined Labour civil libertarians in accusing Mr Straw of "a complete and total volte face" that would undermine public confidence in the criminal justice system if the bill in this form were passed.

The nub of the dispute, which saw a cross-party coalition of peers throw the bill out of the half-reformed Lords, is the fear that accused people with no previous convictions will be convicted in magistrates' courts - and suffer a loss of reputation far worse than any jail sentence imposed.

Originally Mr Straw had required magistrates to consider the risk to an accused person's reputation and livelihood if a jury trial were denied on middle-ranking charges such as theft. Peers complained that this would create a two-tier system, damaging to the poor, especially racial minorities.

When Mr Straw redrafted the bill, he included a faster appeal process against magistrates' rulings and required them to state their reasons. But, to the dismay of MPs - including his Tory predeces sor, Michael Howard - he reversed the proposal on reputations and livelihoods.

Labour loyalists, including solicitors and magistrates, rallied to Mr Straw last night. But Mr Howard told MPs that it was "absolutely vital" that people of previously good character get protection as they had most to lose.

Mr Marshall-Andrews, MP for Medway, called the bill "one of the worst pieces of legislation" for many years, a home office scheme which successive home secretaries - "not one a Hampstead liberal" - had rejected until now.

fields.headline: Beware of barristers
fields.standfirst:
The police and court system still harass and belittle rape victims

International women's day: special report
fields.trailText: The police and court system still harass and belittle rape victims
fields.body:
The continuing fall in the conviction rate for rape has understandably caused concern. The reasons are highly complex. I recently looked at the processing of rape cases by conducting in-depth interviews with, amongst others, women who had reported rape, police who handled rape cases, police surgeons, crown prosecutors and barristers. There would appear to be problems at every level of the system.

One of the new myths about rape is that, since the notorious 1982 documentary which showed Thames Valley police officers bullying a woman who had reported rape, police have entirely overhauled their system.

The study revealed that this was by no means the case. Whilst some officers went to endless trouble and treated victims with great understanding and sympathy, other women seem to have been treated disgracefully. The attitudes of some police officers to rape were still highly sceptical. Moreover, in the metropolitan police area, since their procedures were overhauled in the early 1980s, the number of rapes reported has increased so dramatically that it is not clear that existing systems can cope without further funding.

Interviews with forensic medical examiners were again highly revealing. Whilst some were consummate professionals, others brought to the task attitudes that were glaringly hostile to many women who reported rape. Some would take exhaustive and irrelevant medical histories, the main effect of which was to furnish material to the defence which could be used to undermine the woman in court. Interestingly, although all were highly trained professionals and not unused to appearing in court, many found giving evidence there a disturbing and upsetting experience.

In interviews with 10 highly experienced barristers who between them had acted in hundreds of rape trials, they were asked how they set about prosecuting and defending rape cases. The barristers were clear that prosecuting rape is not easy.

It takes great skill and experience to get the alleged victim to explain in detail what happened to her. For many "complainants" this can be very painful and difficult. A number of QCs said that they were shocked at the inexperience of some of the counsel prosecuting rape cases. One QC described them as an "open target" for the defence. Another considered that the low conviction rate in rape cases was directly attributable to the level and quality of some of the people prosecuting.

One female barrister who mainly prosecuted rape cases was critical of some cases that were brought. Her main objection was to prosecuting in cases where there had been a permanent relationship between victim and accused, since she considered that unless there was extreme violence involved or it was part of a campaign of harassment it was of no consequence whether the woman had been raped or not. She said: "I feel very strongly that it's a great waste of public money to prosecute the ex-husband rape or the ex-boyfriend rape.

"I have had to prosecute an awful lot of cases where people have still been sort of seeing each other after having a relationship, where he wants it and she doesn't. Well she says it was rape and probably yes it really was. But frankly does it matter?"

Quite often female barristers were chosen to defend rape cases. As one barrister explained "A woman attacking another woman is seen by most defendants as much more of a statement than a man attacking a woman".

Barristers conceded that harassment of complainants did still happen occasionally in rape cases but all denied that they practised it. As one barrister put it: "Harassment is very bad advocacy."

They did, however, employ certain clear strategies in defending rape cases. The central strategy is to discredit the complainant. As one barrister typically explained: "You'll put your chap's facts and obviously controvert her facts. They're less important than undermining her personality. It sounds sinister but that's what you are trying to do."

Undermining of the complainant's personality was approached in a number of different ways. One leading QC said that he would, without fail, apply to the judge to permit the complainant's sexual history to be brought out in court. He commented that "juries were not very good at convicting when somebody can be depicted as a slut".

Questions might also be asked about the complainant's clothing. This extended to the clothing she was wearing at court. One barrister spoke of a case in which "the girl was basically just cross-examined because she had a miniskirt with a zip in it".

Ethical considerations seemed to play little part in the way that the defence was conducted. As one barrister put it: "When I am defending it's no holds barred."

The government has an excellent record in seeking to assist victims of sexual offences. It wasted no time in introducing the youth justice and criminal evidence act 1999. But this study suggests that defence barristers will not be deterred by its new provisions designed to control the use of sexual history evidence. On the contrary, we may anticipate that every attempt will be made to make full use of the exceptions contained in the act and to ensure their broad interpretation.

There is a further issue which the legislation does not tackle. At present the defence is at liberty to sling mud at the complainant almost with impunity. This is because rape constitutes a totally unjustified exception to the general rule that a defendant who casts imputations on the character of prosecution witnesses may have his previous convictions revealed in court. Thus the jury will frequently receive an entirely skewed picture of the respective characters of the complainant and the defendant.

The law commission is currently considering the general law relating to evidence of the previous misconduct of the accused. It is clearly of vital concern in rape cases.

Jennifer Temkin is professor of law at Sussex University. Prosecuting And Defending Rape will appear in the summer volume of Journal of Law and Society

fields.headline: Babbling of green fields
fields.standfirst:
It is no use hoping to save them all

Britain's housing problem explained

DETR: the government's housing policy
fields.trailText: To hear Archie "Asda" Norman pretending to be the friend of the green fields yesterday - when was the last time he turned down an out-of-town site? - was comic. It will not be last time an ostensibly free-market Tory, worried about votes, worships at the shrine of Nimby.
fields.body:
To hear Archie "Asda" Norman pretending to be the friend of the green fields yesterday - when was the last time he turned down an out-of-town site? - was comic. It will not be last time an ostensibly free-market Tory, worried about votes, worships at the shrine of Nimby.

Ever since Nicholas Ridley's spectacular U-turn in the mid-80s, the Tories' planning policies have lacked credibility. Labour, the party which created the new towns and the town and country planning framework, came to office with more convincing baggage. But they too have recently made a puzzling spectacle, clothing themselves in the green while extolling deregulated markets. Lord Rogers' excellent report on city regeneration has languished while John Prescott and Nick Raynsford have struggled to re-do some of the sums in what is often presented - wrongly - as the inexorable arithmetic of growth.

Yesterday the deputy prime minister presented his latest figures for the projected growth in households in the south-east. They are higher than the conference of local councils wants but lower than his department's own expert, Stephen Crow, suggested. Mr Prescott says he is no longer forcing the councils to provide; but if Kent and East Sussex do not make the provision as "guided" (and it is not, generally, for incomers, but mostly for sons and daughters of exist ing residents) he will step in - on appeal - in the time-honoured fashion by which the centre ultimately decides what is best.

Even if 60% of growth is accommodated on "brown fields" within existing built-up areas, green fields are going to vanish. John Prescott cannot just say no - unless growth in the most dynamic region of the UK, on which general prosperity depends, is to be choked off. The figures for the south-east might look less oppressive if the government had a dynamic programme of subsidising demand in Merseyside, the north-east and north-west, igniting those regional economies and attracting growth. Development in the south-east might be a lot more "sustainable" if the vague promises made yesterday about concentrating growth in existing centres such as Milton Keynes and Ashford were turned into fully-fledged plans, including the capital subsidy needed for infrastructure. The new towns showed, among other things, that an active programme of land acquisition and subsequent disposals by the state gives back to the public at least some of the proceeds of development.

Nonetheless some of those green fields will be concreted over. Mr Prescott will be held to his promise to bring an "aesthetic" dimension to land use planning and ensure there are no more wasteful and ugly Barrett-style estates.

fields.headline: The policy isn't working
fields.standfirst:
Saddam prospers while his people suffer

Iraq sanctions: the issue explained

Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: Nearly 10 years on, Saddam Hussein is finally winning the Gulf war. Western and Arab opinion, once united in condemning and reversing his 1990 invasion of Kuwait, now affords little support for the US-controlled, UN-directed sanctions regime subsequently imposed on Iraq.
fields.body:
Nearly 10 years on, Saddam Hussein is finally winning the Gulf war. Western and Arab opinion, once united in condemning and reversing his 1990 invasion of Kuwait, now affords little support for the US-controlled, UN-directed sanctions regime subsequently imposed on Iraq.

The American and British governments find themselves almost alone in defending a policy held responsible for high infant mortality, the deaths of tens of thousands of children and elderly people and, more generally, for the impoverishment of most of Iraq's 23m people. The sanctions are officially justified as the primary means of enforcing security council resolutions, particularly the demand that Iraq scrap its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programmes. But the inspections remain incomplete after the UN team withdrew from Baghdad in December, 1998. An ensuing, large-scale Anglo-American attack failed to persuade Saddam to change course. Despite a new UN resolution, the inspectors have still not returned. Meanwhile, the continuing US and British air strikes in the northern and southern no-fly zones - there have been 16 so far this year - have become a paradoxical symbol of allied impotence. Like the victims of sanctions, they are mercilessly exploited by Saddam's propagandists.

Ten years on, Saddam's envoys have succeeded in destroying the security council consensus. France has joined permanent members Russia and China in undermining Anglo-American policy. Iraq is also making steady advances in its return to the Arab and regional fold. Last month it signed a trade deal with Turkey. A Syrian interests section has opened in Baghdad and there is talk of reopening the Iraqi-Syrian oil pipeline shut since 1982. Leading Jordanians launch a pan-Arab campaign to normalise relations; this week, Baghdad's representatives will attend an Arab League meeting in Beirut. Meanwhile, the open flouting of the sanctions regime proceeds apace. Supplies, licit and illicit, for Iraq's elite flow across the land borders. Turkey is said to be illegally importing 1.1m barrels of Iraqi oil. US naval commanders in the Gulf report a sharp increase in Iraqi oil smuggling, facilitated by the Russians and the Iranians. Rising oil prices are another uncomfortable indicator of Saddam's returning strength: Iraq, after all, has the world's largest proven crude reserves after Saudi Arabia. Saddam hopes to wield this power with a vengeance one day. Some believe Washington's true purpose is to deny him this weapon; it represents a threat far more fearsome than any souped-up Scud.

Saddam's success is also one of survival, measured against the west's premature victory declaration in 1991 and its fierce but now waning determination to depose him. The Clinton administration's attempts to mobilise Iraqi opposition groups, and the CIA's covert efforts to overthrow the Iraqi leader, have at best been half-hearted. The US now seems to have almost given up trying. In a broader sense, the policy of "dual containment" of both Iraq and Iran has unravelled. Despite continuing tough posturing from its ambassador, Richard Holbrooke, the US has lost the argument at the UN. The latest resolution proposes progressively to ease sanctions after weapons inspections are satisfactorily resumed for an initial 120 days. Iraq's flat refusal to accept these conditions would at one time have quickly been squashed. Now most countries seem to sympathise with Baghdad. The new chief weapons inspector, Hans Blix, may make a difference. But while technically successful, the inspection process remains a political minefield. Meanwhile, the recent resignation of Hans von Sponeck, over the inadequacy of the UN's oil-for-food programme for which he was responsible, marked a new low. In vain do US and British officials insist that it is Saddam who is responsible for his people's agony. The finger of blame is pointed at them.

Ten years on, the struggle with Saddam has indeed become the mother of all battles. But it is clear that, infinitely difficult though it is, one more big push to cut a sanctions-inspections deal with Iraq is required. It is true that the unstated purpose of sanctions was to punish, isolate, and ultimately bring down Saddam. This policy has utterly and demonstrably failed. The human cost has been, and is, horrendous. Few believe it is morally justifiable. Even fewer believe it will ever work. But it is also true that an abandonment of the attempt to deny Iraq its weapons of mass destruction would be grossly irresponsible, surrendering the little leverage the outside world still has. It would ensure that Saddam, sooner or later, could again threaten his neighbours and perhaps western Europe. It would be a gamble with the security not only of the Middle East but of any part of the world where "rogue" dictators roam. To drop sanctions without conditions or fulfilment of security council resolutions, as Baghdad insists, would be to shatter the credibility of the UN and the ethos which has underpinned intervention elsewhere. And it would triumphantly secure Saddam at home, guaranteeing perhaps an even more iniquitous oppression of Kurds, Shia, and others who oppose him. His claims that there are no more weapons to find simply cannot be taken at face value. For Saddam is a murderous, reckless man, in all probability a psychopath, who cares nothing for others. Amid all the misery, that must not be forgotten.

So: one more big push, one more effort to find a way. Suspend the non-military sanctions now; have the inspectors return simultaneously; maintain the no-fly zones; watch carefully for dual-use technology imports; then press hard at the end, say, of a six-month trial period, for a settlement that will last. It is possible that Saddam, sensing victory, will reject even this. But we must try. It is time, finally, to end this war. For at present, we have the worst of all worlds. Saddam advances steadily and by stealth, the UN is discredited, the west divided - and the suffering goes on.

The American and British governments find themselves almost alone in defending a policy held responsible for high infant mortality, the deaths of tens of thousands of children and elderly people and, more generally, for the impoverishment of most of Iraq's 23m people. The sanctions are officially justified as the primary means of enforcing security council resolutions, particularly the demand that Iraq scrap its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programmes. But the inspections remain incomplete after the UN team withdrew from Baghdad in December, 1998. An ensuing, large-scale Anglo-American attack failed to persuade Saddam to change course. Despite a new UN resolution, the inspectors have still not returned. Meanwhile, the continuing US and British air strikes in the northern and southern no-fly zones - there have been 16 so far this year - have become a paradoxical symbol of allied impotence. Like the victims of sanctions, they are mercilessly exploited by Saddam's propagandists. Ten years on, Saddam's envoys have succeeded in destroying the security council consensus. France has joined permanent members Russia and China in undermining Anglo-American policy. Iraq is also making steady advances in its return to the Arab and regional fold. Last month it signed a trade deal with Turkey. A Syrian interests section has opened in Baghdad and there is talk of reopening the Iraqi-Syrian oil pipeline shut since 1982. webTitle: BT enters tussle over internet access

fields.headline: BT enters tussle over internet access
fields.trailText: BT leapt into the internet access fray today by offering its own low cost package, but failed to win over analysts with its response to a flurry of rival schemes.
fields.body:
BT leapt into the internet access fray today by offering its own low cost package, but failed to win over analysts with its response to a flurry of rival schemes.

BT will introduce unmetered access to an internet service provider (ISP) for frequent users and metered access for occasional surfers. It believes its SurfTime scheme has significantly lower charges than those in the US.

But analyst John Tysoe at West LB Panmure was unimpressed and warned that BT risked losing its high-spending internet customers just as the US telecommunications giant AT&T had done.

BT chairman Sir Iain Vallance denied that his company had been caught napping by cut-price offers from companies like AltaVista, the internet search engine, and NTL, the US cable group.

"One of the reasons why BT is not able to come out of the traps as quickly as we would like is because of the regulatory system under which we operate," said Sir Iain. "We are running with a ball and chain around our legs. Until that regulatory system is brought up to date we would not be able to move as quickly as we would like." BT has been criticised by government and analysts for keeping telephone charges high, impeding widespread internet use and the spread of e-commerce in the UK. AltaVista and NTL have shaken up the internet market by dropping phone charges or making internet access free.

BT set out to highlight the true cost of the headline-grabbing US deals by including the price of line rental in its packages. It cut the price of its unlimited access service to £29.25 a month (including line rental of £9.26) from the £34.99 excluding rental announced in December - a 43% reduction.

The deal is less generous than NTL's offer of free access for its telephone customers and AltaVista's plan for a one-off fee of up to £50 plus £20 a year for unmetered surfing. But BT said its plan was good value when line rental and other costs were added to the rival products.

"We want to put the focus on the complete costs of telephony," a BT official said.

Shares in BT rose on news of its internet scheme. The stock climbed as high as 1,205p after a 118p loss on Tuesday, and traded 1.1% or 13p ahead at 1,183p in morning trading with 4.5 million shares changing hands before 10am. Analysts said the stock was also supported by news that BT had won a £2.5bn contract to provide the police with a digital radio service.

BT reduced the cost of metered access to a penny per minute during the day, 0.6p in the evening and 0.5p at the weekend, with no additional monthly charges on top of line rental. All prices will apply to any internet service provider (ISP) offering dial-up to a new 0844 number, meaning users will not be forced to use BT's service. June 1 is the target date for the initiative.

webTitle: THE BEST TREASURE MAP SCENE: THREE KINGS

fields.headline: THE BEST TREASURE MAP SCENE: THREE KINGS
fields.trailText: Kuwait, 1991. Colonel Archie Gates (George Clooney) discovers a gaggle of troops huddled around a seemingly indecipherable map. He strides to the centre of the room and examines the document - which, until earlier that day, had been secreted inside an Iraqi soldier. Scrutinising it, he lifts his fingers to his nose.
fields.body:
Kuwait, 1991. Colonel Archie Gates (George Clooney) discovers a gaggle of troops huddled around a seemingly indecipherable map. He strides to the centre of the room and examines the document - which, until earlier that day, had been secreted inside an Iraqi soldier. Scrutinising it, he lifts his fingers to his nose.

"Well," Gates muses, "you know you've found the path to truth when you smell shit."

He turns to Sgt Troy Barlow (Mark Wahlberg).

"Isn't that what they say, Sergeant?"

Conrad Vig (Spike Jonze) looks nervously at Gates from the corner of his eye.

"I don't recognise you, sir. Are you in this division."

Chief Elgin (Ice Cube) glances suspiciously at the interloper.

"He's not from this division. He's Special Forces."

Unperturbed, Gates addresses the assembled troops.

"You good soldiers present this map to your commanding officer?"

"Not yet, sir" Barlow replies.

"I'll take it to him."

"That's not necessary, sir. He's my commanding officer."

Barlow tries to snatch the map back from Gates.

"Don't get grabby, Sergeant."

"He's my CO, sir. I'll have to tell him you took it."

Gates smiles slyly.

"And that won't do either of us any good, will it?"

Barlow notices Gates' expression. Realisation dawning, he smirks back.

"No, sir."

Gates gestures to the troops.

"Sit down."

See also: Raiders Of The Lost Ark, Sinbad The Sailor, Trespass, Cash And Carry

Don't see also: City Slickers II - The Legend Of Curly's Gold

Pointless trivia: George Clooney has a pet pig named Max.

fields.headline: £1.2m gift follows 'crank call' to university
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: As crank calls go it was intriguing. A wealthy American offering to make a large donation to a British university. Fearing a hoax, the person on the other end of the phone at the unnamed institution, suggested, none too politely, that he try elsewhere.
fields.body:
As crank calls go it was intriguing. A wealthy American offering to make a large donation to a British university. Fearing a hoax, the person on the other end of the phone at the unnamed institution, suggested, none too politely, that he try elsewhere.

So he did. And Glasgow university is £1.2m richer thanks to the generosity of the mysterious William R Lindsay of Las Vegas.

The unusual tale emerged yesterday after Glasgow university officials revealed that their new chair in health sector economics had been funded by a donation from a very private, very wealthy American with no apparent connection to the university, or Glasgow, or even Scotland. Not only that, he had no fax, no email, and only a post office box by way of contact.

Mr Lindsay had phoned the university's development office nearly two years ago to say he was "minded" to give some money to the institution. He asked how much it would cost to fund a professorship and was told £1.2m would cover it.

Following various correspondences between Mr Lindsay and the university, and a series of checks to ensure there were no ethical implications, the Friends of Glasgow University Society in New York received a fat cheque. The university has no idea why it was chosen by Mr Lindsay.

A spokesman said Mr Lindsay had contacted another university first but their reaction was less than polite so he went to Glasgow university instead. "I think the difference was that we handled the phone call in a professional way. They just weren't as receptive to him."

The chair will be named the William R Lindsay chair in health policy and economic evaluation.

"He didn't want any publicity at all and it was as much as we could do to persuade him to let us name the chair after him," added the spokesman.

webTitle: Soviet spy challenges freeze on his book profits

fields.headline: Soviet spy challenges freeze on his book profits
fields.trailText: George Blake, the notorious Soviet spy, yesterday challenged before the law lords a court order freezing royalties on his memoirs, 34 years after he escaped to Moscow.
fields.body:
George Blake, the notorious Soviet spy, yesterday challenged before the law lords a court order freezing royalties on his memoirs, 34 years after he escaped to Moscow.

He did not turn up in person in a case which, while sometimes appearing unreal, has widespread implications for government control of information.

His counsel, Richard Clayton, accused the attorney general of trying "very extravagantly to increase his jurisdiction" by attempting to use the civil law when he cannot pursue individuals in the criminal courts.

He said the government had conceded there was nothing confidential in Blake's memoirs, No Other Choice, and that disclosures in it had not damaged the public interest. Blake therefore did not break any duty of confidence and did not commit any serious criminal offence by writing the book.

However, the government, represented by Ross Cranston, the solicitor general, argues that Blake owes a life-long duty of confidentiality to the crown whether the information he discloses is secret or not, and that any official information disclosed by Blake is crown copyright.

Government lawyers have deployed identical arguments in the attempt to silence the former MI5 officer, David Shayler.

Blake received £50,000 in advance for his memoirs, published by Jonathan Cape in 1989. A further £90,000 was frozen after the appeal court ruled that the attorney general was "entitled to intervene ... to uphold the public policy of ensuring that a criminal does not retain profit directly derived from the commission of his crime".

The court overturned a high court judgment by Sir Richard Scott that the government's claim that Blake could not gain financially from writing anything about his work as a spy amounted to "an interference with his rights of freedom of expression".

Blake was sentenced in 1961 to 42 years in jail for betraying MI6 operations and agents abroad but escaped from Wormwood Scrubs prison four years later.

Mr Clayton said that the official secrets act made it a criminal offence for a former member of the security and intelligence agencies to disclose "any information" damaging or not.

In a separate development yesterday, lawyers acting for Julie Ann Davies, 35, the Kingston university student arrested on Monday under the official secrets act, described her as "very confused and shocked at the way she has been treated". She had been released on police bail until June.

Her solicitor Neil O'May, of Bindman & Partners, said: "The use of the draconian provisions in the official secrets act for intelligence gathering operations by the special branch is becoming more frequent.

"Given the extent to which David Shayler's allegations have been printed and discussed within the British media, it is astonishing that the police felt it necessary to deal with Julie Ann Davies in this way."

fields.headline: Ode to a road
fields.standfirst:
Author's tribute to the A272
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pieter Boogaart is used to eyes glazing over as he explains the subject of his book: the past splendours and present glories of the A272, a road which straggles for 90 miles through Hampshire and Sussex. "It has three digits in its name, that's really quite remarkable for an A-road," he says.
fields.body:
Pieter Boogaart is used to eyes glazing over as he explains the subject of his book: the past splendours and present glories of the A272, a road which straggles for 90 miles through Hampshire and Sussex. "It has three digits in its name, that's really quite remarkable for an A-road," he says.

For the past 10 years Mr Boogaart, a Dutch language teacher, has spent his holidays walking, cycling and driving every foot of the road. He has spent months in bed and breakfasts along the route, and scrambled through nettle patches and over barbed wire fences to inspect anything of interest.

His book lists every road, railway track (current and long gone) and footpath which intersects the A272, and where it is crossed by the Greenwich meridian (near Newick).

At Dragons Green crossroads in West Sussex he was able to point to a hall where the young Dirk Bogarde performed in amateur dramatics, and the oak tree un der which Pope wrote The Rape of the Lock.

Millionaires and free-range egg producers have been astounded and flattered by his interest, and welcomed him in for tea and local history. One of the few doors which remained closed belonged to the National Trust, which owns the palatial Petworth House, and its Capability Brown park.

"I knew the house was closed for the season, but I knocked on the door and asked if I could possibly see the ice house. It was snowing. The door was closed and I remained standing outside until somebody came back and said 'no', and closed the door again."

Road engineers insist the A272 is less than a century old, but Mr Boogaart remains true to his quest to prove it is a pilgrim's route from Winchester to Canterbury. He lists every Angel hotel and pub on the route as evidence.

 A272, An Ode to a Road, published by Pallas Athene, £14.95

webTitle: Tough new code on wife beating

fields.headline: Tough new code on wife beating
fields.standfirst: International women's day: special report
fields.trailText: Prosecutors must consider taking wife beaters to court even if their victims withdraw their complaints, under new guidelines on combating domestic violence published by the home office yesterday.
fields.body:
Prosecutors must consider taking wife beaters to court even if their victims withdraw their complaints, under new guidelines on combating domestic violence published by the home office yesterday.

The crown prosecution service guidance - launched to coincide with International Women's Day - advised that, while the wishes of the victim should be taken into account in any prosecution, they "cannot be the final word" in deciding whether or not to press charges.

The document also called on local authorities to evict domestic abusers.

Groups campaigning against domestic violence welcomed the guidelines and a 10-point plan for agencies tackling domestic violence announced by the home office minister, Paul Boateng.

Although home office figures suggest that one in four women will experience domestic violence at some point, many prosecutions are dropped because the victims are intimidated.

Under the new guidelines, when a woman withdraws her evidence, prosecutors must take into account factors such as whether it is in the wider public interest to pursue the case.

Mr Boateng said the guidelines were part of a package of measures aimed at tackling domestic violence.

He said: "As a result of domestic violence around 63,000 women and children spend at least one night in a refuge and one woman is dying every three days. We have a moral duty to make sure we make serious inroads in tackling this horrendous problem."

webTitle: 'Change rules' to allow more women MPs

fields.headline: 'Change rules' to allow more women MPs
fields.standfirst:
As Labour fears exodus of Blair Babes the prime minister is urged to back legislation to permit all-women shortlists

On international women's day, debate the issues with Guardian Women's page editor Libby Brooks and deputy editor Raekha Prasad live online today at 2.30 pm here
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday faced renewed pressure to change the law to allow political parties to select candidates using all-women shortlists as it emerged that, on current trends, it will take another 30 years before there are equal numbers of male and female MPs.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday faced renewed pressure to change the law to allow political parties to select candidates using all-women shortlists as it emerged that, on current trends, it will take another 30 years before there are equal numbers of male and female MPs.

The former women's minister, Joan Ruddock, launched a bill in the Commons to amend the sex discrimination act as female Labour MPs made clear they wanted to see women chosen in safe seats in selections taking place over the next few months. The Guardian disclosed last month that Mr Blair had changed his mind over all-women shortlists, and was now a convert to the mechanism.

Following a legal challenge, women-only lists were dropped by Labour in 1996, but the party is now fearful that, without positive action, there could be an embarrassing exodus of women MPs at the next general election. At least four are standing down, a number are defending highly marginal seats, and the notoriously family-unfriendly conditions at the Commons are likely to deter new recruits.

Ms Ruddock's 10-minute rule bill has no chance of becoming law, but Mr Blair has told members of the parliamentary Labour party that he would be willing to see a legal change after the general election if constituencies still proved reluctant to select women. She told MPs: "In a democracy, the elected parliament should reflect the society it represents. Over 80% of Westminster MPs today are men. Parliament must recognise its own democratic deficit."

In a letter to Mr Hague, the former women's minister, Harriet Harman, and Labour MP Anne Campbell, call on Mr Hague to repudiate proposals in a Conservative think tank report Clear Blue Water for the abolition of equal pay and sex discrimination legislation.

fields.headline: Plenty to declare
fields.standfirst:
If you want to understand woman's place in the 21st century, try looking in a box at Stansted airport. John Henshall reports

International women's day: special report
fields.trailText: Travellers who pass through Stansted airport in Essex over the next four months will be able to view a radically original touring exhibition of the work of women artists from around the globe.
fields.body:
Travellers who pass through Stansted airport in Essex over the next four months will be able to view a radically original touring exhibition of the work of women artists from around the globe. One hundred boxes, featuring a huge range of art forms, go on display from today, International Women's Day. They will remain at the airport, accessible to all visitors, until the end of June, when the curators hope to show them in London for at least a week before they travel to Athens on the next leg of their journey.

The show is called Women/ Beyond Borders (W/BB) and its British visit constitutes the millennial exhibition by the London-based Foundation for Women's Art, which was launched in 1992 as the Museum of Women's Art. The FWA persuaded the airline KLM and BAA to co-sponsor the Stansted display, and most of the boxes, which are made from pine and are about the size of a large chocolate box, are in KLM's departure lounge.

It seems fitting that these exquisitely decorated artefacts, from which explode displays of painting, sculpture or found objects (with the box as part of the artwork) should be displayed in an airport, since they have been circling the earth since their creation.

The W/BB "mail art" project was started by two American artists, Lorraine Serena and Elena Siff, at Santa Barbara, California, in 1992. Their idea was to devise a travelling show "to honour and connect women on a global, grass-roots, collaborative basis". They sent self-assembly kits to curators in 15 countries, who each invited 12 women artists to transform a box into a work of art. The pieces were first shown in Santa Barbara in 1995; now there are 400 boxes, and W/BB shows have been staged in 26 countries. The Stansted show is the first in the UK. The participating artists have agreed to give up ownership of their works for the permanent collection that Serena and Siff intend to establish in California next year. While the W/BB exhibition is in this country, a number of British women artists and women in public life will construct their own boxes, to add to an already diverse collection.

The chair of the FWA, Barbara Grundy, used to run a commercial gallery in London, and took on the job of organising the MWA/FWA at the end of last year. Since then the FWA has identified a suitable exhibition space in central London, one that is not currently used for showing art.

The FWA has not yet secured funding for a permanent space, though Grundy will oversee the preparation of a new application to the heritage lottery fund.

So far, a lack of funds has restricted the FWA to mounting about one show a year, at other people's galleries. Previous exhibitions have included the work of the tragic and neglected Cynthia Fell, who died in a psychiatric hospital in 1977 aged 44.

An earlier show highlighted the work of Charlotte Salomon, a Jewish artist working in wartime Europe who entrusted her "visual autobiography" of 1,300 gouaches to a French friend before she was killed by the Nazis at Auschwitz in 1943, aged 26.

Grundy describes the W/BB project as "an example of women at the end of a century of intense change, showing solidarity with one another and looking at where we've got to in relation to our role and place after decades of struggle". The result is an exhibition of masterly creativity and admirable resourcefulness. That doyen of box art, Joseph Cornell, would no doubt approve.

Women/Beyond Borders is at Stansted airport, Essex, till late June. The W/BB website is www.womenbeyondborders.org. The FWA is at 0171-251 4881.

webTitle: BT under siege as web use takes off

fields.headline: BT under siege as web use takes off
fields.standfirst:
Free internet access: the issue explained

The key players
fields.trailText: Just over four years ago Tony Blair stole a march on the Tory government by announcing plans to link thousands of schools, colleges and hospitals to the internet. His chosen vehicle was British Telecom.
fields.body:
Just over four years ago Tony Blair stole a march on the Tory government by announcing plans to link thousands of schools, colleges and hospitals to the internet. His chosen vehicle was British Telecom.

Yesterday, in a clear dig at his erstwhile ally, the prime minister urged BT - and others - to bring the cost of internet access down to US levels, in a reprise of the attack by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, on the former state monopoly.

The chancellor's demand that BT open up its local network to cheaper, faster suppliers helped wipe billions off its market value. BT feels under siege: from the government, the city and its competitors.

Yesterday the company defended itself against this barrage of criticism, claiming it is developing products that are competitive and will lower the cost of connecting to the internet. But the City believes that BT, which claims to have 2.5m online customers already, will be forced to adopt more radical change.

Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, a stockbroking firm, said the move towards free internet services would force suppliers such as BT to offer free voice connections - much as in the US, where local calls are free. This would severely dent BT's revenue.

Steve Thorpe of the Telecommunications Users Association said: "I would expect to see BT alter its position. It wouldn't want to be left out of this with a package that could be seen as old hat."

But a BT spokesman denied the company faced pressure from government and industry. "We've got no beef with the government. We are pretty much at the forefront of this and in what we are offering people," he said.

BT has an internet package priced at £6.99 per month that offers customers a flat rate and unlimited access at night and at the weekend. It is also developing a package called SurfTime for users to surf the net on an unmetered basis for £34.99 a month plus VAT.

The onslaught of service providers such as Freeserve, AOL UK and AltaVista which offer free unmetered access, threatens BT's internet market share, said Doug Wight, an analyst at Commerzbank AG.

"I think the competition will bring down prices in parallel with the US," said Mr Wight, who predicted that the emergence of faster internet connections in the next year would lead some customers to prefer metered access to the web rather than a monthly fee.

Government dissatisfaction with BT's internet charges comes at a bad time for the company. It has been overtaken by European former state monopolies and is considering a management shake-up and the float of businesses such as Cellnet, its mobile phones network, to boost its value. Probably not something Mr Blair contemplated when in opposition.

webTitle: Harman sets out to rally female vote

fields.headline: Harman sets out to rally female vote
fields.standfirst: International women's day: special report
fields.trailText: It is Opportunity Women day for Rotherham Labour club and the town's female activists are discussing leaflet delivery. One sixtysomething campaigner, fresh from a stint pounding the driveways, offers a tip for those fearful of lurking dogs: "Wrap your leaflet round a wallpaper stripper and poke it through the letterbox - that way you don't get bitten and the dog gets a right surprise".
fields.body:
It is Opportunity Women day for Rotherham Labour club and the town's female activists are discussing leaflet delivery. One sixtysomething campaigner, fresh from a stint pounding the driveways, offers a tip for those fearful of lurking dogs: "Wrap your leaflet round a wallpaper stripper and poke it through the letterbox - that way you don't get bitten and the dog gets a right surprise".

The Labour women of this South Yorkshire town are not to be trifled with. Rottweilers do not scare them, and neither do Alastair Campbell and the party men at Millbank.

"With the demise of coal and steel, women are often the only family breadwinners," observes Rotherham MP Denis MacShane. "There is real strength there - with the miners' strike they held the community together."

It is this spirit which lures Harriet Harman, former minister for women, from London intent on retaining their services to secure the female vote to ensure a second Labour term. But the ladies of the heartlands make clear they are as sceptical as their menfolk over dictats from the party machine. Norma Hill, chair of the local district party and of the women's forum in Wentworth constituency, is one among many voices raised against Millbank spin doctoring. "Sometimes they spin and you believe it and then very often you find they are not exactly sincere," she confides after Ms Harman has been applauded and presented with a Rotherham commemorative coffee mug.

Tony Blair, she accepts, is "good for the party" in that he will help it retain power after 18 years in the wilderness. "But I think he is forgetting, while he reaches out to Middle England, that the heartlands of Yorkshire have voted for him for a long, long time. We have always been solid Labour, all these years. And if he forgets us, we might forget him."

Helen Wyatt, a lifelong party member who met her husband at a CND Young Socialists meeting, also puts no trust in Millbank. "I would not be the one to talk us out of a second term. But you will find there is a great difference between spin doctor politics and the politics in this room."

Ms Harman, ousted as social security secretary and women's minister in Mr Blair's first reshuffle, is embarking on a series of visits to women activists after convincing Labour election strategists that the party must return to its pre-97 efforts to attract women voters if it is not to see new converts stay at home or swing back to the Tories. The party, fearful that disillusion in its heartlands could see swaths of core voters staying at home on polling day, hopes that a direct appeal to women could help turnout and reassure doubters on family issues.

But the women of Rotherham, who put their local MP firmly in his place at the lunch with a badge reading "Denis MacShane - Token Man", are sceptical of Ms Harman's call for positive action to help win more female MPs.

"Those Blair Babes I find very offensive," says Ms Wyatt. "They got in on all-female shortlists: they never put in the graft like women here have done." Younger women are no longer as willing to put in the hours for the party, the older activists agree. "I remember leafleting up one of the steepest streets in Rochdale at six months pregnant," says one veteran party member. "You don't get that commitment now - women are working and they've no time."

But Ms Harman, selling the message that gender issues matter more to women voters and activists than any north-south row, departs with more than merely her centenary mug.

Rotherham's activists are strongly behind much of Labour policy affecting women, universally supporting government moves to improve work-home balance, and to provide more childcare and money to pay for it.

And, while they are ready to take on the spin doctors, there is a strong streak of pragmatism. "We may complain as much of the men who want their jobs and the old days back," says one. "But when it comes to it, we are adapting better to the new jobs - and to the new party too."
