fields.headline: Direct hit
fields.standfirst:
Unions wage online campaign against privatising air-traffic control

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Three unions yesterday launched what they claimed to be Britain's first internet-based campaign to persuade the government to drop its £1bn privatisation of air-traffic control.
fields.body:
Three unions yesterday launched what they claimed to be Britain's first internet-based campaign to persuade the government to drop its £1bn privatisation of air-traffic control.

They urged tens of thousands of air travellers and others to hit their website, www.safeskies.co.uk and email John Prescott in favour of a non-profit making public corporation or trust to run air traffic control (Nats).

Paul Noon, leader of IPMS, the air traffic controllers' union, said: "80% of the general public don't favour privatisation and we want them to say this clearly to John Prescott using this unconventional method: you're not on, John, dot.com."

The unions, including the PCS, which represents support staff, and Balpa, the pilots' union, hope to provide evidence of a huge number of hits to the deputy prime minister before the transport bill returns to the commons at report stage after Easter.

The government plans under the bill to sell off 51% of Nats but the unions claim this would jeopardise the safety of the skies be cause the private sector would be forced to cut costs, including staff, to maintain profit margins.

Mr Noon said the travelling public would also pay because this would force up the price of tickets as airlines passed on their own increased costs.

It would be far better for the government to reallocate some or all of the £700m a year raised through to investing in Nats. The government says air-traffic control needs £1bn spent on it over the next 10 years.

Barry Reamsbottom of the PCS said the chancellor, Gordon Brown, already had a big enough surplus to invest in Nats and the London Underground without recourse to the private sector.

fields.headline: Aegis adds to team
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Aegis, the media services group, has snatched Andrew Burke from News Corp to help establish its internet investment venture with EM Warburg Pincus & Co.
fields.body:
Aegis, the media services group, has snatched Andrew Burke from News Corp to help establish its internet investment venture with EM Warburg Pincus & Co.

Mr Burke was the chief operating officer of News Corp's eVentures.

The internet investment firm, eEverger will be owned jointly by Aegis and Warburg, with a plan to invest $100m (£63m) in 15 internet start-ups over 18 months. The start-ups will be focused on developing online marketing services that Aegis will be able to integrate into its core business.

Aegis yesterday also revealed a 26% increase in pre-tax profit to £64.6m before goodwill, amortisation and the profit from the disposal of France's Consodata.

Aegis also confirmed it had acquired Hong Kong-based Asia Market Intelligence Group for an initial cash injection of £15m and a 35% stake in European market research group Ipsos Access Panels for £2.7m.

webTitle: Why are troops not mending the roads?

fields.headline: Why are troops not mending the roads?
fields.standfirst:
The role of the foreign soldiers now in Mozambique is unclear

Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: The first American troops arrived in Mozambique yesterday amid growing doubts about how more than 1,000 soldiers from at least six countries are going to contribute to the rapidly expanding relief effort.
fields.body:
The first American troops arrived in Mozambique yesterday amid growing doubts about how more than 1,000 soldiers from at least six countries are going to contribute to the rapidly expanding relief effort.

While the influx of dozens of helicopters and planes has met an urgent need by delivering food and other aid to at least 250,000 flood victims, some UN officials and aid workers believe military expertise should also be used to rapidly rebuild Mozambique's devastated roads and railways.

The US commander, Major General Joseph Wehrle, denied his mission was too late. Even though flash floods devastated large areas around the Limpopo and Save rivers 10 days ago, the general said the Clinton administration did not give the Pentagon the go-ahead for the relief mission until Friday; and South Africa, a rear base for the Americans, did not grant them landing rights until the weekend.

But Mozambique's former first lady, Graca Machel, now the wife of Nelson Mandela, added her voice to the criticism of foreign governments' slow response to the crisis.

"It seems the world has no conscience when it comes to human life," she said.

At least 1,000 foreign troops have either arrived in or are destined for Mozambique, but it is not clear what the bulk of the soldiers will be doing.

Hundreds can be seen milling around the tarmac at Maputo airport with mountains of kit. However, while most of the German, Spanish, American, British, French and Portuguese forces include specialists such as medics, there appeared to be a shortage of expertise in some of the areas crucial to the relief operations.

Engineers, for example, would be particularly welcome given the large numbers of bridges and roads washed away by the flood waters, the force of which also buckled railway lines.

Aid workers have been asking for some days why foreign armies, with their bridge-building skills, are not also being directed to rebuild the roads and railways, which would allow better aid distribution. The road north from Maputo to the devastated town of Xai-Xai and on to Beira is breached in several places.

The World Food Programme's (WFP) deputy executive director, Namanga Ngongi, said rehabilitating overland transport should be a priority. "Food delivery by air is very, very expensive. If we can move some by road, we can save money and reach more people. This is why we need to accelerate road repairs as the waters recede," he said.

At the moment, reconstruction of the roads is being left to gangs of unskilled Mozambican workers, equipped with shovels and sandbags.

Fresh rains began falling on Maputo and some of the flooded areas yesterday, with forecasts of a heavier downpour to come. The UN is discouraging people from returning to their homes in the stricken areas because of the risk of further flooding.

Aid workers also fear a serious outbreak of disease caused by corpses and animal car casses, and a shortage of clean water. The World Health Organisation warned that reports of malaria had "risen sharply" and that people are increasingly at risk from cholera.

The WFP estimates that it will have to feed some 650,000 Mozambicans, most of them for at least six months. But how long international food aid will be depends on whether the country's farmland drains in time for the planting season, which begins in three weeks. If not, many people could be reliant on aid for 10 months.

The combined foreign aid pledge from at least 16 western and African governments has risen to more than $100m, including emergency relief and money for long-term recon struction. Washington is also proposing greater debt relief for Mozambique.

But Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, yesterday pleaded for more assistance: "Let me appeal to the whole world to give them as much help as possible, and as soon as possible," he said.

fields.headline: B&B links with Alltel
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bradford & Bingley building society has announced a link-up with US telecommunications and IT company Alltel.
fields.body:
Bradford & Bingley building society has announced a link-up with US telecommunications and IT company Alltel.

The two have teamed up to provide hi-tech mortgage processing services and systems support for lenders in Britain and across Europe.

The new company will initially focus on B&B's mortgage business and is expected to improve customer service and drive down costs by making use of Alltel's "leading-edge technology", a spokesman said.

Alltel, America's biggest mortgage processing firm, is a Fortune 500 company with a market value of $30bn (£19bn).

fields.headline: Orange makes big licence bid
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The second day of bidding for third-generation mobile telephone licenses ended yesterday with Orange taking the lead as the highest bidder, offering some £186.7m for the single licence being targeted by its parent company, Vodafone AirTouch.
fields.body:
The second day of bidding for third-generation mobile telephone licenses ended yesterday with Orange taking the lead as the highest bidder, offering some £186.7m for the single licence being targeted by its parent company, Vodafone AirTouch.

The bidding moved slowly in the second day of the auction as the prices offered for each of the five licences inched only slightly higher than those set as reserve levels.

Orange put in the highest offer on licence B at £186.7m, followed by Vodafone, BT and the Virgin-led SpectrumCo consortium, which each offered £185.4m. Licence B is the largest of the four licenses for which the existing mobile phone operators can compete.

Industry observers are bemused by Vodafone's strategy, given that it is selling Orange later this year as part of the conditions of its acquisition of German-based Mannesmann.

If Orange - Britain's third largest mobile carrier - fails to win a licence, it would affect the sale price Vodafone would achieve for it.

But some analysts believe Orange could yet be sold to a new entrant in the third-generation mobile market.

NTL Mobile overtook Canadian cellular group TIW in the battle to win licence A, which is reserved for new entrants.

NTL bid £178.5m against TIW's £170m. Telefonica, 3GUK and One2One emerged as the highest bidders for the remaining three licences.

The auction of the operating licences - which will run on the universal mobile telecommunications system - are expected to raise as much as £5bn for the treasury's coffers.

The licences are due to come into effect in 2002.

webTitle: Archer returns, with more neck than a giraffe

fields.headline: Archer returns, with more neck than a giraffe
fields.standfirst:
Parliament: special report
>The fall of Archer: special report
fields.trailText: On my way to the Lords to attend the debate on their future, I stopped to pick up one of the guides printed for tourists from exotic lands - the latest being in Welsh.
fields.body:
On my way to the Lords to attend the debate on their future, I stopped to pick up one of the guides printed for tourists from exotic lands - the latest being in Welsh.

Apart from learning that the woolsack is y sach wlan , and that the LibDems are the democratiaid rhyddfrydol , I discovered that the lord chancellor, Derry Irvine, is known to his Welsh subjects as Arglwydd Ganghellor .

The Great Lord Gangler! What a title! I watched him with increased reverence, as he gangled around in his pocket, appeared to pull something out of his ear and put it in his mouth, then gangled inside his wig, rummaging round as if trying to find a small woodland creature that had got lost.

I was so wrapped up in this display that I failed to spot someone who had slipped unnoticed into the chamber, and was sitting behind him on the steps to the throne - not just on the steps, but bang in the middle in front of the throne, in such a position that if Her Majesty were in place, she would be able to kick him swiftly and painfully in the kidneys. Jeffrey Archer was back.

Only four months after what we assumed to be the terminal disgrace of his career, he was there, among his colleagues in what is nominally still our upper house, not just listening in a concerned, sage sort of way to the debate, but - given that he can no longer sit with the Tories, having been expelled from the party - in the most prominent position the whole chamber has to offer, short of perching on y sach wlan itself.

I have seen giraffes with less sheer neck than Archer. Short of his asking the Queen to pretend she would have dinner with him, I cannot imagine a greater display of nerve.

Unless, perhaps, it was Lady Jay's speech on the reform of the house itself. They were discussing the royal commission report. The government wants an appointed house, but with a few - a very few - elected members.

Now we know the real reason, which is that if you start letting the electorate decide who represents them you get all kinds of non-New Labour riffraff: look at the vote for London mayor. But nobody can say this in public.

Instead Lady Jay announced gravely: "Any proposal totally to elect the second chamber, under the mistaken view that it would increase the democratic base of parliament, would in fact undermine democracy."

This was breathtaking enough. But, perhaps fearing a barrage of rotten fruit and eggs from the benches opposite, she felt she had to explain things more fully. If the house were elected, she said, "perhaps on a different franchise, the clear voice of the people would be obscured, and perhaps paradoxically, democratic responsibility weakened".

I sat slack-jawed through this rococo example of sophistry without sophistication. Lord Strathclyde, the Tory leader, confined himself to saying that he wanted more voting. "We do not think there is anything to fear in an election." What a wonderful turn-up: a hereditary Tory peer telling a Labour government that they should trust the people more. I truly never thought I would live to see it.

As soon as Lord Strathclyde finished, peers - including "Lord" Archer - disappeared, which was a shame since they missed a good speech by the democratiaid rhyddfrydol leader Bill Rogers. He said he had been promised that, if his party co-operated with the government, they would get more peers.

Lady Jay, clearly baffled by this revelation and perhaps out of the government loop, demanded to know who had told him. Lord Rogers said that, to spare her blushes, he would not say.

Beside her, staring into space, a look of truculent innocence on his face, Lord Irvine sat, happily gangling away to himself.

webTitle: X-box console to take on top players

fields.headline: X-box console to take on top players
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft is expected to launch its X-box games console on Friday, ending speculation about its entry into the games and set-top box market dominated by Sony's PlayStation and Sega's DreamCast.
fields.body:
Microsoft is expected to launch its X-box games console on Friday, ending speculation about its entry into the games and set-top box market dominated by Sony's PlayStation and Sega's DreamCast.

Microsoft chairman Bill Gates is to announce the unit at the Games Developer Conference in San Jose, California, on March 10, and executives from Microsoft's home and retail and games divisions are to brief British analysts in London on Thursday.

Analysts see the X-box as a way of Microsoft reducing its dependence on PC-based revenues.

The games and PC markets have been awash with rumours as to what the specifications of the console will be; the consensus emerging appears to be that it will be a video gaming console that plugs into TV sets with high speed internet access, some personal computer hardware such as a hard disk drive and possibly a DVD player.

"The X-box is likely to try to be all things to all people, aimed squarely at the set-top box market and positioned for converging media," said Nick Gibson, a Durlacher games analyst.

fields.headline: Microsoft talks peace
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: An influential Wall Street analyst indicated yesterday that Microsoft wanted to reach a swift settlement of its anti-trust battle with the US government.
fields.body:
An influential Wall Street analyst indicated yesterday that Microsoft wanted to reach a swift settlement of its anti-trust battle with the US government.

Rick Sherlund, technology analyst at Goldman Sachs, said in a note to investors that the settlement talks with an independent mediator "may be heating up as we near the end" and he was "hopeful" that an agreement would be reached.

He predicted that such a settlement would lift the group's share price, which has been depressed by the legal battle in the past two months. Shares in Microsoft rose 6% to more than $96 at midday yesterday, valuing the company at more than $500bn (£323bn).

Mr Sherlund, who helped take Microsoft public 13 years ago, issued the note after a meeting with Microsoft's new chief financial officer. In it, he stressed that "management appears very focused on settling the [Department of Justice] lawsuit" and "there appears to be a flurry of activity on the settlement front".

However, he warned that Microsoft would not comment on the state of the talks and suggested the company had ruled out "any self-imposed break-up". Such a refusal has been at the heart of disagreements in the legal dispute.

Government lawyers have indicated that the extent of the company's monopolistic be haviour demands a structural remedy. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson is expected to publish his findings in the next month or so. Any sign of a breakthrough in the settlement talks, being conducted by an independent mediator, could delay this judgment, however.

Other analysts have also suggested that the severity of Judge Jackson's earlier ruling against Microsoft could encourage the company to concentrate on an appeal. George W Bush, the presidential front runner for the Republican party, has voiced opposition to the anti-trust case.

The analysis by Goldman Sachs also offered a bullish revenues outlook for the company. In his meeting with the bank, John Connors, Microsoft's new chief financial officer, said March sales were likely to return to double-digit growth partly because of the launch of Windows 2000 and receding millennium bug fears.

Microsoft also announced yesterday a strategic alliance with NDS, which provides software for digital set-top boxes. Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation owns 80% of NDS. The London-based software group is likely to be one of the companies included in the sell-off of satellite operations being considered by News Corp. Microsoft has been in talks with News Corp about buying a stake in the satellite business.

Abe Pele, chief executive of NDS, said yesterday that there had been no discussions involving Microsoft taking a stake in NDS. He said that the two companies would work together on improving digital televisions for clients.

"Microsoft's adoption of NDS's open system solution for enhanced television will be a major boost to the industry as it builds momentum throughout the world," he said.

Under yesterday's agreement, Microsoft and NDS will pool marketing and engineering resources in development of digital television products.

 Microsoft is supplying "boxes and boxes" of documents to the European Commission's inquiry into the Windows 2000 operating system, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

fields.headline: Don't believe a free munch
fields.trailText: Walker's crisps "free" books for schools campaign was deemed such a success, they have repeated it. It was certainly successful for Mr Walker, whose sales reached record levels; schools were pleased with their new books and the government was delighted it didn't have to pay for them. But what about the children?
fields.body:
Walker's crisps "free" books for schools campaign was deemed such a success, they have repeated it. It was certainly successful for Mr Walker, whose sales reached record levels; schools were pleased with their new books and the government was delighted it didn't have to pay for them. But what about the children?

After munching their way through a mountain of crisps, to compete with other schools for the most tokens, their salt intake goes through the roof but they still have to read the Daily Mirror and gorge on McVities biscuits for maths equipment. The children then shop at Tesco for computers and wash it all down with Pepsi-Cola, who are sponsoring jotters covered in their logo. Not only are the Pepsi "jazzy" jotters imprinting consumer products on the children's subconscious minds, they are a distraction to the serious studies the jotters are intended for.

Children for whom the novelty has worn off are being bribed by some teachers with school trips for providing more tokens, but kids are always enthusiastic about collecting things: when Blue Peter appeals for milk bottle tops for an incubator, they are inundated by a tidal wave of tin foil. But this is not about recycling waste products for humanitarian causes; it is about corporate management in the boardroom with their laser pointer aiming at increased profits from subliminal advertising in the classroom.
HWM McKinlay
London

fields.headline: Queuing up to leave
fields.trailText:
So asylum seekers wait 13 weeks for their case to be processed (Tougher rules for refugees delayed, March 7). They are very lucky. Non-asylum seekers are now waiting up to eight months for simple visas. It seems that immigration administration can work efficiently for hijackers, boxers who are convicted rapists, war criminals and even pets. But not for people whose only offence is to marry a British citizen.
Dr Chris Williams
University of London
c.williams@ioe.ac.uk

fields.headline: Bum notes
fields.body:
Anybody who wonders why this country is so far behind most of the industrialised world in so many areas, should have been at the Albert Hall on Monday night for the Celebration Of Prep Schools Music, to mark the millennium. The music ranged from 1540 right up until the Dambusters March. No Bernstein, no Gershwin, no Beatles or Simply Red or Robbie Williams. In fact, nothing that 99% of the 1,000 children present have any real interest in or will take with them into the new century. As usual, the middle classes are at their happiest looking back.
Harvey Silver
London
harsil@lineone.net

fields.headline: Net sets a legal challenge
fields.body:
Your leader (March 7) on some of the implications of the regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill was wrong on one important count: there is no presumption of guilt. Before a person might be convicted of failing to produce for the police the necessary key to decrypt an encrypted file, a jury has to be convinced that the person concerned was in possession of that key. A jury would therefore be invited to conclude that the person's failure now to produce the key was simply an attempt to avoid disclosing the content of their encrypted messages or files. However you then go on to bemoan the fact that, for example, paedophiles who did exactly that might get away with only a two-year jail sentence for failing to produce a key to decrypt their files "instead of the long stretch they deserve". The fact is that, if the police do not have the means of decrypting the pornographer's files there would be no prosecution at all because there would be no evidence . The truth is that the internet in general, and encryption technologies in particular, are generating new challenges to all sorts of laws. New solutions are needed: if they do not work as intended they should be scrapped but sitting back hoping for someone else to come up with the perfect technological solution that will still fit cosily with the norms of a pre-internet age will please only the new class of techno- criminals.
John Carr
London
johnc1912@email.msn.com

fields.headline: Charity staff who face jail
fields.trailText: I, too, am a manager of a drop-in day centre run by the local branch of a national charity (Anti-drugs chief led double life as dealer, March 2). Many of our clients are users of illegal drugs, and I cannot give a cast-iron guarantee that dealing could not occur in our premises. Including me I have a full-time staff of three, supported by volunteers, certainly not enough to keep all public areas of our premises under observation at all times, let alone private areas such as toilets.
fields.body:
I, too, am a manager of a drop-in day centre run by the local branch of a national charity (Anti-drugs chief led double life as dealer, March 2). Many of our clients are users of illegal drugs, and I cannot give a cast-iron guarantee that dealing could not occur in our premises. Including me I have a full-time staff of three, supported by volunteers, certainly not enough to keep all public areas of our premises under observation at all times, let alone private areas such as toilets.

Such glib solutions as CCTV or a sniffer dog (plus handler) to check each person as they come in are, quite frankly, laughable. What does it cost to employ a trained dog plus handler? Yellow Pages has an unexplained omission in this category. For a charity dependent on niggardly local authority and central government grants both would be out of the question, financially. In either case such draconian measures would only succeed in driving away the very clients that we wish to, and in some cases actually do, help.

So in the meantime, in addition to the normal stress we live with every day, we now have to face the possibility that the next unknown who walks through our door may be an undercover police officer whose activities may result in a jail sentence for me and my staff.
AM Robertson
Hounslow, Middx

webTitle: Serbs opt out of UN council in Kosovo

fields.headline: Serbs opt out of UN council in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Despite pleas from the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, and the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, the leaders of the Serb moderates in Kosovo again failed to take their seats alongside the Albanians in the UN-led administrative council yesterday.
fields.body:
Despite pleas from the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, and the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, the leaders of the Serb moderates in Kosovo again failed to take their seats alongside the Albanians in the UN-led administrative council yesterday.

Bishop Artemije and Father Sava Janjic, two senior local churchmen who represent Kosovo Serbs and who helped found the Serb National Council, returned from Washington at the weekend after confirming that - unlike the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic - they favour close cooperation with the UN administration in Kosovo.

"But we must be able to report some progress in getting Serbs back to their homes before we take part," Father Sava said. "Milosevic's influence among Kosovo Serbs is growing stronger day by day. We must have something done urgently if we want the survival of the Serb National Council, but as the situation [has] worsened, with an organised attempt to drive Serbs out of Kosovo, our position has weakened."

Although the two men are not yet ready to take their seats with the UN-orchestrated council, Father Sava did hint yesterday at the possibility of a compromise, if invited.

"We could attend the administrative council as observers, and participate more or less, though not officially," he said.

webTitle: Counting the cost of UN sanctions

fields.headline: Counting the cost of UN sanctions
fields.standfirst:
People eke out a living in Baghdad, a city of power cuts, sweltering heat and spiralling poverty

Iraq sanctions: the issue explained
fields.trailText: The road to Baghdad was completed just before the 1990-91 Gulf war. Today, not a scratch mars the 340-mile highway from the Jordanian border to the capital of Iraq, a country which has been living under sanctions for a decade.
fields.body:
The road to Baghdad was completed just before the 1990-91 Gulf war. Today, not a scratch mars the 340-mile highway from the Jordanian border to the capital of Iraq, a country which has been living under sanctions for a decade.

Baghdad is a sprawling, flat city. The absence of high-rise buildings is partly explained by 20 years of conflict (first with Iran, then with Britain, the United States and their allies following the invasion of Kuwait).

The hotel balcony overlooks a landscape of green trees and dun-coloured homes - and of United Nations flags atop many buildings.

The UN plays a complex role in this country: part sanctions-manager, part provider of humanitarian aid in an attempt to alleviate the consequences of the sanctions for 22m Iraqis.

Saddam, sanctions and suffering seem to be all the news fit to print. Yet there are other stories, of ordinary people getting on with life, of writers and artists changing the shape of their world.

It is not easy being an intellectual in Iraq. Many writers have sold their libraries to survive. A street in the Souq used to be full of antique books. It is now occupied by stationery stores. It is not clear who can afford the stationery - certainly not government departments, where everyone carefully conserves and uses the other side of printed pages.

Close by, Al Mutannabi Street hosts an open-air book market every Friday. Old books and magazines line the pavements. You can see where the clock has stopped. There are few books from the 1990s.

But the sense of humour that helps Iraqis cope is never far from the surface.

Many personal libraries sold over the past decade included books dedicated by authors to their friends. Authors often stumble across signed copies of their books on sale on Al Mutannabi Street, and then take their friends to task.

One Iraqi bought a large number of signed copies from the market and organised an exhibition: "Books Dedicated and Sold".

There is a serious debate about development in Iraq. At a workshop convened last month by the Beitul Hikma thinktank, economists and social scientists discussed the indices used by the UN's annual global human development report, which measures progress and poverty.

In 1990, Iraq ranked 55th out of 130 countries on the human development index (HDI). By 1995, it had slipped to 106th, and by 1999 it had plummeted to 125th, behind Bolivia, Mongolia, Egypt, and Gabon.

According to the HDI, an Iraqi born in 1987 could expect to live 65 years. But whereas neighbouring Jordanians saw their life expectancy improve from 67 years in 1987 to 70 years in 1997, life expectancy in Iraq dropped to 62.4.

Whereas Jordan saw its literacy rate rise from 75% in 1985 to 87.2% in 1997, Iraq's dropped from 89% to 58%.

In the 1990 HDI, Iraq ranked three places above Jordan. By 1999, it ranked 31 places below.

A few days after the Beitul Hikma workshop, experts from the planning commission discussed an Iraqi human development report.

But discussions in Iraq are regularly interrupted by power cuts. The government provides power to Baghdadis according to a strict rota - three hours on, six hours off.

In outlying areas and the provinces, the power cuts are longer. People plan their lives according to the rota - work, laundry, cooking, haircuts. A lucky few, including UN staff, have generators.

Soon, temperatures will soar to 50C (122F). During the summer, few people sleep at night, and children get sick. Repairs to the national grid proceed at a snail's pace; more than £320m worth of contracts are currently held up at the UN sanctions committee.

Deprivation has made recycling a thriving business, and families can earn a living collecting plastic and glass. Women are particularly enterprising at devising new ways to earn a living - becoming landscape gardeners, caterers, taxi drivers, nursery managers or wedding consultants. Apparently, people still want to get married, and want to do things right.

In fact, a few families can be spotted at one of the restaurants beside the River Tigris. The scene is unexpectedly serene: a few motorboats ply the Tigris carrying customers from the restaurant; the girls' hair streams out behind them.

The Tigris is lower than ever because of the Turkish dams upstream, according to every Iraqi who raises the subject. They all do: the siege mentality has many dimensions here.

But the low waters provide an opportunity to repair the riverbanks. The bridges damaged by bombing have long since been rebuilt.

webTitle: Waverers decide in death or glory state

fields.headline: Waverers decide in death or glory state
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Ronald is a lifelong Democrat, but yesterday morning in California he was planning to vote for the Republican outsider John McCain. "He's a maverick and I like that. He's not a party kind of guy and he's seen a side of life that none of the other candidates has seen. He's not just a breath of fresh air, he's a blast of fresh air."
fields.body:
Ronald is a lifelong Democrat, but yesterday morning in California he was planning to vote for the Republican outsider John McCain. "He's a maverick and I like that. He's not a party kind of guy and he's seen a side of life that none of the other candidates has seen. He's not just a breath of fresh air, he's a blast of fresh air."

His views were echoed by audio engineer David Green who said as he left the voting booth in Santa Monica that he hoped Mr McCain's campaign had spurred a new interest in politics in the state, adding: "I would hate to see another puppet government."

It was precisely this message - that no one pulls his strings - that John McCain was trying hard to push on what was the crucial day of his campaign for the Republican nomination. California has long been regarded as the death or glory state for the Vietnam war veteran, even although he has vowed to fight on "win or lose".

There are 162 Republican delegates to be won and only the votes of registered Republicans count in this process. Even Mr McCain's team has conceded that he would need a miracle to turn the tide and beat the Texas governor George W Bush among Republicans.

However, California also has what is known as a "beauty contest" in which every registered voter can vote for their preferred candidate. Mr McCain is placing his hopes on this contest because if he beats Mr Bush among all voters, rather than just Republicans, he can argue that he is his party's best bet for the presidential election in November.

Opinion polls before the vote indicated that Mr Bush was favoured by 54% of Republican voters compared to 26% for John McCain. Among all voters, however, the two are virtually neck and neck and it is clear that undecided Democrats and independents would choose Mr McCain.

When polling started Mr McCain was watching a film with his family in a Los Angeles hotel while he prepared for a final rally in West Hollywood at the end of the day. He would not make predictions about the final tally, saying: "The only thing I'm certain of is that it's uncertain."

At a rally the previous night at the University of California, Los Angeles, Mr McCain attacked the men he has accused of pulling Mr Bush's strings: the Texas financial backers, Sam and Charles Wyly, whom Mr McCain has described as "sleazy".

In the last stages of the campaign, his strategy has been to persuade voters that he alone can defeat the Democrats. "I'm going to beat Al Gore like a drum!" he told viewers in eve of polling television commercials in which he was presented as the "one Republican who can beat Al Gore".

Mr Bush, hoarse from making constant speeches, was back in his governor's office in Texas as voters went to the polls in California. His team had ordered enough confetti to swamp the reception room of the Four Seasons hotel in Austin, where he was planning to hold what he hoped would be a victory rally.

The day before he had visited the Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles in an apparent attempt to repair the damage caused by last month's visit to the Bob Jones university in South Carolina, where inter-racial dating was banned until a few days ago. Mr Bush told the gathering: "We must teach our children to respect people whose skin is of a different colour."

Later Mr Bush recorded a show with the comedian Jay Leno and addressed a final rally in Long Beach, where he told the audience: "This is my last speech before the general election."

His campaign team was predicting that Mr McCain would have disappeared from the race by this time next week.

In an attempt to persuade people that Mr Bush is not in the pocket of big money, the team announced last night that 180,000 individuals had contributed to his campaign funds so far.

The media has continued to largely favour Mr McCain because he is a more outspoken and entertaining candidate than Mr Bush.

A survey by the Centre for Media and Public Affairs the week after Mr McCain had won the New Hampshire primary indicated that 74% stories about him were positive compared with 46% for Mr Bush.

Meanwhile, Alan Keyes, the third man in the race, appeared resigned to being buried in the California primary. He has not gone down without a fight, telling viewers in the Los Angeles Times/CNN debate last week that the media had pulled a mask over people's eyes, and he became the invisible candidate. His conservatism - his views on many issues are more rightwing than those of Mr Bush - has not won him even the limited support he might have hoped for.

fields.headline: A 'devious and very dangerous' man
fields.trailText: John Allan was lining up his next victim within weeks of poisoning his wealthy girlfriend with cyanide as they holidayed on the Nile in October, 1998. Soon after Cheryl Lewis's gruesome death, Allan befriended a friend of hers, Jennifer Hughes, 53.

John Allan was lining up his next victim within weeks of poisoning his wealthy girlfriend with cyanide as they holidayed on the Nile in October, 1998. Soon after Cheryl Lewis's gruesome death, Allan befriended a friend of hers, Jennifer Hughes, 53.

Police believe that he tried to poison her too with cyanide. Ms Hughes, newly divorced and wealthy, knew Cheryl from a golf club on the Wirral, Merseyside. When she woke up from a minor operation a week after Cheryl's murder, she was surprised to find Allan at the foot of her hospital bed clutching a bunch of flowers. Allan invited her out for dinner, she accepted and they slept together. A few weeks later he gave her a gold bracelet which had belonged to Cheryl and which Cheryl had worn during their holiday in Egypt.

In February last year Ms Hughes was rushed to hospital with stomach pains. Tests proved inconclusive - cyanide is difficult to detect as it passes through the body rapidly.

Allan was immediately arrested, just two weeks before they were due to go away on holiday - to Egypt. Detective Su perintendent David Smith said: "We believe Jennifer Hughes was the next victim." She made a full recovery.

"Allan attracts women by flattering them and making them feel like they are the centre of attention. But in reality he has no respect for women."

The police found pornography and print-outs of racist jokes at Allan's home. It emerged that he had used prostitutes while he was with Cheryl and within weeks of her death he was also responding to lonely hearts adverts in newspapers.

He had gone out with Cheryl for seven years. She was 43 and a senior partner in a Liverpool law firm. In October, 1998, he slipped the poison in her gin and tonic nightcap in room 508 of the New Winter Palace in Luxor.

The gin was to mask the taste of sodium cyanide. The smell of the poison - likened to the smell of sweaty armpits - was not a problem: Cheryl had lost her sense of smell in a car accident.

She died an agonising death. She suffocated while Allan watched, before he eventually went down to the hotel reception for help.

Pamela Black, an American tourist, followed him to the room where Cheryl lay half-naked on the bed writhing in agony. Miss Black said he refused to carry out mouth to mouth resuscitation. It later emerged that if he had, he would have inhaled dangerous fumes formed when the cyanide mixed with Cheryl's stomach acid.

Heidi Rees, a Thomson holiday representative, recalled how Cheryl was "frothing at the mouth". She said: "She was a horrible colour with blue showing through her suntan. Her eyes were open, she looked as if she was choking."

Early the next morning, Allan summoned her to the hotel reception where she overheard him on the phone saying: "They've got Cheryl, she's dead, you'd better go into hiding."

He later told a holiday representative that the death was all due to his past coming back to haunt him. John Allan lived in a fantasy world in which he claimed to be a former arms dealer in Africa and a legitimate target for hitmen.

But in reality he was an unemployed chemist, who had not worked for seven years and lived off his girlfriend.

He was a compulsive liar with two failed marriages behind him. He met his first wife, Jacqueline Millard, a fellow student, while at Hatfield polytechnic in the early 1970s. They lived in Africa where they worked as chemists in the mining industry. She recalled how he used cyanide to kill butterflies.

His second marriage, in 1980, was to an Iranian, Sima, the mother of his three children. She was shot in the arm when they lived in Zambia. Allan told his friends that the bullet was meant for him and that they had to leave Africa.

Detective Sergeant Steve Moore last night described Allan as a psychopath. "He thinks he is better and superior to everybody else. There were women who were for business and there were women who were for pleasure. He is a very dangerous man."

Cheryl's father, Eric, a retired solicitor from Pwllheli, Wales, said he was always suspicious of Allan. "He is an extremely devious and skilful manipulator and a very, very dangerous man. I just want him to have his just deserts and as the law stands now we know what life means.

"Cheryl was a truly lovely person, a wonderful daughter who had not one ounce of bitterness or hate in her. I believe this cost her her life."

After his daughter's death Mr Lewis discovered that a ring - set with blue topaz and diamonds - had gone missing during a holiday with Allan in Wales over the new year in 1997. She placed an advert in a local paper for its return and received a ransom demand for £2,150. She paid the money and got the ring back - but it disappeared again after her death.

Police then recovered the ransom note along with photocopies of £5 notes totalling £2,150. The day before Allan's trial began, detectives discovered that the stamp on the ransom letter contained Allan's DNA, although for legal reasons this was never put before the jury.

Mr Lewis said: "I am convinced Allan was behind this and I also believe that this was the beginning of the end of their relationship."

In the months leading up to her death, Cheryl became more distant. "She was not her usual self when spoken to. We saw less of her."

At about the same time, Allan was talking to a friend, Julie Dalby. They discussed a book she was reading called The Wimbledon Poisoner, about a man who murders his wife using thallium. "There are better things than that," Allan boasted to Mrs Dalby.

Allan forged Cheryl's will in August, 1997, so that he would benefit from her £460,000 estate. Allan preserved the original final page containing her signature and those of the two witnesses. Her father said it was unthinkable that she would not think of her family in her will.

A post mortem examination revealed that Cheryl had died from haemorrhaging in her stomach caused by a severe irritant. Small amounts of cyanide were found, but they were initially not thought to be significant.

It was only when police ordered further tests that significant levels of cyanide were found - three months after the original post mortem.

Briquettes of sodium cyanide were later discovered in her company car. Once more Allan was to make pitiful attempts to cover his tracks. He went on to fabricate a story that they were robbed of money and Cheryl's jewellery from the hotel room.

A ring with five diamonds, a large diamond solitaire ring, and a blue topaz ring were missing. Later the same month, Allan walked into Kaye's jewellers in Chester and sold the rings for £2,050. Only one has been recovered by police.

He told more lies when he suggested that Cheryl was a heroin user, informing her friends that she had used the drug on several occasions when she was stressed. Forensic tests found no evidence of heroin.

When he was interviewed by police, Allan maintained that she had suddenly collapsed in their hotel room. "I didn't kill Cheryl, I loved her," he claimed as he was charged with murder. Nobody was convinced.

webTitle: Gore on course for decisive victory

fields.headline: Gore on course for decisive victory
fields.standfirst:
Super Tuesday: Vice-president's rival Bill Bradley expected to bow out in fight for Democratic nomination

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Al Gore flew in to his home state of Tennessee yesterday with the triumphant, relieved swagger of a crown prince whose coronation - once shadowed in doubt - had been resoundingly confirmed, as he awaited Democratic primary results expected to force his challenger, Bill Bradley, out of the race for the presidential nomination.
fields.body:
Al Gore flew in to his home state of Tennessee yesterday with the triumphant, relieved swagger of a crown prince whose coronation - once shadowed in doubt - had been resoundingly confirmed, as he awaited Democratic primary results expected to force his challenger, Bill Bradley, out of the race for the presidential nomination.

Mr Bradley was trailing in all 15 states holding Democratic contests, with a double-digit shortfall in most of them.

By yesterday, Super Tuesday, his campaign had slipped into a serene wistfulness more focused on posterity than on votes.

"We're far from the end," Mr Bradley said. But his aides were telling journalists that, barring an electoral miracle, the Missouri-born challenger would formally bow out of the Democratic nomination battle by tomorrow.

Before Super Tuesday, the Bradley campaign had not won one state, and his camp was hoping last night to avoid a complete Gore whitewash.

In a valedictory gesture, seven male Bradley staffers stripped to the waist on a New York street yesterday, displaying painted letters on their chests spelling out their candidate's name, and cheered him as he walked among the morning crowd.

Invoking the example of President Harry Truman, who confounded the pollsters with his 1948 victory, Mr Bradley insisted: "I'm feeling good. I think there will be some surprises today."

Meanwhile, the vice-president's arrival in Nashville on board Air Force Two was symbolic of his campaign's renaissance.

He moved his headquarters to Nashville from the capital last October, at a time when he was dogged by the image of a stiff Washington insider, and Mr Bradley - a former basketball star and senator - was gaining ground.

The move, along with his change of wardrobe from power suits to casual polo shirts, was initially ridiculed in the US media, but the voters responded to the more aggressive and focused campaign style which accompanied the Gore makeover.

While Mr Bradley aimed for lofty, almost ethereal rhetoric, promising a new form of politics, the vice-president busied himself securing the traditional pillars of the Democratic party: the unions, minorities, women and gays.

His campaigning this week was no exception. In a last swing through New York he addressed a Jewish organisation, reminding it of his support for Israel, and visited the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Centre in Greenwich Village.

As soon as he arrived in Nashville yesterday he met union representatives from the paper and oil industries, as a token of his gratitude for the decision by the biggest union federation, the AFL-CIO, to endorse him in October, long before the primaries began.

As his lead over Mr Bradley lengthened, Mr Gore's rhetoric looked beyond the primaries to the general election and the contest he expects with George W Bush. His early strategy has been to bind himself as tightly as possible to the economic successes of the past eight years of the Clinton administration.

"Instead of a deep recession and high unemployment, we have now broke the all-time record for the longest period of economic prosperity in all of American history," the vice-president declared. "I'm here today to tell you: You ain't seen nothing yet. To keep our prosperity going and to make sure no one is left behind - we have only just begun to fight."

But Gallup opinion polls published yesterday found that although 71% of those questioned thought the economy was in good shape, Mr Gore was not extracting political advantage from it. Mr Bush even had a slight edge on the vice-president when voters were asked who they would trust most to run the economy.

Gore aides are working on a new set of speeches that would target Mr Bush's economic inexperience and warn that his promised tax-cuts would jeopardise the economic stability created by the Democratic administration.

Mr Gore also attacked the Texas governor's record on healthcare, telling hospital workers: "Under his leadership, the state of Texas now ranks 49th in health insurance for children" and 50th in the nation for health insurance for women.

A victory party was being prepared last night at a plush hotel in central Nashville, where Mr Gore waited with his wife, Tipper, for the results to come in. Today, he plans to visit his mother in the small town of Carthage, reinforcing his newly-established image as a down-to-earth candidate from the American heartland. He will then head on to Michigan and Minnesota, which will hold weekend caucuses.

On the Democratic side of the primaries, 15 states and the Pacific territory of American Samoa will choose a total of 1,315 delegates to the party convention - potentially enough to put the nomination out of Mr Bradley's reach.

In what was probably a telling omen for the Bradley campaign, a campaign banner inscribed with the slogan "It Will Happen, March 7" fell off a New York podium on which the candidate was speaking.

Campaign workers speedily rolled the poster up and removed it from sight under a park bench, but the damage had already been done. For Mr Bradley, it won't happen.

fields.headline: Prince woos commonwealth support
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales is mounting a discreet and sensitive campaign to ensure that the monarch remains head of the commonwealth when the Queen dies.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales is mounting a discreet and sensitive campaign to ensure that the monarch remains head of the commonwealth when the Queen dies.

The succession is not automatic, and royal aides are concerned about the prince's perceived lack of enthusiasm for the commonwealth among some leaders of the 54 member states. Their greatest fear is that support will grow for calls to sever the automatic link with the monarchy.

This dilution of the commonwealth's "Britishness" would be regarded as disastrous in royal circles, since leadership of the institution is seen as one of the monarchy's most important functions. Losing it could seriously undermine the monarchy.

The prince's first public salvo came in a speech during his tour of the Caribbean. "I have long had an instinctive sense of the value of the commonwealth," he told an audience in Trinidad. "For me, the commonwealth is something rather special, and worth cherishing." It was a "wonderful resource" that embodied "a particular kind of decency and humanity". The speech was his strongest public statement on the subject.

Over time, the prince will become more publicly associated with the commonwealth, making more speeches, meeting business leaders and holding talks with political figures. "It will be a drip, drip effect," one royal aide said.

The Trinidad speech was also interpreted as a shot across the bows of prime minister Tony Blair. At the last commonwealth heads of government meeting in November, Mr Blair was instrumental in setting up a committee to examine the options for change.

He told commonwealth leaders that the institution had to modernise. But the prince indicated disagreement, saying that the commonwealth was a house that "does not necessarily need rewiring".

There are no written rules about the succession of the head of the commonwealth. The Queen took on the role on her coronation in 1952 when it was three years old. Now thoughts are turning to whether it should be so closely allied to the monarchy.

Prince Charles is in a tricky position because he cannot be seen to be openly campaigning for the position which his mother has made her life's work while she is still alive. His official website lists only one previous speech on the subject of the commonwealth, delivered to an audience in Australia six years ago.

Even in private, aides are unwilling to use the word "campaign" to describe the prince's tactics. Yet the need for a strategy is clear: if the prince does nothing to endear himself to commonwealth leaders, the job may slip out of his grasp.

webTitle: CPS clerk guilty of leaks to crime family

fields.headline: CPS clerk guilty of leaks to crime family
fields.standfirst: Policeman's son smuggled files to notorious London gang
fields.trailText: A crown prosecution service clerk was yesterday convicted at the Old Bailey of betraying the justice system by selling case secrets about one of London's most dangerous criminal families.
fields.body:
A crown prosecution service clerk was yesterday convicted at the Old Bailey of betraying the justice system by selling case secrets about one of London's most dangerous criminal families.

Mark Herbert, who was allowed access to intelligence on some of the most high profile and sensitive cases handled by the CPS, copied and smuggled out many files and a list of 33 informers while working on a team investigating the notorious Adams family. He will be sentenced on March 28.

He was convicted of corruptly receiving £500 and disclosing information without lawful authority. But he and his co-defendant Kevin Sumer were cleared of conspiring to pervert the course of justice. Sumer, 41, from Brentford, west London, was also cleared of aiding and abetting Herbert to disclose information.

Herbert, 31, from Twickenham, west London, had access to what police described as the "crown jewels" of CPS prosecutions, involving terrorism and official secrets cases.

Said to be one of the worst potential breaches of security in the service's history, the CPS has been forced to change its computer system after the case. An independent review of security recommended a series of improvements which were being implemented, the CPS said yesterday. "The CPS is putting more resources into security ... However, no system can insure against a breach of integrity by a member of staff," a spokesman said.

Herbert, a policeman's son, joined the CPS in 1992, moving to the service's headquarters in 1998, where he became part of a confidential team under a senior lawyer, Michael Spong, which was dealing exclusively with the Adams family.

Under the umbrella code-name Operation Trinity, the team was investigating a wide range of criminal activities engaged in by the family and their associates, including armed robbery and drug smuggling. When Herbert ran into debt he began to hand over sensitive information about the three brothers.

Herbert said he and his girlfriend were threatened, telling the court he feared for his life after being warned the Adams family "do not mess about ...", and "They want to be your friends. They may occasionally ask you for information. You don't want to upset them. You just have to play along."

But his girlfriend denied that Herbert had ever told her he was worried about his or her safety, or that anyone had threatened him.

At the time Herbert was smuggling documents out of the central London offices of the CPS, Tommy Adams was facing a drugs trafficking trial. He was subsequently jailed for 7 years after pleading guilty.

A memo from the prosecutor in the case, which discussed whether there was sufficient evidence to proceed with the prosecution as well as police reluctance to disclose surveillance techniques in open court, was the first document Herbert smuggled out.

He also obtained details of a case against an alleged Adams family "enforcer" who was accused of a knife attack on a businessman over £1.4m he was given to invest by one of the brothers.

The businessman was left with his ear and nose hanging off after his face was slashed with a Stanley knife. The man accused of the attack was acquitted of grievous bodily harm with intent at the Old Bailey in May last year.

Herbert was caught before he could pass on the 33 names on the informant list. But it needed "little imagination to anticipate what might happen if the names of informants were to fall into the wrong hands", Victor Temple QC, prosecuting, said.

Describing the Adams gang as a "formidable and feared organisation steeped in the highest levels of criminal activity", Mr Temple said it was "no stranger to the imposition of serious violence".

He also obtained details of a case against an alleged Adams family "enforcer" who was accused of a knife attack on a businessman over £1.4m he was given to invest by one of the brothers. The businessman was left with his ear and nose hanging off after his face was slashed with a Stanley knife. The man accused of the attack was acquitted of grievous bodily harm with intent at the Old Bailey in May last year. Herbert was caught before he could pass on the 33 names on the informant list. But it needed "little imagination to anticipate what might happen if the names of informants were to fall into the wrong hands", Victor Temple QC, prosecuting, said. Describing the Adams gang as a "formidable and feared organisation steeped in the highest levels of criminal activity", Mr Temple said it was "no stranger to the imposition of serious violence".

webTitle: Trimble claims Channel 4 put innocent lives at risk

fields.headline: Trimble claims Channel 4 put innocent lives at risk
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Channel 4 placed at risk the lives of "decent people" when it broadcast a documentary about a spate of loyalist murders, Northern Ireland's first minister, David Trimble, said in the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
Channel 4 placed at risk the lives of "decent people" when it broadcast a documentary about a spate of loyalist murders, Northern Ireland's first minister, David Trimble, said in the high court yesterday.

The Nobel peace prize winner claimed the 1991 Dispatches programme, The Committee, had suggested members of the Ulster Independence Committee, a political movement dedicated to Ulster's independence, were connected to an alleged committee of Protestant dignitaries and RUC officers who colluded with loyalist death squads to arrange the murders of innocent Catholics.

The "dishonest" way in which the programme had been edited - with quotes from the IUC's head, the Reverend Hugh Ross, juxtaposed with an interview with a loyalist fanatic - compounded this impression. "By doing a programme about this alleged committee that was responsible for murders and in the same context mixing in Hugh Ross's group, known in Northern Ireland as the Ulster Independence Committee, that exposed to attack members of Hugh Ross's committee," the Ulster Unionist leader said.

"While I wasn't a supporter, or associated with Hugh Ross's committee, there were people on that committee that I knew, whom I knew to be decent people and whose lives, I thought, had been placed at risk by Channel 4."

Mr Trimble was giving evidence for the Sunday Times in its defence of a libel action brought by the documentary's producer, Sean McPhilemy, over a 1993 article deriding the film as a hoax based on "unsubstantiated rumours and fabrications" from its main source, a loyalist fanatic, Jim Sands.

The programme had alleged that the committee had arranged, with the collusion of the RUC, for Protestant death squads to carry out the killings of Catholics and republicans.

No one was named, but in a book of the same name published in the US two years ago, Mr McPhilemy listed the alleged members and accused Mr Trimble of involvement. The Upper Bann MP was "knowingly associating with and assisting those responsible for the murder of his own constituents", he said, and was as culpable for terrorist acts as the leader of Sinn Fein.

Yesterday Mr Trimble, who is pursuing a separate libel action against the internet firm Amazon UK, which distributes the book in Britain, denied there was "a shred of truth" in such allegations.

He said: "To say that I was knowingly associating with and assisting people responsible for the murder of my constituents is grossly offensive to me and would be extremely damaging but for the fact that I have not met anybody in Northern Ireland who takes this book seriously."

He denied it was merely his "entourage" who dismissed the allegations. They were so "incredible" that not even the Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, or its chief negotiator, Martin McGuinness, believed them.

Mr Trimble insisted the Orange Order, of which he had been a member since 1961, was a fraternal organisation which did not promote sectarianism.

James Price QC, for Mr McPhilemy, said that "fraternal" was not a word that sprang to mind in the light of its insistence on marching in uniform through nationalist areas - and asked if it was true that, after a silent march at Drumcree in 1995, he had danced a celebratory jig with the DUP leader, the Rev Ian Paisley.

Mr Trimble replied: "I have never danced a jig with anyone, least of all Ian Paisley. There was something you could describe as rejoicing, and yes, I did put my hands together with Mr Paisley - but we certainly weren't dancing."

The hearing, in which the Sunday Times denies libel and pleads justification, continues.

webTitle: Death on the Nile poisoner gets life

fields.headline: Death on the Nile poisoner gets life
fields.standfirst: Industrial chemist forged girlfriend's will a year before her agonising cyanide death in a hotel room while on holiday in Egypt
fields.trailText: An unemployed industrial chemist who murdered his girlfriend with cyanide while they were on holiday in Egypt was jailed for life yesterday for the "cruel and premeditated killing".
fields.body:
An unemployed industrial chemist who murdered his girlfriend with cyanide while they were on holiday in Egypt was jailed for life yesterday for the "cruel and premeditated killing".

John Frederick Allan, 48, from the Wirral, Merseyside, denied murdering Cheryl Lewis, 43, in October, 1998.

The jury had heard how he had forged her £460,000 will a year before he watched her die in agony in their Luxor hotel room after poisoning her.

He remained impassive in the dock at Liverpool crown court as the guilty verdict was read out. There was a gasp of relief from the public gallery.

The jury of five men and five women had taken more than 17 hours and 20 minutes to reach their majority decision. They had indicated in a note to the judge that they were unable to reach a unanimous decision.

Sentencing Allan, Mrs Justice Smith said: "You have been convicted of murder by this jury on the basis of what, in my view, was convincing evidence.

"This was a cruel and premeditated killing in the privacy of your hotel room.

"You abused the trust and confidence which Cheryl Lewis placed in you as your partner. In my view you tricked her into taking cyanide. You must have then watched her suffer until she was beyond making any complaint.

"In my view it is clear you were motivated by greed and in my own mind I am satisfied that you forged her will and were determined to take for yourself virtually her entire property."

The life sentence would be accompanied by a recommendation to the home secretary that Allan should stay in prison for a long time.

"The loss of a daughter or sister in the prime of her life is a personal tragedy for any family. But to lose her in circumstances where you really did not know what had happened to her must have been a torment."

Cheryl's father, Eric Lewis, wept at the verdict and hugged his eldest daughter.

He said afterwards: "All we as a family have wanted is justice for Cheryl. I thank God that justice has prevailed."

Jennifer Hughes, a wealthy divorcee and friend of Cheryl Lewis who began a sexual relationship with Allan within weeks of her friend's death, said: "I feel relief for Cheryl Lewis's family who have been through a terrible ordeal. I am very relieved that it is all over."

Detective Superintendent David Smith, of Merseyside police, who led the inquiry, said: "I feel very pleased for the family because they have gone through a tremendous ordeal.

"When someone is dying and the person you rely on most for help is denying you that help, it must have been most difficult for the family to understand."

Allan was a very dangerous man. "I feel the sentence makes the community a great deal safer."

webTitle: Hull strikes it rich in phone company share bonanza

fields.headline: Hull strikes it rich in phone company share bonanza
fields.trailText: The biggest financial windfall ever landed by a British city had people in Hull yesterday celebrating in appropriate style.
fields.body:
The biggest financial windfall ever landed by a British city had people in Hull yesterday celebrating in appropriate style.

Instead of dancing in the street, hundreds of local investors were logging on to financial bulletin boards to check the soaring share price of their former municipal phone company.

The latest entrant to the FTSE 100, following a sevenfold rise in value since flotation last July, Kingston Communications has made the Labour council the richest local authority in the country, with its 45% stake now worth £2.5bn.

One in three residents of the Yorkshire port bought shares in the company.

"My gas man was really miffed this morning because he sold his Kingston shares last week when the price dipped," said Emma Marson clocking on for work at Hull council for voluntary services. "He was convinced they'd carry on falling, so he'd buy them back more cheaply and then make a profit. But they just went back up, and up." That suited the rival strategy of Alan Symington, a 21-year-old student at Hull university, whose brother John works alongside Emma. "Alan's holding on tight," said Mr Symington.

"Because he's absolutely sure there'll be a takeover bid soon and the shares'll go through the roof."

Kingston marketed its shares locally on a combination of traditional service and technical innovation.

"Unlimited use is all the rage now with people like Alta Vista and the internet. But we've had it here in Hull for nearly a century," said Colin Ashcroft of Kingston, leafing through the first Hull phone directory of 1904 to find an offer of unlimited phone use for six guineas a year.

Local calls cost a standard 5.5p even if they go on all day and the principle was extended to internet use over a year ago.

Digital TV systems which allow ordinary Hull subscribers to get their internet on their televisions - where much of the bulletin board scrutiny was under way yesterday - are the backbone of the huge rise in share value. Retired docker Frank Robertson who made £500 by selling his initial £1,000 stake in the autumn, said: "We knew that sort of thing was bound to make it a good investment. We had an interest with it being Hull, but we got the shares because there was money to be made."

One man who did not buy in was traffic warden Jim Hull. "There was too much paperwork," he said. "I found that out from the gas and BT share offers."

Pat Doyle, leader of the council, decided not personally to join the 51,000 initial investors - down only 10% to the current 45,800 who hold stakes between £100 and £5,000, forming 8% of the company's stock.

Although delighted to be able to freeze council tax for at least two years and put £35m into school repairs, he is absorbed in trying to relax government restrictions on local council investment policy.

"If we can get more flexibility out of Gordon Brown we can almost double the interest we're currently receiving," he said.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Briton feared killed in SA
fields.body:
Briton feared killed in SA

A British doctor was yesterday feared murdered after being abducted from his car in South Africa.

Police said Alec Grant, 53, left Sunninghill hospital in Johannesburg, where he worked as a neurosurgeon, to visit his sister in nearby Sandton on Sunday morning.

On Monday, Johannesburg police found his abandoned green Peugeot 406 about 220km away in the Northern Province with a bullet hole in the driver's window.

The tip of a damaged bullet, believed to have been fired from a 9mm pistol, was found on the back seat where it had ricocheted after hitting the dashboard, but no blood was found inside the car.

The words "We kill all white trash" had been burned on to the inside of the car's roof using a cigarette lighter.

"We will take note of the message on the roof but we are not concentrating on that," a police spokesman said.

A search of the area had yesterday failed to find Dr Grant, who emigrated from Britain 12 years ago with his wife.

His briefcase and mobile telephone were still in the car and police did not know if one or more gunmen had been involved.

Dr Grant seemed to have been in good spirits before his disappearance.

"We are working on the basis that he must have been shot at, taken out of the vehicle and then shot, but at the moment we have no evidence," police said.

Film report complaint is rejected

The Press Complaints Commission has rejected a complaint from the independent film maker Ray Fitzwalter about the Guardian's coverage of his programme, called Guns on the street.

The commission found that there had been no breach of its code over the original article - entitled Channel 4 in new documentary fake row - and subsequent reporting.

In its ruling, published yesterday, it said that the allegations in the original piece had been put to Channel 4 and had included quotes from Channel 4 supporting the documentary.

The newspaper had subsequently reported the findings of an Independent Television Commission inquiry "in detail under a headline which made clear they had not found the film misleading". There were quotes from Channel 4 and a statement from the newspaper saying that it did not agree with the ITC's findings.

It was clear that the articles concerned a dispute over which the newspaper, the programme makers, Channel 4 and the ITC took different views. "The newspaper had set out the arguments on both sides."

How Hewitt re-enacted Diana drive

James Hewitt has claimed he drank a bottle of wine then raced photographers through the streets of Paris to re-enact the accident in which his former lover, Diana, Princess of Wales, died.

In an interview in GQ magazine the former cavalry officer said he had done it to "conduct a little test".

He claimed paparazzi were waiting outside a Paris restaurant where he was having lunch with four women about a year after the accident which killed Diana, Dodi Fayed and their driver, Henri Paul.

One of the women had the same model of Mercedes as the one Diana was in. "So I decided to conduct a little test. I reckoned I was about as drunk as Dodi's driver was that night. I'd had one, maybe two bottles of wine."

Hewitt said he drove to the underpass where Diana died, but when he got there the photographers stopped pursuing him. "They weren't about to make the same mistake twice." He then drove at speed, reaching 120mph, and passed through the tunnel safely.

"It's a completely straight road. I don't care how drunk you are. There's no way you'd hit that pillar unless something happened to make you veer off the road."

Hewitt sprang to fame as the man who romanced Diana, but was condemned for his willingness to cash in on the relationship. He revealed his version of the five-year affair in the book, Princess In Love.

Diana accused him of betrayal during her famous interview for the BBC's Panorama programme.

Lockerbie trial cannot be televised

The BBC and other broadcasters have been refused permission to televise the Lockerbie trial after a Scottish judge ruled that the proceedings could be compromised by network cameras in the court.

The trial, due to start at Camp Zeist in the Netherlands on May 3, is to be relayed by closed circuit TV to victims' relatives in Britain and the United States.

But Lord MacFadyen ruled at the high court in Edinburgh yesterday that TV networks will not be allowed to transmit it to a wider audience for fear of intimidating witnesses or prejudicing the proceedings.

He acknowledged, however, that his refusal over the transmission may have freedom of speech implications under the European convention on human rights.

There has been intense interest in televising the trial, which broadcasters say could reach a potential global audience of more than 100m.

Lawyers for the BBC and eight other broadcasters, including CNN, had argued that the unique international significance of the event, due to take place under Scots law, gave it a special status.

They said the fact that agreement had already been given for the relatives' screenings meant consent to the principle of broadcasting the trial had effectively been approved. The two Libyans accused of the bombing, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmmed al-Megrahi, 47, and Al Ali Lamine Khalifa Fhimah, 43, have denied charges of conspiracy and murder over the disaster, in which 270 people died after their plane exploded over Lockerbie in December 1988.

Lord MacFadyen said, in his ruling, that he agreed that televising proceedings would pose a greater risk of prejudice to the administration of justice than would occur in ordinary criminal cases.

The BBC had argued that refusing their request could run counter to freedom of expression considerations under the European convention on human rights.

He said the point was arguable but declined to express a "concluded opinion" as he had only heard limited evidence on that aspect.

fields.headline: Elderly 'need £10 or more on pensions'
fields.trailText: Pensioners need at least £10 a week more than the government provides, and in some cases up to £44 more, to meet their minimum needs, research suggests today.
fields.body:
Pensioners need at least £10 a week more than the government provides, and in some cases up to £44 more, to meet their minimum needs, research suggests today.

The income shortfalls are even greater for more than 500,000 pensioners who are failing to claim their entitlement to an income support top-up of the state pension, according to the study.

Age Concern, the charity which commissioned the research, is calling for the basic pension to be urgently raised 35% to £90 for a single person to cover basic living costs, excluding rent and council tax.

Sally Greengross, the charity's director, said: "It is appalling that the poorest older people are effectively second class citizens, excluded from buying a drink in a pub or clothing from a high street shop."

The study, by the family budget unit at King's College, London, analyses what pensioners need to fund a "low cost but acceptable" standard of living. This includes savings for a week's annual holiday, hobbies and presents for grandchildren.

The weekly needs of a single male pensioner were assumed to include margarine for thin spreading on 10 slices of bread, two slices of corned beef, a heaped teaspoon of salt and jelly sweets to the value of 34p.

Overall, a single woman tenant receiving housing benefit would need £10 more than the £75 minimum income "guarantee" currently provided by the government. This relies on people making a claim for income support on top of the basic pension of £66.75 - but between 500,000 and 870,000 eligible pensioners do not claim.

The government is increasing the income guarantee in line with average earnings, so that from next month it will be worth £78.45 for a single pensioner and £121.95 for a couple. However, it has yet to produce a strategy to ensure that more eligible people claim their income support.

The government is increasing the income guarantee in line with average earnings, so that from next month it will be worth £78.45 for a single pensioner and £121.95 for a couple. However, it has yet to produce a strategy to ensure that more eligible people claim their income support.

fields.headline: Nanny's mum fights back
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The mother of Rosalind Mark, the nanny being sued by the Prime Minister's wife, last night reacted angrily to her daughter's treatment by Downing Street, saying No 10 was trying to portray her as the villain.
fields.body:
The mother of Rosalind Mark, the nanny being sued by the Prime Minister's wife, last night reacted angrily to her daughter's treatment by Downing Street, saying No 10 was trying to portray her as the villain.

Margaret Mark said she feared her daughter could lose her home over the legal action. Speaking about the injunction and claim for damages by Cherie Blair against her daughter, she said she felt she no longer had the full support of the Blairs. "We are all devastated about what has happened. Tony and Cherie Blair say they are trying to protect their children. Well now I am trying to protect mine."

The prime minister's official spokesman last night denied suggestions that Ms Mark could lose her home, describing the damages claim as a "legal technicality". He said: "All they are seeking to do is prevent publication of material about their family life and to get return of the manuscript."

Mrs Mark, from Galgate, near Lancaster, said the Blairs had initially said they would help them get through the situation. But she said: "I can no longer stand back as my daughter is made out to be some sort of evil money grabber intent on causing the Blairs grief."

Mrs Mark said the stories included in her daughter's book would only have shown how nice the Blairs had been to her family. She insisted that the book would not have been published without the Blairs' consent.

When her daughter began working for the Blairs she and her son Tom moved into their Islington home, and then later No 10, where her son worked as an unofficial butler while pursuing an acting career.

Cherie's father, the actor Tony Booth, also gave Tom some acting lessons.

"As a thank-you for organising the move into No 10 after the election they paid for all of us to have first-class flights to Cannes and stay a week at Geoffrey Robinson's apartment," Mrs Mark said. "Cherie would lend me expensive clothes and jewellery and we would go out to the ballet together.

"That's the kind of people they are and that is the type of story we wanted to put in the book."
