fields.headline: Grassroots gains
fields.standfirst:
The importance of local campaigns during general elections cannot be underestimated - just look at their part in the Labour landslide

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Local political campaigns - so it used to be said - are mere rituals with little influence on voters. This was widely believed on the strength of a book on the British party system written by the late Bob McKenzie, Peter Snow's predecessor on swingometer on BBC election night programmes.
fields.body:
Local political campaigns - so it used to be said - are mere rituals with little influence on voters. This was widely believed on the strength of a book on the British party system written by the late Bob McKenzie, Peter Snow's predecessor on swingometer on BBC election night programmes.

McKenzie, an academic at the LSE, discounted the importance of party members in general. In a similar vein, the influential Nuffield election studies by David Butler and collaborators tended to emphasise the dominance of the national campaign over local political activity during elections. This was also inferred from the fact that swings from one party to another in general elections were fairly uniform across the country up until the 70s. If swings were pretty much the same everywhere, it meant that what party workers got up to locally had little or no effect on the vote.

That was then. Recently, electoral behaviour has become more volatile. In 1997 the change in Labour's vote in comparison with the previous election varied from a 23% increase in its share in Liverpool Wavertree to a 12% decline in Bradford West. This kind of variation is the direct result of weakening party loyalties together with regional and local differences in voting: voters are more open to influence by local campaigns.

Before the 80s only a handful of local party functionaries could say what the electoral effects of canvassing, delivering leaflets and local campaigning were. Then studies showed electoral swings were linked to how much was spent on campaigns at the local level.

The best available recent evidence comes from the Liberal Democrats in the 1997 general election. Their share of the total vote fell by 1% compared with 1992, and yet they ended up with more than twice as many seats in parliament.

Our survey consisted of almost 4,500 party members in a random sample of 200 constituencies across the country. We examined canvassing, leafleting and election-day activities such as reminding people to vote, transporting them to a polling station and helping out in election committee rooms. Overall, Liberal Democrats were very active, with a quarter of them canvassing and half delivering leaflets. On polling day about a fifth drove voters to polling stations, just over a quarter reminded voters to turn out, and more than a third took numbers at polling stations. Not surprisingly, there were big variations across the country in the amount of activity they undertook and they concentrated their efforts on the winnable seats.

The figure shows the relationship between Liberal Democrat campaigning and the party's vote in the election. There is a very clear relationship in the figure between campaigning and the vote share, with more campaigning being associated with a higher vote share.

To get an accurate picture of the relationship between campaigning and the vote it is necessary to take into account other factors which might influence Liberal Democrat support, such as the campaigning efforts of the other parties and whether or not the seat already had a Liberal Democrat MP. By incorporating such factors it is possible to develop a good predictive model of Liberal Democrat voting. Our computer simulations show that if the Liberal Democrats had done no campaigning at all in 1997 they would have won only one seat in the sample of 200 constituencies, instead of the 10 seats they actually won. So the effects are large.

This poses a puzzle. If local campaigning is so important, why were the swings to Labour in their target seats not bigger than swings elsewhere? In the target constituencies where Labour challenged the Conservatives, the swing was 12.5% whereas in the non-targets it was 13.4%. On the face of it we would expect to see much bigger swings in these target seats; but it did not happen.

There is a simple explanation for this: the targeting strategy which involved asking Labour members to campaign in constituencies other than their own, was not very successful. Our survey of Labour party members in 1997 showed that while 28% were asked to work in one of the target constituencies only 3% actually did any serious work in those seats. Rather they campaigned in all types of seats which they hoped to win, and this had a big influence on the outcome. In constituencies where Labour came second in 1992 the swing to Labour was 12.3% in 1997. On the other hand, in safe Labour seats, which everyone knew would be won anyway, the swing was only 7.1%. Local campaigns had a big effect which was not recognised at the time, affecting many more seats than just the target ones.

Again computer simulations show that if Labour party activists had done no campaigning at all when the Liberal Democrats and Conservatives campaigned at the intensity that they did in 1997, then Labour would have ended up with a majority of only 33.

The conclusion has to be that while local campaigns were not responsible for Labour's great victory, they were responsible for its landslide. It is not difficult to predict that if the Tory party got going again at the grassroots level and Labour's activists gave up and stood aside, future elections would see New Labour's dream of making the century its own run into the sand.

 Paul Whiteley and Patrick Seyd are professors of politics at Sheffield University. Send a cheque for £2.50 payable to the University of Sheffield for their full report on the effects of political campaigning

webTitle: The Tory party might yet find its way back to power

fields.headline: The Tory party might yet find its way back to power
fields.standfirst:
The ablest Conservatives are leading a move back on to the centre ground

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Tories are stirring in their sleep. With his recent statement refusing to rule out forever Britain's joining the euro, Michael Portillo has made a final break with Thatcherism. At the same time, by disowning official Conservative policy on immigration and section 28 Steve Norris has put down a marker for an intelligently populist Conservatism that points well beyond London's mayoral election. The Tories' ablest politicians are leading their party back on to the centre ground. Labour's prospects at the next election depend on how far it can retain this ground as its own.
fields.body:
The Tories are stirring in their sleep. With his recent statement refusing to rule out forever Britain's joining the euro, Michael Portillo has made a final break with Thatcherism. At the same time, by disowning official Conservative policy on immigration and section 28 Steve Norris has put down a marker for an intelligently populist Conservatism that points well beyond London's mayoral election. The Tories' ablest politicians are leading their party back on to the centre ground. Labour's prospects at the next election depend on how far it can retain this ground as its own.

So far there is nothing that resembles a real Tory revival. Few of the voters who defected to Labour at the last election seem tempted to return to the fold. The Tories continue to look incompetent even as an opposition party. Yet, in one of the many paradoxes of current British politics, they could end up doing well out of a strategy that has isolated them from the majority of voters.

William Hague is not interested in reclaiming the centre ground. He has long since settled on the more modest goal of consolidating core Tory support. It is this strategy that accounts for his absurd stance on Europe. The Tory leader has committed himself to a policy that is irresponsible, extremist and barely coherent in order to mobilise his party on an issue that is more important than any other to its most loyal workers and voters.

Hague's stance on Europe is easily mocked. It makes little sense to rule out joining the euro categorically for a predetermined and arbitrary number of years. It makes even less to insist that Britain can remain secure in the EU while making demands that require a far-reaching renegotiation of our treaties with it. Hague's anti-European campaign can also be excruciatingly comic. His patriotic perorations in defence of the pound, delivered from the back of a lorry supplied exclusively for that purpose, have been greeted with bemusement, as if his audiences suspected they might have strayed on to the set of a particularly surreal scene from The League of Gentlemen. Ill-advised stunts of this kind strengthen doubts about Hague's judgment. But it would be a fundamental mistake to underestimate the threat to Labour posed by his anti-euro campaign.

The risk is not that voters will be swayed by the Tory leader's posturings. It is that, by energising his party and tapping into the strongest emotions of its core voters, Hague will ensure a high Tory turnout while Labour's slumps. A low turnout by Labour's traditional voters could make a noticeable dent in the government's majority. If it was combined with a falling-off of support among first-time Labour voters in marginal seats the result would be a major setback for the government. With Labour's majority slashed to double figures the Tories would be back in business.

It is partly the scale of its success that has made the government so vulnerable. The Tories were not merely defeated at the last election. They were reduced to irrelevance. The impact on Labour has not been altogether benign. To govern without the inconvenience of effective opposition might seem ideal, but in fact it has many dangers. It is easy to imagine that the forces that brought the government to power can safely be relied on to keep it there.

In reality, the electoral coalition that produced Labour's landslide has always been a fragile construction. Partly it was an artefact of anti-Tory tactical voting which can hardly be expected to be repeated. More significantly, it was the product of a realignment of Labour policies to take account of the needs and values of sections of the electorate that had never voted Labour before.

More than on anything else, Labour's future hinges on whether it can retain its hold on these voters. Contrary to what some of its Liberal Democrat critics have argued, the government's future certainly does not depend on its stance on Europe. For first-time Labour voters - as for Labour's traditional supporters - there are many things more important than when, or whether, Britain joins the euro. It is conditions in schools and hospitals, on the roads and in the economy, that matter most to the voters who will decide the outcome of the next election.

A strong commitment to public services is not needed just to keep first-time Labour voters on side. It is no less important in relation to Labour's traditional supporters. Those who claim that Labour has done nothing for the poor have chosen to ignore the substantial shift in resources that has been achieved since the government came to power. Both taxation and spending have been tilted significantly to the benefit of the worse off. Even so, redistribution by stealth has its limits. There is only one way to convince wavering or apathetic long-time Labour voters that the government cares about public services. The government will have to commit more money to them - lots of it. Yet it cannot raise taxes without breaking its compact with new voters, without whose renewed support it can do nothing for Labour's heartlands. To seek to wish away this dilemma, as do some of the government's critics on the left, is mere folly. How the government responds to it will decide whether Labour emerges from the next election shaken and weakened or - and this is still a possibility - even stronger than before.

Labour is not facing electoral meltdown. The government remains strong, and hugely popular. Tony Blair retains an unprecedented command over British politics. But the near-hegemony he exercises today could vanish overnight. If Labour voters - new and old - fail to turn out at the next general election the Conservative party will revive by default. It will then not be long before a generation of newly reinvented Tories - such as Portillo and Norris - begins to threaten the very foundations of Labour's power.

John Gray is professor of European thought at the London School of Economics

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: We've had Justices of the Peace since 1361, but there remains surprising public ignorance about them. In Lay Magistrates: Without Fear Or Favour (11.0am, Radio 4), Sallie Davies talks to JPs and court officials about these misconceptions. There are 30,000 JPs, evenly divided between men and women, handling 95 per cent of all criminal cases. But the effort to recruit more from every social group is in trouble: employers won't allow people the time off.

But the effort to recruit more from every social group is in trouble: employers won't allow people the time off.

If the government's shift on genetic engineering brightened your day, Peter Evans offers a new cloud for this silver lining. Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4) reminds us that Earth's last major hiccup came not 65 mil lion years ago, when dinosaurs vanished, but 10 million years after that. It's thought that global warming melted vast quantities of frozen natural gas beneath the oceans to retard evolution. We could be in for a replay.

webTitle: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Should you find yourself, now or in the future, with an uncontrollable urge to call Whitney Houston "Mommy", here's one simple piece of advice: don't.
fields.body:
Should you find yourself, now or in the future, with an uncontrollable urge to call Whitney Houston "Mommy", here's one simple piece of advice: don't. Otherwise, you'll only wind up in the same position as New Yorker Desiree D Weeks, slapped with a restraining order by a New Jersey judge last week after a nine-month campaign of letter-writing which reportedly gave the soul-lite maven a serious case of the hives (and how).

According to a lawsuit recently filed by Houston - which then inspired the subsequent restraining order - Weeks has spent much of her time since last August sending innumerable packages to her heroine, including countless letters referring to her as Mommy, My Supernatural Reincarnated Mother and Queen Whitney; the same missives also described Houston's mother as Nana, and her seven-year-old daughter as Little Sister.

But it doesn't end there: further care parcels - dispatched to Houston via her management, with the return address frequently listed as the Bronx Psychiatric Center - contained underwear, a make-up kit, and a custom-made four-tiered cake. The unfortunate Weeks now faces a custodial sentence should Houston receive any more little surprises in the post.

Meanwhile, bad news for stand-up Don Rickles , best known these days as the voice of Mr Potato Head in Toy Story and currently on the business end of a LA Superior Court lawsuit from a security guard at the Beverly Hills Hotel. And the reason? Rickles allegedly attacked the complainant, Lee Lark, after he intervened in a heated argument between the comic and an African-American guest - an altercation, says the suit, started by Rickles reminiscing about the time "when blacks weren't allowed in this hotel". Perhaps unsurprisingly, the septugenarian funny man is yet to comment.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText:
Phantoms
(Joe Chappelle, 1998)
10pm, Sky MovieMax
fields.body:
Phantoms
(Joe Chappelle, 1998)
10pm, Sky MovieMax

Effective post X Files chiller. Sheriff Ben Affleck teams with a local doctor (Joanna Going), her younger sister (Rose McGowan) and a boffin (Peter O'Toole), when the population of a Colorado town are torn apart by an unidentifiable entity. Suspenseful early scenes that, for once, don't get less scary when the creature is revealed.

Red Corner
(Jon Avnet, 1997)
8pm, Sky Premier

Here's Richard Gere's media executive doing big business in China, spending a night with a beautiful woman who in the morning is dead. Suddenly our heroic American abroad is framed for murder, the victim of a vast, opaque and implacable foreign justice system. But luckily, along comes another beautiful woman (Bai Ling) and this one's a lawyer who believes he's innocent. Kafka it ain't.

The Adventures of Robin Hood
(William Keighley, Michael Curtiz, 1938)
9pm, TCM

By far the best Robin Hood in the forest. It's played with enormous brio, Errol Flynn at his devil-may-care best as the fastest bow in town, Olivia de Havilland his haughty but melting Maid Marian; and Basil Rathbone and Claude Rains make a fine dastardly duo as Guy of Gisbourne and Prince John. The non-stop, high-spirited action (Keighley was replaced by the more dynamic Curtiz), builds to a classic final duel between Robin and Guy; all superbly photographed in the new, lustrous, Technicolor.

Mina Tannenbaum
(Martine Dugowson, 1993)
1.50am, FilmFour

Dugowson also wrote the prize-winning script about two young Jewish women whose long, close friendship grows antagonistic when they become rivals in love. Reticent, bespectacled Mina (Romane Bohringer) has artistic ambitions, Ethel (Elsa Zylberstein) is a vivacious media type; the actresses make the odd-couple relationship a plausible, painful affair; but the film fades away after the account of the pair's chirpy, charming early years together.

Sheriff Ben Affleck teams with a local doctor (Joanna Going), her younger sister (Rose McGowan) and a boffin (Peter O'Toole), when the population of a Colorado town are torn apart by an unidentifiable entity. Suspenseful early scenes that, for once, don't get less scary when the creature is revealed. Red Corner (Jon Avnet, 1997) 8pm, Sky Premier Here's Richard Gere's media executive doing big business in China, spending a night with a beautiful woman who in the morning is dead. Suddenly our heroic American abroad is framed for murder, the victim of a vast, opaque and implacable foreign justice system. But luckily, along comes another beautiful woman (Bai Ling) and this one's a lawyer who believes he's innocent. Kafka it ain't. It's played with enormous brio, Errol Flynn at his devil-may-care best as the fastest bow in town, Olivia de Havilland his haughty but melting Maid Marian; and Basil Rathbone and Claude Rains make a fine dastardly duo as Guy of Gisbourne and Prince John. fields.headline: Last night's TV
fields.standfirst: You're a big man, but...
fields.trailText: As my osteopath said yesterday while bending my leg sideways at right angles, the only mammal that does not suffer from arthritis is the three-toed sloth. I have not confirmed this personally with a sloth - you do get fed up waiting for an answer - but you cannot fail to envy the creature's laid-back life-style. The sloth does not spend its life fruitlessly defying gravity. It lets it all hang down.
fields.body:
As my osteopath said yesterday while bending my leg sideways at right angles, the only mammal that does not suffer from arthritis is the three-toed sloth. I have not confirmed this personally with a sloth - you do get fed up waiting for an answer - but you cannot fail to envy the creature's laid-back life-style. The sloth does not spend its life fruitlessly defying gravity. It lets it all hang down.

Man's troubles began when he stood up.

The subject of this week's Ape- Man: Adventures In Human Evolution (BBC 2) was homo erectus. The 12-year-old boy whose bones were found beside Lake Turkama in Kenya walked upright. He was intimidatingly powerful and surprisingly tall. Had he lived he would have been well over six feet. Curiously, many misty myths, including Genesis, ("There were giants in the earth in those days") suggest that the human race has shrunk. The boy had curvature of the spine from a fall or fight, a condition found in human beings but not in apes, and he died an agonising and delirious death from blood poisoning, caused by an abscess in the mouth.

A million and a half years passed.

Richard Leakey, Professor Alan Walker and their team excavated the boy's scattered bones. There were so many that every time their little picks hit bone, they rang "Ping!" and the whole group turned. This over-produced series is so prone to portentous booming that the sound of the bone, calling from the ground, was overlooked. We got the usual boom. The boy's teeth were found in the footprint of a hippopotamus. An acacia tree, mad for moisture, had germinated in the cup of his skull.

Crucially, inside the skull Walker found a curved area normally connected with speech. "I thought 'Ah-ha!' this was a child who could speak."

The missing link. There has been nothing like it since Jimmy Durante found the lost chord. President Reagan, stumbling charmingly over the name, gave a medal to Kamoya Kimeu, the fossil hunter who found the first bone.

Then Walker had one of those second thoughts that wake you sweat-drenched from deep sleep. He remembered the boy's vertebrae.

They suggested that the spinal cord was too small for speech. Walker concluded that homo erectus had the brain of a one-year-old baby and the communicative skill of a chimpanzee. Richard Leakey differed sharply. "I think homo erectus spoke. I'm sure of it, but it's a reaction from the gut not the head."

In any difference of opinion, the better speaker will be the winner. That is the point of speech. Walker's communicative skills cannot be faulted. He imagined an eerie encounter with homo erectus. They were in the distance. They looked like human beings. They walked like human beings. You hurried hopefully towards them.

"You might feel that you'd see something human in their faces and be able to communicate but it was probably much more like the feeling you get when you come round a bush and you see a lion. You see those big, yellow eyes staring at you and you know there is nothing there communicating with you."

I used to see the last totter on the Thames, an old man in an old boat, rowing his way up the river. He was particularly fond of the curve where the millennium dome now stands. The river takes a tight bend there, slows down and drops its surplus freight. Once upon a time he would have had rich fishing, flotsam and jetsam and boxes that had fallen off the back of a boat. Now he found, perhaps, a pallet. Still, looking on the bright side, it was something for nothing.

The Antiques Show (BBC 2), an effortlessly elegant and overlooked programme, did an item on finding treasure in the Thames. It is called mudlarking. You need a licence from the Port of London Authority to become an accredited mudlark and are supposed to have a soul above vulgar value. Which is just as well, as the river, like a true Londoner, tends to drop rubbish. Anything you find must be offered to the Museum of London, who will probably give it back briskly. They have a whole drawer of buckles and another of rusty daggers ("Ordinary civilian daggers that all the best dressed men in London would have worn.") You do wonder a bit about those daggers.

"Londoners will not choose on the basis of who's best on telly."- Paul Boateng.

Discuss incredulously.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What wine tasters watch on television
fields.trailText: Vincent Duer: "I'm not an avid watcher of television, but I like to settle down in front of the box as a de-stressing exercise, obviously with a bottle of wine, heh. I do like that Tony Robinson programme, Timewatch or something, where there's a historical twist. I used to love watching him in Blackadder too, I have all the videos. Last thing I watched was probably the Brits awards, and I got a bit sucked in because I do love Davina McCall, I think she's tremendous, gutsy. Person I can't stand? Charlie Dimmock. Exploits her position, if you see what I mean."
fields.body:
Vincent Duer: "I'm not an avid watcher of television, but I like to settle down in front of the box as a de-stressing exercise, obviously with a bottle of wine, heh. I do like that Tony Robinson programme, Timewatch or something, where there's a historical twist. I used to love watching him in Blackadder too, I have all the videos. Last thing I watched was probably the Brits awards, and I got a bit sucked in because I do love Davina McCall, I think she's tremendous, gutsy. Person I can't stand? Charlie Dimmock. Exploits her position, if you see what I mean."

May Lionel: "I feel terribly guilty when I'm watching television, like I should be actually doing something, like going for a swim or cooking. I do like a bit of Morse, or a bit of costume drama, but I'd rather have a good bottle while I'm cooking, Keith Floyd style, rather than drink in front of the gogglebox."

Derek Peat: "Oh, it's very fashionable to be an expert on television these days, keeps us lot in business. I can't stand that Jilly Goulden woman, I know she's helped us all out, and I think she is a good, popular critic, but I just find her personality annoying. I for one liked the job when people found me interesting at par ties, but now all you get is 'Jilly Goulden this and that', and now I'm not half as scintillating as telly. What I watch is very arbitrary. I like a bit of Emmerdale, because it's filmed near where I live, and I like a bit of the morning BBC television, because the news coverage is so good. I'll tell you what I used to love, One Man And His Dog. Marvellous, zen TV."

Keith Jameson: "Can't stand it, drives me mad. Actually, I'll tell you, I like that advert with the old man and the grandson, because my family say I'm like the old man. Werthingtons - Werthers Original, that's it. That's my sort of television, old man's channel, that's what I'd watch. Three hours of people building ships out of matchsticks, hahah. One person I dislike? Who's that camp fellow? Dale Winton. Need I say anything else?"

fields.headline: Beyond a joke
fields.standfirst: Great gags, stunning animation, superb characters - everybody knows why Toy Story II was a huge hit. Everybody, that seems, except for Disney, which is throwing out all that for its Buzz Lightyear TV spin-off.  Mark Morris is alarmed
fields.trailText: Great gags, stunning animation, superb characters - everybody knows why Toy Story II was a huge hit. Everybody, that seems, except for Disney, which is throwing out all that for its Buzz Lightyear TV spin-off.
fields.body:
Odds are, you saw the original Toy Story. Just in case you didn't, or it has vanished from your memory, or you are a Disney executive: the central joke in the film is that Buzz Lightyear knuckleheadly refuses to believe that he is a plastic TV tie-in action figure. Instead, he is absolutely, religiously insistent that he is a Space Ranger from the Universe Protection Force, battling to save the galaxy from the evil Emperor Zurg. He tries to repair his rocket shaped box. He convinces himself that a pizza joint is a spaceport. His delusion is total. It's very funny. "You're a TOY, idiot!" his fellow plaything Woody screams at him, vainly. The moment when Buzz is disillusioned by a TV ad that ends with an image of a superstore packed with hundreds of identical Buzzes sets up the most touching moment of the movie, when Buzz forlornly flips up a flap on his arm and reads the words "Made In Taiwan".

Why does this matter? Because in the new Buzz Lightyear TV spin-off, he really is a Space Ranger from the Universe Protection Force, battling to save the galaxy from the evil Emperor Zurg. That's it: Flash Gordon simple. No delicate play with notions of what's real and what's not, or gentle deflating of square-jawed all-American heroes with no sense of their own absurdity. No, "the success of the Toy Story movies and the fan base surrounding the characters made Buzz Lightyear an obvious choice as the heroic lead for a comedy-adventure TV series", Buena Vista's Janice Marinelli blandly announced last week.

She's probably right: Buzz Lightyear already has a life beyond the limits of the two Toy Story films. The first film is on the side of the old-fashioned Woody: you know that from the start, because he is voiced by Tom Hanks. But kids buying Toy Story toys always ignore Woody in favour of Buzz Lightyear. For the very reasons you're meant to be suspicious of him in the film: he's shinier, flashier and does more stuff.

Along with abandoning the best idea in the film, the Buzz Lightyear series does away with its other selling point. While Toy Story was marketed on the basis of its revolutionary computer animation - to the point where it came as something of a surprise that they had actually bothered to make a good movie to go along with the technology - the Buzz Lightyear series is a cartoon like they used to do them, drawn flat. Unless something astonishing happens in the scriptwriting, Buzz Lightyear will be the Toy Story spin-off that takes everything that made the movies so good and throws it away before they even begin.

And it's not alone: lurking on Sky One on Saturday mornings is Starship Troopers. Although plenty of educated people went into denial about it, Paul Verhoeven's movie is - whether you like it as a film or not - a satire. As it takes roughly two minutes of the film to make clear, the Dutchman is laughing at those grinning 90210-rejects getting sliced up by the claws of those angry bugs.

The computer animated TV series is, of course, another matter entirely. The viewers are meant to be sympathetic to the boxheaded space commandos. You're not meant to think they are stupid. You're not meant to snigger when they're wasted. And here's why: it turns out that although the series was made off the back of the movie, it snuck back to the source material, Robert Heinlein's 1959 novel. Heinlein existed for budding fascists everywhere who found Ayn Rand a bit of a tough read - so unlike Verhoeven, Heinlein was right behind his surf Nazis. And although there is still plenty of violence in the TV series, it is marketed at kids who wouldn't be allowed to see the more sneakily intelligent movie.

Maybe it's just all those years of the Simpsons, South Park, Rugrats or Pinky And The Brain, but it has become too easy to have high expectations of cartoons, whether ostensibly aimed at kids or adults. We almost take it for granted that they will somehow undermine the American Way. But it ain't necessarily so.

That's what Kevin Smith seems to be learning: he's been getting excited about Clerks: The Animated Series, for a long time. When he was going around the world plugging Dogma, he spent a lot of time talking about the TV show instead. Now, he's worried that the series will never be shown at all. It was originally scheduled to start on ABC in March, but has been put back to the end of May, where it will get lost amid the summer repeats.

"So let's all give Disney-owned ABC a big round of applause," Smith wrote on his www.viewaskew.com. "I don't know why I bother. You go bottomless amongst penned-up anal rapists like these, sooner or later, you're going to get cornholed against your will."

Which might be an unnecessarily graphic image, but then, if we can't get our subversive or just plain crass kicks from TV cartoons anymore, what's left?

fields.headline: Lords reform delay angers Tories
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday came under fire from Conservative peers after it failed to offer a timetable for second stage reform in the House of Lords.
fields.body:
The government yesterday came under fire from Conservative peers after it failed to offer a timetable for second stage reform in the House of Lords.

Tories accused ministers of being "secretive, partisan, non-consensual and lacking in any long term vision" as the leader of the Lords, Lady Jay declined to give a detailed response to recommendations made in the Wakeham report on the house's future structure.

In the face of Conservative scepticism, Lady Jay insisted the government was determined to press ahead with further Lords reform and not leave plans on a "dusty top shelf". She also confirmed indications given when the report was published in January that the government will reject the most democratic option of three offered by the royal commission, each proposing different numbers of elected peers.

Ministers will not accept a proposal which would see 195 peers elected, preferring to confine the elected element of the upper house to either 65 or 87 peers out of some 550 in a reformed chamber. The rest would be appointed by a statutory appointments commission - another Wakeham proposal which the government backs "in principle".

A totally elected Lords could obscure "the clear voice of the people" and "weaken" democratic responsibility, Lady Jay claimed. She disclosed the government was having "informal" discussions to seek the basis for a consensus. She had talked to Conservative and crossbench leaders, as well as with representatives of Scotland and Wales, the Church of England and other denominations. The Tory peers' leader, Lord Strathclyde, condemned the government for not giving a reform timetable, demanding to know whether changes would happen before the election or in the next parliament.

The Conservatives believe that the current Lords, minus the hereditary peers, can cause difficulties for the government since ministers have acknowledged that it has greater legitimacy than the previous chamber. Peers have already rebelled onthe right to jury trial and the repeal of section 28.

webTitle: Knives out for McDonagh after selection fiasco

fields.headline: Knives out for McDonagh after selection fiasco
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The knives were being sharpened last night as Labour MPs launched an inquest into the fiasco which has turned Londoners against Tony Blair and virtually guaranteed that Ken Livingstone will be swept into office as London's first directly elected mayor.
fields.body:
The knives were being sharpened last night as Labour MPs launched an inquest into the fiasco which has turned Londoners against Tony Blair and virtually guaranteed that Ken Livingstone will be swept into office as London's first directly elected mayor.

Margaret McDonagh, Labour's fearsome general secretary who masterminded the "Stop Ken" campaign, found herself first in the firing line when a London Labour MP launched an extraordinary public attack on her.

Stephen Pound, MP for Ealing North, called on Ms McDonagh to explain why she failed to heed "loud and clear" signals about the depth of support for a Livingstone campaign.

"When the dust has settled and the blood has soaked into the carpet and the bodies have been dragged away for burial, there will be a postmortem as there hasn't been in London Labour politics this side of the war," Mr Pound said.

His outburst was echoed privately - in milder terms - by Blairite loyalists who criticised Ms McDonagh for making a catastrophic miscalculation in believing that Mr Livingstone would "bottle out" of an independent campaign.

Ms McDonagh plumped for the complex electoral college on the correct assumption that it would block Mr Livingstone, without apparently appreciating that such a discredited system would only serve to boost his independent campaign.

"We all thought he would bottle it," a senior London Labour figure said. "This is not a battle we thought we would have to fight."

In a sign of the renewed Labour in-fighting, Ms McDonagh's supporters sprang to her defence last night.

Fraser Kemp, a former Labour election campaign co-ordinator, said: "For people now to come out with the suprising revelation that Ken Livingstone is popular in London and Margaret McDonagh kept it from them is ridiculous. She warned them every step of the way."

Ms McDonagh's defenders believe she should be given credit for avoiding the worst case scenario: a Livingstone victory in the selection contest which would have seen him stand as Labour's official candidate.

Tony Blair, who believes that the likes of Mr Livingstone were responsible for keeping Labour out of power for nearly a generation, was determined to block him.

Despite the apparent cross-party love for the former Greater London council leader, the prime minister was adamant that a Livingstone mayoralty in Labour colours would alarm middle England voters in the run-up to a general election.

Ms McDonagh argued correctly that the electoral college, which ensured that the votes of a Labour MP were worth the votes of 1,000 ordinary party members, was the only way of beating Mr Livingstone if he were allowed to stand.

When the party's London selection panel allowed his name to go forward last November Ms McDonagh argued - once again correctly - that the election should be strung out to allow Mr Dobson to build up momentum.

webTitle: Favourite concedes race will be close

fields.headline: Favourite concedes race will be close
fields.standfirst:
Mayor contest: Labour admits Dobson is underdog as Livingstone warns supporters against over-optimism

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday warned his supporters that the London mayoral race would end up being a tight fight between himself and the Labour and Tory party machines, despite his runaway lead in the Guardian/ICM opinion poll, published yesterday.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday warned his supporters that the London mayoral race would end up being a tight fight between himself and the Labour and Tory party machines, despite his runaway lead in the Guardian/ICM opinion poll, published yesterday.

On his first full day campaigning as an independent, the former Greater London council leader tried to wind down expectations aroused by his 55-point lead over the official Labour candidate Frank Dobson, as Labour's spokesman declared: "Frank is the underdog now".

"My expectation is that between Steve Norris, the Tory candidate, Frank Dobson and myself there is going to be very little in it on polling day and every vote is going to count," said the newly-suspended Labour MP for Brent East. "I am certain as the campaign rolls on, it is actually going to be a very tight fight. There is no way to go but down."

Mr Livingstone also went out of his way to emphasise his Labour credentials and support for the re-election of Tony Blair's government, despite the prime minister's prediction that he would be a disaster for London. "This isn't some fundamental schism," he insisted.

Appealing to his supporters to cast their potentially crucial second preference votes on May 4 for Mr Dobson, who has pointedly refused to say who he wants his own voters to transfer to, Mr Livingstone said he hoped one day to be back in the Labour party.

"I am not setting up another rival party, I am just giving Londoners the right to choose who they want as mayor," he said.

The Labour hierarchy meanwhile sought to turn the tables on its tormentor by proclaiming Mr Dobson as the underdog, now that he is trailing Mr Livingstone by 55 points. "Ken cannot have it both ways," a spokesman said, deriding the idea that he had "only three men and a goat helping him".

Mr Livingstone appealed for Londoners to donate the £500,000 he says he needs to run a "people's campaign". Bobbie Law, an official of the London region of the Rail Maritime and Transport union, said it intended to campaign and raise funds for his campaign.

As cabinet office minister Ian McCartney branded Mr Livingstone "the David Owen of the hard left", and Mr Blair's spokesman called him "poor little unspun Ken", the former GLC leader was mobbed and cheered by students when he arrived for a lunchtime hustings at the London School of Economics.

Mr Dobson, by contrast, was initially greeted with laughter as he began to address the hundreds of students packed into a lecture hall, telling them that his rival had failed to win the Labour nomination because he had been opposed by MPs - "the people who knew him best trusted him least".

Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat candidate, who yesterday announced her running mate as Baroness Hamwee, a local government stalwart, said she believed the faultline "tearing Labour in two" could mark a sea-change in British politics, signalling an end to traditional broad church "umbrella parties".

But while she accused Mr Dobson and Mr Livingstone of turning the mayoral contest into a "laughing stock" and pleaded for an end to "celebrity and personalities", Mr Livingstone won enthusiastic applause when he told the students: "You, the voters, should decide who represents you, not party bureaucrats or rigged electoral colleges".

He went on to attack London businesses for failing to do more for the city's ethnic minorities.

Labour's spokesman countered: "There is no doubt this man is anti-business."

fields.headline: Michael Holland
fields.trailText: Michael Holland, who has died of heart failure aged 73, was headmaster of Milton Abbey School in Dorset, and later rector of Steeple Aston and two other parishes north of Oxford. His task at Milton Abbey was to raise academic standards and draw the public school away from its country-club image. After 10 years he left behind a serious educational establishment.
fields.body:
Michael Holland, who has died of heart failure aged 73, was headmaster of Milton Abbey School in Dorset, and later rector of Steeple Aston and two other parishes north of Oxford. His task at Milton Abbey was to raise academic standards and draw the public school away from its country-club image. After 10 years he left behind a serious educational establishment.

Holland was a canon's son. After schooling at Marlborough, he went, via the navy, to read history at Cambridge. He then taught history and coached rugby and athletics at Eastbourne College before moving on to Milton Abbey.

At 52, Holland offered himself for ordination. After a curacy, he moved to Steeple Aston, drawing parishes together, preaching with care and resource, and conduct ing services with presence and dignity. He and his wife, Gillian, were an unusual pair to find in a country rectory, but were a highly effective team.

After he retired to Iffley, Holland continued to help in parishes, and formed a link with the Community of the Sisters of the Love of God, in Oxford, often celebrating their Saturday eucharist. Between their different traditions there was a flowering of great mutual respect.

Holland was open, generous and unselfseeking. He had friends in many walks of life and God was at the centre of his own. He and his wife had four daughters.

 William Michael Tristram Holland, schoolmaster and priest, born November 20 1926; died January 22 2000

fields.headline: Adi Boman
fields.standfirst: Scientist on an unresolved search for a cancer cure
fields.trailText: In the mid-1970s Dr Michael Tisdale, then at St Thomas's Hospital medical school in London, was contacted by a pharmacist friend. The friend had been providing chemicals for the extraction of an active component from yeast to an Indian scientist living in a Welsh village. The scientist was Dr Adi Boman, who has died aged 90, and was then working on an anti-cancer agent. The pharmacist suggested that Tisdale might be able to test the agent for evidence of anti-tumour properties.
fields.body:
In the mid-1970s Dr Michael Tisdale, then at St Thomas's Hospital medical school in London, was contacted by a pharmacist friend. The friend had been providing chemicals for the extraction of an active component from yeast to an Indian scientist living in a Welsh village. The scientist was Dr Adi Boman, who has died aged 90, and was then working on an anti-cancer agent. The pharmacist suggested that Tisdale might be able to test the agent for evidence of anti-tumour properties.

Tisdale was sceptical; proposed cures for cancer are commonplace, successful ones are not. But preliminary testing went ahead. The results were promising; the agent appeared to inhibit cancer growth in mice.

A central problem that Boman and Tisdale faced was lack of funding. To get money for controlled testing, data was needed; this meant prior, controlled testing, and itself required money. Yet funds were raised from Boman's fellow villagers in Wales and testing went ahead.

Boman's quest had begun in the late 1940s, when his son, Darius, was born with Down's syndrome and had not been given long to live. The doctor developed a homeopathic vaccine, which he administered, and, whether due to the vaccine or not, the boy survived. He is now 51.

The doctor's research was published in the Homeopathic Journal. Later, Boman developed it towards finding a cancer cure. He concluded that an extract of baker's yeast, which he called "canyeast", appeared to display anti-tumour activity with no toxic effects. It was, however, distinctly pungent. Boman prepared it in a caravan, some distance from his house.

Research continued. Funds were raised, and there seemed to be positive clinical responses in private patients, although these findings were not controlled. They could not be measured - which was when Tisdale, now professor of cancer biochemistry at Aston University, Birmingham, came in.

Boman was born in Bombay to a distinguished Parsee family. In 1934, he graduated from the city's medical school. Arriving in London in 1948, he worked at the Royal London Hospital of Homeopathy until 1951. From the 1960s until the late 1990s, he was an allopathic and homeopathic doctor practising in Harley Street and Camden Town.

Tisdale's support for Boman back in the 1970s took place with the knowledge that, in the l940s, it was shown that extracts of yeast produced tumour growth inhibition in animal experiments. But there was not be a happy ending to their research. The Aston professor believes that, in the mid-1980s, they were about three quarters of the way towards identifying the key element within the yeast when funding finally ran out. The research, he suspects, has probably died with Boman, a man whose mind, he observed, remained as active as ever to his final days.

In 1939, the expressionist dancer Hilde Holger fled the Nazis from her native Vienna. Denied access to Britain, she went to India. Poor and lonely, she was introduced to Dr Boman; the dancer and the doctor married in l940.

They both worked intensely into their 90s, and Hilde still teaches. As for Adi Boman, his friends speak of him as a quiet genius whose work was never carried through to full term. He is survived by his wife, two daughters, Primavera and Tehmina, and his son.

 Adi Boman (Ardeshir Kavasji Boman-Behram), homeopath, born December 21 1909; died February 10 2000

fields.headline: Esmé Goldberg
fields.standfirst: A fighter against apartheid, with and without her jailed husband
fields.trailText: As the wife of a Rivonia "lifer", Esmé Goldberg, who has died in London aged 70, was one of a select band of women in South Africa's anti-apartheid struggle. When, in 1964, her husband Denis was jailed with Nelson Mandela and six other freedom fighters, she was left in no doubt that his life sentence meant "until death". He was, in fact, released after 22 years, but during that time Esmé established an independent identity with originality and a certain joie de vivre.
fields.body:
As the wife of a Rivonia "lifer", Esmé Goldberg, who has died in London aged 70, was one of a select band of women in South Africa's anti-apartheid struggle. When, in 1964, her husband Denis was jailed with Nelson Mandela and six other freedom fighters, she was left in no doubt that his life sentence meant "until death". He was, in fact, released after 22 years, but during that time Esmé established an independent identity with originality and a certain joie de vivre.

Esmé was born in Johannesburg and trained as a physiotherapist at St Mary's Hospital, London. In 1960, when Denis was detained under the apartheid regime's state of emergency for four months, Esmé started a physiotherapy practice, to be sure of a family income. She was terrified of arrest, for no relative was prepared to look after their two children if she was taken in as well.

Her worst fears were soon realised. When the Pretoria government introduced imprisonment without trial, Denis went underground, but was soon arrested, together with much of the high command of Urnkhonto we-Sizwe (Spear of the Nation), at the Rivonia farmstead. The family drove 1,000 miles to Johannesburg, hoping he might be released after 90 days. Instead, Esmé herself was arrested.

During 38 days in a cell in Cape Town, her interrogators threatened to put her children, Hilary and David, into separate government orphanages. In the end, the police had to believe she knew nothing. Her humorous, matter-of-fact way with people helped - she brought her massaging skills to bear on the tired feet of the chief wardress. Although loathe to leave her husband facing the death penalty, she took her children to England, where she addressed dozens of meetings.

As a physiotherapist, her patients included Barbara Castle, Peter O'Toole, Peter Cook, Dudley Moore and the anti-apartheid exile community. She was not a member of the Communist party, and avoided the rigorous control that the South African CP cells in London liked to impose on a comrade's lifestyle.

Her lifestyle could not have been more different. It was open house to the world's youth, including the young Thabo Mbeki, now president of South Africa, and Oliver Tambo's children. Many came for an afternoon and stayed for months. Most important, she had carried out her husband's wish that she make a home for her children in a safe place.

Esmé was allowed to visit Denis twice in Pretoria central prison, although their children went more regularly, their fares paid by Canon John Collins's defence and aid fund. But 22 years is a long time, and it became harder to sustain their life through letter-writing. Then, unexpectedly, Denis was released in 1985. By now, Esmé was entrenched in England (coming from his solitary cell, Denis was forever tripping over people in his new house). She could not return home when the thaw came in 1990. The grandchildren were English. It was a double exile.

Her cremation attracted friends from around the world. The family dressed her in a simple caftan and no make-up. That, said her husband, was Esmé.

fields.headline: Claude Raymond
fields.trailText: General Claude Raymond, who has died aged 69, oversaw the installation of a befuddled 19-year-old as dictator of Haiti in 1971, opening a new chapter of misery for Latin America's poorest nation after the rule of the youth's father, President-for-life François "Papa Doc" Duvalier.
fields.body:
General Claude Raymond, who has died aged 69, oversaw the installation of a befuddled 19-year-old as dictator of Haiti in 1971, opening a new chapter of misery for Latin America's poorest nation after the rule of the youth's father, President-for-life François "Papa Doc" Duvalier.

Haitians called Raymond, who spent the last four years of his life in prison, a "dinosaur". He was one of the barons of the Duvalier family's 29-year dictatorship who, led by Raymond, did their best to snuff out attempts to establish democracy after the regime collapsed.

A distant relative (and godson) of Papa Doc, Raymond earned his spurs as a young captain, when he helped fight off a band of rebel invaders who, in 1958, tried to seize the national palace with the dictator inside it. A grateful Duvalier made him head of the presidential guard and an early chief of his private militia, the Tontons Macoutes. When Papa Doc lay dying, he named Raymond as army commander, with the task of seeing that Duvalier's son, Jean-Claude, succeeded as the country's sixth "president-for-life". The general ensured that it all went like clockwork.

It was a good time for the Raymonds. Claude's younger brother, Adrien, got the foreign ministry, his sister, Paulette, was private secretary to the new president's iron-willed mother, and two other brothers were living it up abroad as diplomats. But by the summer of 1973, things had fallen apart.

Claude lost a power struggle and was exiled as ambassador to Spain. Adrien was pushed out soon afterwards. In 1979, the general was summoned back as interior and defence minister to deal with growing unrest, but was sent on his way after only five months, accused of pocketing the cash set aside for the president's celebrations on the eve of his wedding.

After the Duvaliers fled to France in 1986, Raymond tried to rally the fallen regime's thugs and enforcers. A year later, a score of people were hacked and shot to death in a schoolyard as they queued to vote in what was to be Haiti's first free presidential election, from which Raymond had been banned. The ballot was cancelled in mid-vote.

The killers had been seen leaving Raymond's villa in a pick-up truck shortly before the massacre. A few weeks later, he was tut-tutting to me in his garden about people being "killed in the streets like wild beasts." He generated such fear that he was barred again as a presidential candidate in 1990.

Raymond's political career came to an end in 1996. He was arrested on his way back from a voodoo festival and thrown in jail for "terrorist and subversive activities" linked to a supposed anti- government plot and the murder of policemen by ex-members of the dissolved army.

But he was never tried. The courts ordered his release several times, but the government kept him in prison for the election massacre. Ironically, Raymond ended his days an incongruous martyr to Haiti's dilapidated legal system, with UN human rights officials holding him up as an example of how justice was not being done.

 Claude Raymond, general and politician, born 1930; died February 9 2000

Claude's younger brother, Adrien, got the foreign ministry, his sister, Paulette, was private secretary to the new president's iron-willed mother, and two other brothers were living it up abroad as diplomats. But by the summer of 1973, things had fallen apart. Claude lost a power struggle and was exiled as ambassador to Spain. Adrien was pushed out soon afterwards. In 1979, the general was summoned back as interior and defence minister to deal with growing unrest, but was sent on his way after only five months, accused of pocketing the cash set aside for the president's celebrations on the eve of his wedding. After the Duvaliers fled to France in 1986, Raymond tried to rally the fallen regime's thugs and enforcers. A year later, a score of people were hacked and shot to death in a schoolyard as they queued to vote in what was to be Haiti's first free presidential election, from which Raymond had been banned. The ballot was cancelled in mid-vote. The killers had been seen leaving Raymond's villa in a pick-up truck shortly before the massacre. A few weeks later, he was tut-tutting to me in his garden about people being "killed in the streets like wild beasts." He generated such fear that he was barred again as a presidential candidate in 1990. Raymond's political career came to an end in 1996. He was arrested on his way back from a voodoo festival and thrown in jail for "terrorist and subversive activities" linked to a supposed anti- government plot and the murder of policemen by ex-members of the dissolved army. But he was never tried. The courts ordered his release several times, but the government kept him in prison for the election massacre. Ironically, Raymond ended his days an incongruous martyr to Haiti's dilapidated legal system, with UN human rights officials holding him up as an example of how justice was not being done.  Claude Raymond, general and politician, born 1930; died February 9 2000

fields.headline: John Colicos
fields.standfirst: Actor enmeshed in Churchill controversy
fields.trailText: In 1968, John Colicos, who has died aged 71 after a heart attack, was briefly sucked into a Fleet Street controversy surrounding the German Rolf Hochhuth's play, Soldiers, in which the stocky Canadian played Winston Churchill. The play had to wait for the abolition of the role of the lord chamberlain - as theatre censor - before its London production at the New Theatre. It had already been taken to New York.
fields.body:
In 1968, John Colicos, who has died aged 71 after a heart attack, was briefly sucked into a Fleet Street controversy surrounding the German Rolf Hochhuth's play, Soldiers, in which the stocky Canadian played Winston Churchill. The play had to wait for the abolition of the role of the lord chamberlain - as theatre censor - before its London production at the New Theatre. It had already been taken to New York.

In Soldiers, Churchill is seen as condoning (if not actually arranging) the death of his friend, the Polish leader General Sikorski, to pacify Stalin - a thesis that led to a successful libel action against Hochhuth. At the play's centre is a debate on the policy of the saturation bombing of German cities, conducted between Churchill and the policy's critic, the Bishop of Chichester.

"An uncannily believable and sustained portrayal of Winston Churchill by John Colicos was hypnotically interesting," wrote a New York critic. "The actor created, not a replica, but a strong impression of the great man." Colicos got all the notices in what was, in truth, a rather plodding play.

Later, wearing a sickeningly green velvet garment and a hairpiece with its suggestion of satanic horns, Colicos was to be found playing the treacherous Count Baltar in the cultish TV sci-fi series, Battlestar Galactica. Spending a great deal of time in a high-backed swivel chair on a pedestal, issuing fateful commands, Baltar, the arch-enemy of Adama (Lorne Greene), commander of the eponymous spaceship, betrayed his fellow human beings by throwing in his lot with the Cylons, a reptilian race from a far corner of the galaxy.

"Villains, like blondes, have more fun," said Colicos. "When you do science fiction, then the imagination can run wild. These films appeal to the childish imagination in everybody. Battlestar was like playing games again, with mad costumes and ridiculous lines. It was a ball." Previously, he also had fun as the bellicose Klingon Commander Kor in several Star Trek episodes. "On Star Trek I just literally walked from set to set following my makeup around," he commented.

Colicos was born in Toronto but grew up in Montreal, where he made his acting debut playing Jesus in a biblical pageant. "One of the first roles I ever played was the Son of God, and I've been going downhill ever since."

In fact, Colicos gained a reputation in the theatre as a powerful Shakespearean actor, making his New York debut as Edmund, in King Lear, in 1957, before joining the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre at Stratford, Connecticut, where he played a range of roles that included Leontes, in A Winter's Tale. At Stratford, Ontario, in the early 1960s, he impressed as Petruchio, in The Taming Of The Shrew, and in the title role of Timon Of Athens.

At the same time, he was appearing regularly on television, gaining recognition in various episodes of Mission Impossible. "I think I've been on just about every crime or adventure TV drama there is," he claimed.

The dozen or so roles Colicos had in feature films were less memorable. He co-starred with Richard Burton in Anne Of The Thousand Days (1970) as Thomas Cromwell, and in Raid On Rommel (1971). He killed his cheating wife in the tawdry Doctors' Wives (1971), was the CIA boss who wants agent Burt Lancaster killed in Michael Winner's Scorpio (1973), and portrayed a camp New Orleans dandy in the lurid Drum (1976). In contrast, he was effective as the likeable Nick Papadakis, brutally murdered by his wife and her lover in Bob Rafelson's steamy The Postman Always Rings Twice (1981).

But it was as Count Baltar, from the first episode of Battlestar Galactica in 1978, and in the film version a year later, that he pleased audiences most. "Half the time when I was playing Baltar, the scene started when I would whirl around in the chair, and there I would be, the regal lord, sitting on top of the pedestal. The most dangerous part of the whole performance was getting up 30ft on that ladder, with four stagehands hanging on. They shot all my stuff on a crane. What with 'By your command' and all this, I finally got to the point where I thought if I talked any more to bloody robots, I would go out of my mind."

Colicos lived most of the time with his wife Mona - they had two sons - in Toronto in a house that contained his 4,000-volume theatrical research library. "I've always remained a 19th century, slightly hammy, overblown actor," he said. "I prefer gigantic parts with huge emotions to playing kitchen drama. I'm too big for television now. I'm too big for my house. I belong on another planet somewhere. I wish there were a space shuttle going to Mars. I would take my Shakespeare and start a new company . . . somewhere up there."

 John Colicos, actor, born December 10 1928; died March 6 2000

fields.headline: Israeli minister faces sex charge
fields.trailText: A tearful deputy prime minister yesterday appeared on Israeli national television to announce that he was taking leave of absence while police investigate allegations that he sexually assaulted an employee in his transport ministry.
fields.body:
A tearful deputy prime minister yesterday appeared on Israeli national television to announce that he was taking leave of absence while police investigate allegations that he sexually assaulted an employee in his transport ministry.

After a day of drama played out on the airwaves in excruciating detail, Yitzhak Mordechai denied the charges made by an unnamed 23-year-old woman.

In excerpts from a polygraph lie-detector test broadcast on radio, the woman said Mr Mordechai locked her in an office, touched her under her shirt, kissed her neck and pushed her on to a sofa in an attempt to have sex.

The test related to just one incident in an alleged campaign of harassment. The results indicated the worker was telling the truth, police said.

"I want to tell the whole house of Israel and everyone who knows me: everything I have been accused of is not true. It never happened. I say this with a tranquil heart," Mr Mordechai told a press conference.

He added that he would cooperate with police and would absent himself from public life for two weeks.

For Israeli feminists, Mr Mordechai's temporary departure was a victory for a campaign - conducted on radio and in a demonstration outside the Knesset - that was launched within minutes of an earlier statement by the deputy prime minister on Israeli Radio this morning that: "I do not spend time on nonsense."

"This is your best example of how far we have come," said Knesset member and feminist Naomi Chazan. "If this had happened five or 10 years ago, it would have been pooh-poohed. Now there is a public outcry."

The unnamed woman, accompanied by her mother and boyfriend, first notified the speaker of the Knesset, Abraham Burg, of the assault two weeks ago. The allegations became public knowledge after the woman turned to police on Monday and a newspaper ran a story yesterday.

If Mr Mordechai were to be prosecuted, his parliamentary immunity would have to be lifted first.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
No Papon pardon
President Jacques Chirac has rejected an appeal by convicted French Nazi collaborator Maurice Papon for a pardon because of his poor health, the president's office said yesterday.
fields.body:
No Papon pardon
President Jacques Chirac has rejected an appeal by convicted French Nazi collaborator Maurice Papon for a pardon because of his poor health, the president's office said yesterday.

Papon, 89, who is serving a 10-year sentence for his wartime role in deporting Jews to Nazi death camps, has a history of cardiac illness. He has been rushed to hospital twice since he began serving his sentence in October. [Reuters, Paris]

Bosnian arrests
Police in the southern city of Mostar have arrested five Bosnian Croats suspected of war crimes, a law enforcement official said yesterday. The five are accused of "ethnic cleansing" and other war crimes and are being questioned on the disappearance of 13 Muslim soldiers arrested in Mostar in 1993. [AP, Mostar]

Porn doesn't pay
A Frenchman who dozed off while watching a porn film in a sex shop on Saturday had to be rescued by police, the daily Libération reported. The 25-year-old called police after he woke during the night to find the shop, in Reims, north-east France, was locked and the owner had gone for the weekend. [Reuters, Paris]

webTitle: Japanese to halt advance into human cloning

fields.headline: Japanese to halt advance into human cloning
fields.trailText: The Japanese government is planning to ban research into human cloning in what would be its first legal regulation of life science studies.
fields.body:
The Japanese government is planning to ban research into human cloning in what would be its first legal regulation of life science studies.

Under a new bill drawn up by the science and technology agency, researchers who attempt to produce clones of human beings will be subject to a fine or imprisonment.

"Human cloning may pose a threat to the maintenance of social order, the foundation of which is the family," Kimihiko Oda, an agency spokesman, said.

The bill, which is expected to be submitted to parliament by the end of the month, reflects rising concern in Japan about cloning in the wake of the birth of Dolly the sheep, produced at the Roslin Institute in Scotland.

If passed, the law would ban the implanting of cloned human embryos in the uterus of a woman or animal. Cloned embryos are formed by transplanting the nucleus of a human cell into an ovum whose nucleus has been removed.

It would also ban the transplantation of chimera embryos, which are created by mixing human and animal cells, and hybrid embyros, which are formed by artificially fertilising an animal's ovum with human sperm.

In addition, the bill would tighten regulations on other cloning techniques, such as dividing fertilised eggs.

The agency said it would not close the door on all cloning research, but would monitor the field closely. Academics wanting to produce, transfer or import cloned embryos for research purposes would have to notify the science ministry.

According to Japanese media reports, the government is considering a maximum sentence of between three and seven years.

The measures, which would be among the most stringent in the world, are unusual in Japan, where non-binding administrative guidelines and self-regulation have been used to control the development of life science research.

The new stance follows a public outcry over the loopholes in the existing system of regulation. Many Japanese were shocked in December 1998, when American scientist Richard Seed announced that he had secured funds and sites to begin human cloning research in Japan.

Last November, researchers at Tokyo's university of agriculture were lambasted in the media for using cloning techniques to create human embryo stem cells.

Doctors have resisted tighter regulation, which they say would hinder research into therapeutic cloning, which aims to develop remedies for cancer, heart disease, Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease.

But the proposed move would bring Japan in line with European countries, including Britain, where the cloning of human embryos is banned for reproduction and research.

Japan remains a leader in cloning technology, particularly in the artificial reproduction of cattle. The technology is expected to produce herds of cloned cows soon.

The new bill effectively halts advances into human cloning, but this may prove to be temporary since the panel which proposed it has recommended that the legislation be reviewed after three to five years to take into account shifts in public opinion and scientific developments.

For the moment, however, the government's advisers are unequivocal. "Neither economic nor research benefits are to be gained from cloning human beings," said Yoshio Okada, the head of the panel.

fields.headline: French to boost women's wages
fields.standfirst: International women's day: special report
fields.trailText: On the eve of International Women's Day and a month after approving a law to boost sexual equality in politics, French MPs yesterday began debating new legislation that would force companies to pay women and men the same wage for the same job.
fields.body:
On the eve of International Women's Day and a month after approving a law to boost sexual equality in politics, French MPs yesterday began debating new legislation that would force companies to pay women and men the same wage for the same job.

"Discrimination against women in terms of recruitment, salaries and access to training and promotion has far from disappeared," said the Socialist MP Catherine Génisson, who proposed the bill. "This is a modest start to a very necessary process in France."

The "professional parity" bill, likely to become law next year, follows a "political parity" law passed in February, which threatened cuts in state funding for any party fielding more men than women in local, regional, general or European elections.

According to a report presented by Ms Génisson to the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, last year, women are woefully under-represented in the upper echelons of business and are almost invariably paid less than their male colleagues.

The report revealed that the average pay gap between women and men for the same job is 27%. It also showed that only 7% of managers in France's top 5,000 companies are women, while 80% of part-time workers are women, as are nearly 90% of workers on less than £6,000 a year.

The bill will force companies and trade unions - on pain of stiff penalties - to hold annual negotiations on sexual equality in the workplace, and to submit progress reports.

French women got the vote only in 1944, decades after many other European countries, and today occupy only 10.4% of seats in the 577-member National Assembly - the worst record in any EU country except Greece.

Women occupy just 10% of top civil service jobs, cannot boast a single senior executive among France's top 200 companies, and are still suffering the legacy of the 19th century Napoleonic code that gave husbands sweeping powers over their wives.

But not all women were pleased with the proposed bill. "Basically, it's not necessary," said Nicole Catala of the opposition RPR party, which has already said it will abstain from the eventual vote. "Existing labour legislation covers most of the ground."

The employers' federation, Medef, said it agreed with the principle, but did not see why France wanted to legislate on the issue when a wide-ranging European directive was being prepared in Brussels.

"This is ideological point-scoring," a Medef spokesman said.

fields.headline: Truth lies in ruins
fields.standfirst: Archaeologist uncovers evidence that Hadrian was rivalled by opportunistic developers
fields.trailText: Architectural triumphs credited to Emperor Hadrian at the zenith of the Roman empire were in fact built by opportunistic property developers, according to a British archaeologist.
fields.body:
Architectural triumphs credited to Emperor Hadrian at the zenith of the Roman empire were in fact built by opportunistic property developers, according to a British archaeologist.

Historians have feted Hadrian for his building projects but the initiative and money for some of his reign's most enduring structures came from profit-seeking speculators, often ex-slaves, says Janet DeLaine, a lecturer at the University of Reading.

Brickwork preserved by almost 2,000 years of silt and sand at Ostia, Rome's main port, has revealed evidence that private enterprise was more dynamic than the state.

Trademarks on the bricks and design details indicate that the port's Garden Houses - a four-storey complex of 34 luxury apartments - was almost certainly built by entrepreneurs as rented accommodation, Ms DeLaine said. "It is quite likely that this pattern was repeated in the larger cities of the empire. This must have happened at Rome, Alexandria, Carthage and Antioch."

Hadrian, who ruled from AD117-138, is widely acknowledged to have sponsored architecture across the Roman world. But the work at Ostia is revealing the role of private developers.

The same contractor commissioned by the state in AD116 to build a portico, marketplace and temple also amassed enough money and backing to privately build the Garden Houses - a mansion dubbed the house of the muses because of its wall paintings, commercial centre and internal gardens.

The brickwork, arches and floor supports also suggest he used the same suppliers, builders and methods.

"From the guild of builders it is clear that many of them [private developers] were freed slaves," Ms DeLaine said. "They had a bad reputation. They were seen as pushy and nouveau riche."

Ms DeLaine's 10-year research is part of the Tiber Valley project of the British School at Rome. It is supported by the Soprintendenza Archeologia di Ostia.

Ms DeLaine says the site is yielding insights as valuable as those of Pompeii. "This takes us beyond seeing the city just as a finished plan and helps us to understand not just how it was built but how it was maintained at a human level."
