fields.headline: The name game
fields.standfirst:
Inside Story : Ken is, of course, Ken, but Frank is Mr Dobson (when he's not Dobbo). Michael White on the benefits of being on first-name terms with the voters

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Lucky Ken. Love him or hate him, the papers and the public remain on first name terms where Candidate Livingstone is concerned. "Ken gets the sack as he bids for mayor," said yesterday's Sun. "Red Ken kicks off with 55% lead over Dobson," declared the Mail's later editions after reading the Guardian's opinion poll findings.
fields.body:
Lucky Ken. Love him or hate him, the papers and the public remain on first name terms where Candidate Livingstone is concerned. "Ken gets the sack as he bids for mayor," said yesterday's Sun. "Red Ken kicks off with 55% lead over Dobson," declared the Mail's later editions after reading the Guardian's opinion poll findings.

Note that "Dobson". Sometimes it is "Dobbo", a nickname with amiable overtones. But it is almost never "Frank", though the official Labour candidate's first name has fewer letters than his surname, a factor which ought to help in the space-constrained art of headline-writing.

In their domestic setting, as parents or a couple, the Blairs sometimes get the friendly treatment as Tony and Cherie. But yesterday's Daily Mirror - which is anti-Livingstone - sported a splash headline which declared: "Nightmare: Blair faces civil war as Ken splits Labour."

There it goes again. Ken and Blair, not Ken and Tony. Thus the Independent's splash headline yesterday struck a slightly false note for well-intentioned reasons. A triple-banner proclaimed: "Ken says: 'I'll let London decide.' Frank says: 'The ego has landed.' Tony says: 'He would be a disaster.' "

But Tony, when used in both headlines and conversation, is often used ironically, for instance to mock the vicar's touchy-feely style in Private Eye's St Albion's Parish News. It is the same with "Mandy" Mandelson, the diminutive is ambiguous in the extreme, implicitly homophobic in the wrong hands.

"Paddy" (as in Ashdown) might also have been pejorative if anyone regarded the MP for Yeovil as a real Irishman. But Ken is Ken even to Blair and those Westminster colleagues who loathe him - quite a lot of them, actually - and do not see him as a latterday Charlie Chaplin, the lovable cockney underdog, Labour's irrepressible cheeky chappie.

They see him as an unprincipled opportunist, a loner and a liar, an egotist, not really a party man. There is truth in many of the accusations. But there is little evidence so far that they will do him much harm. Ken is a brilliantly-marketed brand, which means different things to different people, from newt-fancier to Blair-baiter.

Advertising agencies would pay - do pay - a fortune to gain such name recognition for their clients. How often do we observe this phenomenon in politics and why? Not often. In recent times there was "Maggie" Thatcher, a cheeky diminutive which did not sit easily with the Iron Lady's daunting public personality.

Her friends called her Margaret. Indeed old-school Tories tend to frown on vulgar diminutives among their leaders. Chris Patten's use of "Chris" was a black mark against him. Anthony Blair (as he styled himself during the 1982 Beaconsfield byelection) became something of a class traitor when he became plain Tony.

The Rt Hon Anthony Wedgwood Benn's demotic crime was even greater after he not only refused to become Lord Stansgate, but rebranded himself in Who's Who as plain Tony Benn. Yet, even in the heyday of his fame and influence, he was rarely spoken about as "Tony" without self-conscious intent, friendly or foul.

In the same era, Sir Edward Heath's friends call him "Ted" ,but not voters or editorial writers. William Hague's colleagues self-consciously refer to him during TV interviews as "William" - not Mr Hague - but the trick does not work. As the Australian expression goes: "If his name was William you wouldn't call him Bill."

Maggie was an attempt to humanise the prime minister of the day. With Ken Livingstone it is different, he is human already and people like him for it. He has "pintability" - the sort of bloke you'd happily have a pint with.

Coincidentally Ken Clarke - who calls him Kenneth? - has many of the same qualities, though the Labour MP for Brent East is clearly the senior Ken in the public mind. We see Ken in a headline and know which one we mean. There may be a deeper reason for that. Clarke is a serious political heavyweight who cultivates a bloke-ish, populist style.

Voters enjoy it, but they are not deceived. The ex-chancellor may boast that he has not read the Maastricht Treaty, and he really does like pints and cigars. But he is not really like most of us. Ken really is a populist who expresses better than most people the gut instincts and prejudices of a significant section of voters.

There have always been politicians who can do this sort of business, but not very many. They do not even have to be populists, though they do have to be able to communicate their thoughts, lofty or low, in terms which the rest of us can understand and, preferably, be moved by. Gladstone was "the People's William", Churchill sometimes Winston or even Winnie.

Thus when he returned to be first lord of the admiralty when war broke out in September 1939 a simple message was signalled throughout the Royal Navy: "Winston is back." He had held the same job in 1914. It helps, of course, to have a distinctive name. Winston, Enoch, Harold . . .

Harold Wilson was probably the last Labour politician to evoke such feelings of affection among ordinary voters. They felt that, despite being prime minister and being so clever, he remained one of them. Wilson played on it, no brandy and cigars in public, he drank pints on camera.

Changing standards of public decorum have a bearing on all this. Nye Bevan passed muster as a much-loved (and loathed) orator, democratic socialism's great romantic hero, and a funny name too. People spoke of "Nye and Jenny" - Jenny Lee MP, his formidable wife - but not in a Kennish way. He was Bevan or Mr Bevan. Harold MacMillan was Supermac.

It is a sign of the times that the Tory candidate for London mayor can be referred to in print and on the air as Shagger. No one ever said that about Lloyd George who won an Archer-ish libel case merely because his wife turned up in court. She didn't even have to give fragrant evidence.

That was before women had the vote, let alone exercised political power. Is it a coincidence that two prominent women in Anglo-Saxon political culture pass the Ken test? Dr Marjorie Mowlam is famously voter-friendly and has been rewarded with the fetching soubriquet Mo.

No wonder that Downing St has intermittently eyed her up as a Dobson-substitute. Across the pond the former Hillary Rodham Clinton first dropped the Rodham, now she has dropped the Clinton as she courts New York voters. Is it a populist move or top-down marketing? We shall find out in November. But Hillary still has a long way to go to catch up the cheeky chappie. His brand name is all over London, South Ken, Kennington, Kenwood, Kentish Town . . .

fields.headline: Watching the dectective
fields.standfirst:
Leads, he's had a few. Theories, he's heard more than enough. But nearly one year after Jill Dando was gunned down on her doorstep, the man in charge of the country's biggest murder inquiry has yet to make an arrest. Hamish Campbell talks to Nick Hopkins about months of frustration

More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: Leads, he's had a few. Theories, he's heard more than enough. But nearly one year after Jill Dando was gunned down on her doorstep, the man in charge of the country's biggest murder inquiry has yet to make an arrest.
fields.body:
Hamish Campbell remembers the moment that became the turning point in his life with great clarity, allowing himself one of those little chuckles which suggests both pleasure and pain. It was lunchtime. He was sitting in his office on the second floor of the murder squad's headquarters in Kensington, west London, when the fingerprint officer poked his head round the corner to say that a woman had been stabbed in Fulham.

Within minutes, Campbell was in a car speeding towards the scene, believing that he was heading for a serious, but probably routine crime. "On the way, I heard that the woman was Jill Dando," he says. "I was shocked like everyone else. I told the driver to get there as quickly as possible."

Reminders of the gruesome sight awaiting him in Gowan Avenue that bright afternoon last April transfix any visitor to his cramped but tidy room that overlooks Earls Court Road. Close-up photographs of the blood-smeared doorstep taken shortly after what proved to be a shooting are pinned on a noticeboard. He offers to take them down, then disappears to make a cup of tea.

Next month will see the first anniversary of Dando's murder and Campbell, the detective chief inspector in charge of the inquiry, is painfully aware that the pressure on him and the rest of the 45-strong murder squad in the build-up will be excruciating. They are bracing themselves for inevitable public frustration and, possibly, derision that nobody has yet been caught.

Campbell is prepared. He is rare among senior police officers. He is good at handling the media, but he does not enjoy the spotlight. This interview, the first he has given in nearly 11 months, is an opportunity to set the record straight before the frenzy starts again.

"He will be caught. Don't ask me when. It could be this month, it could be next month. If it is an ex-lover somewhere from her past who has arranged for this to happen, someone will eventually break the silence. If it is a loner, it will come out eventually. I'm a great believer. I really am." He does not deny that he feels the self-same "puzzlement and perplexion" that he felt the day she was shot. But he insists good progress is being made.

Finding Dando's killer has become his obsession. Campbell has not taken on any other cases since April 26 and his team of detectives and civilians has been ringfenced so they can concentrate on what has become the biggest murder investigation the country has seen since the hunt to capture the Yorkshire Ripper a quarter of a century ago.

The man in charge of that inquiry, assistant chief constable George Oldfield, pursued that case with a zeal that eventually destroyed his career and his personal life. He saw it as a straight fight between him and culprit. He was shifted from his post before Sutcliffe was caught and died a broken man in 1985.

Campbell laughs at the suggestion that the Dando hunt might one day take a similar toll: "That will not be me, I can assure you."

Colleagues say that, by nature, Campbell is a patient man. He needs to be. So far, the 13-hour days (he's in at 8am), the expectation of "getting a result" and the frustrations of not appearing to make a substantial headway do not seem to have affected his spirits. In many ways, his lugubrious style suits this pace of investigation. Before Dando, he was in charge of two baffling cases, the disappearance of the Argentinian Gracia Morton in Kensington in November 1997 and the murder of the Macedonian schoolgirl Katrina Koneva in Hammersmith in May 1997.

At the Dando squad's headquarters, an anonymous building next to Kensington police station, his team seems busy rather than frantic. Campbell is surrounded by files with more than 1,000 statements, the names of potential suspects and endless computer-generated flowcharts linking what evidence they have. He waves some of them, shakes his head and says: "Before the end of the second day of the investigation I knew it was not going to be solved easily. I wrote it in my notes and I remember telling the team that this has all the hallmarks of being a long inquiry. It can be difficult and obviously there is tiredness, but I am not despondent."

He says he needs to be positive to keep spirits up. "That's part of leadership. If the others saw me and said 'Have you seen the boss today, he is totally depressed about it', that would filter down. This is hard but not impossible. It's not beyond the wherewithal of this organisation with all the resources we have. Everyone must see a light at the end of the tunnel."

He treats the murder as a puzzle rather than a personal crusade. "I like logic, and this is a logical process. What we are trying to do is link the victim to the crime scene to the suspect." He prefers, he says, to cajole and encourage rather than to shout and scream. "I have never been like that. It serves no purpose. I need a team that is going to speak to each other. They need to be clear headed because they will be the ones who will knock on the door and see the killer, not me."

The frustrations, though, have been barely tolerable. Campbell has gathered a mass of information which still cannot be distilled into pertinent intelligence about what happened last year. Although Dando, 37, was killed in broad daylight, there were no witnesses. Apart from the bullet, which was "crimped" into a cartridge in a very distinctive way, there was no forensic evidence. Worst of all, from a detective's point of view, there was and remains no obvious motive. The squad has also not had any luck.

To some, it may seem that the inquiry is no further forward. The highs have often been followed by lows, requiring Campbell to use his weekly meetings to reassure his team that they still have much work to do and are heading in the right direction.

He gives two examples. Scotland Yard appealed for help to track down someone who had accessed an internet service, 192.com, to pinpoint exactly where Ms Dando lived. The discovery that someone (possibly a stalker) had used the site was a breakthrough, and the fact they managed to trace the person was a triumph. Yet the man, who lives in Wales, was quickly ruled out as a suspect. "Finding him was a tremendous piece of detective work. He was totally oblivious to the appeals we had made. He told us he hadn't been watching the TV at the time. We get caught up in the trauma and the storm, and sometimes forget that other people are concentrating on their own priorities."

It was a similar story with the mysterious blond-haired gas meter reader spotted near Dando's house. When he was eventually traced he said he hadn't bothered to get in touch because he had nothing to tell them. Theories are another source of irritation. He gets them wherever he goes and tries to deal with them with "quiet respect".

Only his opinion is truly important, and he has been reluctant to share his thoughts - until now. The inquiry has two central strands; Dando was killed by a crazed stalker or by a contract killer, possibly working with a team. Campbell has never been drawn on the subject before, but he says his "gut feeling" is that she was killed by loner.

"My instinct was that it was an individual rather than a group. The lack of criminal intelligence, the confusion at the scene and the mess over the firearm . . . and there's something not quite right about the bullet.

"If a criminal gang, let's say of three, were at work in Gowan Avenue, then there'd be three times as many people behind the scenes who would know about it. Yet we've heard nothing from the underworld. We haven't had one call. Not one. Detectives across London have spoken to all of their informants, and heard nothing. Someone from that group would have come forward to claim the £250,000 reward, and they haven't. Did every single informant just dry up on April 26?"

His officers have been to see major criminals to sound them out about underworld figures who might have been tempted to put out a contract, possibly because Dando presented Crimewatch.

"The lads who have gone to prison and spoken to these people have been laughed at. The major criminals all say the same thing: 'Why would we want to do that?' She was a newscaster who did holiday programmes. So why her? Why not Roger Cook or Shaw Taylor [who used to present the ITV programme, Police Five]. On that basis, Shaw Taylor would have been killed 100 times over. Criminals were upset if they didn't get a mention on his show."

Campbell stresses that the loner theory does not preclude the idea that she was killed by a contract killer, and that the investigation has not lurched in a different direction. But he adds: "In most contract killings, the victim is a criminal. Dando was not a criminal. She was as much involved in crime as you or I."

Campbell loses his temper once, when he recalls how the police have not been able to trace several men who were in Gowan Avenue in the hours before she was shot. "There were 23 sightings yet none of these men have contacted us. Why not? As I sit here in the middle of this storm, I think that is pretty extraordinary." When he is animated he has a tendency to look over his shoulder out of the window. "I have appealed again and again for the men in that blooming road to come forward! It would make our job so much simpler. I cannot believe that some of those people don't know who they are. Have they been on another part of the planet? There's little point being frustrated, but I find it really disappointing."

Campbell has told his detectives to ignore the stories that have appeared in the press over the past year. "They never cease to amaze. The one about her being shot by a Russian [mafia boss] came out of thin air. Once they are out there, some of them seem to take on a life force of their own."

In the weeks up to next month's anniversary, he will ask the public to forget them, too, and concentrate on three important areas. He wants to hear about people who have had "an unhealthy interest in Jill Dando". "Not people who had a passing interest or balanced admirers. If someone is harbouring doubts about an individual, I would like to know."

He pleads again for the men in Gowan Avenue to ring him, if only so they can be eliminated as suspects, and for information which will solve the mystery of the cartridge, which was crimped with six unusual indentations. The evidence presented to him so far has been neither "convincing or compelling", but Campbell says he remains optimistic.

"We can find the person responsible. Someone, somewhere, knows who he is. We will find him."

Blind alleys: clues that led nowhere

Theories about who killed Jill Dando have been progressively outlandish. Early reports suggested she had been stabbed; it was assumed a stalker was responsible.

When the police revealed she had been shot, the idea of a contract kill emerged. It was speculated (by the media) that she might have been targeted by a crime boss featured on the programme she presented, Crimewatch. Then Scotland Yard said it wanted to trace a man seen running from the scene and at least two others, who were possibly acting as lookouts. A Range Rover seen in Gowan Avenue could not be identified, nor could a car seen speeding from the area.

Dando's private life did not reveal any obvious leads, so the less obvious ones were entertained. With the Kosovan war at its height, the media wondered whether she might have been shot in retaliation for the Nato bombing of a Serbian TV station. Dando had made a TV appeal to raise funds for Kosovar refugees and had received critical letters, but the stories were dismissed by the Yard. All manner of others followed in the subsequent months. One suggested that a Serb, who matched the E-fit of the suspect, had been arrested in Manchester as he tried to leave the country. Another purported to identify the pub in the Midlands where detectives believe the gun was bought.

The most colourful theories have included the possibility that she was murdered on the orders of a Russian Mafia boss whose sexual advances she snubbed while filming the Holiday programme in Cyprus. It was also reported that she might have been killed by an agent from the Israeli secret service, or by former IRA terrorists.

"The lads who have gone to prison and spoken to these people have been laughed at. The major criminals all say the same thing: 'Why would we want to do that?' She was a newscaster who did holiday programmes. So why her? Why not Roger Cook or Shaw Taylor [who used to present the ITV programme, Police Five]. On that basis, Shaw Taylor would have been killed 100 times over. Criminals were upset if they didn't get a mention on his show." Campbell stresses that the loner theory does not preclude the idea that she was killed by a contract killer, and that the investigation has not lurched in a different direction. But he adds: "In most contract killings, the victim is a criminal. Dando was not a criminal. She was as much involved in crime as you or I." Campbell loses his temper once, when he recalls how the police have not been able to trace several men who were in Gowan Avenue in the hours before she was shot. "There were 23 sightings yet none of these men have contacted us. Why not? As I sit here in the middle of this storm, I think that is pretty extraordinary." When he is animated he has a tendency to look over his shoulder out of the window. "I have appealed again and again for the men in that blooming road to come forward! It would make our job so much simpler. I cannot believe that some of those people don't know who they are. Have they been on another part of the planet? There's little point being frustrated, but I find it really disappointing." Campbell has told his detectives to ignore the stories that have appeared in the press over the past year. "They never cease to amaze. The one about her being shot by a Russian [mafia boss] came out of thin air. Once they are out there, some of them seem to take on a life force of their own." In the weeks up to next month's anniversary, he will ask the public to forget them, too, and concentrate on three important areas. He wants to hear about people who have had "an unhealthy interest in Jill Dando". "Not people who had a passing interest or balanced admirers. If someone is harbouring doubts about an individual, I would like to know." He pleads again for the men in Gowan Avenue to ring him, if only so they can be eliminated as suspects, and for information which will solve the mystery of the cartridge, which was crimped with six unusual indentations. The evidence presented to him so far has been neither "convincing or compelling", but Campbell says he remains optimistic. "We can find the person responsible. Someone, somewhere, knows who he is. We will find him." Blind alleys: clues that led nowhere Theories about who killed Jill Dando have been progressively outlandish. Early reports suggested she had been stabbed; it was assumed a stalker was responsible. When the police revealed she had been shot, the idea of a contract kill emerged. It was speculated (by the media) that she might have been targeted by a crime boss featured on the programme she presented, Crimewatch. Then Scotland Yard said it wanted to trace a man seen running from the scene and at least two others, who were possibly acting as lookouts. A Range Rover seen in Gowan Avenue could not be identified, nor could a car seen speeding from the area. Dando's private life did not reveal any obvious leads, so the less obvious ones were entertained. With the Kosovan war at its height, the media wondered whether she might have been shot in retaliation for the Nato bombing of a Serbian TV station. Dando had made a TV appeal to raise funds for Kosovar refugees and had received critical letters, but the stories were dismissed by the Yard. All manner of others followed in the subsequent months. One suggested that a Serb, who matched the E-fit of the suspect, had been arrested in Manchester as he tried to leave the country. Another purported to identify the pub in the Midlands where detectives believe the gun was bought. The most colourful theories have included the possibility that she was murdered on the orders of a Russian Mafia boss whose sexual advances she snubbed while filming the Holiday programme in Cyprus. It was also reported that she might have been killed by an agent from the Israeli secret service, or by former IRA terrorists.

fields.headline:
No: 1589
 Yettie
fields.trailText: Age: 28, on average.
fields.body:
Age: 28, on average.

Habitat: Native to the San Francisco bay area, but now thriving in New York, London and Cambridge.

Appearance: Prada and thrift-shop chic for the girls; Banana Republic chinos and Puma trainers for the boys. Small, angular black specs all round.

Dressed like that, no wonder they've evaded explorers for decades! The enormous footprints must have been a giveaway. You wouldn't be deliberately confusing the yeti - aka the Abominable Snowman, that mysterious ape-like scourge of the Himalayas - with the entirely different yettie, in the hope of creating comic effect, would you?

How perceptive of you. So what is a yettie? It stands for Young, Entrepreneurial and Tech-based. They've dominated the headlines for a few years now, but, finally, the venture-capital-funded, Starbucks-wired e-elite have attained the ultimate symbol of world domi-nation: they've got their own demographic label.

Like yuppies? Precisely. Except that the last remaining members of that cigar-chomping, braces-wearing breed have long been locked up in a Canary Wharf wine bar for conservation purposes. PDA-touting yetties are the future now.

PDA? A personal digital assistant. Listen, you're never going to become a multimillionaire in the new e-economy if you can't get a hang of these TLAs.

TLAs? Three-letter acronyms. Do keep up!

But why "tech-based"? Obviously, "hi-tech" or even just "internet" would have been a little more accurate. But you just try pronouncing the acronym that would have produced. It's not easy.

You'll be telling me there are sub-species of yettie next. Well, yettie-spotters have come up with three classifications: nerds, neo-yuppies, and mouse jockeys.

Don't say: "Never mind internet start-ups - this demographics lark sounds like an easy way to make a fast buck!"

NTBCW (not to be confused with): Nimbys, dinkies, guppies, puppies.

fields.headline: US hardliners soften on debt
fields.standfirst:
Way opens for £62bn relief package

Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: The odds on a comprehensive package of debt relief for the world's poorest countries shortened yesterday as right-wing republicans on Capitol Hill called for a total write-off of loans to the 41 worst affected nations.
fields.body:
The odds on a comprehensive package of debt relief for the world's poorest countries shortened yesterday as right-wing republicans on Capitol Hill called for a total write-off of loans to the 41 worst affected nations.

The move by one of the last bastions of opposition to loans forgiveness delighted debt campaigners, Jubilee 2000, who have been calling for unpayable third world debts to be written off by the end of the year.

"A committee dominated by neo-liberal republicans is calling for outright debt cancellation for HIPC countries. There is now almost unanimous agreement on this issue, yet the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank will not put this overwhelming consensus into action," said Anne Pettifor, Jubilee 2000's director.

"Even in Mozambique after the total devastation, the IMF and World Bank refused to cancel debts and instead are imposing new loans and calculating future payments."

House republicans proved to be one of the biggest stumbling blocks to American implementation of a $100bn (£62bn) international loans forgiveness package proposed by world leaders last September. The White House failed to get funding from congress for the US share of the deal which would have written down about half the loans of the worst affected countries.

The call for total debt relief comes in a report on the future of the IMF and the Fund, released yesterday by an advisory committee to the congress, dominated by republicans. The commission voted unanimously that the Bank and the Fund should write off their claims against all heavily indebted poor countries that implement effective economic and social programmes in conjunction with the Bank.

"What they have said about debt relief is very encouraging, but they've got to put their money where their mouths are," said Justin Forsyth, head of policy at Oxfam.

Aid campaigners hope the report will break the logjam and give the US administration the political backing to fund America's contribution to the trust fund. The fund was set up by Britain's Gordon Brown for underwriting the Bank and the Fund's share of debt relief.

Other development experts fear that traditional hostility towards the Fund on Capitol Hill may yet sink the US administration's attempts to find the $210m shortfall.

The report calls for the IMF to pull out of long-term lending in the third world and to restrict itself to emergency lending to countries facing financial crises, a view supported by the US Treasury secretary, Larry Summers.

The Bank should replace its loans programme with grants and stop lending to countries which have access to private capital markets.

Development experts warned that slimming down the Fund and focusing the Bank only on the poorest countries could reduce the amount of funding for development.

"Building sewers and schools is vital for development even in middle income countries, but no private sector fund is going to be interested in lending for that," said Seth Amgott, a spokesman for Oxfam America.

fields.headline: Secret service bullies
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: At about 3.30 on Monday afternoon four special branch officers armed with warrants turned up at Kingston university in south west London. The warrants required the college authorities to provide the address of a student and give the police access to her personal computer. The student, Julie Ann Davies, was taken out of a lecture she was attending and promptly arrested.
fields.body:
At about 3.30 on Monday afternoon four special branch officers armed with warrants turned up at Kingston university in south west London. The warrants required the college authorities to provide the address of a student and give the police access to her personal computer. The student, Julie Ann Davies, was taken out of a lecture she was attending and promptly arrested.

She was told she was held under the official secrets act, described as "draconian" when Labour was in opposition but clearly regarded as a useful weapon now it is in power. The writer Tony Geraghty was similar charged last year for disclosing information about mass surveillance by the army in Northern Ireland. Lord Williams of Mostyn, the attorney general, subsequently saw sense and dropped the charges, though secrets charges against colonel Nigel Wylde, holder of the Queen's Gallantry Medal for helping to defuse 96 bombs in Northern Ireland, remain.

Ms Davies has been active in the campaign to get the secrets charges against whistleblowing ex-MI5 man David Shayler dropped and for more accountability of the secret agencies. Peter Scott, the university vice chancellor, describes her as an excellent and well-regarded student.

"The university," he said, "as an institution committed to freedom of expression, would be particularly concerned if it turned out that a discredited piece of legislation, the official secrets act, was being used to suppress legitimate journalistic investigation and the public's right to know about alleged abuses by the security services."

Despite official denials, serious questions remain unanswered about MI6 involvement in the 1996 plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy. And we still do not know what MI5 knew about the bombing of the Israeli embassy bombing in London in 1994: the courts won't release the information to the two Palestinian defendants.

Shayler's latest allegation is that the security services bugged an interview between Michael O'Brien, an IRA suspect, and his lawyer, Gareth Peirce, at Belmarsh prison in 1992. O'Brien received an 18-year sentence for attempted murder of a special constable in North Yorkshire though he has since been released.

I can disclose it is not an isolated case. The security services also admit bugging a conversation between other defendants and lawyers at Belmarsh. The Guardian cannot yet reveal the names of those involved because of a contempt order imposed by the courts.

The arrested Ms Davies was held at a police station until 1am when she was released on police bail until June. It is a classic tactic of bullies - if you cannot get the big fish, frighten the unwary.

Her arrest is the latest episode in increasingly desperate attempts by MI5 and MI6 to isolate Shayler. The agencies have been deeply frustrated by the steady erosion of injunctions designed to shut Shayler up. They appear to be concerned in particular about how a secret MI6 report about the Gadafy plot was placed on the internet last month. That is their excuse to send the special branch, traditionally regarded as MI5's footsoldiers, on a disgraceful fishing expedition.

For the police have also served notice on the Guardian that they intend to apply to the courts for an order to require the newspaper to hand over the original of a published letter from Shayler last month.

The letter consisted mainly of abuse aimed at MI5, the parliamentary intelligence and security committee for being so spineless, and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook. Other newspapers - there can scarcely be any which Shayler has not communicated with - have had similar approaches from the special branch.

After failing to get Shayler extradited from France to face a prosecution under the official secrets act, government lawyers are trying to silence him by serving him with a writ claiming damages in the civil courts. But the writ goes much further - it claims that the media is bound by the same duty of confidence, the same contractual obligations and the same copyright rules, as former crown servants, including spies, whenever they report allegations deemed to cause "injury to the national interest".

These claims are being tested in a case which came before the law lords yesterday. The former Soviet spy George Blake is challenging the government's argument that it owns any information, however sensitive, however old, provided by him.

His lawyer, Richard Clayton, told the lords that the official secrets act contravened the European convention on human rights. What makes the arrest of Ms Davies even more outrageous is that government lawyers privately concede this.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In early editions of an article headed, I'm backing the Pope, page 22, yesterday, we began, "Pope John XXIII is very active..." Quite the contrary, of course, since he died in 1963. We corrected that in later editions to "Pope John Paul II..." Pope John Paul II has appointed two archbishops in England and Wales recently, Cormac Murphy-O'Connor to Westminster and Vincent Nichols to Birmingham.
fields.body:
In early editions of an article headed, I'm backing the Pope, page 22, yesterday, we began, "Pope John XXIII is very active..." Quite the contrary, of course, since he died in 1963. We corrected that in later editions to "Pope John Paul II..." Pope John Paul II has appointed two archbishops in England and Wales recently, Cormac Murphy-O'Connor to Westminster and Vincent Nichols to Birmingham.

We got a little mixed up in our piece about the Norwegian monarchy, Just a regular guy, pages 2 and 3, G2, March 6. King Haakon VII (formerly Prince Carl) was not the grandson of King Edward VII. He was his son-in-law, having married his daughter, Princess Maud (Maud was his wife not, as we wrongly said, his mother). He was therefore the brother-in-law of King George V. He was also a nephew of Queen Alexandra, as his father was her brother.

In our feature for International Women's Day, pages 6 and 7, G2 (Women), yesterday, we omitted the name of one of the contributors, providing only the following description as a clue, "Women's rights and healthcare advocate, New Zealand." She is Sandra Coney. Sorry for that.

In our obituary of Lionel Salter, page 22, March 6, we mentioned the associated board for music. The correct title is The Associated Board of The Royal Schools of Music.

In one of our London mayoral contest reports, page 5, yesterday, we numbered among the candidates of the London Socialist Alliance, the journalist Paul Foot and the comedian Mark Thomas. We should have referred to the comedian Mark Steel (not Thomas). Apologies.

In the solutions to our quiz, Guardian Weekend, March 4, page 65, we spelt Gandhi wrongly (we did what we often do and spelt it Ghandi).

webTitle: BAT peace signals elicit no government response

fields.headline: BAT peace signals elicit no government response
fields.trailText: An attempt by British American Tobacco to improve deteriorating relations with the government over a cigarette smuggling epidemic appears to be going up in smoke the company admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
An attempt by British American Tobacco to improve deteriorating relations with the government over a cigarette smuggling epidemic appears to be going up in smoke the company admitted yesterday.

The world's second largest cigarette manufacturer wrote to ministers a month ago in an attempt to create a more constructive dialogue, but has not heard back. BAT's chairman, Martin Broughton, described Tony Blair's administration as confrontational, admitting that "relations with government have not been good since it came into power".

BAT is angry about the tax differential on tobacco between Britain and continental Europe which has led to black-market cigarettes taking a claimed 25% market share.

But BAT's own position has been under fire after revelations in the Guardian that the company itself had exploited smuggling.

Yesterday BAT, which owns the Rothmans, Lucky Strike and State Express 555 brands, produced an 86% increase in pre-tax profits at £1.36bn.

Mr Broughton said there was no way of knowing how much 1999 figures were affected by black market sales.

BAT's financial position has been dramatically improved by the £13bn merger with Rothmans earlier last year which brought it closer to competing for pole position with Marlboro maker Philip Morris.

Merger integration has developed faster than expected and BAT is in line to exceed targets of shaving £250m a year off operating costs.

But this was achieved through taking a £357m charge in 1999 meaning the planned £400m charge anticipated over three years will be exceeded.

The group said its volumes rose 5% to 735bn cigarettes but without the merger, sales were down 9%, in line with international competitors.

The company's shares, which have underperformed the FTSE all share index by 20% over the last 12 months fell to end the day down 13p at 261p.

webTitle: Byers urged to clarify and simplify utilities bill

fields.headline: Byers urged to clarify and simplify utilities bill
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, yesterday came under renewed pressure to reshape the government's flagship utilities bill only days after jettisoning large chunks of the legislation.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, yesterday came under renewed pressure to reshape the government's flagship utilities bill only days after jettisoning large chunks of the legislation.

The electricity industry demanded urgent talks with Mr Byers in order to "clarify and simplify" the bill and remove the arbitrary powers given to the secretary of state and the industry regulator, Ofgem.

The move by the Electricity Association coincided with the bill's return to a commons standing committee where it is to be shorn of its telecoms and water provisions after last week's reversal by Mr Byers.

Industry insiders said the thrust of the neutered bill contradicted the competition act - which came into effect on March 1 and allows fines of up to 10% of sales for uncompetitive behaviour - by proposing unlimited penalties.

The utilities bill, which focuses on consumers, is meant to complement the competition act. Mr Byers is already under siege for his mishandling of the "rip-off Britain" campaign and failure to influence the cabinet debate over raising the minimum wage.

Last week he was forced by interventions from Tony Blair and John Prescott to remove telecoms and water from the scope of the utilities bill.

But the Electricity Association said the changes, seen as reducing the putative com mon regulatory framework for utilities to a shell dealing with energy, still left too many generic provisions.

The bill still gave Mr Byers and Ofgem "open ended" powers which could cause uncertainty and lead to higher costs to business and consumers.

If a customer were disconnected and a firm failed to reconnect him or her within 24 hours, for instance, the consumer could be awarded compensation and take legal action while Ofgem could levy a substantial fine - "triple jeopardy", according to insiders.

DTI officials said some of these powers would be limited to two years and the proposed penalties would be "appropriate and proportionate".

The Electricity Association insisted it strongly supported a bill implementing the new wholesale trading arrangements, separate distribution and supply, underpin Ofgem as a legal entity and create the new combined gas and electricity consumer council.

Industry insiders said the thrust of the neutered bill contradicted the competition act - which came into effect on March 1 and allows fines of up to 10% of sales for uncompetitive behaviour - by proposing unlimited penalties. The utilities bill, which focuses on consumers, is meant to complement the competition act. Mr Byers is already under siege for his mishandling of the "rip-off Britain" campaign and failure to influence the cabinet debate over raising the minimum wage. Last week he was forced by interventions from Tony Blair and John Prescott to remove telecoms and water from the scope of the utilities bill. But the Electricity Association said the changes, seen as reducing the putative com mon regulatory framework for utilities to a shell dealing with energy, still left too many generic provisions. The bill still gave Mr Byers and Ofgem "open ended" powers which could cause uncertainty and lead to higher costs to business and consumers. If a customer were disconnected and a firm failed to reconnect him or her within 24 hours, for instance, the consumer could be awarded compensation and take legal action while Ofgem could levy a substantial fine - "triple jeopardy", according to insiders. DTI officials said some of these powers would be limited to two years and the proposed penalties would be "appropriate and proportionate". The Electricity Association insisted it strongly supported a bill implementing the new wholesale trading arrangements, separate distribution and supply, underpin Ofgem as a legal entity and create the new combined gas and electricity consumer council.

webTitle: Face saver Germany sounds out new candidate for IMF's top job

fields.headline: Face saver Germany sounds out new candidate for IMF's top job
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gerhard Schröder sought to salvage national pride yesterday by backing a new German candidate for the top job at the International Monetary Fund .
fields.body:
Chancellor Gerhard Schröder sought to salvage national pride yesterday by backing a new German candidate for the top job at the International Monetary Fund .

Horst Köhler, head of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, revealed he had been approached after the humiliating withdrawal of German deputy finance minister Caio Koch-Weser from the contest to become IMF managing director.

He said he was willing to take up the offer, but only after being assured of enough support to win.

Although Mr Köhler was once a close adviser to Mr Schröder's rival and predecessor, Helmut Kohl, acceptance by the international community of an alternative German candidate would save face for Mr Schröder.

While Mr Köhler is seen in European capitals as a serious contender, some governments are thought to remain keen on the Italian treasury minister, Giuliano Amato.

German finance minister Hans Eichel told journalists Mr Köhler was "a good man" but declined to say how far he had EU or US support.

Mr Köhler told the EBRD board and staff that "if a broad majority of [IMF] shareholders is of the view that I am needed at the helm of the IMF then I would not decline that request".

By coincidence, the EBRD today announces its results for 1999 which are widely expected to show a sharp recovery from the problems of 1998.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Cadbury board revamped

Cadbury Schweppes said it had made radical changes to its management, including the appointment of John Brock as chief operating officer. He was formerly managing director of the beverages unit. Mr Brock will be responsible for increasing the performance of the confectionery and beverages businesses through a single operational organisation, Cadbury said.
fields.body:
Cadbury board revamped

Cadbury Schweppes said it had made radical changes to its management, including the appointment of John Brock as chief operating officer. He was formerly managing director of the beverages unit. Mr Brock will be responsible for increasing the performance of the confectionery and beverages businesses through a single operational organisation, Cadbury said.

Todd Stitzer, president and chief executive officer of Dr Pepper/Seven Up in the US, becomes chief strategy officer reporting to John Sunderland and joins the main board. Doug Tough, president of Cadbury Schweppes International Beverages, will take over full responsibility for DPSU. Responsibilities of the other main board directors reporting to Mr Sunderland would be extended to support the new structure, the company said. Ian Johnston, managing director of the confectionery stream, will be leaving.

BoS offers free bank services

Bank of Scotland will offer small businesses free banking services in a bid to boost its 2% share of the market outside Scotland.

BoS, which failed to takeover NatWest, said it believed 50% of businesses in Britain are in credit but are paying hefty charges for a relationship they do not use. Its service is based on 24-hour telephone banking, with more sophisticated relationship managers available during extended office hours.

The service will be free, provided customers keep balances above £5,000 and issue no more than 100 cheques a month.

Flextech boss's £5.4m windfall
Adam Singer, chief executive of pay television group Flextech will pocket about £5.4m when the company completes its merger with Telewest, the offer document disclosed yesterday.

Around £4.4m of Mr Singer's windfall will come from a long-term incentive scheme which will mature on the day of the deal.

The exact amount is uncertain because it will be based on the average share price of the three months prior to completion.

Although Flextech is technically being taken over by Telewest which is four times its size, Mr Singer will be chief executive of the combined group.

Flextech's deputy managing director Brent Harman stands to make £3.2m from the deal.

fields.headline: German pact scares City
fields.trailText: More than 3,000 City jobs were under threat last night as two of Germany's biggest financial institutions prepared to unite to create the world's largest bank.
fields.body:
More than 3,000 City jobs were under threat last night as two of Germany's biggest financial institutions prepared to unite to create the world's largest bank.

Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank are expected to unveil a $1,200bn (£900m) combination by assets in Frankfurt tomorrow in a move which is expected to be billed as a merger but is more likely to involve a Deutsche takeover of its smaller rival.

As information about the deal, which has been under discussion for weeks, leaked into the financial markets fears grew that the investment banking arms of both banks faced severe job culls.

While neither bank would comment on the extent of any cuts, one investment banker predicted "carnage on the streets" and suggested that the heaviest blow would fall on Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, which employs 3,500 bankers in the City. Deutsche Bank employs 8,000 in the Square Mile.

The two banks were giving few details but confirmed that they were conducting talks over "wide ranging cooperation" and discussions "were at an advanced stage". Talks are said to have been conducted at the highest level to keep the deal under wraps. Some observers suggested the Dresdner name would disappear in investment banking.

The results of the negotiations will be put to the boards of the two banks today.

Analysts believe that the deal to be unveiled tomorrow by Deutsche chairman Rolf Breuer and his Dresdner counterpart, Bernhard Walther, have the form of a merger, although they do not rule out the prospect some operations within the two banks being excluded. The deal is bound to put pressure on other leading banks, including Commerzbank in Germany, Spain's expansion-minded BSCH and France's BNP Paribas.

Areas at the heart of the talks are expected to be retail banking in Germany and the global investment banking business.

Deutsche and Dresdner have had on/off talks for months about how to combine their retail businesses. Although it is not clear how their extensive branch networks will be combined, the German insurance group Allianz, which is a major shareholder in both banks, will play an important role in the final outcome, probably as a big minority shareholder.

The banks are desperate to cut the costs of their retail networks - together they hold about 10% of the retail banking market in Germany - in the face of increasing competition from internet banking. But any deal combining the networks will need the nod from Europe's competition authorities.

But sources in Frankfurt suggested that Deutsche is keen to build up its investment banking operations to meet the challenge presented by US institutions such as Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. A merger would also produce a heavy weight fund manager.

"Other activities of the banks are important, too. They have to look at Europe and indeed globally," one observer said.

Both German banks built up their investment banking business by buying top City names: Deutsche through Morgan Grenfell and Dresdner in acquiring Kleinwort Benson.

webTitle: Man Utd set to become the world's first £1bn club

fields.headline: Man Utd set to become the world's first £1bn club
fields.trailText: Manchester United was last night on the verge of becoming the world's first £1bn football club.
fields.body:
Manchester United was last night on the verge of becoming the world's first £1bn football club.

Shares in the European champions' company climbed almost 15% to 376p yesterday, valuing the club at £978m - less than a David Beckham transfer away from the billion-pound mark.

The rise was sparked by a research note from Warburg Dillon Read stating its belief that United shares could actually be worth 500p - a price that would give it a market value of some £1.3bn. Eighteen months ago the club's directors agreed to sell United to BSkyB for £623m.

Warburg Dillon Read's analyst, Julian Easthope, describes United as "the ultimate content provider" and says its net division has not been fully valued by the stock market.

He said manutd.com, the club's website - which attracts 8m hits a month - and other new media possibilities make the shares worth at least £4.27 each.

The forthcoming bidding process for the Premier League broadcasting rights and more attractive sponsorship deals will also prove "very profitable for the group".

It is thought United will generate significant new revenues from its pay-per-view and webcasting rights. It has signed an online gambling deal with the tax-free bookie Eurobet, based in Gibraltar. The club will receive a percentage of any bets placed there, and its merchandising such as strips is also sold online.

The ground is being prepared for the advent of high-speed net links enabling the club to broadcast live games on the net. Freeserve is rumoured to be a possible partner.

"The telecast rights are the most controversial and potentially most exciting," the Warburg Dillon Read note said.

"Manchester United has the most visited website in China; it has a massive base of fans in the Far East generally and in Scandinavia, which has the highest internet penetration.

"With the introduction of broadband and improvements in streaming technology the opportunities are huge. When live games are available on the site subscription revenues would soon follow."

Player wages are the only down side at the club, with stars demanding in excess of £40,000 a week.

Shares in United have more than doubled since Christmas, when they traded at 160p. Much of the rise has been attributed to a £30m sponsorship deal with Vodafone AirTouch.

fields.headline: Williams ends age of empire
fields.trailText: Sir Nigel Rudd signalled the close of the conglomerates era yesterday with the break-up of the Williams empire he founded 18 years ago.
fields.body:
Sir Nigel Rudd signalled the close of the conglomerates era yesterday with the break-up of the Williams empire he founded 18 years ago.

The company which has spanned businesses ranging from foundries to BMW dealerships, Crown paint to Smallbone kitchens, is to split itself into two separately listed companies - Chubb Security services and Kidde Fire Protection products - and the Williams name will disappear.

A third business, Yale locks - which includes the right to make Chubb door locks under licence - is to be sold to Stockholm-based Assa Abloy for £825m, while negotiations on the remaining US paints business are under way with two potential buyers.

The company is investigating ways to generate new business from e-commerce.

Williams, built up by Sir Nigel and co-founder Brian McGowan out of a £200,000 investment in a Caerphilly aluminium foundry, was one of the go-go stocks of the 1980s. It acquired - and sold - businesses ranging from engineering plants to Polycell wallpaper paste and Aqualisa showers. But yesterday Sir Nigel admitted there was no longer a role for conglomerates.

"Since the end of the 1980s we have seen that conglomeration was not the way forward. In a multi-business it is always hard to allocate resources."

Williams had been considering the demerger for a year. Its shares have gone from 460p in 1998 to 231p recently but after announcement of the break-up yesterday they rose nearly 30% to close at 340p.

Sir Nigel refuted suggestions that by breaking the company into two more focused units he was setting them up to be picked off by rivals. "I've not put 18 years of my life into something to let someone steal it. I'm just not having it."

Williams also reported flat 1999 profits of £289m on turnover up from £2.5bn to £2.7bn.

webTitle: Double-D merger based on shaky logic

fields.headline: Double-D merger based on shaky logic
fields.standfirst: Bankers think God favours the big
fields.trailText: The consolidation of Europe's banking sector is picking up speed. Later this week Germany's Deutsche and Dresdner banks are expected to unveil what will almost certainly be sold as a merger but in effect will be a Deutsche takeover. Yes, we are talking about Germany's two biggest banks here.
fields.body:
The consolidation of Europe's banking sector is picking up speed. Later this week Germany's Deutsche and Dresdner banks are expected to unveil what will almost certainly be sold as a merger but in effect will be a Deutsche takeover. Yes, we are talking about Germany's two biggest banks here.

The move will put pressure on others to respond. Commerzbank, which will be relegated to a distant third in the German league table by the double-D deal, will be the first to feel the heat from shareholders. The Nordic banks are already playing their own version of musical chairs. Any bank with pretensions to be more than a niche player in its eurozone domestic market will need to reassure investors that it has no shortage of partnership options for the consolidation waltz.

Does size matter so much? Certainly a merged Deutsche/Dresdner bank will be hard to ignore, especially if, as expected, insurer Allianz takes an important role in the retail side of the operation.

A little below the surface, a rather different picture emerges. Deutsche and Dresdner are being driven together by two distinct factors. The first is the growth of internet banking. Established banks are caught in a cost double whammy - the need to maintain expensive high street branch networks whilst building up internet based services to combat new rivals for whom high technology is a low cost entry route.

Deutsche and Dresdner have more than 2,500 branches and around 40,000 staff in the retail sector. Something will have to give. The second aspect is the development of the international investment banking side. Deutsche Bank has never lacked ambition in the field. Despite the problems of putting together two different cultures at a time when Deutsche can barely have digested Bankers Trust, the German bank appears convinced that if investment banking has a God he will be on the side of the big battalions.

Whether Deutsche is right or wrong remains to be seen. Certainly the bank has placed a hefty enough bet in its bid to match the Americans. What is becoming clear however - apart from the prospect of hefty job losses in London and Germany - is that if the logic behind a bank spanning high street retailing to Wall Street deal-making was shaky in pre-internet days it now looks positively antediluvian. Just ask the American investment banks Deutsche has set its heart on rivalling.

The key to riches

These days, there are three words guaranteed to send analysts and investors into a state of tingling excitement: demerger, divestment and - the really big one - internet.

So any company that can come up with a combination of all three in one go is on to a winner, as Williams proved yesterday when its previously soggy stock price climbed 30% to 340p.

Rarely in the history of the world wide web, has one company's e-business plans been more sketchy. The internet is clearly not the specialist subject of the Williams chief executive, Roger Carr.

Yesterday Williams unveiled a strategy to separate its products (Kidde) from its services (Chubb) divisions as separately-quoted enterprises. Its Yale locks division is being sold - for a very handsome 20 times earnings - to Swedish group Assa Abloy.

Williams' founder Sir Nigel Rudd will chair the products company, while his long time chief executive (Mr Carr) will slip into the chairman's office at Chubb. There, he will oversee a new e-venture - Chubb Information Security Services - already branded Infosec, ready for that inevitable flotation.

So what will this new outfit do? Er, well. Mr Carr isn't too sure yet. "What the opportunity is and what the scale of the opportunity is we are waiting to see," he says. "There does seem to be something here of value."

What exactly? Well, he explains, Chubb has a Class B internet licence. There were only 500 granted and no more will be issued. Must be valuable then.

And what do they do? Well, he goes on, you can enter the internet with them, and run a private network. They give you "nodes into the structure."

And Nokia has one, so it must be useful. "I'm not an expert", Mr Carr adds. Clearly.

Sir Nigel intervenes: "We are going to have a business case put to us".

In readiness, he explains, the two men have put a management structure in place, even though they do not yet have a business plan, or indeed any idea what they will be doing.

Reading the runes - or rather, having it explained by one of the company's advisers later - it appears that Chubb has been contacted by hot stock Baltimore Technologies with a view to a business proposition. Baltimore, specialists in secure delivery of information, encryption etc, evidently want to use the Chubb brand name.

Pity the poor people setting up Chubb's Information Security division.

fields.headline: Waterford Wedgwood
fields.trailText: A newspaper tycoon, Greek shipowner and member of the royal family are just some of the cast at Waterford Wedgwood trying to reproduce a must-have stock.
fields.body:
A newspaper tycoon, Greek shipowner and member of the royal family are just some of the cast at Waterford Wedgwood trying to reproduce a must-have stock.

Tony O'Reilly, head of Independent Newspapers and chairman of Waterford together with Peter Goulandris, deputy chairman, have drafted in the Duchess of York, Sarah Ferguson, as spokeswoman for its US operations.

The company's shares halved from €1.5 in the middle of 1998 because of panic about the state of the ceramics division. It recovered some of its value when six plants were closed and 2,000 jobs cut.

Yesterday Waterford Wedgwood showed some of the benefits of that restructuring by unveiling a 35% increase in pre-tax profits to €68.7m.

Waterford Crystal sales rose 37% in the United States, partly due, apparently, to the activities of the Duchess.

Mr O'Reilly said sales for the first two months of the new year are up 20% with double digit growth in both sides of the business.

He said he looks forward to "outstanding rewards for our shareholders" and, certainly, investors benefited from the 1999 results, with a dividend up 17% to 2.67 cents.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: When internet service provider Freeserve launched with no monthly subscription fee it caught the rest of the market napping and quickly became Britain's biggest player.
fields.body:
When internet service provider Freeserve launched with no monthly subscription fee it caught the rest of the market napping and quickly became Britain's biggest player.

Yesterday, however, it was Freeserve's turn to look tired as the country's largest cable company, NTL, began offering a service that goes one further with no call charges. Much of Freeserve's revenue come from a share of call charges and suddenly its entire economic model was on shaky ground. Its shares collapsed 18% to 725.5p.

NTL can use free internet access as an effective loss leader to drive penetration of its cable TV and telephony packages. Freeserve has no such luxury.

Dixons, the high street electrical goods retailer which still owns 80% of Freeserve, also fell 254p to £12.31 while beleaguered British Telecom was again on the back foot and fell 121p to £11.69.

BT's slide plus a rout in the Dow Jones Industrial Index, which fell back below 10,000 in early trading, weighed heavily on the FTSE 100.

The seismic shake-up of members of the FTSE also proved a drag as investors placed their bets on which companies would be joining the blue chips.

For those expected to make way it was a vicious circle. If a share is expected to lose its place in the FTSE the tracker funds are expected to get out, the share price goes down, it becomes less valuable and it loses its place in the FTSE.

PowerGen slid 53.5p to 369p, Thames Water was off 26p at 671.5p and Whitbread lost 43p to settle at 507.5p.

The FTSE 100 was 101.3 lower at 6466.5.

A profits warning from Procter & Gamble, the world's largest consumer goods group, was part of the reason for the Dow Jones fall and it had a knock-on effect on London stocks. Unilever was down almost 9% to 347p and Reckitt Benckiser was 44p lower at 472p after P&G's statement that third-quarter earnings would be 10-11% lower than last year.

Media stocks were in favour after Pearson's barnstorming performance when it reported its 1999 results on Monday. Carlton Communications, backed by a Commerzbank note, climbed 64p to £9; fellow ITV company and potential bedfellow Granada was 23.5p better at 672.5p. Pearson climbed another 89p to £25.74.

Cable & Wireless was enlivened by talk of an impending bid from Deutsche Telekom and closed the session up 32p at £15.52.

British Energy, in the wake of a profits warning on Monday, crashed 11.45% to 213p, not helped by a negative note from Goldman Sachs.

fields.headline: Wall Street plunges by 400 points
fields.trailText: Frenzied dealings on Wall Street saw the Dow Jones industrial average plunge late yesterday with fears over higher interest rates, a rise in oil prices to a post-Gulf war peak and a profits warning from one of America's heartland companies combining to wipe 400 points - or almost 4% - off the premier American stock market index.
fields.byline: Mark Milner, Larry Elliott and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Frenzied dealings on Wall Street saw the Dow Jones industrial average plunge late yesterday with fears over higher interest rates, a rise in oil prices to a post-Gulf war peak and a profits warning from one of America's heartland companies combining to wipe 400 points - or almost 4% - off the premier American stock market index.

But in an extraorindary illustration of the so-called splitmarket, investors in technology related companies shrugged off warnings that they were in danger of falling victim to a "casino mentality", driving the hi-tech Nasdaq index through the 5,000 barrier for the first time.

Analysts said they were amazed by the speed of the Nasdaq's rise, which has seen the index more than double in the last year. It reached 3,000 in November and breached the 4,000 level only a month later.

"This is the biggest, fastest move for a major index in the history of market indices," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Price Charter. "It's a panic. It's a frenzy."

While the Nasdaq was soaring, the Dow Jones dropped sharply in early trading following a profits warning from Procter & Gamble - the world's largest household goods company.

Bill Clinton yesterday underlined mounting concern in Washington over dearer energy prices when he urged the Opec cartel to ease the production curbs which have sent crude prices from $10 (£6) a year ago to $33 last night.

The currency markets were also in turmoil. The dollar strengthened against a weak euro, which hit a record low against the Japanese yen.

"To understand this market you don't need to be an economist, you need to be a behavioural psychologist", said one currency analyst.

webTitle: Greece looks east in quest for business

fields.headline: Greece looks east in quest for business
fields.standfirst: Despite its forthcoming entry to eurozone, the big money from Athens is being pumped into Turkey
fields.trailText: Greek tycoons are expanding eastwards, injecting their formidable fortunes in Turkey as trade begins to blossom on the back of political rapprochement between Athens and Ankara.
fields.body:
Greek tycoons are expanding eastwards, injecting their formidable fortunes in Turkey as trade begins to blossom on the back of political rapprochement between Athens and Ankara.

Business has been the first to profit from the unexpected love-in between the once implacable foes. Magnates, keen to move into markets in a region encompassing the Balkans, Middle East and central Asia, are lining up to exploit the thaw as Greece, in turn, prepares to join the cherished eurozone by adopting the single currency.

Tomorrow will see the first indication that Greece has taken its rightful role on the world stage. Finance minister Yannos Papandoniou said yesterday that Greece had met the final qualification for entering the eurozone, bringing its inflation down to Maastricht levels.

Historic
Greece plans to apply formally for membership of Europe's economic and monetary union (Emu) tomorrow with an eye to entry into the eurozone on January 1, 2001. Papandoniou said Greece's convergence with mainstream European inflation rates was a "historic moment" for the country.

According to its proponents the region is ripe for growth. Officials say the penny has finally dropped that the two nations - which have almost gone to war three times since the 1974 Turkish invasion of Cyprus - can reap handsome dividends if they forge economic ties. Last month, tycoons including Socrates Kokkalis, owner of the big telecommunications company Intracom, and Spyros Latsis, who runs the oil tanker business set up by his uncle Yannis - Greece's richest ship owner and long time host to the British royals - gathered in Istanbul to discuss ways of developing joint business ventures.

"We live in a global economy. If Greece and Turkey don't act together, then they will be marginalised," the Greek foreign minister George Papandreou said. "It is clear there are benefits to be gained by exploiting our dynamism as economies in the Balkans, Caucasus and Middle East."

Until now Greco-Turkish trade links had always been susceptible to political tensions. Despite the doubling of bilateral commerce in the four years since Turkey initiated a customs union with the European Union, cross border trade is still nowhere near where it could be.

To date, only 34 small and medium sized Greek businesses have made acquisitions or joint ventures - mostly in the service sector - in the neighbouring country.

Last year cross-border commerce fell from $900m ($560m) to $720m after revelations that Greece had given refuge to Turkey's most wanted man, the Kurdish rebel leader, Abdullah Ocalan.

Besieged
"In the next five years we would like to see trade reach the $4bn mark," said Panayiotis Koutsikos who heads the Federation of Greco-Turkish business cooperation.

Mr Koutsikos may not be waiting long. In the past six months more has been done to facilitate contact between the two countries than in the past 40 years with nine, mostly economic, accords being signed.

In the past few weeks businessmen anxious to take advantage of the agreements, which include protection of cross border investments, have besieged the Federation of Greek Industries (SEB), the main body pushing for closer economic ties, with telephone calls.

"Turkey offers a market of 75m people, seven and a half times the size of Greece. Businessmen are eager to know everything about it," said SEB's foreign market analyst, Elena Nicolaidou.

"They have waited a long time for this to happen and they are thinking in the long term."

The improved climate has already prompted several Greek shipping tycoons to venture into Turkey with many buying mooring facilities and announcing new ferry routes between Greece's eastern islands and the Turkish coastline. The companies, which reputedly include the hovercraft firm Minoan Flying Dolphins, will begin plying Turkish waters this summer.

"As EU members we can get the necessary EU bank funds for construction projects in Turkey and in doing so help them join the bloc," said Mr Koutsikos.

"They, in turn, can help give us access to the Turcophone Republics of Central Asia and several countries around the Black Sea where we currently have zero investments."

Increasingly, the Greeks say their future lies in the east. As the European Union's only Balkan nation, entrepreneurs from Greece have established over 2,500 firms in Albania, Bulgaria and Romania since the collapse of communism - a feat that has boosted confidence and whetted appetites to work abroad.

For many, Turkey is now the logical next step in what most companies regard as their regional expansion. As Vassili Tsimas, who owns a tourist business in the Greek town of Volos, points out: "we lived alongside the Turks for 400 years during the Ottoman Empire, we share the same mentality and see the sun rise at more or less the same time every day. We should have done this years ago."

fields.headline: Weatherspoon bucks teary trend
fields.trailText: The beer business is enough to make you feel woozy: today Scottish & Newcastle and Whitbread will be ejected from the FTSE 100 index. Bass brewers, purveyor of the bubbly nectar whose name adorns the Premiership, is up for sale.
fields.body:
The beer business is enough to make you feel woozy: today Scottish & Newcastle and Whitbread will be ejected from the FTSE 100 index. Bass brewers, purveyor of the bubbly nectar whose name adorns the Premiership, is up for sale.

Ale is out, lager - and wine - are in. We are doing our downing in All Bar Ones and Pitcher & Pianos, rather than traditional Dog & Ducks, and smuggled foreign lager is undermining the entire sector.

So why is JD Wetherspoon doing so well? Its cheap beer, no-music, TV-free pubs are pulling in the punters as if there were never to be another opening time.

Yesterday the group announced better than expected first-half profits, up 34% at £15.6m, and that was after paying out £4m in staff bonuses. It has also awarded share options to 2,200 of its pub workers. Group chairman Tim Martin said: "Its a virtuous circle ... The more we reward staff the bigger our profits grow. Wetherspoon is the Goldman Sachs of the pub industry."

That is the sort of behaviour that could get the pub business - which whined so much about the devastation that would be wrought by the minimum wage - a good name. Mr Martin, the former solicitor who dreamed up Wetherspoons, said sales were up 44% to £174.7m, and 16.9% on a like-for-like basis. The shares rose 26p to 387p.

Wetherspoons is aiming to cut the time from being given licensing approval to opening the doors of a new pub from 19 to eight weeks. The idea is to boost profit by shaving around 6% off total spend. New agreements with wine, spirits and bar snacks suppliers are expected to save £3m.

Not that the pace of new openings is slowing. Mr Martin now has 370 pubs and plans 185 more in the next two years. He reckons there is room for 1,500, is planning his first foray into Northern Ireland and not ruling out a move to the Republic either.

City analysts like what they see. Williams de Broe changed its recommendation from hold to buy, while house broker WestLB Panmure rates it outperform with a 425p target. Deutsche Bank also reckons they are a buy, with a 482p target.
