fields.headline: Feast for the eyes
fields.standfirst: Adelaide's festival could teach Edinburgh a thing or two about showmanship, says  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: The Adelaide festival is like Edinburgh on heat: 39 celsius on one baking day last week. Superficially, there are resemblances between Adelaide in March and Auld Reekie in August. Both offer a three-week cultural binge in cities of extraordinary beauty.
fields.body:
The Adelaide festival is like Edinburgh on heat: 39 celsius on one baking day last week. Superficially, there are resemblances between Adelaide in March and Auld Reekie in August. Both offer a three-week cultural binge in cities of extraordinary beauty. Both have a bustling fringe: in Adelaide, 530 events in 100 venues. Both have accompanying conferences and writers' weeks: this year, Adelaide blends native talents including Tom Keneally and former prime minister Paul Keating with overseas visitors such as Vikram Seth, Richard Ford and Hilary Mantel.

But it is the differences between Adelaide and Edinburgh that really strike me. In Adelaide there is far more stress on innovation, experiment and outreach. Under the direction of singer Robyn Archer, this year's festival offers a wealth of new work; the guess is that her successor in 2002, the American director Peter Sellars, will take the process further. On the evidence of the first few days, I would say that the eye has dominated the ear: I have had any number of visually astonishing experiences.

Adelaide's major museums and galleries are an integral part of the festival, something woefully untrue in Edinburgh. Without doubt the big event so far has been the opening of a new Australian aboriginal cultures gallery in the local museum, a stunning revelation using archival film, videos and computerised graphics. Next door in the Art Gallery of South Australia there is an equally overwhelming temporary exhibition, Beyond the Pale, celebrating the work of modern indigenous urban artists. Vibrant, colourful, often rudely satirical - the current Australian PM, John Howard, is seen raping the land - the exhibition would grace any gallery in the world. Caroline Baum, an ABC radio producer, neatly summed up the significance of both exhibitions: for the first time in Australia, she said, the aboriginals are being seen not as historic victims but as exuberantly original artists.

Australia's complex attitude to its past has dominated every discussion I have had in a week in Sydney. But, in festival terms, it is the power of the image that has constantly hit me. That was certainly true of the big opening night event: the Netherlands Opera production of Writing to Vermeer, with music by Louis Andriessen and libretto by Peter Greenaway, previously seen in Amsterdam. The production, by Saskia Boddeke and Greenaway himself, is a visual feast: the eye is constantly ravished by Vermeer images, video footage and, at the end, cascading water as the Dutch open the dykes to repel the invading French in 1672. My feeling is that the assertive production overwhelms Andriessen's music and even the libretto, dealing with the letters written by Vermeer's wife, mother-in-law and model while he was away in the Hague. This is opera as entrancingly liquid spectacle rather than experience driven by music and character.

The interaction of film and theatre, which we have only tentatively explored in Britain, is taken even further in a work by the Melbourne-based Arena theatre company, ominously entitled Eat Your Young. This 80-minute show posits a future world in which delinquent children in care are controlled by means of neural implants and offered simulated reality as a reward for good behaviour. The script smacks of B-feature schlock but the production, devised by Rosemary Myers, is brilliantly sophisticated in its integration of live action and automated images. As giant robotic screens circle the three young actors you feel that the troubled boss of the institution - played by the rotund Merfyn Owen - is invading their imagination. I recently saw Britain's Station House Opera offer a similar mixture of live action and film, but at home we have a long way to go in exploring the theatrical potential of mixed media.

If the eye has so far dominated in Adelaide, the word fought back strenuously with Howard Barker's eight-hour epic, The Ecstatic Bible, jointly staged by the Wrestling School and Adelaide's Brink Productions. As so often with Barker's work, I was left in several minds. The play offers an excavation of western culture, with references not just to the Bible but to Euripides, Shakespeare, the Shaw of Back to Methuselah, Brecht, Bond and Beckett; Barker himself describes it as "an archaeological dig". I was also reminded of Janacek's opera, The Makropoulos Affair, in that Barker's heroine is a kind of eternal woman who lives on into her second century and even goes on bearing children: in her boundless fertility, she seems fecund to none.

Barker's epic vision of the chaos of human experience, in which desire and creativity are seen against a background of war and destruction, has some powerful scenes and much leavening humour: I was particularly taken with a harassed poet whose dream of happiness is "to sit in a cafe laughing with other poets, some of whom are less talented than me". My problem with Barker's own poetic allegory is that it is not grounded in social reality. His leading characters - the fertile heroine and a vagrant priest, excellently played by Victoria Wicks and Gerrard McArthur - journey through a war-ravaged landscape that could be almost anywhere at any time. But myths, as CS Lewis always insisted, need to be anchored in observable truth; Barker puts the allegorical cart before the narrative horse.

One has, however, to admire his dauntless ambition. The production, directed by Barker and Tim Maddock and designed by Mary Moore, was also a remarkable joint venture between two companies from different continents. And, in a festival dominated so far by ocular experiences, Barker reasserted the power of muscular theatrical language. But eight hours is a long time in theatre and I have to confess there were moments when my own dream of happiness became to sit in one of Adelaide's numerous cafes laughing with other critics.

The production, by Saskia Boddeke and Greenaway himself, is a visual feast: the eye is constantly ravished by Vermeer images, video footage and, at the end, cascading water as the Dutch open the dykes to repel the invading French in 1672. My feeling is that the assertive production overwhelms Andriessen's music and even the libretto, dealing with the letters written by Vermeer's wife, mother-in-law and model while he was away in the Hague. This is opera as entrancingly liquid spectacle rather than experience driven by music and character. The interaction of film and theatre, which we have only tentatively explored in Britain, is taken even further in a work by the Melbourne-based Arena theatre company, ominously entitled Eat Your Young. This 80-minute show posits a future world in which delinquent children in care are controlled by means of neural implants and offered simulated reality as a reward for good behaviour. The script smacks of B-feature schlock but the production, devised by Rosemary Myers, is brilliantly sophisticated in its integration of live action and automated images. As giant robotic screens circle the three young actors you feel that the troubled boss of the institution - played by the rotund Merfyn Owen - is invading their imagination. I recently saw Britain's Station House Opera offer a similar mixture of live action and film, but at home we have a long way to go in exploring the theatrical potential of mixed media. If the eye has so far dominated in Adelaide, the word fought back strenuously with Howard Barker's eight-hour epic, The Ecstatic Bible, jointly staged by the Wrestling School and Adelaide's Brink Productions. As so often with Barker's work, I was left in several minds. The play offers an excavation of western culture, with references not just to the Bible but to Euripides, Shakespeare, the Shaw of Back to Methuselah, Brecht, Bond and Beckett; Barker himself describes it as "an archaeological dig". I was also reminded of Janacek's opera, The Makropoulos Affair, in that Barker's heroine is a kind of eternal woman who lives on into her second century and even goes on bearing children: in her boundless fertility, she seems fecund to none. Barker's epic vision of the chaos of human experience, in which desire and creativity are seen against a background of war and destruction, has some powerful scenes and much leavening humour: I was particularly taken with a harassed poet whose dream of happiness is "to sit in a cafe laughing with other poets, some of whom are less talented than me". My problem with Barker's own poetic allegory is that it is not grounded in social reality. His leading characters - the fertile heroine and a vagrant priest, excellently played by Victoria Wicks and Gerrard McArthur - journey through a war-ravaged landscape that could be almost anywhere at any time. But myths, as CS Lewis always insisted, need to be anchored in observable truth; Barker puts the allegorical cart before the narrative horse. One has, however, to admire his dauntless ambition. The production, directed by Barker and Tim Maddock and designed by Mary Moore, was also a remarkable joint venture between two companies from different continents. And, in a festival dominated so far by ocular experiences, Barker reasserted the power of muscular theatrical language. But eight hours is a long time in theatre and I have to confess there were moments when my own dream of happiness became to sit in one of Adelaide's numerous cafes laughing with other critics.

fields.headline: The great experiment
fields.standfirst: You won't have heard of Artsadmin. But if you're a fan of cutting-edge performance, you'll have felt its influence.  Lyn Gardner reports
fields.trailText: You get some surprising answers when you ask foreign arts promoters to name the best of British theatre. Rather than the RSC, the National Theatre or the Royal Court, they often point to companies and artists such as DV8, Forced Entertainment or Bobby Baker.
fields.body:
You get some surprising answers when you ask foreign arts promoters to name the best of British theatre. Rather than the RSC, the National Theatre or the Royal Court, they often point to companies and artists such as DV8, Forced Entertainment or Bobby Baker. Those names mean little to the average British theatregoer; what they have in common - apart from a willingness to experiment - is that they have at some stage been involved with a largely invisible organisation.

Artsadmin was born in 1979 at Oval House in south London, then a hotbed of radical theatre. The name is deceptive: Artsadmin has done everything from sorting out artists' petty cash to finding them rehearsal space, but it is much more than a freelance administrator. It is a curious hybrid of producer, manager, facilitator and promoter. Most of all, it has become a champion of new work. Among its first clients was Mike Figgis, now a movie director.

Performance artist Gary Stevens was once asked what he really wanted from an administrator. A mother, he replied. Artsadmin is now run by Judith Knight, one of its founders, and was for many years a solely female outfit. It's still predominantly so, and has done plenty of mothering in its time. But it has also fought ruthlessly for an area of performance that is still marginalised in this country. There is an irony that while the British Council promotes live art abroad, the Arts Council dithers about how to categorise and fund it.

Artsadmin tirelessly seeks to raise funding for its artists and to provide continuity in their lives. Their projects tend to be site-specific and they don't have full-time companies, so they can become invisible.

"Artsadmin joins up the dots," says Graeme Miller, whose work crosses the boundaries of choreography, composition and theatre. "They give me a place to exist; without them I'd be a bloke on the street. The whole thing is more than an arbitrary collection of people. It has its own ethos and its own taste."

It has been a struggle, as Rose Fenton of the London International Festival of Theatre points out. "Artsadmin is feted abroad, but policymakers in this country have been slow to recognise how important it is." This is probably because it has fingers in so many pies. When the London Arts Board tried to assess the company five years ago, it couldn't find any remotely similar body with which to make a comparison.

Five years ago Artsadmin took over Toynbee Studios, a warren of a building in London's East End. The building became its administrative HQ and is slowly being transformed into rehearsal and performance spaces. Forced Entertainment will premiere its latest piece, Disco Relax, next week in its theatre.

But public performances are only the tip of the iceberg. Artsadmin is turning the building into what Knight calls "a laboratory - a space where artists can develop work and show it in a safe house". Station House Opera's brilliant Roadmetal Sweetbread, now in demand all over Europe, began life in Toynbee Studios, and owes its present form to feedback from that showcase.

It's not just established companies such as Station House that are seeing the benefit. An Arts for Everyone grant has enabled Artsadmin to support those starting out in live art and those wanting to change direction. The writer David Gale recently received one so he could try his hand at directing.

Wandering around the building and drinking in the passion of the Artsadmin team, I am struck by the similarities between what is happening at Toynbee Studios and the boost that the National Theatre Studio gave to new writing more than 10 years ago. Perhaps this time Artsadmin will get the recognition it deserves.

Disco Relax is at Toynbee Studios, London E1 (0171-960 4242), from next Tuesday.

fields.headline: New start for the kids
fields.standfirst: The government is investing more than £500m in a scheme  that focuses on the early years to try to avoid problems  later, writes Judy Hirst
fields.trailText: The government is investing more than £500m in a scheme that focuses on the early years to try to avoid problems later, writes Judy Hirst.
fields.body:
You're just home from hospital with your new baby, when there's a knock at the door. It's not the health visitor, but yet another professional offering all kinds of advice. How would you feel? Relieved, wary, insulted? Sixty "trailblazer" Sure Start teams are about to find out, as the government's £542m early years programme gets off the drawing board and into targeted families' front rooms this month.

All parents of under-fours in selected catchment areas are being offered a Sure Start visit. The aim is to help these families - many of them lone parents - head off potential child-rearing problems. This can cover anything from how to get your screaming baby to sleep, to finding a playgroup, taming a hyperactive toddler or coping with your own confused feelings.

In Hastings, one of the earliest schemes to get up and running, Sure Start coordinator Jan Casson is confident they can negotiate the tricky business of offering parents support without patronising or stigmatising them. "Our programme is based on Playlink, a home visiting scheme we've been running for several years," she says. "They call us the 'bag ladies' round here, because we arrive with a big bag of toys and a playmat, and basically get down on the floor for an hour and help mum play with the kids."

Over 90% of families on the four housing estates that make up Ore Valley - "the trailblazer catchment area" - have taken up the offer of an initial visit. But it's been running on a wing and a prayer, with a long waiting list.

Now a £2.8m, three-year Sure Start grant means they can employ more visitors, build a community centre, and extend services, such as toy libraries, playbuses and drop-ins.

Ore Valley, with a population of over 10,000, has one of the highest rates of unemployment, teenage pregnancy and poverty in the country, plus substantial drug and crime problems. But now, with all this extra money, there's a glimmer of hope - not just for the children, who will benefit from new one-stop health and social services, but for the parents too. A young parents' group, parenting classes and a range of NVQs will soon be on offer on their doorstep.

Casson, a former nursery nurse, does not envisage much resistance from local families to an initial Sure Start visit, or too many fears about social worker types coming to take children away. "After all, people are not being referred to us individually," she says. "The whole district has been targeted. And where child protection issues do arise, we'll handle them sensitively. The entire emphasis is on family support."

Certainly, the rationale behind Sure Start - "the reason the trea sury is so firmly backing it," according to Casson - is its "catch 'em early" philosophy. By focusing on early years family support, with specific targets for birth weight, child development and those at risk, the government hopes to reduce expensive social problems in years to come.

This month, 69 "second wave" bids go in and 250 schemes should be operational by April 2002.

To work, though, Sure Start needs to be sustainable. Which means that, when the money runs out in a couple of years, these communities must be able to go it alone, maintaining the momentum for older children.

At the other end of East Sussex, Jack Smith, social services lead officer for the Wealden Sure Start scheme, is convinced that the best way to do this is by relying on parents themselves. He says: "We've been training up local people - not to be health visitors and such like, but to become 'community parents'. Many mothers and fathers object to professionals coming in and telling them how to parent their children. They feel it labels them as a problem. This way, we are drawing on the resources of local parents, who know first-hand what it's like to bring up children round here."

Their catchment area is based on three housing estates in Hailsham East, a very poor ward with a 10% traveller community, very high levels of special needs, and around one-third of young mothers with post-natal depression. A £2.3m from Sure Start and a £2.8m grant from the single regeneration budget (SRB), means there will soon be a new community centre, offering a range of services to older as well as pre-school children. But to succeed, says Smith, the whole scheme must be firmly community-led.

Naomi Eisenstadt, head of Sure Start, says: "The programme is explicitly designed to avoid stigma, and a key principle is to involve local communities in provision from the outset." However she concedes that the extent to which this is happening in practice is patchy.

A note of caution is also sounded by Walter Barker, head of the early childhood development at Bristol university. He was consulted early on by Sure Start civil servants looking for models to build on, and is helping some local schemes to develop a community parenting approach. "It's not the quick fix that politicians are looking for," he warns. "But it is a way to give poor families some control over their lives."

Barker fears a token involvement in Sure Start - "a meek and mild parent representative on the local board" - while power remains firmly in the professionals' hands.

It's a tough one to crack. But the path Sure Start takes - as a well-meaning benefactor or as a genuine empowerer of local communities - could well determine its success for generations to come.

fields.headline: Chelsea 1 - 0 Marseille
fields.standfirst: Refresh this page for the latest update
fields.trailText: Kick off 7.45pm
fields.body:
Kick off 7.45pm

Chelsea: De Goey, Ferrer, Leboeuf, Desailly, Babayaro, Morris, Deschamps, Wise, Poyet, Flo, Zola. Subs: Cudicini, Sutton, Di Matteo, Ambrosetti, Lambourde, Thome, Harley.

Marseille: Trevisan, Cyprien, Luccin, Abardonado, Perez, Brando, Leroy, Dalmat, Pires, Bakayoko, Pouget. Subs: Carasso, Martin, De La Pena, Keita, Martini, Fischer, Moses.

Referee: J Fernandez Marin (Spain)

1 The sell-out crowd give Chelsea a huge raw as they emerge from the tunnel. Gianluca Vialli's men will be desperate to gain some advantage tonight in the group that still has everything to play for. Chelsea kick off and immediately probe the Marseille half before the French side test De Goey with a long-range shot from Dalmat.
3 Chelsea respond with a break and Poyet forces a save from Trevisan with a swiftly taken shot.
4 Chelsea making all the early running as Zola begins to expose Marseille down the right.
5 Leboeuf releases Flo but Trevisan is wise to the chance and clears for a corner. Wise takes but the ball lofts high and into space on the far side of the area before Flo is reprimanded for climbing.
8 Booking Deschamps. The English Frenchman recklessly hacks a challenge in response to losing possession and pays the price.
11 Chelsea still doing a good job of pinning Marseille back.
12 Chelsea's best chance so far; Poyet finds Flo on the right who then crosses to Zola but the little Italian fluffs his chance and hits the ball straight at a defender. Ten seconds later, the ball is looped back into the box from Trevisan's clearance and finds Poyet running on to goal - Trevisan just beats him to it.
14 Intense pressure from Chelsea results in a corner. The ball is flighted into the area and headed on for Babayaro to take over the title of Chelsea's Best Chance So Far when he gets in a great close-range header only to see it cleared for a corner.
16 Wise takes the corner but Marseille clear.
18 Marseille start to get into the game as Pouget and Pires cause problems in the Chelsea penalty area. They win a corner but Chelsea scramble a clearance.
22 Babayaro races away down the left and gets in a cross that leaves Marseille exposed but Trevisan makes a flying catch.
24 The left flank is proving fertile ground for Chelsea as Zola races to the edge of the area. He exchanges passes with Morris before cutting inside and crossing for Wise to head down weakly.
27 Goal: Chelsea 1 - 0 Marseille Flo, in possession on the left of the penalty area, crosses to Zola who heads down for Wise to fire across the face of goal and put Chelsea in the lead.
31 Chelsea have never lost at home in Europe and now clearly have their tails up as they search of a second.
33 Apart from an early flourish, Marseille have up to now struggled to find the form that gave them victory at home but now enter a good spell of play as they seek an equaliser.
34 Bakayoko comes close when he forces a fine save from De Goey with a viciously struck shot.
36 Marseille continue to step up the pace after that chance and come close again when a scrambled Pires shot is saved by the flailing De Goey.
38 Substitution Marseille: Fischer on for Perez
39 Booking Leboeuf for a blatent shove on Bakayoko.
42 Chelsea have a free-kick from a good 30 yards out; Leboeuf has go and gets it on target but Trevisan makes the save.
44 Chelsea claim handball when a Flo cross from the right is obstructed inadvertently. Wise takes the resulting corner, Desailly misses the ball and Flo scrambles a shot that Trevisan saves before Babayaro prods in a shot that goes just wide.
45 Zola charges off again down the right but runs the ball out of play before referee Marin blows for half-time.

46 A quiet start to the second half as both teams enjoy a gentle knock around.
48 Flo, Babayaro and Wise combine in midfield as Chelsea attempt to get things moving through the middle rather than down the flanks.
50 Zola receives the ball on the edge of the penalty area but his shot across goal goes wide after taking a touch.
51 Wise takes the corner, plays it short to Zola then picks up the return before passing back for Zola to deliver a cross; Marseille clear.
52 Booking Pouget for a challenge on Wise.
55 Chelsea free-kick from 30 yards out. Zola has a pop, but puts it wide after clearing the Marseille wall.
59 Chelsea free-kick, flighted in by Zola but Cyprien clears to give away a corner. Comes to nothing.
63 The match hits a bit of a lull before Marseille get back into the action thanks to some slack play by Chelsea. Babayaro gives the ball away to Pires who passes for Leroy to fire in a shot from the edge of the area. De Goey saves.
66 Substitution Marseille De La Pena on for Cyprien.
67 Wise passes wide to Babayaro out on the left. He races up and whips in a deep cross for Flo to head over from the edge of the area. Poyet looks miffed as he was arguably in a better postion behind the lanky Norwegian.
72 Marseille refuse to give up (not surprisingly as they are only a goal down). Dalmat makes space on the left before finding Pouget 20 yards out; Chelsea stifle the opening.
76 Marseille corner; De La Pena takes and Chelsea clear. Dalmat spoons the ball back into the area and finds a rather surprised Abardonardo, but the defender can only hoof the ball over the bar.
79 Substitutions Chelsea Harley and Di Matteo on for Zola and Deschamps. Both players look a tad put out at their departures despite the obvious tactical nature of the decision as Chelsea attempt to hang on to their lead.
81 Probably Marseille's best chance. They win a free-kick over 30 yards out, De La Pena takes and beats the wall to see his effort hit the right-hand upright.
82 Marseille keep up the pressure as Leroy forces a fine save from De Goey. Dalmat takes the resulting corner and the ball bounces around just outside the area before De La Pena slides a lovely pass through to Bakayoko. He uses his weight well to make space before Babayaro marshals him wide and regains possession. De La Pena's introduction has ignited Marseille.
89 Booking Fischer
90 Marseille have a direct free-kick from just outside the area. De La Pena again takes; he lifts the ball into the area but Chelsea muster well. Marseille continue to put pressure on the Chelsea goal. Brando finds Bakayoko on the left of the six-yard box and his shot flies across the face of goal and, luckily for Chelsea, misses the post by inches. Full-time: Chelsea 1 - 0 Marseille. Chelsea hang on to claim top spot in Group D

He races up and whips in a deep cross for Flo to head over from the edge of the area. Poyet looks miffed as he was arguably in a better postion behind the lanky Norwegian. 72 Marseille refuse to give up (not surprisingly as they are only a goal down). Dalmat makes space on the left before finding Pouget 20 yards out; Chelsea stifle the opening. 76 Marseille corner; De La Pena takes and Chelsea clear. Dalmat spoons the ball back into the area and finds a rather surprised Abardonardo, but the defender can only hoof the ball over the bar. 79 Substitutions Chelsea Harley and Di Matteo on for Zola and Deschamps. Both players look a tad put out at their departures despite the obvious tactical nature of the decision as Chelsea attempt to hang on to their lead. 81 Probably Marseille's best chance. They win a free-kick over 30 yards out, De La Pena takes and beats the wall to see his effort hit the right-hand upright. 82 Marseille keep up the pressure as Leroy forces a fine save from De Goey. Dalmat takes the resulting corner and the ball bounces around just outside the area before De La Pena slides a lovely pass through to Bakayoko. He uses his weight well to make space before Babayaro marshals him wide and regains possession. De La Pena's introduction has ignited Marseille. 89 Booking Fischer 90 Marseille have a direct free-kick from just outside the area. De La Pena again takes; he lifts the ball into the area but Chelsea muster well. Marseille continue to put pressure on the Chelsea goal. Brando finds Bakayoko on the left of the six-yard box and his shot flies across the face of goal and, luckily for Chelsea, misses the post by inches. Full-time: Chelsea 1 - 0 Marseille. Chelsea hang on to claim top spot in Group D

fields.headline: BBC to gamble on youth in radio war
fields.trailText: The BBC is considering extending cricket bulletins to Radio 1, whose core listeners are in the 15-to-24 age bracket, as part of its fight to retain the broadcast rights to international matches.
fields.body:
The BBC is considering extending cricket bulletins to Radio 1, whose core listeners are in the 15-to-24 age bracket, as part of its fight to retain the broadcast rights to international matches.

Radio 4 will be covering England's matches against Zimbabwe and West Indies this summer, but the rights for the following season are up for grabs. The BBC is under threat from Talksport, which covered the winter tour of South Africa, but is trying for exclusive rights by promising it can woo a younger audience to the game.

Andrew Caddick was the only Englishman named in a Rest of the World XI to play Asia in Dhaka next month.

The growing emphasis on the national team continued yesterday when the First Class Forum, representing the 18 counties, surrendered most key decision-making powers to the England management board.

fields.headline: Elementary for a dual sportsman
fields.trailText: Frank Keating Willie Watson was 80 yesterday. It was sadly touching to telephone him with birthday greetings a day after the untimely death of Chris Balderstone, a far younger footballing cricketer of the legend.
fields.body:
Willie Watson was 80 yesterday. It was sadly touching to telephone him with birthday greetings a day after the untimely death of Chris Balderstone, a far younger footballing cricketer of the legend, who had followed Watson a generation later in cutting his sporting teeth both as a Huddersfield Town bootboy and at Headingley's indoor nets.

Watson was shocked at the news. He moved to South Africa in 1968 to be administrator at Johannesburg's Wanderers club. Yesterday he was in Cape Town for a family celebration, surrounded by grandchildren. "I'm hoping we finish in time to catch Man United in Bordeaux on the satellite," he said with a chuckle. "That's all I'm good for now, a bit of DIY and all the satellite sport."

The famous wavy hair is still there but the gold is a thinning grey now. All his sporting contemporaries liked Watson. Never a bad word. The only rider came from his hero, Len Hutton: "Sport? It all came too easy for our Willie."

Another birthday call, nearer home, is due this Friday, for only two members survive of that club open to those who played soccer and cricket for England: Watson and young Arthur Milton, who will be 72 on March 10. It will never enrol another.

Watson won four soccer caps for England and was a member of the 1950 World Cup squad. He played 23 Tests. Look up any cuttings, they unfailingly call Watson a "cultured" wing-half and an "elegant" left-handed bat.

"How privileged I was to play with and against the best at close quarters: Len, technically the greatest bat ever; John Charles, the complete footballer; Len Shackleton, who had everything as an individual except being a link in the chain; and my old Sunderland wing-half buddy Arthur Wright, who had the lot except his due rewards for ball-playing brilliance."

It was Tuesday June 30 1953 at Lord's which set Watson apart in the lore; from 11.30am to 5.51pm, to be exact. He had gone in the night before, at No5, with England at a perilous 12 for three against Australia, 332 behind with six and a bit hours to bat.

Next morning Denis Compton was out for 33 at 12.40 and England were 73 for four. Trevor Bailey joined this same cheerful ancient who is now at the end of a phone-line 47 years later. "Funny, isn't it? I can't remember five days ago but can vividly recall near 50 years.

"Denis never got credit for setting us on the road that day. He reined in his natural happy style and that rubbed off on me and Trevor.

"We still had to take the runs and by lunch we were on 116; 96 in the morning, damn good going, eh? An hour after lunch the new ball was due. That would decide it, everyone knew. As well as [Ray] Lindwall and [Keith] Miller, they had [Bill] Johnston and [Alan] Davidson, each ripe-cherry men all right. They took it dead on five to three.

"I can still feel the tension quadrupling out there in the middle and round the whole packed arena. The crowd kept increasing as word got round. Every delivery was of such importance, the duel of tactics and concentration compelling. Trevor stuck his nose down the pitch to every ball. A squadron of tanks couldn't have budged him. We were still there at tea.

"After that, daylight; and then it was like we were almost sailing into the sunset. At 20 past five Trevor got his 50; at about 25 to six I got my 100 with a sweep for four which Richie [Benaud] nearly caught."

Watson was out for 109, Bailey following for 71. Match drawn, one for posterity. The brand new octogenarian chuckles on: "The hubbub went on for weeks, didn't it.... well, for years really?"

fields.headline: Wickets tumble in Peshawar
fields.trailText: Pakistan lost their last eight batsmen for just 62 runs as 14 wickets fell on a thrilling third day of the second Test against Sri Lanka in Peshawar yesterday
fields.body:
Pakistan lost their last eight batsmen for just 62 runs as 14 wickets fell on a thrilling third day of the second Test against Sri Lanka in Peshawar yesterday

The hosts resumed on 67 for one in reply to Sri Lanka's first innings score of 268, but were dismissed for just 199.

However, the tourists didn't have it all their own way second time round, closing on 129 for five for an overall lead of 198 in a match they need to win to make the three-match series safe.

In the seventh over of the day Pakistan's Yousuf Youhana was caught behind by wicketkeeper Romesh Kaluwitharana off the bowling of Chaminda Vaas for just eight - and the wickets continued to tumble for the rest of the day.

Inzamam-ul-Haq started with a flourish of driven boundaries but settled down and advisedly took few risks.

Sri Lankan skipper Sanath Jayasuriya dismissed Saeed Anwar, caught by Muttiah Muralitharan, for 74 with the total on 137.

Muralitharan claimed his first victim of the Test in the 70th over as Younis Khan was caught close in by Mahela Jayawardene for eight.

Inzamam comfortably held up one end but Shahid Afridi was next to go, caught driving by Russel Arnold to give Vaas his second wicket of the innings.

Abdur Razzaq went for a duck, lasting only six balls before Jayawardene took his second catch off Muralitharan. Then debutant wicketkeeper Atiq-uz-Zaman lasted just 15 balls for a solitary single before edging Pramodya Wickremasinghe to Kaluwitharana.

Waqar Younis (3) gave Jayawardene another comfortable catch and Arshad Khan (0) was trapped lbw as Muralitharan picked up two wickets in three balls to leave the home side on 177 for nine.

Only 22 more runs were added before Marvan Atapattu took a simple catch at mid-off to dismiss Akhtar for five and end the Pakistan innings leaving Inzamam unbeaten on 58.

Muralitharan was the pick of the Sri Lanka bowlers, taking four wickets for 77. Starting their second innings with a lead of 69, the tourists soon lost Jayasuriya, trapped lbw by paceman Waqar Younis.

Arnold and Jayasuriya's fellow opener Atapattu put on 62, before the latter was held by Aamir Sohail for 29 off the bowling of off-spinner Arshad Khan. Waqar accounted for new batsman Jayawardene (10) lbw to leave Sri Lanka 90 for three in the 31st over.

TM Dilshan was the next to go, making just seven before becoming part-time bowler Sohail's third victim of the match when he edged to Atiq-uz-Zaman behind the stumps.

A fifth wicket fell in the next over with the scheduled close seven overs away - Akhtar removing Kaluwitharana lbw for a third ball duck.

fields.headline: Kidnap capers
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Corporate team-building exercises used to be all about swinging from rope bridges and shooting your manager with paintballs. How dull. Companies nowadays are looking for more authentic thrills to terrify co-workers into getting along briefly.
fields.body:
Corporate team-building exercises used to be all about swinging from rope bridges and shooting your manager with paintballs. How dull. Companies nowadays are looking for more authentic thrills to terrify co-workers into getting along briefly. That, at least, was the thinking of the Swedish telecom company Ericsson last month when it sent its staff on a bus tour of Greece. Bored with sending them down streams on barrels, the company decided to test how staff responded to stress - by arranging for one of the group to be kidnapped.

The kidnappee realised it was a hoax when two masked men armed with (empty) shotguns stormed the bus and threatened to whisk her off. Unfortunately the police did not, and the coach was rapidly surrounded by armed commandos from Corinth - whose sensitive handling of two real hijackings last year left three dead. They were not, as may be imagined, best pleased on realising the whole thing was a hoax, and promptly arrested the entire party. One would have thought travelling on a Greek bus would have been stressful enough.

Geek tragedy

Tony Blair wants to make the net attractive to all, so doubtless he will be following closely next week's "sexiest geek alive" contest. Twelve contenders have emerged from an initial field of 18,000, after displaying proficiency at Quake and Linux and an encyclopaedic knowledge of Star Trek. Clockwatcher's tip for the title didn't quite make the cut, but we feel 16-year-old Justin Lintz deserves an honourable mention all the same. "I'm young and in the midst [sic] of becoming one of the sexiest geeks alive," reads his online manifesto. "Instead of going to parties on the weekend and drinking, I stay up all night till about two in the morning playing Quake, reading websites, going on IRC, etc. I read slashdot, geeknews, hackernews, securityfocus daily and I'm subscribed to about seven security mailing lists including NT Bugtraq and Bugtraq. I have three years of experience in VB, five years html, two years JavaScript, one year in 16-bit C++ and one year ASP." Come on ladies, form an orderly queue.

fields.headline: House of horrors
fields.standfirst: The Blue Chamber,  Duff House, Banff  *****
fields.trailText: As you pull into the long drive leading up to William Adam's 1735 baroque creation, a sign says it all: "Duff House, Country House Gallery". The most remote outpost of the National Galleries of Scotland's empire, this grand 18th-century pile could well be a hotel sitting in splendid grounds. In fact, this house in the country between Aberdeen and Inverness is one of those slightly-too-perfect reconstruction jobs, a house frozen in a fictional moment of saccharine-tinged history.
fields.body:
As you pull into the long drive leading up to William Adam's 1735 baroque creation, a sign says it all: "Duff House, Country House Gallery". The most remote outpost of the National Galleries of Scotland's empire, this grand 18th-century pile could well be a hotel sitting in splendid grounds. In fact, this house in the country between Aberdeen and Inverness is one of those slightly-too-perfect reconstruction jobs, a house frozen in a fictional moment of saccharine-tinged history.

Opened to the public in 1995, its many rooms are rich in fine paintings, furniture (the best bits discreetly roped off) and works of art. As in so many of these swanky gaffs, every scrap of life seems to have been drained and, wandering through the drawing rooms, past endless marble columns, it's hard not to get distracted by a fundamental question. Why do we pay to toddle round such restoration comedies?

Enter six mischievous spirits, a gaggle of cutting-edge young artists. The result is a provocative intervention, a fizz of life, a complex bewilderment in the heart of history made clean and civilised. Actually, it's an uneven show with a couple of underwhelming pieces: Jessica Stockholder has never exhibited in Scotland before and she is unlikely to win friends with a scrawny little drawing; Gareth Fisher's plaster and fibre optic sculptures don't intrigue. But there are some priceless moments.

In one of the well-behaved rooms sit Claire Barclay's gorgeous, wicked and perverse contributions - a small hoop of rabbit's fur laid on the floor, a rush of kinky black feathers, and a pair of pigs' ears with silver rings displayed on the mantelpiece. As ever with Barclay, incongruity is all, as is a playful look at why some things are licit, others ruled taboo. Her piggy trophies are no stranger than the others displayed on every plinth and cabinet around them. And, in the human history of the house, Barclay knows that sex and the slaughter of animals will have both had their murky, starring moments.

Best of all is Kenny Hunter's update on the historical bust. Placed in the gallery this represents everything the other rooms erase: the rhythm of life, laughter, music; but also the historical reality of the slavery on which the wealth that built houses like this was often raised. A big dub-head, a cool black bust on a rudimentary sound system - it is the wisest retort to this house .

Until 30 April. 01261 818181

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Lloyds promises fair Link charges
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB yesterday responded to government anxieties by pledging not to discriminate against people in rural and remote areas when they withdraw money from isolated cash machines.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB yesterday responded to government anxieties by pledging not to discriminate against people in rural and remote areas when they withdraw money from isolated cash machines.

In its "ATM code of conduct", Lloyds TSB also made it clear it would not "double charge" customers as the government had feared through a "surcharge" and a "disloyalty" fee. It failed to address the vexed question of the level of any charge.

The charm offensive came the day before bankers and the head of the Link cash machine network are due to meet with Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary. Mr Byers has made it clear to the 34 bank and building society members of Link that he is considering a competition investigation in to the way they set charges for cash withdrawals.

Lloyds TSB's code also made clear it would not charge its own customers for use of its 4,400 cash machines and that it would not change its charging structure until next year. It will notify non-customers of any charge they face.

fields.headline: A star in the ascendant
fields.standfirst: Wayne Krantz, Pizza Express, Dean Street, London  ****
fields.trailText: "Musicians' musician" can be a treacherous tribute, locking the subject in a closet to breathe a rarefied air nobody else can survive on. But Wayne Krantz, the young Oregon-born guitarist who once worked with Steely Dan, is a musicians' musician and a music-lovers' musician too. Fellow practitioners from the local scene crowded the bar at Pizza Express on Monday, nodding animatedly. But the regular punters got the point about Krantz's dense, fiercely spontaneous brand of electric guitar fusion as well, even if some of the nuts and bolts of his remarkable, alert trio's technical resourcefulness might have passed them by.
fields.body:
"Musicians' musician" can be a treacherous tribute, locking the subject in a closet to breathe a rarefied air nobody else can survive on. But Wayne Krantz, the young Oregon-born guitarist who once worked with Steely Dan, is a musicians' musician and a music-lovers' musician too. Fellow practitioners from the local scene crowded the bar at Pizza Express on Monday, nodding animatedly. But the regular punters got the point about Krantz's dense, fiercely spontaneous brand of electric guitar fusion as well, even if some of the nuts and bolts of his remarkable, alert trio's technical resourcefulness might have passed them by.

The gig confirmed the broad appeal Krantz makes to jazz- fusion listeners. A forceful opening set demonstrated his absorption of many of the idiom's rules - bluesy chords, a rhythm guitarist's concept of a lead line, big volume and a raw, metallic sound. The latter was varied by electronics, occasionally for a hollow, blown-pipe effect. Admirers of John Scofield can hear echoes of that muscular style in Krantz's uncompromising attack.

But Krantz's sound also appealed on a hardcore improv level, in its sustained intensity (he likes long solos with few spaces, but his imagination and fluency save him from prolixity), avoidance of the usual fusion or straight-jazz thematic vehicles, and the one-touch collective empathy of his group. Krantz works every week with bassist Tim Levebre and drummer Keith Carlock at New York's 55 Bar (his recent albums have been fascinating cut-and-paste operations on live material from there), and it shows.

Carlock is a formidable percussionist of restless intensity who brings a jolting subversiveness of accent and timing to the rigid familiarities of funk drumming. Levebre conversed incessantly with Krantz, with supple and resonant lines providing melodic and rhythmic contrasts. His quick response to the guitarist's changes of tack gave the music a constant edge of expectancy, even when its wall-of-noise periods threatened to do the opposite.

Krantz doesn't deliver "tunes" the way Scofield or Pat Metheny do; he folds fragments of melody within harmonic movements more like Bill Frisell. Yet the inter-minglings of lazy funk chord patterns, briefly arching treble phrases, heavy-metal collisions and long legato lines that make up his own special notion of a repertoire are endlessly gripping. A new kind of jazz star in the making, except that that's probably exactly what he doesn't want.

The Wayne Krantz trio play the Bonington Theatre, Nottingham (0115-967 0114), on Thursday; Sandringham Hotel, Cardiff (01222 232161), March 10-11 and Brewery Arts Centre, Kendal (01539 725133), March 12

webTitle: Internet reaches era of free surfing

fields.headline: Internet reaches era of free surfing
fields.standfirst:
Blair vision closer as US firm offers links without 'bill shock'

Free internet access: the issue explained

The key players
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's vision of a Britain where people can surf online for free for as long as they want moved a significant step closer yesterday when the cable company NTL announced plans to offer free unmetered access to the internet.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's vision of a Britain where people can surf online for free for as long as they want moved a significant step closer yesterday when the cable company NTL announced plans to offer free unmetered access to the internet.

The move from the American company follows sustained pressure from the government to lower the cost of using the net and was welcomed by Mr Blair. It is also likely to spark a price war among the major internet access providers that will cause the biggest shake-up yet experienced by the nascent web industry and from which the consumer is poised to be the eventual winner.

High call charges - or "bill shock" as the industry describes the reaction when customers see what their internet calls have cost - are often identified as one of the major barriers to people, particularly those with low incomes, from using the net.

ntlworld will be launched on April 17 for internet access by personal computers, with web access through the television coming soon after. Homes with direct links to NTL cable will gain access as part of a £9.25-a-month telephone and TV package.

Customers on other networks, such as BT, will pay a one-off £10 fee for a line adaptor and then pledge to spend more than £10 per month on NTL voice calls.

Barclay Knapp, chief executive of NTL, said: "ntlworld will help the UK in a drive to lead the world in making e-commerce, e-entertainment and e-education available to everyone."

Mr Blair, speaking at an internet conference yesterday, reiterated his desire to see internet costs cut to help the UK keep up with the online world and get all Britons on to a "people's internet" by 2005.

"Our goal must be to see prices comparable with anywhere in the world, including the US," he said.

Mr Blair fears that unless call charges are cut, Britain will lag behind as the "new economy" develops and the internet could become the preserve of the wealthy and highly educated.

His message appears to be getting through to leading net providers. AltaVista, the US search engine, said on Monday it would offer unmetered access for an initial signing-on fee of up to £50 and an annual renewal fee of between £10 and £20.

Established companies such as Freeserve, the UK's largest internet service provider, and AOL, its biggest rival, are examining ways of matching their rivals to protect their market position. Freeserve, which relies on telephone calls for much of its revenue, has most to lose from the move towards unmetered access. Yesterday its shares fell 19% to 712.5p, wiping £1.7bn off its value, as the stock market reacted to NTL's move.

A recent report by the internet specialists Durlacher said unmetered access in the UK would treble the time people spent online.

The cable company Telewest was overwhelmed by demand when it launched its "unmetered package" last month and has since been forced to limit the number of subscribers it is signing up.

Mary Martin, a 33-year-old freelance sound recordist from Bristol, spent most of yesterday logged on through Telwes while she was building a web page for a musician friend.

"I've been online pretty much since I got up this morning, done a lot of work and not once worried about the cost," she said. "Cost was definitely one of the reasons stopping me from doing more on the net."

In most European countries, the big telephone companies provide web access for the general public.Britain's web sector is unique - partly because BT failed to act and let in rivals such as Freeserve and AOL.

But it is the American model that Britain is seeking to emulate. Average internet usage in the US is twice as high per person as in Britain.

Andrew Mitchell, AltaVista's UK managing director, de scribed his company's offer as a "kick-start" to the UK industry. "What we need is predictable, understandable and clear charges," he said.

Despite the move towards free calls, City analysts believe many consumers will still pay subscriptions for access to guarantee better reliability and high quality content.

Ajay Chowdhury, managing director of LineOne, which has around 800,000 customers, said: "Internet users have a variety of different tastes so internet providers will make available a selection of different flavours to match their appetites."

Teething problems included AOL Europe being overwhelmed by calls yesterday after a portion of its 0800 network went down.

fields.headline: Of pigs and men
fields.standfirst: An employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: Farm animals can be a swine for the modern employment lawyer
fields.body:
In some of the photographs, the sow is on her own, spread out on her side, head thrown back and mouth open like a murder victim. Her teats are lined up in front of her like pints on a bar.

In other photographs, her piglets are active around her, impossibly perky and clean and pale fondant pink. She is not really looking at them.

I am looking at these photographs in conference with a pig expert because an upcoming case turns on the proper method of dealing with sows in "farrowing crates". A farrowing crate, it turns out, is where the sow lives whilst she is waiting to give birth, whilst she is giving birth and after she has given birth to her piglets.

The farrowing crate is a sort of rectangular pen not much bigger than the sow, made up of metal tubes and fastened to the floor at the corners. The sow can stand up in it or lie on her side in an exhausted-looking way but she cannot move anywhere or accidentally harm her piglets. There is an arrangement at one end which, as the expert explains to me, "to be delicate about it, allows the piglets to be born but not right against the bars."

A problem which arises with these farrowing crates, and which is an important point in our case, is that the sow's urine and dung can build up and cause corrosion of the metal posts at the corners of the crate. A strong sow might then be able to pull the crate from the floor and walk around with it on her back. This all leads in a somewhat obscure manner to my client's accident.

So we are all sitting around a table: expert, client, solicitor, me, looking at these photographs and discussing the sows as if they were car components or cabbages being processed. After the farrowing process, I gather, the dancing piglets are taken off to some other part of the piggery in due course to be "finished".

My client says rather sadly: "I have been interested in pigs all my life, and now I can't work with them any more". The expert clearly also has an interest in pigs. I am just having difficulty in understanding what kind of interest it is.

After the conference, a friend rings up with the news that she is pregnant. Involuntarily, I imagine her lying on her side in a metal crate, giving birth to her baby against the bars and then lying in her own urine and dung until; her baby is taken away to be finished.

Which leads me to think that I will have to restrict my pig practice severely on the grounds that I am emotionally unequipped to deal with pig pictures and cannot help looking forward to the day when all the sows rise up with their farrowing crates on their backs and roam free in the fields with their piglets. Although no doubt the pig expert could tell me any number of reasons why that would be an undesirable arrangement.

fields.headline: Desk therapist
fields.standfirst:
We showed psychologist Donna Dawson the desk of politician and author Edwina Currie

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: We showed psychologist Donna Dawson the desk of politician and author Edwina Currie
fields.body:
This desktop feels masculine, dominated as it is by technology. It speaks of speed, its owner dashes in and out. The desk itself is a strong, solid, well-crafted piece of furniture, revealing an owner who loves beautiful things that are useable.

This is a very practical person, with a strong aesthetic sense; the inlaid blotter reveals a man who either enjoys writing, or does a lot of writing in his work. Or maybe even someone who wishes he were a writer.

Judging by the creative chaos on the desk, there is a lot to do. He needs inspiration: the ledge above his desk is full of things that probably inspire him. Family and friends are also important.

This is a man fuelled by nervous energy, who needs to be moving, doing, exploring, and learning and he's his own worst enemy when it comes to taking breaks. Driven and ambitious would describe him; also versatile, energetic and sociable. However, playtime is kept separate - he could never take a break at his desk.

Did our expert get it right? Edwina Currie responds

Ho ho! Our therapist should abandon the prejudice that only men are technology-friendly. Very naughty. Everything is spot on, apart from the obvious howler that I am a writer, with my fifth novel just out. It is also quite right that I don't take breaks at my desk. Never - I can't bear crumbs all over the keyboard.

Chasing Men, Little Brown, £9.99

fields.headline: It could be you
fields.standfirst:
What does it take to be a Branson or a Gates? A US marketing guru says you don't need an MBA to be a self-made millionaire - just his magic formula and the right mindset. Sharon Krum meets Thomas Stanley

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: First, the bad news. To qualify as a millionaire in the United States today, you need to earn approximately $4m (£2.4m). Thanks to taxes, $4m whittles down to $1m before there is time to add it up. But here is the good news. Earning $1 m, $4 m, even $50m, is as simple as baking a three-layer cake. According to Dr J Thomas Stanley, a marketing guru who studies millionaires for a living, there is no need for quiz shows, wealthy parents or a Harvard MBA to get you into the club. In fact, you don't even need an A-level.
fields.body:
First, the bad news. To qualify as a millionaire in the United States today, you need to earn approximately $4m (£2.4m). Thanks to taxes, $4m whittles down to $1m before there is time to add it up. But here is the good news. Earning $1 m, $4 m, even $50m, is as simple as baking a three-layer cake. According to Dr J Thomas Stanley, a marketing guru who studies millionaires for a living, there is no need for quiz shows, wealthy parents or a Harvard MBA to get you into the club. In fact, you don't even need an A-level.

What you do require is the recipe for achieving wealth. Stanley claims to have formulated one, which he has published, after a study of 1,300 self-made American millionaires. He calls this recipe, and the eponymous book, The Millionaire Mind. This is a state of being and a career that consistently trumps shortcomings in intelligence or connections, a mindset guaranteed to earn you a fortune.

The crux of his findings is that hard work, focus, goal-setting and discipline are the direct path to riches. Understandably, the idea that a rigorous work ethic, as opposed to an Oxbridge education or mummy and daddy's money - is what it takes to make millions has been greeted with delirious delight by Bill Gates wannabes.

Released in the US only three weeks ago, Stanley's book, The Millionaire Mind, is already number four on the New York Times bestseller list. "What I found, consistently, is that of all the factors involved in financial success, hard work was first, and graduating at the top of the class ranked last," says Stanley, who lives in Atlanta. "Most millionaires made Bs and Cs at university. But education is such a major issue in America. Parents get hysterical if their children don't get As in kindergarten; but I found a high IQ is no indicator of success. Millionaires build empires on creativity and common sense."

The millionaires Stanley studied had an average net worth of $9.2m (£5.5m). The majority were entrepreneurs and 73% were described as academically average. He also found that they were not motivated by money or dreams of yachts in the Greek islands and castles in Marbella. "Self-made millionaires do not look at money as a goal in itself. Ninety per cent told me their objective in starting out was to be independent, to follow their passions, to control their lives."

So if intelligence, degrees, quiz shows and lottery winnings don't count, what does? Stanley sums it up neatly: "First, millionaires choose a career in an area that matches their talents and interests. This ensures they are always motivated to work harder and longer than anybody else.

"Then they consistently think outside the box, seeing opportunities others have ignored. This is exactly what Richard Branson did with Virgin. He really is my hero. He consistently thinks outside the box to expand his empire."

Consider also the case of Donald Sonner, the 64-year-old head of the Southern Bloomer Manufacturing Company in Tennessee, one of the millionaires Stanley interviewed. Sonner only completed one year of high school but was a millionaire by 24. He uses scrap cloth discarded by garment manufacturers to make underwear for prisons and gun-cleaning patches. "Mr Sonner got rich by working hard and coming up with an idea nobody else had," says Stanley.

The trick is to pick a career wedded to your interests, think laterally, then pair those elements with a disciplined work ethic. Stanley emphasised that all the millionaires in his survey set high goals and then worked around the clock to meet them. "Millionaires say they work harder, place a high priority on honesty and integrity in business, and are prepared to take financial risks. They draw up plans and constantly evaluate them. They never lose sight of their goal."

They also use time efficiently. Another millionaire Stanley interviewed was a Mr Benjamin, a school-bus driver who spent all his work breaks studying the stock market instead of messing about with his friends at the bus station. He began investing tiny amounts, taking risks and rolling with the punches when stocks took a tumble. He retired after 20 years, worth $3m.

"It's all about focus. Millionaires make a decision to tune out everything else and concentrate on one thing, be it creating a retirement fund, or launching a record label. Mr Benjamin focused on investing, schooled himself, and took calculated risks that paid off."

In New York, where there are said to be 30,000 millionaires, all the talk is of Joseph Park, 28, who quit his well-paid job as a Wall Street trader to launch www.kozmo.com, a company that delivers goods to your home within an hour of you emailing an order. Analysts dismissed the idea as unworkable and Park was warned that he might be headed for bankruptcy. But the public loved the idea, business is booming and last month Park raised $100m in venture capital. Stanley says Park is a perfect example of someone having a novel idea, laser-like focus, motivation, and the gumption to take a risk.

Stanley also found that psychologically, like Park, self-made millionaires were resolved to overcome predictions by school teachers or bank managers that they or their plans would not amount to much.

Many, he discovered, used negative criticism of their efforts and characters as a spur. "What is interesting is that many millionaires also had parents who never told them they would be losers if they didn't get into Harvard or Yale. They said you can do anything you want to, try everything. If you fail, keep going."

So where will tomorrow's millionaires come from? Contrary to conventional wisdom, they are not lining up at the trough of the internet. Park, he says, was one of the lucky ones.

In fact, Stanley's findings were that steel manufacturing, commercial equipment rental, dredging, mushroom-growing, outdoor advertising, commercial banking and construction contracting produced at least five times more wealth for their owners than for others in the same age and income brackets. "Sure, some new millionaires will come from the web, but you will always need food, clothing and shelter, and the person who has a new idea in those areas, who is disciplined and sets goals, will become a millionaire," he predicts.

Rich list

Stanley discovered that self-made millionaires:

* Choose their careers so they can take full advantage of their abilities and aptitudes.

* Understand that the key factors rewarded by the economy are integrity, discipline, hard work, leadership, a supportive spouse, enjoying one's career and focus.

* Have usually inherited less than 10% of their household net worth and 61% have never inherited, or received gifts of money.

* Live a comfortable but not extravagant lifestyle, with little or no debt.

* Take calculated financial risks and do not gamble.

 The Millionaire Mind is published by Andrews McMeel, $26.95. It is not yet available in British shops.

In fact, you don't even need an A-level. What you do require is the recipe for achieving wealth. Stanley claims to have formulated one, which he has published, after a study of 1,300 self-made American millionaires. He calls this recipe, and the eponymous book, The Millionaire Mind. This is a state of being and a career that consistently trumps shortcomings in intelligence or connections, a mindset guaranteed to earn you a fortune. The crux of his findings is that hard work, focus, goal-setting and discipline are the direct path to riches. Understandably, the idea that a rigorous work ethic, as opposed to an Oxbridge education or mummy and daddy's money - is what it takes to make millions has been greeted with delirious delight by Bill Gates wannabes. Released in the US only three weeks ago, Stanley's book, The Millionaire Mind, is already number four on the New York Times bestseller list. "What I found, consistently, is that of all the factors involved in financial success, hard work was first, and graduating at the top of the class ranked last," says Stanley, who lives in Atlanta. "Most millionaires made Bs and Cs at university. But education is such a major issue in America. Parents get hysterical if their children don't get As in kindergarten; but I found a high IQ is no indicator of success. Millionaires build empires on creativity and common sense." The millionaires Stanley studied had an average net worth of $9.2m (£5.5m). The majority were entrepreneurs and 73% were described as academically average. He also found that they were not motivated by money or dreams of yachts in the Greek islands and castles in Marbella. "Self-made millionaires do not look at money as a goal in itself. Ninety per cent told me their objective in starting out was to be independent, to follow their passions, to control their lives." So if intelligence, degrees, quiz shows and lottery winnings don't count, what does? Stanley sums it up neatly: "First, millionaires choose a career in an area that matches their talents and interests. This ensures they are always motivated to work harder and longer than anybody else. "Then they consistently think outside the box, seeing opportunities others have ignored. This is exactly what Richard Branson did with Virgin. He really is my hero. He consistently thinks outside the box to expand his empire." Consider also the case of Donald Sonner, the 64-year-old head of the Southern Bloomer Manufacturing Company in Tennessee, one of the millionaires Stanley interviewed. Sonner only completed one year of high school but was a millionaire by 24. He uses scrap cloth discarded by garment manufacturers to make underwear for prisons and gun-cleaning patches. "Mr Sonner got rich by working hard and coming up with an idea nobody else had," says Stanley. The trick is to pick a career wedded to your interests, think laterally, then pair those elements with a disciplined work ethic. Stanley emphasised that all the millionaires in his survey set high goals and then worked around the clock to meet them. "Millionaires say they work harder, place a high priority on honesty and integrity in business, and are prepared to take financial risks. They draw up plans and constantly evaluate them. They never lose sight of their goal." They also use time efficiently. Another millionaire Stanley interviewed was a Mr Benjamin, a school-bus driver who spent all his work breaks studying the stock market instead of messing about with his friends at the bus station. He began investing tiny amounts, taking risks and rolling with the punches when stocks took a tumble. He retired after 20 years, worth $3m. "It's all about focus. Millionaires make a decision to tune out everything else and concentrate on one thing, be it creating a retirement fund, or launching a record label. Mr Benjamin focused on investing, schooled himself, and took calculated risks that paid off." In New York, where there are said to be 30,000 millionaires, all the talk is of Joseph Park, 28, who quit his well-paid job as a Wall Street trader to launch www.kozmo.com, a company that delivers goods to your home within an hour of you emailing an order. Analysts dismissed the idea as unworkable and Park was warned that he might be headed for bankruptcy. But the public loved the idea, business is booming and last month Park raised $100m in venture capital. Stanley says Park is a perfect example of someone having a novel idea, laser-like focus, motivation, and the gumption to take a risk. Stanley also found that psychologically, like Park, self-made millionaires were resolved to overcome predictions by school teachers or bank managers that they or their plans would not amount to much. Many, he discovered, used negative criticism of their efforts and characters as a spur. "What is interesting is that many millionaires also had parents who never told them they would be losers if they didn't get into Harvard or Yale. They said you can do anything you want to, try everything. If you fail, keep going." So where will tomorrow's millionaires come from? Contrary to conventional wisdom, they are not lining up at the trough of the internet. Park, he says, was one of the lucky ones. In fact, Stanley's findings were that steel manufacturing, commercial equipment rental, dredging, mushroom-growing, outdoor advertising, commercial banking and construction contracting produced at least five times more wealth for their owners than for others in the same age and income brackets. "Sure, some new millionaires will come from the web, but you will always need food, clothing and shelter, and the person who has a new idea in those areas, who is disciplined and sets goals, will become a millionaire," he predicts. Rich list Stanley discovered that self-made millionaires: * Choose their careers so they can take full advantage of their abilities and aptitudes. * Understand that the key factors rewarded by the economy are integrity, discipline, hard work, leadership, a supportive spouse, enjoying one's career and focus. * Have usually inherited less than 10% of their household net worth and 61% have never inherited, or received gifts of money. * Live a comfortable but not extravagant lifestyle, with little or no debt. * Take calculated financial risks and do not gamble.  The Millionaire Mind is published by Andrews McMeel, $26.95. It is not yet available in British shops.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: www.workunlimited.co.uk.
fields.trailText: Fiona Wilkinson, 45 Educational officer
fields.body:
Fiona Wilkinson, 45 Educational officer

I worked in a school where an older, married teacher would press himself up against me at the office filing cabinet, under the pretence of offering help. At an office party I found out he was doing this to all the young women teachers, so I put a note on the filing cabinet saying: "Don't do any filing if you are alone in the room with (this man). He'll treat you like his personal property." He was so embarrassed that he stopped immediately. We could have gone to the headmaster, but the note was so effective we didn't need to make a fuss.

Liz Oliver, 29 Retail manager

I used to work with a man who pressed up against me in the doorway and did lots of "accidental touching". I ignored it for about three months then lost my temper and told him to get lost. The next week he went to my manager and complained about my work. When I found out I stormed into the boss's office to justify my position. I didn't complain about this man's behaviour because I was more furious about the slur on my abilities. After that he ignored me. Looking back, life would have been simpler if I had nipped the situation in the bud by standing hard on his foot every time he got close. I don't think yelling in the boss's office did me any favours.

About five years ago I became very good friends with a male colleague. We would socialise a lot on our own and he developed a crush on me. Things turned nasty when I refused to have an affair. He sent me endless emails at home, including one with naked photographs of himself. I started being horrible to him to put him off but everyone at work just thought I was a bitch. I knew if I complained I'd get no sympathy because people were convinced we'd had an affair. In the end I left. Now if someone flirts I take it seriously and am much more cautious. I've stopped being too friendly with men in the office - it's not worth it.

Theresa Woodcock, 35 IT consultant

I started a new job where the boss's behaviour made me feel uncomfortable. I was keen to make an impression so when he started giving me a lift in his car to meetings and taking me out to lunch I didn't protest. He used to look at me a lot and would use any excuse to touch my hand. One lunchtime he made that "my wife doesn't understand me" speech. I offered some advice and he kissed me on the cheek. I pulled away quickly but didn't say anything because I was embarrassed. I think he realised that he had crossed the line and backed off. If all this happened now I'd take my own car to meetings and make an excuse about not going for lunch. As you get older you get more confident. When you're young you don't know what to do.

Jane McGowan, 30 Public relations manager

I used to work for a small fashion company where the boss's brother was an old lech. He was 65 and I was 24. He'd come back from lunch rather worse for wear and go on at me about how sexy I was. It made me feel uncomfortable and I didn't really know what to do. I tried to ignore him but it didn't make any difference. As I became more confident in my job, I started giving him as good as I got. I sexually harassed him back. I'd say things like, "Drop your trousers, then." In the end he left me alone because he wasn't getting the response he wanted. Sex pests are like bullies. Give as good as you get and they will leave you alone.

fields.headline: Charm school turn
fields.standfirst: Day One  Dingwalls, London  ***
fields.trailText: Charm is a rare commodity in British pop, and charm is something Day One's Phelim has in spades. It's there in person, as he paces the stage, refusing to remove his dark designer mac, just a hint of swagger in his step, a mellow come-hither demeanour in his avuncular between-song intros. But the Phelim charm lies mainly in the lyrics on forthcoming album Ordinary Man - a set of considered-yet-vulnerable vignettes on life and love, bristling with wit and comic observation.
fields.body:
Charm is a rare commodity in British pop, and charm is something Day One's Phelim has in spades. It's there in person, as he paces the stage, refusing to remove his dark designer mac, just a hint of swagger in his step, a mellow come-hither demeanour in his avuncular between-song intros. But the Phelim charm lies mainly in the lyrics on forthcoming album Ordinary Man - a set of considered-yet-vulnerable vignettes on life and love, bristling with wit and comic observation.

Whether charm in itself is enough is a moot point. Tonight's first major London gig shows up all the difficulties involved in transferring subtlety and intimacy to the live arena. The band are signed to Massive Attack's Melankolic label, and it shows: songs drift by on a bed of roughish hip hop breaks, dubwise bass, and unobtrusive guitar, keyboard and violin twiddlings. Phelim's voice is pitched somewhere between Tricky-style rapper and American singer-songwriter, despite coming from Bristol and being of Irish stock. The result is that opening trio Bedroom Dancing, Waiting for a Break and the playfully vengeful Trying Too Hard sound great, winning the audience round immediately, before the set slowly peters out, in dire need of a gear change, an injection of energy, a shuffle of the aural pack.

The one attempt to alter the vibe is an acoustic version of Ordinary Man, handled only by Phelim and his writing partner Donni's celtic-flecked strumming. It's Phelim's most touching lyric, almost a New Man anthem in its self- effacing worship of the perfect, unrequited love. But this is deep in sensible, confessional AOR territory, and every tasteful nerd from Paul Simon to him out of Eels comes to mind. Not, I suspect, the effect that Day One are aiming for.

But it would be unfair to damn Day One at this juncture. The album is a delight and, if the show wasn't a revelation, it did seduce the Camden Town Massive into Phelim's sly, philosophical way of thinking. All Day One need is a shot of their label bosses' intensity, and Phelim could emerge as the thinking woman's coffee-table crumpet.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Playing footsie with our futures
fields.trailText: Later today a committee few people even knew existed will change our perceptions of the health, or otherwise, of British business. Without overstating things, we might declare this a "defining moment."
fields.body:
Later today a committee few people even knew existed will change our perceptions of the health, or otherwise, of British business. Without overstating things, we might declare this a "defining moment."

At 5.30pm or thereabouts, the ad hoc collection of City practitioners and statisticians will decide on this quarter's changes to the FTSE 100 index - and this time around the changes will mark a truly radical reassessment of what constitutes a "top British company". The blue chips are being shuffled as never before.

In will come an Irish software company, three corporate spin-offs, possibly a couple of upstart drug firms and a company which, until very recently, was best known for doing the boring chores local authorities could not be bothered to do themselves.

Out, most probably, will go two of the nation's best known brewers, our second biggest cigarette company, the biggest food producer, one of the best known building materials group - oh, and some outfit named Hanson.

Why is this happening? Well, investors have already voted on the matter. If the stock market is taken as a mass opinion poll then the voters no longer think this country's future prosperity hinges on the likes of Whitbread or Thames Water.

It rests instead on whether Psion, with its big buddies in mobile telephony, can do with mobile computing what Bill Gates did with the processor on your desk. It rests on whether Freeserve can really turn a giveaway CD into dominance of the consumer net market, and it rests on whether Scottish Power can get away with changing the name of one of its divisions from Scottish Telecom to Thus, floating the business and then shouting the fact to the rafters. In the corporate world we have the shock of the new and the shock of the old.

Germany's two biggest banks are to merge - old economy stuff. But the driving force behind the merger is the threat from internet banking - new economy stuff.

Oil prices are rising and rates in the United States are set to follow - old economy. Nasdaq rises through 5,000 - new economy. Procter & Gamble issues a profits warning, leading to a big sell-off in the Dow Jones industrial average - old stuff. Manchester United is said to be worth £1bn, not primarily because of its considerable success on the field but because of its link to stock market darling Vodafone - new stuff. What is clear here is that friction between old and new is creating energy, and the question now is whether it is something creative or downright dangerous.

Believers in the new economy argue that this force will make us all richer, - in a cultural as well as a financial sense.

Technology is changing the way in which all business is done, and productivity gains will eventually produce the profits that will justify the sky-high valuations of today.

The old economy faithful stand behind the securities and exchange commission's chairman, Arthur Levitt, who warned of a "casino mentality" developing in the American equity markets. They would share the analysis by City guru Tim Congdon that the aggregate price to earnings ratio on Nasdaq is now around 150 - "a figure never seen before in the organised stock market of any industrial country".

New book, old doctrine or simply financially agnostic: all we can say for certain at present is that the fundamentals have changed.


Expected FTSE changes

In ...

Cable & Wireless Communications; Freeserve; Thus; Baltimore Technologies; Psion; Ncycomed Amersham; Celltech Chiroscience; Capita Group; Emap

Out ...
Wolsley; Imperial Tobacco; Thames Water; Powergen; Scottish & Newcastle; Whitbread Hanson; Allied Domecq; Associated British Foods
